From sfraves-owner  Sat Oct  2 16:39:24 1993
From: ccat@netcom.com (Chris Beaumont)
Date: Sat, 2 Oct 93 16:38:50 -0700
Subject: CALL FOR HELP-A CHALLENGE (Malachy-net-empowerment)
Status: 

A very dear friend of the San Francisco house scene and one of the 
founders of the incredible journey we call the Full Moon Raves was injured 
seriously several months ago in a terrible car accident.The accident
partially severed our friend,Malachy's spine and he is now confined to a
wheelchair.He has
lost the use of his hands,for the most part,but his motor function is slowly
returning.Soon he will be getting a computer,a Macintosh 660AV with voice
control, and will be joining us here on the net.This is a call for ideas    
and suggestions that will enable and empower him to join us and be able to
explore and expand his horizons through cyberspace.We need:

1.) Mac and net savvy people who have ideas that could help Malachy (our
friend)
customize his voice controller software specifically to allow net access.

2.) Software resources that might be particularly adaptable to his situation.
(not much hand and finger control,but full use of his eyes and voice,as well
as his mouth.)

3.) Knowledge of net and corporate resources that would be able to help Mal.
Organizations that specifically help the disabled with computers.etc.Trainers!
Obviously-
there is no need to reinvent the wheel..Such software probably already exists
or is being developed.We need to get Mal into any beta-testing programs.
He doesnt have any computer experience,really,but he's an incredibly 
intelligent person..and we should look at this as a exciting challenge.....
We owe him a huge debt just for bringing us the huge amount of joy he has over
the years...(At least us here in the Bay Area) Many of you must have heard
of the three benefits that people here in California had for him.
(Definitey the best events of the last year here in SF.)

He will be online with an email address of his own soon within a few weeks,but
until then Im hoping to collect information for him.Please mail it to me
at the address ccat@casa.stanford.edu 

His hardware configuration will be
as follows: Centris 660AV with AV monitor and TV camera.high speed modem...
Unix account,probably not SLIP,initially,but maybye later on.
There will also be a need for teacher/helpers.. so if you feel like you
could spare a bit of your time.and you live near Berkeley.by all means,get in
touch! Malachy is a real gem of a person and he is specifically asking for
our,the net-ravers help.

-Chris
ccat@casa.stanford.edu

is still a go.  I spoke to the park officials and rangers
yesterday and was reassured that It would have to be raining
hard for them to cancel our event.  The rangers said that they
have "never thrown anyone out of the park."  I don't know what
the deal was with the Elmo cancellation, but I am optimistic
that Connection Earth will happen as planned.  Any changes will
be put on the Fluid Groove line - 415.487.8497

From sfraves-owner  Sun Oct  3 12:31:31 1993
From: rberger@internex.net (Robert Berger)
Date: Sun, 3 Oct 93 12:26:28 PDT
Subject: Resources for Malachy-net-empowerment and Handicapped computerists in
Status: 

Try the World Institute on Disablity Janina Sajka WIDNet Project Manager
510 Sixteenth St., Suite 100
Oakland, CA 94612-1502
Voice 510-763-4100
FAX 510-763-4109

Disabilities Served:  All disabilities.

Users Served:  Disabled persons and their families,
government agencies, legislative bodies, disability
organizations, centers for independent living, media,
international visitors.

The Organization:  The World Institute on Disability (WID)
is a public policy institute seeking solutions to major
problems faced by people of all ages with disabilities.
It was founded in 1983 by disabled people who have
extensive personal and professional knowledge of
disability-related issues and who were among the founders
of the independent living movement.  WID has focused on
areas that have significant impact on the basic human
rights and needs of disabled individuals.  There areas
include public education, service systems consultation,
and national and international development of independent
living.

------
"The Macintosh and Disability Access," prepared by Jane Berliss and Alan
Brightman, SYLLABUS, P.O. Box 2716, Sunnyvale, CA  94087-0716, Summer
1992, Number 23; 408-773-0670; Internet: syllabus@applelink.apple.com.

It is estimated that one out of every five U.S. citizens is physically
or mentally disabled. Can technology help bring them into the
mainstream? Perhaps, but only if these individuals have access to
computers and other equipment. "The Macintosh and Disability Access"
describes the role of technology in disability access, Project EASI
(Equal Access to Software for Instruction), an outgrowth of EDUCOM's
Educational Uses of Information Technology (EUIT) program, as well as
operating-system features for people with disabilities.

Filename Filetype: DISABLED BERLIS_J CCNEWS

------------
CODI Cornucopia of Disability Information gopher: val-dor.cc.buffalo.edu 70

 CODI is a gopher, intended to serve as a community resource for 
     consumers and professionals by providing, via the Internet, disability 
     related information in a wide variety of areas. The information 
     addresses university (SUNY @ Buffalo), local (Buffalo & WNY), state, 
     national and international audiences. Its contents are determined 
     by these communities; their submissions and suggestions are welcome.

   Currently, the material is accessible via 21 main menu items. This
     article, 'About the Cornucopia of Disability Information', is the
     first menu item. 

---------

     international.  National Easter Seal Society, 70 East Lake
     Street, Chicago, IL  60601.  Telephone: (312) 726-6200, ext.
     143.

From:   IN%"VFOAO073@VAX.CSUN.EDU"  "Harry Murphy"  6-JUL-1993 23:52:58.87
Subj:   CSUN Conference
 
                        CALL FOR PARTICIPATION
 
California State University, Northridge (CSUN).  A Call for
Participation has been issued for the Ninth Annual, International
Conference, "Technology and Persons with Disabilities," to be held
at the Los Angeles Airport Marriott Hotel, March 16-19, 1994.
 
Papers are solicited across all disabilities and age groups.
Practical applications of technology, research findings, and 
reports of innovative projects are encouraged.
 
There will be special sessions in these areas:  Virtual Reality
and The Electronic Highway.  For the past three years, CSUN has
included sessions on Virtual Reality in its March conference.  In
June of 1993 CSUN also conducted a special meeting on Virtual Reality
and Persons with Disabilities that drew 300 people to SF.  The
Electronic HIghway is the coming together of telephone, cable,
video, computer, and other media into an interactive medium.
For both Virtual Reality and The Electronic Highway, papers are
solicited which deal with access, applications, and employment
issues.
 
An "Invitation to Exhibit" has also been issued.  About 140
exhibit stations in 23,000 square feet of space will be a part of
the March, 1994 conference.  As of July 1, 1993, there are 18 exhibit
booths left for the March, 1994 conference.
 
CSUN's March, 1993 conference drew more than 2,000 persons from
almost every state and 25 foreign countries, 250 speakers and 120
exhibitors.
 
For information:
 
Dr. Harry Murphy
Founder and Director
CENTER ON DISABILITIES
California State University, Northridge
18111 Nordhoff Street - DVSS
Northridge, CA 91330
Phone: 818 885 2578 V/TDD
FAX:   818 885 4929  
EMAIL: VR@VAX.CSUN.EDU 
 
                           CALENDAR ITEM
 
Second Annual Virtual Reality and Persons with Disabilities
conference, sponsored by CSUN's CENTER ON DISABILITIES, June 9-10,
1994, San Francisco Airport Marriott Hotel.

  This Thursday, Oct 7th "The Edge" welcomes Organico recording artist

                      DUB TRIBE - direct from San Francisco
But who's DUB TRIBE?
DUB TRIBE are a new recording and performance group from S.F.; they are
completely Live. No DAT machines are used in their performance.  This
4 member band, known for their extended sets, create original music on
the spot - even adding improvisational percussion over the D.J.'s breaks.
  -URB magazine writes:  "...these guys and girls, with their tribal
    live percussion, sizzling optics, beefy funked-up breaks, swirly
    dubbed vocals and bass tremors unlike anything felt here in the Bay,
    are a live force everyone must hear...they are a collective, and...
    when they perform, the audience is part of that collective too"
                                                - April 1993

From sfraves-owner  Mon Oct  4 06:43:50 1993
From: geoffw@nexsys.net (Geoff White)
Date: Mon, 4 Oct 93 06:19:56 PDT
Subject: Info on russia
Status: 

From: <peacenet>
Subject: Yeltsin Cuts Phone Lines

Before we get on the Yeltsin "move toward democracy" let us pause...





Date: Thu, 30 Sep 93 10:38:08 PDT
From: Labor Video Project <lvpsf>
To: peacenet
Subject: alerts: Yeltsin Info Blockade

              KAS-KOR LABOR INFORMATION CENTER
              PHONES CUT BY YELTSIN GOVERNMENT
        PROTESTS NEEDED TO DEFEND FREEDOM OF INFORMATION
 
 
9/30/93
San Francisco
 
     We have just received information that the Kas-Kor Labor
Information Center's phones and faxes have been cut by the
Yeltsin government. This means that the only means of
communication with the center is with the use of electronic mail. 
     Please sent protests to the Russian consulate/embassy with
copies to krazchenko@glas.apc.org. It is also important to break
the infomation blockade in the US about the dictatorship being
imposed on the people. Please spread the information.
     The following is from reports from the Kas Kor Information
Center in Moscow.
ty
                  Information Blockade
 
 
 
     A strict  information blockade  has been imposed on the 
country. Telephone lines to the Supreme Soviet building have 
been   cut off; this has made it impossible for the people's 
deputies   who are in the building to contact their electors 
and explain  the  stands they have taken. After establishing 
control over   the  television and  radio, Boris Yeltsin has 
subjected them  to  strict censorship. Newspaper offices are 
being placed  under lock   and key, and television and radio 
programs  are  being  cancelled.    This  is  depriving  the 
country's population  of the opportunity to  learn the truth 
about the  events that  are unfolding  in the   country  and 
about the  positions taken by people's deputies and  members 
of the Constitutional Court. 
     Public organisations  are under  blockade as  well.  In 
particular,  telephone  lines  have  been  cut  off  to  the 
building of   the  country's  main  trade  union  body,  the 
Federation of   Independent  Trade Unions of Russia. Leading 
figures in  the   executive authority are making unambiguous 
threats  that   these    trade  unions  will  be  dissolved. 
Finally,  totally   fabricated  and   unproven  charges   of 
organising acts  of terrorism  and other criminal activities 
are  being levelled against the people in the Supreme Soviet 
building.  People are being openly and publicly described as 
criminals, a   practice which has nothing in common with the 
presumption of  innocence. 
     A savage  personal dictatorship is thus being installed 
in   Russia. The  following basic  human  rights  are  being 
violated: 
     * The right of citizens to participate in administering 
state affairs through their freely elected representatives; 
     * The right to free thought, to free speech, and to the 
unrestricted expression of ideas and convictions; 
     * The  right to  seek,  obtain  and  freely  distribute 
information; 
     * The  right to privacy in correspondence, in telephone 
conversations and in telegraphic and other communications; 
 
     #Moscow City Soviet member Boris Kagarlitsky, who is in
charge of  liaison  between  the  deputies' meeting and  the 
trade  unions,  declared at the press conference that the
struggle to defend  the  parliament  remained the principal
thrust of the activity of  all  progressive organisations in
Russia. Thanks to the actions of the  people's  deputies, 
Kagarlitsky said,  other forces such as  the  trade unions had
obtained a breathing-space and an opportunity to prepare  for
further actions under the conditions of a ``liberal- fascist''
regime. 
As if to remove all doubt that the bases for a repressive regime 
are now being established, police at 8 p.m. on September 28 began
forcing   demonstrators  away  from  the  cordons  blocking   the 
entrances  to the White House.  Equipped with steel  shields  and 
clubs,  massed  ranks of Interior Ministry special forces  troops 
drove  the  protestors out of the neighbourhood adjacent  to  the 
White  House.  In a number of cases where people tried to resist, 
they were savagely beaten. 
Outraged  by  the  actions of the troops  and  militia  members, 
protestors began building barricades on nearby streets.  However,
no shops were destroyed and no cars damaged.  Any attempts to  do 
this were prevented by the barricade-builders themselves. This in 
itself  is  proof  that  the crowd was not  made  up  drunks  and 
maniacs,  as the mass media tried to imply.   
Just as false is the claim that the night's events were provoked 
by  the  demonstrators  themselves,  trying to  force  their  way 
through  the militia ranks.  No-one who saw the massive  barriers 
strewn with razor wire could doubt that this was impossible.  The 
beatings of protestors were begun on orders from higher up. 
#At 9 p.m.  the forces of the state mounted a new attack, and the 
demonstrators were scattered into nearby laneways.  Hardly anyone 
tried   to  resist.   Before  my  eyes,   the  Chairman  of   the 
Cheremushkinsky  Regional  Soviet  was thrown to the  ground  and 
viciously  beaten  after  he  had urged  the  militia  through  a 
megaphone not to use violence against the people.  
OMON  troops then threw to the ground and began kicking a  young 
woman  with a video camera who had caught the incident  on  tape.
This  victim of the brutalised troops was unable even to pull out 
her   press  card.   After  administering  these  beatings,   the 
``guardians  of  democracy'' hauled the victims  off  behind  the 
cordon. 
#The  number  of participants in these confrontations is hard  to 
estimate,  because  the incidents were scattered  throughout  the 
entire  neighbourhood.  Estimates of the number of  demonstrators 
who  were  near  the White House on the evening of  September  28 
range from 2000 to 8000 people. 
Credit to KAS-KOR Labor Information Center, Moscow 
Ph. (095) 921-0655 


From sfraves-owner  Mon Oct  4 06:43:59 1993
From: geoffw@nexsys.net (Geoff White)
Date: Mon, 4 Oct 93 06:29:34 PDT
Subject: ALT NEWS FROM MOSCOW. October 4
Status: 

/* ---------- "Alt News from Moscow. October 4." ---------- */
ALT NEWS FROM MOSCOW. October 4.

By this time, CNN etc. is probably giving fairly accurate factual
information about the events going on here. Still, we suppose that the
information is extremely one-sided. (We haven't been able to see for
ourselves due to the seizure of Ostankino, from which cable channel 6 is
also televised.)

Last night and this morning, the TV was broadcasting pro-Yeltsin appeals
to the nation. They urged people to take Yeltsin's side and to defend
the Kremlin. There are some people doing this now but it does not seem
like more than 500 people turned out. However the TV broadcast that
"thousands upon thousands of Muscovites are heading to Moscow City
Soviet (Mossoviet) at this moment to defend democracy". Obviously some
people did head that way, but not nearly as many as they claimed or will
try to portray to the nation and the world.

Under such conditions, it is easy to understand why Ostankino would be
stormed.

We of course feel bad for the technical workers, janitors, etc. that got
stuck at Ostankino. The TV announcers, writers etc. the ones that are
really to blame for the media distortion, apparently fled the building
well before hand. Many people were hurt. Last night we saw injured
arrive in trucks at the White House and they claimed that the hospital
refused to treat the wounded. This information is still being
distubuted. I heard that 5 doctors at one hospital refused treatment but
the other hospitals were treating everybody as best as they could. This
is unconfirmed at this time. Different people formed their own red cross
brigades to treat the wounded.

A few people were apparently leaving the White House area by 11 AM. The
people there are clearly sitting ducks. Roads are blocked by tanks and
all the metros around the area and closed so nobody can get through to
help them. There is a small fire at the mayor's building and lots of
shooting, apparently a lot of firing from tanks. Rumour has it that a
few minutes ago they hung up the white flag at the White House but they
are still fighting as nobody has come out yet.

AKAI 10/4
NOON

Spread by KAS-KOR Labour Information Centre, Moscow
Ph: (095) 921-0655
Conf?

From sfraves-owner  Mon Oct  4 07:30:23 1993
From: geoffw@nexsys.net (Geoff White)
Date: Mon, 4 Oct 93 06:46:34 PDT
Subject: ???
Status: 

Topic 565Russia Bulletin #63 responsesRUSSIA@ARIZVM1.ccit.arizona.edubitl.russia11:18 pm  Oct  3, 1993

Reply-To: Russia & her neighbors <RUSSIA@ARIZVM1.ccit.arizona.edu>
From: "VALENTINE M. SMITH" <CDELL@VAX1.UMKC.EDU>
Subject:      Russia Bulletin #6

---------------------- Information from the mail header -----------------------
Sender:       Russia & her neighbors <RUSSIA@ARIZVM1.BITNET>
Poster:       "VALENTINE M. SMITH" <CDELL@VAX1.UMKC.EDU>
Subject:      Russia Bulletin #6
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Yeltsin just gave his speech, in which he said two things
clearly ... "The armed fascist rebellion will be suppressed
in the shortest time possible"0 and he spoke both in memory
of the dead and of his respect for the citizens of Moscow for
their bravery and calmess, "I respect you so much" was his
closing statement. He ordered that the the bank accounts of
all suspect organizations involved in the "Communist/fascist
uprising" be frozen, and that all armed bands be diarmed and
"neutralized."

As he spoke, more and more commando types were advancing on
the east side of the building, and the firing continues to be
heavy, now from both sides. An air assault is predicted, was
announced, but no evidence of it has yet manifested, though
tanks are now moving in closer to the building along with
more and more troops. VMS


Reply-To: Russia & her neighbors <RUSSIA@ARIZVM1.ccit.arizona.edu>
From: "VALENTINE M. SMITH" <CDELL@VAX1.UMKC.EDU>
Subject:      Russia Bulletin #12 ...

---------------------- Information from the mail header -----------------------
Sender:       Russia & her neighbors <RUSSIA@ARIZVM1.BITNET>
Poster:       "VALENTINE M. SMITH" <CDELL@VAX1.UMKC.EDU>
Subject:      Russia Bulletin #12 ...
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

The fire in the White House, claimed by the defenders to have been put
out, is raging anew. After a small lull in the firing, the shooting has
resumed, while black beret troops had begun clearing "the few thousand
people" off the bridge in front of the White House. Lots of the crowd
are reported to be "young kids 12-16" and "ladys with interesting, rare
dogs," according to Art Troitsky, a disc jockey and journalist interviewed
by CNN after a plunge into those self-same crowds. No apartments in the
area have been evacuated, though all American embassy staff & dependents
have been moved to an underground gymnasium. Some bystanders have been
hit by snipers, and some sniper fire has raked nearby apartments. As of
0400 Moscow time, 18 have been killed, 192 wounded, and 158 hospitalized -
a number sure to go much higher after today's fighting. VMS
Conf? 

From sfraves-owner  Mon Oct  4 07:58:08 1993
From: "Niels P. Mayer" <mayer@netcom.com>
Date: Mon, 04 Oct 93 07:58:30 -0700
Subject: Re: Connection Earth 
Status: 

Ditto on the kudos, boyo! That was a great party!

We obviously had good timing given that there were some huge lighting
and thunder strikes last night around 3AM along with heavy rain fall.
But the weather on Sunday afternoon was perfect, IMHO, for dancing all
day -- not too hot, not too cold. Niceness! 

Many thanks to Lee, Markie, and JonD for playing godlike sets, and to
Lee Fogel, Ethan, Bryce and everybody else for filling the air with
beautiful liquid sound. 

So when is the next one? If it's cold, we don't care -- it'll just give
us an excuse to dance harder....

From sfraves-owner  Mon Oct  4 09:55:10 1993

Subject: The Orb More in Brief Tour '93

THE ORB MORE IN BRIEF TOUR '93

_PROMOTER COMPUTER LISTING_

SAN FRANCISCO - OCTOBER 15TH:

	"The Ambient Experience" featuring The Orb is at the Warfield Theatre,
982 Market Street, on Friday 15th of October.  The event starts at 10pm and
goes until 4am.
	Three seperate environments are on hand for maximum enjoyment.  DJ and
artist line up include; DJ Lewis; Alex Patterson; Buck; Markey Mark; Dutch;
Ernie Munsen; Hardkiss Music and Space Time Continuim.
	The night is open to all ages.  Alcohol is served to those with ID.
	After hours is offered at $5.  The location will be revealed on the
night and includes the same DJ line up plus DJ Reese from NYC.

LOS ANGELES - OCTOBER 16TH:

	The Orb will perform in L.A. on Saturday 16th October at the Park
Plaza.  This event will start at 10pm until 3am with the after hours party
running from 3am until 9am.  After hours location will be announced on the
night during the show.
	All ages are welcome and alcohol is served with ID.
	Also deejaying are Doc Martin and Jason Butley.

CHICAGO - OCTOBER 20TH:

	"You are halfway to the weekend - no go all the way to heaven with the
Orb in Chicago on Wednesday October the 20th, 9pm to 4am, at the Metro."
	There are 2 rooms.  THe Orb are in the main room, and Josh Werner and
Tom Pazen will spin in the reggae-dub lounge.
	The even is open to ages 18+ and alcohol is served to those with ID.
For more info call (312) 549-0203.

MONTREAL - OCTOBER 22ND:

	The Bus Company brings to Montreal "The Eclipse", featuring a two hour
performance by The Orb, on Friday 22nd of October at Metropolis, 59 Saint
Catherine East.
	The event stars at 9pm and finishes at 3am and features Dominic Woosey
from Neutron 9000/United Frequencies of Trance in the main room.  A dub lounge
will have Interchill; Stricky Tricky Nicky and DJ Alex Patterson spinning the
latest in trance, house, and ambient.
	Metropolis is open to ages 18+ and a full bar is offered.
	During the show the location of the after hours party will be
announced.  This will be running from 3:30am til 9am and will cost $5-$6.
	For more info call (514) 287-3263.

NEW YORK - OCTOBER 23RD:

	Matt E. Silver/Intermodo and the Blunt Academy present The Orb in
their only East Coast appearance on Saturday October the 23rd.
	"The Journey - Part 1 and 2", has the once in a lifetime line up of
DJ's with Alex Patterson (UK); DJ Lewis (UK); Adam X (Brooklyn); Mr. Kleen
(NET); Repeat (Future Shock); Micro (Caffeine); Joeski (Magic); Soul Slinger
(Liquid Sky); Resse (Communion); Dimitri (Deelite); Kamins (NYC); and Guy DMC
(USA).
	Giant Step with DJ Jazzy nice, Chill Freeze and the Live Giant Step
Crew will be taking over the basement.  Surreal Hose of the most is
Communion's Neville and overloading the visual senses are la la landia and
Spike Millvolte's Psycho Kenetic Gallery.
	Part 1 will be held from 11pm until 6am at the Roseland, 239 W. 52nd
Street, with showtime at 1am.  Part 2 will run from 6am until noon at a new
location announced on the night.  Part 2 will cost $6 with Orb ticket stub.
	For bus or other info call (212) 966-4033.


Note from Pete:  THAT IS IT FOLKS.  FIVE STOPS.  THERE ARE NO OTHER STOPS ON
THIS TOUR.  BUY YOUR PLANE TICKETS NOW IF YOUR TOWN IS NOT LISTED, BECAUSE
THEY AREN'T COMING.

From sfraves-owner  Mon Oct  4 15:00:30 1993
From: dms!curly!grigsby@netcom.com (JUMP IN THE FIRE)
Date: Mon, 4 Oct 93 14:59:07 PDT
Subject: Crash Worship, etc.
Status: 


Well, the much-maligned 16th & Harrison space is being put to better use as
some non-scumbags get hold of it.  The show was $8 (!) for four bands plus
a DJ in the other room.  First were two women with strings playing chamber-
type music (and someone else with a keyboard, I couldn't tell what they
were doing).  A nice change from the usual thump-thump-thump.  Then came
three bands who I wasn't quite in the mood to see: Sleep, God and Texas,
and Neurosis.  Sorry, I just wasn't up for loud angry sludge, especially
given that the sound was deafening but not very good.  Neurosis does put
on an excellent visual show (they have a guy full-time who just does the
video, slides, etc.) and when you want that sort of scream in pain at the
dying world music, that's about the thing.

The main room was full by the time people started filtering in to see CW,
which worried me a bit -- the largest show I had seen them play previously
was at Gilman to ~150 people, and here the crowd was closer to four figures
than two.  An interesting mix of cultures -- lots of punks, some industrial-
type PIBs, some ravers, a few hippies.  The piercing quotient was quite
high >^)  Met a couple people who I recognized from previous CW shows, and
was pleasantly surprised to see Allen@Ameba.  After a long period of 
expectant waiting, punctuated by howls and screams from the crowd plus
some choruses of "We Shall Overcome" and "Do the Hokey-Pokey", the fun
began.

Anyone who's been to a CW show can guess what happened -- it was much the
same as any other show except bigger.  This is, of course, good.  There
were the usual quantities of firecrackers and flash flares, several 
burning torches, the usual quota of naked and half-naked people, cheap
wine in bags, water hoses and fire extinguishers, and more fire.  There's
something primal and magnetic about fire, even in a crummy warehouse near
the Mission.  Fire and drums, drums and fire.  Drums, fire, and the dance.
The fire draws us with its power, yet burns us if we attempt to possess it,
and the drums pound, and we dance, animated by the drums and the fire, and
I'm sorry for this awful stream-of-consciousness crap but it's not a verbal
experience, you just have to go do it and then maybe you'll see what I mean.
It's no good to watch, either: you've got to leave the part of you that
says "Man, that's _dangerous_", "What the hell are they doing?", "What
the hell am _I_ doing?", and "Aw, geez, I'll get my pants dirty" behind,
and trample it into the ground along with your suavity and voguing 
technique.

This is rave for the modern primitive who is tired of the antiseptic, 100%
legally-approved-activity of hanging around in a dark auditorium watching
rainbow-tinted black&white slides while listening to old Japanese machines
pound out 129 BPM for ten hours.  Crash Worship are not the end-all of
fun, nor the best drummers ever; but they're on to something important
that is 100% missing from our everyday (ab)normal life.

// g

PS: Allen was talking about the need for people to check out different
kinds of events sometimes: any being that cannot change eventually dies
out, because the only certainty in the universe is constant change.  If
you start finding "The Scene" a bit dull and lifeless, at least half of
that is in your own head.  Nostalgia is great, but most often the joy was
in being new and different, and an attempt to recapture the "vibe" of the
earlier time will never be the same, because it is the same.  Dig?


From sfraves-owner  Mon Oct  4 15:34:22 1993
From: root@Gregor.Mosheh.Net (Gregor Mosheh, Administrator)
Date: Mon, 4 Oct 93 15:16:09 PDT
Subject: This weekend!
Status: 

First, Sean and I went to Divinity. I didn't know raves were EVER held in
Davis, but it sure was nice to be only five minutes from home, instead of
the usual 90 minute drive from SF.

Divinity was cool. Not what I'd call fantastic, but Sean had the time of
his life. I'd never heard of Dutch, but he spun a really nice trance set.
Carlos was (from what I hear) his usual self, a walking good vibe. It was
great! He was jumping around and waving his arms at everyone, just going
wild. Of course, the crowd gathered around the table was equally energetic,
dancing (on my feet) and waving and yelling. It was a great time, but I
would have had more fun if the dance floor had been better. I thought
dancing on sand was an impossible project (for me, that is - nobody else
seems to have a problem with it), but the floor was covered with an inch
and a half of rubber fragments, like tires bits. (Tire Bits - full of
Vitamin F, part of this nutritious rave breakfast) Dancing was a bitch, but
what the hell.

Then we went to the GG Park rave. It was killer! Markie Mark put on a
really great trance set, and John Drukman put on an AMAZING trance set,
with some of the most original stuff I'd ever heard. (Gee, can ya tell I
like trancey music?) It was just a fantastic time from beginning to (Alas!)
end. I missed the afterparty (couldn't find it), though. Anyone go to that?
How was it?

Anyway, after GGP, most of us went to dinner at some Thai place and then
Sean and I went to Susie's to crash, along with apparently half of San
Francisco. Woke up late, missed my only class (Chemistry, too! Damn!), and
broke my glasses (at least $100 to replace, can't be fixed), but still
rocking on that great vibe. If I'm lucky, it'll keep rocking 'til Thursday.

Hope to see ya all Thursday and ESPECIALLY Friday night. ORB...
huh-huh That'll be cool. huh-huh-huh-huh-huh-huh
Yeah, Orb's cool. heh-heh-heh-hm-hm-heh-hm-hm

Also, there's a song that I just adore. I THINK the name of it is
"Tempestada", or something like that. It kinda goes like this:
duh-duh-duh... Uhm, never mind. Anyone heard of it, or that one called
Circus Bells? Who does them and where can I get them or any other REALLY
acid trancey stuff like that?


                 hazrat Gregor Mosheh
    4301-B Ashland Terrace Davis, CA 95616  (916) 757-7319                 
     
   gmosheh@nyx.cs.du.edu      mosheh@cybernet.cse.fau.edu

> - Sunglasses in case left on picnic table by the DJs

Actually, I found these sunglasses+case on the "dance floor" area covered
in dust. Looked inside, and saw a brand of expensive yuppie-sunglasses that
I always wanted to buy but would be too afraid of losing. So I put them on
top of the "right" speaker stack in the hope that they would be visible to
their owner. I guess not.

I guess after the speakers got moved, they still didn't get claimed
and got moved to the picic table....

Anyways, if you don't find the owner of the sunglasses, I'd be happy too
claim them for you :-). I can even identify the brand and style!

PS: I can happily report that this is one of the first sfraves event where
I did not suffer a loss. At Connection I, I had a nice ($200.00) internal
frame backpack stolen, and at the SF Raves Picnic way back when, someone
smashed the front passenger side windows of 3 cars parked on the road-side
(one of which was mine, cost ~ $180.00 to repair). The low rate of loss
corresponds to my findings that the asshole coefficient of SF is lower than
that of Oakland or Santa Cruz :-). So pinch me before I begin singing a
putrescently florid paean to my home town!

From sfraves-owner  Mon Oct  4 16:33:03 1993
From: Laura La Gassa <laura@soda.berkeley.edu>
Date: Mon, 4 Oct 93 16:32:57 -0700
Subject: Re:  This weekend!
Status: 

>From: root@gregor.mosheh.net (Gregor Mosheh, Administrator)

>Anyone heard of it, or that one called
>Circus Bells? Who does them and where can I get them or any other REALLY
>acid trancey stuff like that?

"Circus Bells" is an old Chicago Acid track from the Warehouse label, and is
by Robert Armani.  "Circus Bells" was remixed earlier this summer by 
Hardfloor (of "Acsperience") and re-released on the Duth label DJAX.  It's
part of a 2x12" vinyl set called "Robert Armani Remixes."  It is not out on
CD . . . however there *is* a DJAX compilation CD coming out (import only)
that might have it on it.

I played "Circus Bells" (the Hardfloor remix) that night you and I were both 
at Your Sister's House.

I suggest trying Gaia Mantra (spelling?) in San Francisco for it, I've never
been there but from what other people say it would be a good store to try.

Warning, though:  it came out in June, so you might not be able to find or
even order a copy now.

Hey, the countdown begins again:  see you all in 10 days!!!!!!  

Laura

From sfraves-owner  Mon Oct  4 17:01:11 1993
From: bbehlen@soda.berkeley.edu (Brian Behlendorf)
Date: Mon, 4 Oct 1993 17:00:54 -0700
Subject: Re: Info on russia
Status: 

Agreed - there are so many sides to this issue that even the Russians 
themselves are confused and uninformed (if you watch CNN you probably know
more about the situation tha 95% of the Russian population.)

There are tqwo much more appropriate newsgroups for this discussion, which I 
have been following closely: talk.politics.soviet (recently revived) and
alt..current-events.russia.  For those of who who want their info LIVE, I
believe the IRC channel #report has been set up as a live feed from people
at demos.su, with reports of happenings and transcriptions of speeches
and such.  Finally, there is a gopher site with tons of info: sunsite.unc.edu.
Check it out (welcome to the information age!)

        Brian

p.s. - the GG Park party ROCKED!  Great job everyone!

From sfraves-owner  Mon Oct  4 18:56:57 1993

 Not all information is totally on the electronic tip these days.
While in Kenya two summer's ago, the Russian Revolution occured and
the only way of receiving information was via shortwave radio.
(viva the BBC) which had hourly updates. Shortwave is broadcast over 
all of russia and is accessed by many common people. Many people found
the truth of what was happining in Moscow over shortwave radio. So
the alternatives are there.

overseas in the mind.

doug ) ( 

From sfraves-owner  Mon Oct  4 20:02:36 1993
From: "Niels P. Mayer" <mayer@netcom.com>
Date: Mon, 04 Oct 93 20:03:03 -0700
Subject: Re: Info on russia 
Status: 

> I suspect that propaganda by either side in Russia right now
> is so biased as to be untrustable.  What I've seen and other
> people are reporting firsthand is different from what that
> article Geoff just posted said.  As always, think about who's
> saying what and why.

Yeah, I sent GeoffW's postings to my father (who escaped from USSR around
1963 and continues to have an axe to grind with them) and he had the
following to say:

> This news clearly comes from the old-guard communists (who seem to
> have kept their contacts to the "peace" movement intact, and are
> trying to get the party line across). 
> 
> I heard most of this on the BBC and VOA, and know how to take Yeltzin
> with a pound of salt.  He is no gentleman either, and I am very
> dubious about the final outcome.  On the other hand, if these guys 
> would have won, antisemitism and repression would have been even
> worse.
 
At this point I don't know who to trust, but I do know that the coverage on
CNN has the feel of CIA disinformation stamped all over it, along with the
fact that the US has been "bribing" Yeltsin with all those billions of $$$
of "aid" money.

I guess there is the other side of the story -- from a US Natl Security
standpoint it's better to have a dictator that is in the palm of our hands
since he does control an awfully large arsenal of nuclear weapons.

(Duck and cover!)

--------------------

PS: The only thing that is more screwy than the slanted coverage of the
situation in Russia is our attempt to set up a military outpost in Somalia
so that we can have a home base for "pacifying" the mideast Oil producing
countries in the Oil wars that the "industrial west" *WILL* be fighting in
the future.

When Somalia is mentioned some people think "africa" but they'd never think
"middle east" -- but take a look at a map sometime, and you'll see what I'm
talking about w/r/t Somalia's strategic location.  And if you don't think
wars will be fought in the future over a dwindling commodity that is the
lifeblood of the industrial world, then you've been doing too much X. (And
don't forget that our war against Iraq was one such war, but nobody seemed
to notice the facts behind all TV-wanna-be-superbowl-sunday coverage of
that war.)

SOMALIA IS PANAMA ALL OVER AGAIN: We set up some US soldiers as sacrificial
lambs, tilt public opinion with George-Bushian-oratory about "unprovoked
attacks on US personnel", and start bombing in retaliation, claiming there
was no way to control the situation. Exactly what happened in Panama.

And after it's all over, we'll have to stick around for a while to ensure
"peace" -- better build an airbase and some barracks. Oh gee, we spent all
that money building air strips and barracks, I guess it must be ours in the
first place.

So yes, it's beginning to sound like the Panama Deception all over again.
(one of the darkest moments in modern US foreign policy that everybody
seems to have completely forgotten about).

And in the end, we get Somalia to control mideast oil, and Panama to
control the coca trade in columbia/peru, and control the Panama canal 
(which we won't be giving back to the Panamanians in 1999, thereby 
violating treaties signed by Jimmy Carter)....

(Hey, I still think that government can be good, but perhaps "Good" can
never happen in a superpower, and perhaps power does corrupt absolutely.)

==           Niels Mayer -- netcom!mayer -- mayer@netcom.com               ==

From sfraves-owner  Tue Oct  5 08:37:01 1993
From: lxfogel@srv.PacBell.COM (Lee Fogel)
Date: Tue, 5 Oct 93 08:30:45 PDT
Subject: Connection Earth 
Status: 


I arrived at the site a little before 11, where there was a steady drizzle.
Ethan & Bryce showed up with the sound system, and we were pretty much set 
up by 12ish  The drizzling had stopped, but hardly anyone else had arrived, 
and I became concerned because we were also missing a number of key people 
who supposed to help get us off to an early start.  

It turns out that there were huge traffic jams, in the city and on the Bay
Bridge due to the Castro Street fair, but Lee arrived just in time to keep
things on schedule, and Brian arrived just after with his DAT, banner etc.

People continued to dribble in while Ethan & Bryce continued to fine tune
the audio.  When I think of how many parties I've been to where the sound
has been distorted, out of phase, or generally screwed, it's a pleasue to
be in the company of sound people who really care.  This was the best 
sounding system the park has ever heard.  

I think we reached critical mass midway through Lee's set.  The vibe 
grew with each minute as more people arrived.  There was fruit, juice,
water, literature, recycling bins, bubbles, juggling - It's these kinds of 
touches, the ones that promote a sense of sharing, awareness and 
participation that make the difference between a fun party and a spiritual 
celebration.  There are few things that feel better than being a part of a
such a cooperative effort.  

Park Rangers - As expected, they showed up with frowns on their faces.  The
older bald-headed guy - we've seen him at other events: what a grump.  
Anyway, they claimed that residents outside the park were complaining 
about the sound, but implied that since it was outside park jurisdiction it 
wasn't their concern.  Nevertheless, I told them that we certainly didn't
want to disturb *anybody* and offered to have the speakers turned.  I don't 
think they believed I was serious until we immediately did so.  This seemed 
to impress them.  They looked over the permit very carefully while I babbled 
on about how peaceful we were and how much we plan to clean up after 
ourselves "cause we want to do more of these." etc.  I managed to get a 
smile out of the female ranger when I invited them to stay and join us.  
They declined, never to return again.

Police presence in the area - Apparently, they were looking for someone
with a gun who had ran into the park.  In fact, I heard that *they* pulled 
a gun on one of us, Mark Metz I believe, in the nearby woods.  A little 
later when the SFPD cruiser pulled up near the dance area, I figured it 
would be for a noise complaint, especially since we were approaching the 
5pm deadline.  Since I was sort of planning to lose track of time around 
then, I really didn't want to talk to them.  I didn't have to; they just 
smiled, turned around and left.

Fire! - An alert MykL Gold noticed smoke nearby, and we ran to investigate.
I had visions of the headlines: RAVERS BURN GOLDEN GATE PARK TO THE GROUND!
Not the kind of PR we're looking for, not to mention that I'd probably have
a hard time getting my security deposit back. ;-)  Anyway, it just turned 
out to be some homeless people around a campfire.

Time! - We got away with having amplified sound from 12:30 - 6pm, 1.5 hours 
more than permitted.  Shaun Ralston, who as recently as a few weeks ago had 
some kind of park event kept telling me how lucky we were, because for him, 
the rangers would next to the sound system looking at their watches.  Based
on what I've been hearing, I have to conclude that there's a lot of 
selective enforcement going on.  Or maybe the rangers were too busy hassling 
someone else that afternoon. 

Garbage? - My worries about garbage were completely unfounded.  I was almost
dissapointed that there wasn't more.  By the time I got hold of a garbage 
bag, other volunteers had already done the job. I satisfied my selfrighteous
environmentalist ethic by spending 5 minutes picking up some old cigarette 
butts from previous events.

DJs! - I want to personally thank the DJs for an outstanding job.  Lee had
done a radio gig the night before only to have me call him early in the
morning to tell him to come to the park extra early.  Then he gets caught 
in a massive traffic jam and has to rush to the tables without a moment to 
spare while the sound was still being adjusted.  His set had to be 
interrupted once while an annoying buzz in the left channel was eliminated.  
Still, Lee managed to set the mood and get the party off to a great start.  
Thanks to Markie for being Markie, mind-blowing as usual.  I was afraid DJ 
snobbery would cause some people to people to leave after Markie, but they 
stayed as Jon kept the vibe going string with a great set, even when the 
weather started to get chilly.  My apologies for jerking him around a bit 
by first telling him "another 10 or 15 minutes" and then extending things 
till 6 "unless I give you a signal."   

Again? - I already called the park, and Marx Meadows is all booked for
October.  I really don't want to deal with the stress of iffy weather but 
if anyone else wants to try to organize one before spring, I'll support the 
effort.  What I'm contemplating for the future is getting 3 or 4 dates in 
advance.  We have a great team here with a lot of talent andheart.  Giving 
something back to a scene that has given so much to us: the self-
reinforcement of positive energy - this is what will keep the scene alive.   
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
Lee Fogel/\/\/\/\/\eVerything/\Is/\possiBlE/\/\/\/\/\lxfogel@srv.pacbell.com
____________________________________________________________________________

From sfraves-owner  Tue Oct  5 09:05:01 1993
From: "Niels P. Mayer" <mayer@netcom.com>
Date: Tue, 05 Oct 93 09:04:53 -0700
Subject: Electronic Spread of Information (was Re: Info on russia )
Status: 


>> Brian talks about alt.current-events.russia

From: dz5401a@palestrina.anderson-lab.american.edu (Douglas Zimmerman)
> Not all information is totally on the electronic tip these days.
> While in Kenya two summer's ago, the Russian Revolution occured and
> the only way of receiving information was via shortwave radio.
> (viva the BBC) which had hourly updates. Shortwave is broadcast over 
> all of russia and is accessed by many common people. Many people found
> the truth of what was happining in Moscow over shortwave radio. So
> the alternatives are there.

Yes, these alternatives are there, and listening to shortwave radio is
a very interesting experience... but please remember that VOA and BBC
are pure unmitigated western propaganda. It's this weird cat and mouse
game -- the western powers beam in megawatts of propaganda into the 
(ex) soviet union, and the (ex) soviet union puts out megawatts of
radio-noise to jam the western stations. In some places, people can
hear past the jammers, but in most places they can't.

Realize that this "radio cold war" has been going on for a long time
and that everything discussed is pure propaganda. Take everything you
hear with a boulder of  salt. 

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=
==           Niels Mayer -- netcom!mayer -- mayer@netcom.com               ==
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=

From sfraves-owner  Tue Oct  5 13:05:51 1993
From: csc@pilot.njin.net (Sean Casey)
Date: Tue, 5 Oct 93 16:05:46 EDT
Subject: Divinity and Connection Earth
Status: 


DIVINITY

Divinity went off really well.  It was held in a trippy three story
rock climbing gym in Davis with rock walls on all sides and above.
Definitely one of the weirdest spaces I've been in :).

More than anything, Divinity was a really good vibe. When I got
there, a lot of people were just standing around. Usually this isn't
too good but even then one could sense a really positive vibe. Maybe
it's just due to the different crowd in Sacramento/Davis, but it gave
me a really good feeling.

Moonpup came on not soon after I got there and just did a fantastic
job and got everybody dancing. His sets are just so PHAT! And I like
his mixes probably better than anyone's.

And Carlos did his usual manic energize the crowd scratch go crazy put
the same record on both turntables and flip back and forth total
wonderful crazy love energy.

True Story: He's playing this really long, really amazingly great
song, and I decide I just *gotta* have it, so I look and there's no
label. I smile at Carlos and point at it and the expression on my
face tells all. So he just blows my mind when he mixes it out and then
just HANDS me the record so I could look at the label which is on the
flip side! Wow! What a nice guy! Spread the energy!

Dutch follows with a nice groovy trancey set which made it just right
for me.

It was also a good night because I made 4 or 5 new friends (Hi Tom and
Crissy and Chris and Eliza and Jen and the lady who was with Carlos
whose name I can't remember but whose smile I'll never forget). Really
nice people who I hope to share the vibe with again. It's interesting
how, if you're having a good time, and you're really open about it and
wanting to connect, you can really affect the people around you and
help them have a better time. It's so much fun and such an amazing
thing for me, connectedness. I was apart for so much of my life, and
rave has taught me so much.

Good: Really far out space. Really friendly crowd and promoters. No
confiscations. Smoke free. Lots of chill space.

Bad: Thick shredded tires on floor. Great for falling off a wall but
quickly tiring for dancing. I'm going to sugest they shovel them up
next time. Sound system wasn't done well so not much in the way of
stereo.


CONNECTION EARTH

The other reviews were right on. A _really_ good vibe, starting out
with about 10 hugs for Sean from happy SF raver folk :). It was a good
vibe all day with people dancing and hanging out and just being
family.

Someone asked why so many people were sitting around. Well it wasn't
the music or the space, I'm sure. Probably more because it was Sunday
and a lot of people were probably thrashed. I know personally that I
was ready for a hot tub by Sunday night.

I thought Jon was especially on Sunday. It was a _kickin_ groove for
hours where the songs just drive into each other. Wow. Poor Greg :)
just about danced a hole in the ground.

Mega-thanks to Lee and all who put this together. It's truly a
privilege to have all of you around as you spread such a good vibe and
so many good feelings. That's what it's all about :).

Sean

From sfraves-owner  Tue Oct  5 15:44:00 1993
From: john@makesys.com (John Turman)
Date: Tue, 5 Oct 93 13:50:43 PDT
Subject: MasqueRave - It ain't nuttin but a house party
Status: 

Hey all you raving lunatics d8~). Just want to let you know that there will be a
MasqueRave in San Jose Oct. 29th. Costumes are encouraged but not mandatory,
after all, "mandatory" is not a rave word. 

All are welcome who would like to come and party with us. Come along and bring a
friend. We've had a few at our house before and they've turned out quite nice.
Good vibes and good friends. Please RSVP via E-Mail to me at john@makesys.com
and I'll give you directions, times etc.

Also, I'm looking for DJ's who would like to "practice" on a live audience. So if
you are an aspiring new DJ, or an established, veteran pacesetter who would like 
to donate your time/talent in return for a great vibe and good fun, please let me
know. I'll provide the pre-amp, power amp, and speakers if some outrageously
nice individual can come up with a couple of turntables and a mixer all will be 
cool. If all else fails I will use pre-mix taped music, but there will be a 
groove. As that guy that sells suits on TV says, "I guarantee it".

I will keep all posted as to the status of the DJ situation for this party. I
know some folks don't like to dance unless it's to their fave DJ but hey, this
party is for folks who aren't all that particular about who they dance to. Just
that they get the chance to dance and have fun and meet some fun people. So if
you have any pretentiousness please leave it at home, this party is about fun and
nothing else.

I will provide plenty of bottled water and cups, you provide the vibe.

And Puhleeze! Consume all chemical substances before you arrive. I do not want
to give any of my neighbors a reason to ruin our groove. So no strange aromas
in the yard or house, and no exchanges of money in a hand shake, OK?

Anyway I look forward to a fun time, I hope you can join us. After all, how many
Roseanne re-runs can you watch on a Friday night?

Bye Y'all.

John T.

PS. I was at "Home" ... good groove. I was wearing the Swiss Army hat and 
over-alls. C-Ya

	According to reports, Saturday at approximately 3 a.m., James
Edwin Stubbs,23, was observed selling balloons of gas at a "rave" party in
a parking lot of the Rocknasium on Olive Drive.  Stubbs was found in
possession of a nitrous oxide tank, balloons, a baggie containing 24
tablets, which tested positive for opiate and methedrin, and $276 in
cash.  The controlled substances and cash were taken as evidence, Stubbs
was booked at the Davis Police Department and lodged at Yolo County Jail.


This makes the Davis Police's biggest bust list I'm sure and now you know
why "raves" get such a bad rap from the police.

From sfraves-owner  Wed Oct  6 10:52:43 1993
From: lxfogel@srv.PacBell.COM (Lee Fogel)
Date: Wed, 6 Oct 93 10:52:34 PDT
Subject: life&raving
Status: 


>anyway, not much more to say that hasn't already been said, except i must
>reiterate THANKS LEE!!  without you, this never would have happened, and

None of it would have happened without the example and path already laid
out for me by Brian, or  without the resources made readily available to
me through SFRaves.  It was a team effort that came together naturally;
entropy in reverse.

Some people on this list might remember that in the days of Connection 1,
I was against the idea of SFRaves becoming anything more than an unbiased
forum for the exchange of information.  I think this was due to my 
paranoia toward power structures, social hierarchies, egos, etc.  I was
afraid the objective character of SFRaves would be compromised, along with
with its purpose.  Well, the truth is that all things tend to either evolve
or die.  SFRaves could of never remained (was it ever?) objective, and
why should it?  There is nothing preventing other lists from being
created with their own evolutionary paths.  Ultimately, knowledge,
information, and the ability to communicate it, is a powerful force.  And 
power can be used just as easily as it can be abused.  

This is what life is about; selfempowerment - making things happen in our
lives and in the world around us.  But what's really cool is this doesn't
have to come at the expense of others.  We can make each other powerful 
and as a result, make the world a more exciting and meaningful place to 
live in.

Every now & then someone inevitably posts the "There is more to life than
raving" statement.  One could ask; Is there more to life than family,
friends, community, spirituality, selfexploration, and connectivity with
our bodies, art, technology and nature?  Many of us have come into contact
with many of these things to varying degrees through raving and through
some of the activities that surround the rave scene.  At the same time,
We've been to enough shitty parties and encountered enough confusion to
realize that like everything, the scene is imperfect, made up of imperfect
people in an imperfect world.  Ideals are things we look toward while
reality is something we live in.  But like any self-fulfilling prophecy,
if enough people believe that an activity contains many of the ideals
and feelings that make life worth living, then these people *will*
incorporate many of these ideals and feelings back into that activity.  I 
know a few people whose lives have been positively transformed by the rave
scene, as imperfect as it may be.  People finding and helping to create a 
path that works for them, and perhaps others, is nothing to be scoffed at.

  "With the vast uncensorable network of communication media, obstacles
  to the free flow of information will become progressively more
  difficult to erect and enforce.  Traditional human power structures
  and their reign of darkness are about to be rendered obsolete.
  If humanity realizes its potential in time, we shall witness strong
  competition among individuals to be allowed to serve on humanity's
  research, development, and production teams.  People's sense of
  accomplishment will derive from showing their peers and demonstrating
  to the great intellectual integrity of Universe, which we speak of
  as God, that they vastly enjoy doing their best in the unselfish
  production of service for others rather than just for the survival
  needs of themselves and their families."
 
                                         R. Buckminster Fuller

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
Lee Fogel/\/\/\/\/\eVerything/\Is/\possiBlE/\/\/\/\/\lxfogel@srv.pacbell.com

From sfraves-owner  Wed Oct  6 11:07:09 1993
From: jeremias@MIT.EDU (Jeremy Grainger)
Date: Wed, 06 Oct 93 14:20:08 0000
Subject: NOTneces.R*VE-REL:TONIGHT! Making Communities? Fax us!
Status: 

Subject: Call for Fax/Mail Art: An Act of Resistance:Making Community(ies)


Hello cybertribe:::

I'm involved in this thing. Thought that some of you might wanna contribute your
wisdom, creativity and community building!!
Peaceout, Jeremy (eeyore) {ne-raver, IDM-er}

>>>>>>FAX ART should be faxed to 617.451.2910 between October 5 and 23. 

Art work is being solicited for the Mail and Fax Art portion of an exhibition 
called _An Act of Resistance: Making Community(ies)_ at Boston's Mobius Gallery 
October 6-23.

All mail and fax art concerning the show's theme will be shown. 
Artwork by "nonartists" is especially encouraged!
Mail art can be in any form, size or shape and should be sent to: 

Arts/Resist Mail Art, 
P. O. Box 1136, Kendall Square, 
Cambridge, MA 02142.

There is no "deadline" persay. ALL mail rec'd during the show dates will be put 
in the gallery. Try to get it to us by the oepning date, so the maximum number 
of people can see it.

FAX ART should be faxed to 617.451.2910 between October 5 and 23. 
The organizers encourage sending fax art during the show's opening reception 
Wednesday, October 6, from 5 to 8 pm Eastern US time.

Mail and Fax art are part of a democratic, decentralized, global "networker" 
movement that seeks to link people and ideas on a grassroots level through 
direct exchange.

Mobius is located at 354 Congress St in Boston's Fort Point Channel district, 
near the South Station stop on the red line.

The juried portion of the exhibition features work by many New England artists 
engaged with political activism and is sponsored by the RESIST Foundation. 
RESIST, begun in 1967 to help fund the growing movement opposed to the Vietnam 
War, is celebrating its 25th anniversary of funding small, grassroots, social 
change organizations.

For more information: On Mail/Fax Art contact 617-242-2442 or Internet 
<jeremias@mit.edu>. On show details: Mobius: 617-542-7416. On RESIST call 
617-623-5110

Thanks in advance for your contribution(s)!

Jeremy Grainger 
for the ARTS/RESIST organizing committee 
<jeremias@mit.edu>

PS: Here's a listing of related events for those of you in the area.

The juried show includes work by: Anonymous, Joe Briganti, Buffalo Gals, Annete 
Dupon, Lydia Eccles, Roberta Hayes, Anne Rocheleau, Ellen Shub, Sarah Slive, 
Karen Kimmel and the Dispersion Project.

Wednesday, October 6, 5- 8 pm - Opening reception Gallery Talk by Buffalo Gals 
who will give a short presentation on their current art campaign to prevent 
installation of commercial-ridden televisions on the "T," the Boston subway.

Thursday, October 14, 8 pm - "Art that netWORKS" a talk by Chuck Welsh (aka net 
artist, the CrackerJack Kid), editor of the forthcoming anthology _The Eternal 
Network: A Mail Art Anthology_, due from the Univ. of Calgary Press next Spring.

Friday, October 15, 8 pm - Video and film presentations by social cahnge group's 
which have received funding from RESIST.

Saturday, October 16, 8 pm - An Evening of Haitian Culture with food, music and 
more. Coordinated by one of the juried artists, Roberta Hayes, whose work 
documents the Haitian refugee community in the area.

From sfraves-owner  Wed Oct  6 14:56:48 1993
From: rpcaras@srv.PacBell.COM (Bob Carasik)
Date: Wed, 6 Oct 93 14:56:41 PDT
Subject: Now what??
Status: 

> 
> Hey kids, fishy thoughts follow :)
> 
> I must agree with Sean in this matter. There is more to life than raving to be
> sure, but can't raving become an affector of a way of life? A way of life

Affector, even effector, but it ain't life itself.  It certainly has given
me a new perspective with which to look at the significance of what I do.
Raves have inspired me to do more dancing, more writing, less worrying.  And
I've met a lot of people.  But, like the guy who reported on Crash Worship &
Burning Man ( grigsby? ) said, the vibe can't stand still, it changes if you
just repeat it endlessly.  There's a rhythm that's right for each of us.  The
next step from raving seems to be different for every person, but a next step
there must be or it's just endless tweakin' each an' every weaken.  

I'm not
>gasp< unsubscribing or anything, but raves aren't new for me, so I try to 
pick events judiciously.  I've had great luck, what with the Bulltproof boat
party and Connection Earth back to back, so I'll probably lay out for about a 
month.  So keep it alive and thrive!  


AstroBoy

> rave? Does the vibe end when you get into your car and drive off into the
> sunrise? :)
> 
> There is more to life than raving, but a rave is more than just a party
> (and no, that's not a veiled jab at Partyon).


"so maybe you'll be happy / but even if you're not
there's more to life than that / Don't ask me what! "

The Matchmaker Song, Fiddler on the Roof

From sfraves-owner  Thu Oct  7 08:53:45 1993
From: lxfogel@srv.PacBell.COM (Lee Fogel)
Date: Thu, 7 Oct 93 8:53:38 PDT
Subject: Re: 20 Years To Ecstasy
Status: 

Larry:
> 
>  On the other hand , now the monk can do it whenever he wants to ,

Maybe.  The conditions under which Zen monks develop the ability to
enter altered states of consciousness involve cutting off most
sensory input and normal thought processes.   You don't see many monks
hobnobbing about town, or at raves, because the abilities they have
developed over 20 years are integreted with a lifestyle that cuts them
off from the more obvious aspects of human interaction.  This seems to
severly limit the ways in which they can share their abilities and energy
with others.  I wish there were some monks on the net who could enlighten 
us further about this.
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
Lee Fogel/\/\/\/\/\eVerything/\Is/\possiBlE/\/\/\/\/\lxfogel@srv.pacbell.com

From sfraves-owner  Thu Oct  7 09:47:29 1993
From: "Scott Nozawa*" <scott_nozawa*@quickmail.apple.com>
Date: 7 Oct 1993 09:40:36 -0800
Subject: Re: 20 Years To Ecstasy
Status: 

                       Subject:                               Time:9:09
  OFFICE MEMO          RE>20 Years To Ecstasy                 Date:10/7/93
Hmmm...

>The conditions under which Zen monks develop the ability to
>enter altered states of consciousness involve cutting off most
>sensory input and normal thought processes.

TRUE

>This seems to severly limit the ways in which they can 
>share their abilities and energy with others.

One of the many reasons why these monks or anyone else meditates is to gain
better understanding of themselves and there world.  All be it true that in the
process of meditation they are withdrawn, in the world of here and now they use
their insights to guide them while fully conscious.  Their abilites are very
personal and private but the energy they exude (sp?) will be present in their
waking state as well.  Just as we (I) can not fully share our (my) experience
while captured in the strobing lights and sonic impulses,  but can later walk
around and share socially.

T. Scot       ********************************************




From sfraves-owner  Thu Oct  7 09:53:55 1993

    >Zen is slow, slow is fine for some, but doesn't work for me.
    >It tends to involve not-moving.
    >Not-moving is not natural for me, and highly distracting.

Hmm... Zen is neither slow nor fast.  It is about awareness of the here and
now.  It is about the realization that one is alive and is a vital part of
this universe this second, this instant in time. Zen awareness is that
moment when you KNOW you are trancing to the groove. When you become aware
that you are one with the music, the people, the environment that you
inhabit.

Peace!

Tigger

From sfraves-owner  Thu Oct  7 10:50:44 1993
From: SCRUTON@JOYCE.dnet.hac.com
Date: 07 Oct 1993 10:50:19 -0800 (PST)
Subject: Monks & Such
Status: 

I would imagine that Zen Meditation is quite similar to Transcendental
  Meditation, from a subconscious point of view; I did TM for about 2
  years; had 2 really good 'trips' during that time while meditating;

Yes, it IS possible to practice meditation and interact publicly;  you just
  have to get your timing right so you can have about 1hr of quiet time
  per day, when no one is talking to you and the phone isn't ringing.

Don't know what the timeload is for Zen Med, but TM only requires 20 minutes
  in the morning and 20 minutes in the afternoon. It really does work, but
  requires discipline (same mentality as practicing the piano)

Dave Scruton

From sfraves-owner  Thu Oct  7 11:22:59 1993

>   enter altered states of consciousness involve cutting off most
>   sensory input

    Which is usually rather difficult to do in a large, noisy, city.
    Sensory *overload* can have the same effect, and is much easier.
    
>   and normal thought processes.

    hee hee hee

>                                               You don't see many monks
>   hobnobbing about town, or at raves, because the abilities they have
>   developed over 20 years are integreted with a lifestyle that cuts them
>   off from the more obvious aspects of human interaction.  This seems to
>   severly limit the ways in which they can share their abilities and energy
>   with others.

    What we are developing here is a way to get there without having to
    live the life of a monk.  We *can* and *do* share our energy, but we
    do not surrender our individuality or our creativity.
    
    Let this combination interact with the world and it *will* move.

>                I wish there were some monks on the net who could enlighten 
>   us further about this.

    Can we get some of them to a rave?  We know that the effects of
    psychedelics on them are similar to what they achived on their own,
    howzabout the effects of the music/dance/vibe?
    
    The sacraments are a way of giving the body/mind permission to do
    what it wants to do anyway.  When the music gets going, my body and
    mind no longer wait to get permission.
    


From sfraves-owner  Thu Oct  7 11:54:20 1993
From: winston@lurnix.COM (Mark Guthrie)
Date: Thu, 7 Oct 93 11:17:09 PDT
Subject: Re: 20 Years To Ecstasy
Status: 

> You don't see many monks
>hobnobbing about town, or at raves, because the abilities they have
>developed over 20 years are integreted with a lifestyle that cuts them
>off from the more obvious aspects of human interaction.  This seems to
>severly limit the ways in which they can share their abilities and energy
>with others.

Maybe, but monks aren't about converting people like christians or other 
religions/philosophies.  Zen and Taoism are personal paths that you seek
and travel on your own.  If you want to learn you seek them out.  They
(Zen buddists) limit contact and involvement in the normal affairs of 
men as part of their philosophy of non-doing and getting out of the
inherantly ratty rat-race of suffering.  Taoists only sever contact to
limit distractions in meditation and study and to commune with nature, or
the great Tao, not to get away from fellow man, who is just acting as man
does by running the rat-race.  Now back to your normal programming.

-Mark

From sfraves-owner  Thu Oct  7 12:07:02 1993
From: Jeffrey Moore <jmoore@well.sf.ca.us>
Date: 	Thu, 7 Oct 1993 12:05:46 -0700
Subject: Re:  Monks & Such
Status: 

Zen is more a way of life than a trick to acheiving altered states of
conciousness. A person who follows the teachings of zen is going to reflect
that in everything they do. In that respect, it is a 24 hour a day thing.
You don't just turn it on and off. The meditation aspect of zen is more a
tool in self exploration that the monks use. Other practioners of zen use
other methods. In fact most of the traditional Japanese arts (like flower
arranging, swordsmanship, archery, etc.) are similar kinds of tools for the
lay zen practioners.  I recommend Eugen Herrigel's book "Zen in the Art of
Archery". It helps clarify what zen's relationship is with everyday life and
the things we do every day.

-Jeff

Garth, Jeno and Thomas are supposed to be down in LA Saturday, which
explains part of the event deficit.  Maybe this is a good weekend to
read a book, do some volunteer work, create something, enjoy nature,
help a friend, make the world a better place.  

Weeklies which have gotten good reviews include Your Sisters' House,
Deep Space, Mission Rock, Corduroy City, Boogie Buffet, Pepper,
Mushroom Jazz, and Together.  If anyone likes any of the others,
let us know!

Try the Be-At info line (415.626.4087) for daily updates on clubs and
parties - it's usually fairly complete, and also includes clubs with
other kinds of music - hiphop, reggae, funk, etc.

To delete yourself from the calendar mailing list, read the instructions
at the bottom.  (don't embarrass yourself by sending a message to the
entire list - never send mail to sfraves-calendar@techno.stanford.edu!).

good. If anyone can provide reviews of them, i.e., their appropriateness 
in being on the list, let me know.  Also let me know when any of them stop...

From sfraves-owner  Thu Oct  7 13:48:10 1993
From: winston@lurnix.COM (Mark Guthrie)
Date: Thu, 7 Oct 93 13:19:19 PDT
Subject: Re:  Monks & Such
Status: 

In fact most of the traditional Japanese arts (like flower
arranging, swordsmanship, archery, etc.) are similar kinds of tools for the
lay zen practioners.  I recommend Eugen Herrigel's book "Zen in the Art of
Archery". It helps clarify what zen's relationship is with everyday life and
the things we do every day.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------

I feel it's important to point out that Zen isn't Japanese in origin, but
Chinese (Ch'an) and it is an off-shoot from traditional buddhism (what's
the name for that, Pali?, someting else?) of India.

-Mark

From sfraves-owner  Thu Oct  7 16:03:41 1993
From: Harry Duran <hduran@UMDNJ.EDU>
Date: Thu, 7 Oct 1993 19:01:08 -0500 (EDT)
Subject: meditationvs Ex..
Status: 

I may have bombed the prior message that i was sending

please forgive me if a garbled glurp comes over in advance of this post

the use of ecstatogenic meditative and dancing techniques is well known to
many western people as a curiosity, or of anthropological interest.

now the purpose of these techniques is to reach a state of awareness beyond
the egocenttric dualistic view

lo and behold when one is exing a similar state is reached (or at least that has been my experience YMMV)

does that devalue the meditative experience? i think not the whole purpose is 
to become a more loving and compassionate being, not just trippy.
But lo and behold a similar state is reached on Ex? Hmmm.

similarly transcendance of self and psychic communion with others, perceptions
freed from time and space referentials all can be had with both.

The power of meditation is that it provides real and enduring change. 

The ecstatogens point the way and enable one to understand the meaning of 
certain meditative terminologies if one is inclined to use them in this way.

the rational end enlightened use of ecstatogens is unfamiliar territory
in the culture at large. My belief is that designed spiritual experiences
can be had at raves with the combination of music dancing alone (much like
the use of these techniques in the 13th century by the Sufis of Turkey).
However, adding an enhancer to the mix may also boost and open the path much quicker. Or so it seems. Nevertheless, responsible use of these agents
is key and their real power is in the way they can shape and alter the psyche.

Nuff senseless blathering from me these are my own rantings and no one elses,

Nyaaaaa, WAZZUPDOQ???????????????

On the club front, Susie and I went to Spundae in the basement of the DV8
building (55 Natoma) and had a pretty good time last Sunday.

However, last night I went to Tilt at DV8 (thanks to just missing my
flight from SFO, but that's another story) but thought it was pretty
un-happening.  

I also saw a listing in the Bay Guardian for 'Reality' on Wednesday
night at 1190 Folsom, but it's definitely not happening.

Finally, although it's not rave-related, I had a really good time at
Nickie's (460 Haight) on Tuesday night with a DJ playing a variety of
African stuff -- some soukous, a little in the Salif Keita vein, some
mbaqanga -- and a small but enthusiastically dancing crowd.  The same
DJ is supposed to be at an event at 1015 Folsom on Sundays starting
later this month -- and that could mean the next time I come to town
I just set up camp at 1015 on Sunday morning and stay for the duration :)

From sfraves-owner  Fri Oct  8 02:26:41 1993

From sfraves-owner  Fri Oct  8 02:47:49 1993
From: spaceman@cats.ucsc.edu (illuminated iconoclast)
Date: Fri, 8 Oct 93 02:47:44 -0700
Subject: new muzik for caliban!
Status: 


	just picked up some cd's....

	a comp called /the secret life of trance/ on rising
	high produuctions.  of special note on the disc is
	hardfloor 'hardtrance acperiance 1', sequential
	'prophet' and spicelab 'quicksand.'  the barbarella
	thing is great too.

	a four trak cd from polygon window (aphex twin).
	'quoth' is the title trak, hsa two mixes, and is
	pretty good.  'iketa' is a great trak, and 'bike
	pump meets bucket' is terrific, more pumping and
	funky that i would have imagined would come from
	this guy... nice distorted kickdrum.

	and finally orbital's /orbital2/.  it starts out
	with a minute and a half of lt. worf's "where time
	becomes a loop" repeated over and over, two different
	trax, one left, one right, slightly out of phase.
	direct rippoff from steve reich's landmark 'come
	out', from like 1968 or something, but i am not 
	bagging the orbital attempt at all. let's just 
	call it quotation.  the whole thing is dripping
	with wonderful emax2 stuff.  they are really good
	with their use of delay, wich is about my favorite 
	element in this sort of music.  also, some songs 
	have *progressions*, which i dig too.  a fantastic
	follow up to the first disc, maybe even better!


From sfraves-owner  Fri Oct  8 07:01:06 1993
From: jsl@netcom.com (John S. Lee)
Date: Fri, 8 Oct 93 07:01:32 -0700
Subject: October - C, it is ugly 8)
Status: 

Just as I expected, October will prove to be a better month for parties, as
far as this year is concerned.  There are two new clubs opening up. 

(Wednesdays starting Oct. 13th) Motion - 400 S. 1st Street in San Jose
$3 before 11:30, $5 thereafter.

Lineup:
Oct 13 - DJ's Lauren, Rick Preston, & Markie Mark
(Loren is the latest in a line of great new up-n-coming DJ's.   Check him out!)

Oct 20 - DJ's Lauren, Harry Who, & Tony

Oct 27 - DJ's Tamotsu, Rick Preston, & Spun

Info: 408-236-3787


There is also a new Friday thang going down (in SF), but I have few
details.  From what I understand though it will be very fresh, and very
new.  Keep your eyes alert for more info as I get a hold of it.


(The rest is just my early morning ramblings...bandwidth!?!  What bandwidth?)

Once again, October will be the ugly month.  There is soo much going on
that you had better have a job, or inherit some cash if you want to go to
all of the events coming up.  Especially near the end of the month.  The
big off-your-face-nights will be the weekend of Haloween.  This madness
will start on a Fri. (the 29th).  Wicked I thought was gonna be on the 23rd
but it seems that there will be something on the 29th as well.  Along with
that you have the 30th with soo many parties and nonsense that there will
surely be casualties :).  And then on the 31st more banality with the boat
party (I've already reserved my tix, if U wanna go you'd watch closely when
they go on sale).  So with all of that going on I have decided to double my
insurance policy.  I should be rather limp come Monday, so I've already
given notice to my supe that the 1st of Nov. is a "mental health day", so I
won't be coming to work!  I can't wait to see the video for the next few
weeks (Nitty Gritty will be in the house roving to every party and getting
the higlights, and lo-lites).

Pace out,
John

Do you select songs you want to remix or do people/labels request it or both.
If you select it, our tastes coincide very well.  There are several tracks
that I had been trying to I.D. for a while now and I was very happy to hear
them when I was listening to the discs for the first time, I know what they
are now.  I feel I realy got a great deal too.  5 disks for $40 - includes
tax.  Wow!  Can't beat that with a stick.  Thanks guys, and keep up the good
work.

-Mark

From sfraves-owner  Fri Oct  8 11:28:09 1993
From: Bob Ramstad <rramstad@us.oracle.com>
Date: Fri, 8 Oct 93 11:28:00 PDT
Subject: YSH
Status: 


After being gone for a while (btw, I was unsubscribed for a couple of
weeks, if anything happened you want me to know about, pls send email)
I decided that I ** had ** to make YSH.

I was a bit disappointed to hear it would be at Cleo's, after hearing
negatives on the space from previous times.  I resolved to go anyway,
mainly because I had bagged on the previous Cleo's deals and figured
that it was pretty lame for me to bag on the space even though I had
never been in it.

Nice cafe, clean, no hassles, good people running it / working there.
Got there early, had a double espresso, read the Guardian and SF
Weekly... but really couldn't imagine a YSH in that space.

WRONGO.  Had a great time, Susan played a very trippy set, followed by
Rebecca with one of the most bizarre sets I've ever heard (I think I
say this every time I see her spin, it was wonderful!) and Cleo was
hospitable above and beyond the call of duty.

So where was everybody?  Saw Sean, Brian (for 2 seconds), Monicat,
Bryce... a good time for the intrepid / determined adventurer.

Yowsa!
Bob

From sfraves-owner  Fri Oct  8 17:08:40 1993
From: "Niels P. Mayer" <mayer@squick.eit.COM>
Date: Fri, 08 Oct 1993 17:08:15 -0700
Subject: FYI -- MTV on the net
Status: 


Here's the readme from ftp.mtv.com:

- ----====----====----====----====----====----====----====----

Welcome to MTV.COM!!!

Well, it's been an interesting startup, I've been learning alot about UNIX
and the Net as I go along, and so far it's been fun.

Here's a brief rundown on this site:

First and foremost I have to make it very clear that mtv.com is NOT
sponsored by MTV Networks. Although they are aware of my cyberspace
dwellings they aren't yet ready to commit to a project like this, but I
have their bessing in spreading the gospel ofcourse ;-)

So this ofcourse means that I am paying for my T1 connection myself, which
is maintained by the fine folks at Digital Express.

Although the startup has been rather slow, look for this site to be really
hoppin' within the next couple of weeks. My personal assistant Ken Clar
(ken@mtv.com) will be posting a weekly newsletter, we'll be putting
bloopers and outtakes up in quicktime format, look for digital presskits
to appear, and yes, even mailboxes for Beavis and Bitthead, huh, huh,heh.heh.

I intend to post programming grids for MTV along with important
development in the music bizz.

Please also not the "Cyber-Sleaze" wich is available through gopher, ftp
or the extended versions which are on the listprocessor, the mailing list
is cyber-sleaze@mtv.com and you should place the following in the message :

subscribe CYBER-SLEAZE your name

This extended reports are shareware, and donations are appreciated.

This is just the start of mtv.com and I hope that you will enjoy your stay
here. Suggestions and comments are always welcome!

All for now.

Adam Curry
- ----====----====----====----====----====----====----====----

=		       Niels Mayer -- mayer@eit.com                         =
=	     MultiMedia Engineering Collaborative Environment               =
= Enterprise Integration Technologies, 459 Hamilton Ave, Palo Alto CA 94301 =
