From sfraves-owner  Fri Oct  8 17:33:03 1993
From: mw@sybase.com (Michael Wertheim)
Date: Fri, 8 Oct 93 17:28:01 PDT
Subject: Re:  Re[2]: new muzik for caliban!
Status: 


>>I just got some new CDs too.  Twitch, volumes 4-8.  Great stuff Mike and Jon.
>Sounds interesting ... what's the label, & maybe a good place to find this one?

The label is Twitch.  The CDs are title "Twitch CD #1" thru "Twitch CD #8".
CDs 1-3 are out-of-print.  And CDs 4 and 5 are extremely endangered species.
Each CD is a compilation of techno/rave remixes and has a running time of
at  least 73 minutes.  The 5-CD set of CDs 4-8 are on sale for $40, which
includes shipping and tax.  For track lists, finger twitch@twitch.stanford.edu,
or email twitch@twitch.stanford.edu.

To order, send a check for $40, made payable to Twitch, to:
Twitch, 584 Castro Street, Suite 600, SF, CA  94114.

And do it *today*.  Once we're sold out, these CDs will never be re-issued.


From sfraves-owner  Fri Oct  8 17:33:04 1993

Hmm...interesting.  It all depends on what you call a club.  Is the club
the venue?  Or is the prodcuer of an event the prime determinant of a club?

Yeah, we all know it's F/X, but it's being done a bit different with a
different vibe, and feel.  So with that in mind, it qualifies as a new
club, since venue doesn't mean anything.  It's what you do with it that
counts!  Hell, following your line of logic, HOME was not HOME, but
Ceasar's Palace.  And I know the majority of people here would disagree. 
HOME was a new club. 

Motion is a new club.

From sfraves-owner  Fri Oct  8 17:43:49 1993
From: phred@well.sf.ca.us (Fred Heutte)
Date: 	Fri, 8 Oct 1993 17:43:12 -0700
Subject: Re: Resources for Malachy-net-empowerment and Handicapped computerists in
Status: 

The lead story in today's Wall Street Journal is very a propos.
It's entitled, "Aided by Computers, Many of the Disabled Form Own
Businesses," and is quite a good survey of some of the technologies
and approaches being used now.

I won't quote it at length, but the article does mention the Stanford
University Center for the Study of Language and Information, whose
Archimedes Project is using a voice-driven infrared unit to control
computers, faxes and phones.  Considering that
Stanford is also home to sfraves, I wonder if it would be possible
to hook Malachy and the CSLI folks up and see what develops :)

Let's see...is the point here to point out that he knows Lauren, or is it
to expose his "real" name?  In any case, I try to respect what a DJ likes
to be called publicly, or what his "show" name is.  We all know Jon D is
Jon Drukman.  But if he wants to be called DJ Jon D, I respect that.  And
when I refer him to others who may want to hire him, or other DJ's who may
spin with him, I refer to him as Jon D.  I dunno, I like to respect the
DJ's when it comes to certain things.  Call me crazy.  

Also, telling the location of peoples work is BS.  I would never do that to
anyone!  If L wants people to know such things, I am sure he would find a
way to tell them himself.  There was no need in posting his whereabouts,
since that is nobody's biz.

My final point:  Instead of not picking nits, maybe you should've given
some details about Lauren's club and support my man's efforts! :)

His party sounds damn good to me!

From sfraves-owner  Fri Oct  8 18:36:47 1993
From: "Niels P. Mayer" <mayer@squick.eit.COM>
Date: Fri, 08 Oct 1993 18:36:15 -0700
Subject: Re: Resources for Malachy-net-empowerment and Handicapped computerists$
Status: 

From phred@well.sf.ca.us:
From: ???
Date: ???
Subject: ???
Status: 

FYI -- some info on the Archimedes project. 

The people involved are all top-notch researchers in psycholinguistics
(Herb Clark), Psychology (Barbara Tversky) Logic/Linguistics/Philosophy
(John Perry, John Etchemendy, Tom Wasow, David Israel), Neural Nets (David
Rumelhart).  However, I have a feeling that as with most things academic
(and especially all things CSLI) they have a very non-practical bent to
things, so they probably won't be interested in specifiically helping
Malachy. I could be wrong of course, since I didn't attend the seminar
mentioned below, and I don't know how "real" the technology they're
developing is.

--------------------

                           CSLI SEMINAR 
                on Thursday, 7 October and 14 October
                        2:15 p.m., Cordura 100
            Theoretical Aspects of the Archimedes Project
                John Perry, Betsy Macken, Herb Clark,
           John Etchemendy, David Israel, David Rumelhart,
                     Barbara Tversky, Tom Wasow
                         Stanford University

The Archimedes Project is focusing on improving access to information for
individuals with disabilities, by utilizing some of the foundational and
applied work that is ongoing at CSLI, and by incorporating state-of-the-art
engineering to develop strategies for providing practical access.  This
project involves researchers and users from many different backgrounds.  The
goal of the Archimedes Project is to improve access to information for
individuals with disabilities by influencing the early design stages of
tomorrow's technology.  We will be discussing theoretical aspects of this
enterprise as it bears on ongoing research at CSLI.

--------------------

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=
=		       Niels Mayer -- mayer@eit.com                         =
=	     MultiMedia Engineering Collaborative Environment               =
= Enterprise Integration Technologies, 459 Hamilton Ave, Palo Alto CA 94301 =
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=

From sfraves-owner  Sun Oct 10 05:14:23 1993

From sfraves-owner  Sun Oct 10 13:26:45 1993
From: (Chris.Hilker) <cspot@cats.ucsc.edu>
Date: Sun, 10 Oct 93 13:26:40 +45722824
Subject: Re: ORB screen saver 
Status: 

>I had the same experience, after downloading, dehqxing and opening the SEA
>I couldn't get the ORB screen saver to run on AFTER DARK (tm).

>Any input would be appreciated.

You need to use the "PICS Player" module in After Dark. There's a button
labeled "Choose File..." that you press that gives you a file-selection
dialog box; select the file you downloaded. I like the float speed
"Slower" and I choose the "Invert" option, but I'm using black-and-white
mac.

C.

--
(chris.hilker) cspot@cats.ucsc.edu

"If spiders were in control, we wouldn't need nuclear weapons."

From sfraves-owner  Sun Oct 10 17:58:20 1993
From: bbehlen@soda.berkeley.edu (Brian Behlendorf)
Date: Sun, 10 Oct 1993 17:58:05 -0700
Subject: RE:ORB screen saver
Status: 

It's a SEA, self-extracting-archives, which means you click on it and it
uncompresses, and then you run it using the PICS player module in After
Dark.  Make sure and tell your Mac that it is indeed a Mac file when you
download it, or else it won't recognize it and refuse to decompress itself
(I lurve macs!)

        Brian

From sfraves-owner  Sun Oct 10 18:12:41 1993
From: (Chris.Hilker) <cspot@cats.ucsc.edu>
Date: Sun, 10 Oct 93 18:12:36 +45722824
Subject: Re: ORB screen saver 
Status: 

bbehlen@soda.berkeley.edu (Brian Behlendorf) writes:
>It's a SEA, self-extracting-archives, which means you click on it and it
>uncompresses, and then you run it using the PICS player module in After
>Dark.  Make sure and tell your Mac that it is indeed a Mac file when you
>download it, or else it won't recognize it and refuse to decompress itself
>(I lurve macs!)

The last part isn't accurate. In addition to being in the SEA format, it's
also been run through binhqx, a utility created for the express purpose of
overcoming the problem of transferring Mac files. Use text transfer, then
run it through binhqx and expand it. I recommend the StuffIt Expander
utility, which is available via FTP from sumex-aim.stanford.edu, among
other places.

C.

--
(chris.hilker) cspot@cats.ucsc.edu

"If spiders were in control, we wouldn't need nuclear weapons."

From sfraves-owner  Sun Oct 10 18:59:58 1993
From: howard@netcom.com (Howard Berkey)
Date: Sun, 10 Oct 93 19:00:13 PDT
Subject: RE:ORB screen saver
Status: 

Brian Behlendorf sez:
> 
> Dark.  Make sure and tell your Mac that it is indeed a Mac file when you
> download it, or else it won't recognize it and refuse to decompress itself
> (I lurve macs!)

Well, not exactly.  It's not really a problem.

Actually I'll bet the biggest problem is people not realizing it's
just a PICS player module.  Downloading is almost as straightforward
as possible.

1.  FTP it.
2.  gunzip it (or do this during ftp)
3.  mcvert it (if you don't have mcvert, and are ftp'ing from a unix
    box, get it.  it's great.  Netcom has it.)
    Note that this could be a problem otherwise.  The file is binhexed
    (apple's own perverted uuencode which converts macbinary files into
    6-bit text) so either de-hqx it on the unix box with mcvert or
    locally with binhex 4.0, stuffit, etc...
4.  Download it.  I use Zmodem with white knight (which automagically
    detects most file transfer protocols, pretty nice)
5.  Double click on its icon (or de-hqx it if ya don't have mcvert)
6.  Move it to your System Folder:Control Panels:After Dark Files folder
7.  Open the After Dark control panel and select PICS player.  You
    should be able to figure it out from there.

Have fun!

-H-



-- 
:::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::
Howard Berkey                                             howard@netcom.com   
  Plato, they say, could put it away... Half a pint of whiskey every day!

From sfraves-owner  Sun Oct 10 21:06:53 1993
From: jsl@netcom.com (John S. Lee)
Date: Sun, 10 Oct 93 21:07:11 -0700
Subject: Re: ORB screen saver
Status: 

>bbehlen@soda.berkeley.edu (Brian Behlendorf) writes:
>>It's a SEA, self-extracting-archives, which means you click on it and it
>>uncompresses, and then you run it using the PICS player module in After
>>Dark.  Make sure and tell your Mac that it is indeed a Mac file when you
>>download it, or else it won't recognize it and refuse to decompress itself
>>(I lurve macs!)
>
>The last part isn't accurate. In addition to being in the SEA format, it's
>also been run through binhqx, a utility created for the express purpose of
>overcoming the problem of transferring Mac files. Use text transfer, then
>run it through binhqx and expand it. I recommend the StuffIt Expander
>utility, which is available via FTP from sumex-aim.stanford.edu, among
>other places.
>
>C.
>
>--
>(chris.hilker) cspot@cats.ucsc.edu
>
>"If spiders were in control, we wouldn't need nuclear weapons."

Stuffit Expander does not have binhex decoding!  So forget about using it
to deocode anything other than stuffit files (Ihave been known to write a
few decoders every now and then ;).
Forget about Stuffit anything...use Compactor Pro....it's shareware and
available everywhere.  It also has binhex decoding built in.  In order to
use stuffit's decoder you have to have certain versions of the software. 
Many of their decoders are not available with the shareware version of
their program.
(I have nothing against stuffit, I do have something I like about
Compactor; it's shareware, and a very good straightforward product! 
Stuffit, gets a bit cluttered at times.  I use both!)

As for any other problem, use PICS Player After Dark module to view your
pics!  It should work fine!

I truly LOVE the MAC.  A fine piece of hardware/software.  Second ONLY to
the SGI in terms of price/performance/features :)


Good Luck,
John

> 
> Stuffit Expander does not have binhex decoding!  So forget about using it
> to deocode anything other than stuffit files (Ihave been known to write a
> few decoders every now and then ;).

Actually, Stuffit Expander does, and has for a while, decode binhex files.
In addition to binhex, it will expand Stuffit, Compact Pro, and AppleLink
compressed files.  I know 'cause I use it all the time.  Latest version
is 3.0.7 and widely available from your favourite sources.

Stuffit Expander will automatically decode binhex and uncompress files
in one drag and drop action, so it's the easiest to use.  It can also 
be configured to check a certain folder everynow and then and decompress
files as they show up.

- Steve

Subject: RE: ORB-AfterDark(tm) hee
Status: 

Thanks for everyones helpful comments

	Heres what I did
	zmodem download (de-gzipped on the fly)
	unbinhexed with binhex 4,0
	double click SEA to self extract
	placed in AfterDark (tm)  files folder
	loaded PICS Player
	selected ORB...screensaver
	the rest you know and voila it worked :).

I got to the place in AD files folder part it was the PICs player portion I didnt quite get at first and thanks again.

From sfraves-owner  Mon Oct 11 14:17:05 1993
From: jamiel@sybase.com (Healthier, More Manageable Hair)
Date: Mon, 11 Oct 1993 14:19:21 -0800
Subject: Re: Mosh pit?
Status: 

At  1:52 PM 10/11/93 -0700, John Draper wrote:
>>>   And if there is a MOSH PIT, I'm leaving :)
>
>>    Aw, cmon.  mosh pits are fun :^) :^)
>
>Whats a mosh pit,  and is there usually dancing at these "Orb"
>thangies??

Whoaboy- punk/hardcore has been dead for a LONG time here, hasn't it? :)

It is an area usually directly in front of the stage, with a crowd of
people kind of slam-dancing in a circle. Ususally not found anywhere but
hardcore/heavymetal shows and,occasionally, a highschool pep-rally.
(Sometimes, I think those are the same thing, though)


jamie

jamiel@sybase.com
"Static- It's all just static"- Bryna Bank



From sfraves-owner  Mon Oct 11 14:30:03 1993
From: pashdown@slack.sim.es.com (Pete Ashdown)
Date: Mon, 11 Oct 1993 15:30:15 -0600 (MDT)
Subject: Mosh pit?
Status: 

> Whats a mosh pit,

Testosterone laced movements of stress relief under close quartered
conditions.  Usually better suited for fast, grindy, banging music, or all of
the above.  Not conditions The Orb meets.

> and is there usually dancing at these "Orb" thangies??

More than you can believe.  Do not miss at all costs.

From sfraves-owner  Mon Oct 11 15:37:10 1993

>
>>If that is truly the state of the industrial art, then I say it's time to 
>>move on.
>
>Well, I'd say the post-industrial genre is moving on, particularly 
>ambient industrial.  While it doesn't get nearly the amount of attention 
>that ambient techno is getting, its a source of the some of the most 
>original music in recent years.  I think that Coil's most recent releases  
>(Stolen & Contaminated Songs and the How To Destroy Angels remixes) 
>particularly attest to the health of post-industrial music.

i have to agree.  in fact, i agree so much i'm going to post.  to the original

sender who wanted to hear some good ambient techno, i would say all of the
above (ie. orb, aphex twin, etc..), sure, but go out and buy How To Destroy
Angels if you want to here some INCREDIBLE ambient music.  

...better than any "ambient techno, not associated with the industrial scene,

as coil is".  sorry for that vague label.

-mARK. (Now Available Without A Prescription)



From sfraves-owner  Mon Oct 11 16:16:53 1993

From sfraves-owner  Mon Oct 11 16:58:47 1993
From: dms!curly!grigsby@netcom.com (JUMP IN THE FIRE)
Date: Mon, 11 Oct 93 16:35:35 PDT
Subject: Re: Mosh pit?
Status: 


> Whoaboy- punk/hardcore has been dead for a LONG time here, hasn't it? :)

Punk's been dead from the start.  That's why punkers always smell bad.

>^)

> It is an area usually directly in front of the stage, with a crowd of
> people kind of slam-dancing in a circle. Ususally not found anywhere but
> hardcore/heavymetal shows and,occasionally, a highschool pep-rally.
> (Sometimes, I think those are the same thing, though)

There are good pits and bad pits.  Most of the shows I've been to (punk
shows, mostly) have good pits, where people pick you up immediately if 
you fall down and aren't out to hurt you.  I've been moshing for over
five years of shows and have never had worse than a bruise or two.  Of
course, you've got to be a little bit careful to protect yourself: boots
and long pants are good, dangly earrings are right out.

It's a great way to get out your aggressions.  I'm not pure enough to 
not have any.

// g

------- Message 2

Date: Sat, 9 Oct 1993 12:15:25 -0700 (PDT)
From: Miles Egan <cullen@scripps.edu>
Subject: Re: Instantiating negative fleas
To: NM-LIST <nm-list@reef.cis.ufl.edu>
Date: Sat, 9 Oct 93 00:33:55 -0700
From: Mason Jones <mason@netcom.com>
To: nmlist@reef.cis.ufl.edu
Subject: Instantiating negative fleas

>From: ecurrent@sizone.pci.on.ca (Mr. Plow)
>
>s_buebl@main01.rz.uni-ulm.de writes:
>
>> I'm searching for prgressive, innovative, eperimentall techno.
>> can you name me a band? e.g. I discouvered "new mind" - they sound
>> interesting, but not shizoid enough. or "G.G.F.H." - not complex
>> enough (what a pitty).
>
>The Orb.  Orbital.  Aphex Twin.  Polygon Window.  Psychick Warriors of 
>Gaia.  Future Sound of London.  Amorphous Androgynous.  

>Innovative? Experimental? Well, I'll just be quiet here I guess.
>He did say techno, after all. ;-)

	I know you've a strong anti-techno bias, Mason, but I really have
to disagree.  The new Orbital album, for example is one of the best
thought out, creative, and truly communicative albums I've heard in a long
time.  Anytime I see someone slagging an entire genre of music, I tend to
assume that it's not done with a high degree of objectivity.  Sure there's
a lot of shitty techno coming out these days.  You may even get me to
admit that the ratio of good to bad is considerably lower than most other
genres.  Nevertheless, the groups mentioned above have put out some of the
most fascinating and satisfying electronic music I've ever heard.  
	I think many people tend to dismiss techno music and rave culture
as naive because they embrace positivity.  Industrial music's
obsession with dissonance and negativity is no more perceptive or
forward looking.  I think I've heard fewer more predictable, boring,
and from my point of view, insincere and uninspired comps than the
recent Dry Lungs V.  If that is truly the state of the industrial
art, then I say it's time to move on.  Dogmatic thinking of any kind becomes
tiresome in a big hurry.

------- Message 3
Date: Sun, 10 Oct 1993 03:59:46 -0700 (PDT)
From: Peter Werner <boe666@u.washington.edu>
Subject: Re: Instantiating negative fleas
To: NM-LIST <nm-list@reef.cis.ufl.edu>
In-Reply-To: <Pine.3.07.9310091223.A6379-b100000@terrapin>

Miles Egan (cullen@scripps.edu) writes:

>>The new Orbital album, for example is one of the best thought out,
>>creative, and truly communicative albums I've heard in a long time.

Is this the same band that's often unfavorably compared to The Orb?

>      I think many people tend to dismiss techno music and rave culture
>as naive because they embrace positivity.  Industrial music's
>obsession with dissonance and negativity is no more perceptive or
>forward looking.

Well, I find it hard not to find ravers incredibly naive and childish at 
times.  I suppose its just a subculture thing.  Industrial is a post-punk 
thing and rave is a sort of return to hippie values.  And as punks used 
to say, "Never trust a hippie."  (I'm being a bit flippant here, though I  
don't feel like inserting the requisite smily face.)  Seriously though, 
in a society which uses psychotherapy and "self-help" as tools of social 
control and brands any act of rebellion as "negative", of course I'm 
going to be damn suspicious of anybody telling me to be more "positive".  
That doesn't mean I necessarily embrace negativity for its own sake (a 
la Boyd Rice) either.

As for the embrace of dissonance, I think its accounted for some damn 
fine music over the years, not just from the industrial genre, but music 
as far back as Stravinsky (if not further).  I'd say a lot of the better 
techno makes use of dissonance as well.  The creative potential of 
dissonance has hardly been exhausted.

I think the rave scene tends to limit the creative potential of techno.  
For example, Sven Vath's Accident In Paradise is a great piece, but how 
widely embraced has it been by ravers?  Not much; "Can't dance to it, man." 

>I think I've heard fewer more predictable, boring, and from my point of 
>view, insincere and uninspired comps than the recent Dry Lungs V.

Aii! I'm staying well out of the way of this issue.
  
>If that is truly the state of the industrial art, then I say it's time to 
>move on.

Well, I'd say the post-industrial genre is moving on, particularly 
ambient industrial.  While it doesn't get nearly the amount of attention 
that ambient techno is getting, its a source of the some of the most 
original music in recent years.  I think that Coil's most recent releases  
(Stolen & Contaminated Songs and the How To Destroy Angels remixes) 
particularly attest to the health of post-industrial music.

Beast of Eden

------- Message 4

Date: Mon, 11 Oct 1993 14:15:39 -0700 (PDT)
From: Miles Egan <cullen@scripps.edu>
Subject: Re: Instantiating negative fleas
To: NM-LIST <nm-list@reef.cis.ufl.edu>
In-Reply-To: <Pine.3.85.9310100213.G8707-0100000@stein1.u.washington.edu>
Message-Id: <Pine.3.07.9310111437.B3417-d100000@pokey>

On Sun, 10 Oct 1993, Peter Werner wrote:

> 
> Miles Egan (cullen@scripps.edu) writes:
> 
> >>The new Orbital album, for example is one of the best thought out,
> >>creative, and truly communicative albums I've heard in a long time.
> 
> Is this the same band that's often unfavorably compared to The Orb?

	I haven't heard any such comparisons.  I think they're pretty
different.  Orbital's stuff is much more predictably rhythmic.  I have no
trouble picturing people dancing to them, whereas much of the Orb's music
is pretty amorphous.  I have to admit that I didn't really like Orbital's
first album much, although I'm very tempted to look into again after being
completely overwhelmed by their second.

> Well, I find it hard not to find ravers incredibly naive and childish at 
> times.  I suppose its just a subculture thing.  Industrial is a post-punk 
> thing and rave is a sort of return to hippie values.  And as punks used 
> to say, "Never trust a hippie."  (I'm being a bit flippant here, though I  
> don't feel like inserting the requisite smily face.)  Seriously though, 
> in a society which uses psychotherapy and "self-help" as tools of social 
> control and brands any act of rebellion as "negative", of course I'm 
> going to be damn suspicious of anybody telling me to be more "positive".  
> That doesn't mean I necessarily embrace negativity for its own sake (a 
> la Boyd Rice) either.

	I think it's an oversimplification to dismiss rave culture as a
neo-hippie movement.  They do have many values in common, but I think that
many of the ideals the hippies embraced were experimented with long before
the 1960s.  I think many people believe that the hippie movement failed
because its ideals were too naive.  I think the movement failed because
its ideals were trivialized and commercialized.  Unfortunately, this also
seems to be increasingly true of rave culture as well.  This seems to be
the trend in all underground movements.  
	The mainstream steals from and is strengthened by the innovations
of the avante garde.  A perfect example is cinema.  Mainstream movies are
much more technically sophisticated now, due in large part to assimilation
of techniques developed by experimental directors.  However, they are just
as inane and manipulative as they have always been.  
	I recognize that there are many subtle mechanisms of control
operating in our society.  Did you consider that one of the most effective
and insidious is to allow 'rebellious' behavior to be rigorously defined
and channeled.  Raves used to get busted by the police all the time.  When
was the last time you went to an industrial show that was raided?  I think
the fact that rave raids are becoming rarer all the time is a sign that
the movement has been diverted and diluted and that the powers that be
don't consider to be much of a threat anymore. 

> As for the embrace of dissonance, I think its accounted for some damn 
> fine music over the years, not just from the industrial genre, but music 
> as far back as Stravinsky (if not further).  I'd say a lot of the better 
> techno makes use of dissonance as well.  The creative potential of 
> dissonance has hardly been exhausted.

	I agree, but there are many artists who seem to believe that
dissonance can substitute for creativity or genuine emotion.

> Well, I'd say the post-industrial genre is moving on, particularly 
> ambient industrial.  While it doesn't get nearly the amount of attention 
> that ambient techno is getting, its a source of the some of the most 
> original music in recent years.  I think that Coil's most recent releases  
> (Stolen & Contaminated Songs and the How To Destroy Angels remixes) 
> particularly attest to the health of post-industrial music.

	I was quite impressed with _How to Destroy Angels_.  My first
impression of SCS wasn't as favorable, but I intend to give it several
more listenings.  It's funny that you use Coil as an example, because
they also serve as a good example of what's possible when techno is
approached creatively.  I have in no means given up on industrial music
as a genre.  It just has a less prominent place in my listening than it
once did.

------- Message 5

Date: Mon, 11 Oct 1993 14:39:21 -0700 (PDT)
From: Miles Egan <cullen@scripps.edu>
Subject: Re: Hey Mr Fellow Shine Keeper
To: NM-LIST <nm-list@reef.cis.ufl.edu>
In-Reply-To: <9310110534.AA13886@netcom3.netcom.com>

On Sun, 10 Oct 1993, Mason Jones wrote:
> >Sure there's
> >a lot of shitty techno coming out these days.  You may even get me to
> >admit that the ratio of good to bad is considerably lower than most other
> >genres.  Nevertheless, the groups mentioned above have put out some of the
> >most fascinating and satisfying electronic music I've ever heard.  
> 
> People keep saying that, and I keep trying it, and I keep hearing more
> of the same old same old. I borrowed a friend's Orb CDs, and listened
> to them, and heard nothing which hadn't been done in a similar and
> fresher way many years back by Zoviet France. I bought a Future Sound
> of London CD and found most of the tracks to be barely-differentiatable
> dance beats with minimal use of anything beyond rudimentary drum
> programming. I had friends tape me stuff by Aphex Twin and Polygon
> Window, and found it to be quite similar to analog recordings done
> in 1983 by people like Un-Film, Pacific 231, and If Bwana, merely
> laid down over a minimal trademark techno beat. I just haven't heard
> anything more than a few songs here and there which I found interesting,
> but I do keep trying. One of these days, maybe. I will freely admit
> that I haven't heard the new Orbital CD yet, and comments I've heard
> about the Gaia folk made me curious. I'll give them a shot at some
> point when someone makes me a tape or something, but I simply can't
> get my hopes up anymore, since so many people whose tastes I respect
> have proven to be unreliable for me when it comes to techno (nothing
> against them, I know it's all me).

	Perhaps it is more appropriate to talk about innovation and
experimentation within the confines of the genre.  Although there is a lot
of precedent for the compositional elements found in techno, I think the
most interesting artists have combined them in new ways.  Although I love
Zoviet France, I'm also quite fond of the Orb and I find that the two put
me in completely different states of mind.  It's not innovative structures
that draw me to the music as much as aesthetic enjoyment of it.  I think
what I find most satisfying about Zeni Geva (who totally blew me away last
night here in San Diego, by the way) and the Boredoms is that they present
both formal innovation :)  and a powerful, logical aesthetic.  The Orb and
the Orbital rely on less radical forms, but I don't think this compromises
the beauty or interest of their music.

> Absolutely true -- no argument here. I have nothing against positivity.
> I do have plenty against the empty, meaningless, vapid positivity that
> I see in most of the rave culture, but that's just the way things go
> when people start trading on the style, and not the substance, of
> something. The rave culture's been around here in SF for so long that
> it's become a parody of a parody of itself, or worse.

	I have to admit that I'm much more comfortable defending techno
music than the rave scene in general.  On the other hand, I also was very
dismissive of raves until I went to one in the proper state of mind :) and
had one the greatest evenings of my life.  It was an excellent opportunity
for me to re-examine some of the assumptions I had made about my ability
to move my body gracefully, interact with new people, and to be happy.  It
was very valuable to me and I think I would suggest that anyone ready to
write off raves without first trying a complete immersion should reconsider.

------- End of Forwarded Messages

From sfraves-owner  Mon Oct 11 20:49:55 1993
From: "Niels P. Mayer" <mayer@squick.eit.COM>
Date: Mon, 11 Oct 1993 20:49:15 -0700
Subject: SRL show in SF Bay Area
Status: 


Rumor has it that SRL is having a show in the SF Bay Area... I believe it
is on Nov 17 or 19, but can't exactly remember the date becuz my notes are
at home and I'm still at work. I heard that this is going to be at the
Phoenix Iron Works warehouse in Oakland, and that they will destroy the
building (??).

Not quite a site worth destroying, IMHO, but maybe all the squatters
decrepitated it, or maybe someone snagged some aluminum siding on his
facial piercings, and in the process of extrication, decided see whether
the siding would pull out before the facial piercing did. This act of "self
expression" causing enough structural damage to get the building condemned,
thereby paving the way for SRL's show. I believe the act also spawned a
whole genre of neo-avant-circus performance-art, the pinnacle of this
movement being the interlocked nosering tug-o-war.

So anyways, last time I was at Phoenix Iron Works was like 3-4 years ago to
see the BeatNigs and a bunch of other bands doing a "rock against racism"
shindig (which was bumrushed by a bunch of Nazi skins who subsequently got
the shit beaten out of them, much to my pleasure). But I digress, eh?

Anyways.... if that rumor is true, I'm wondering what this event will be
like.  Given that the turnout for SRL is massive, and Phoenix Iron Works is
not so large, I would imagine that most of the audience will be watching
this event from out on the street (in a totally scrungy part of Oakland's
warehouse district). Could be interesting, but I wonder how they're going
to get away with it.

From sfraves-owner  Tue Oct 12 12:28:20 1993
From: "Morris, Peter S." <psmorris@ucdavis.edu>
Date: Tue, 12 Oct 93 11:57:00 PDT
Subject: FW: levitate the s.f. stock exchange oct. 29
Status: 


This came in thru the lectronic vine, anyone heard anything about it????
Peter

================================

This item has been floating around our office a lot lately.  It's bound to 
be
 extremely well-attended, cause SF is a real Halloween kind of town.
 Yesterday, I read a posting that a whole crew of people were coming from
 Belgium just for this occasion, and bringing along a whole bunch of
 mondo-fresh acid!  It is a do-it-yourself kind of thing, I guess, because
 no one is oraganizing it (which is just fine with me).  Anyway, I picked up
 a flyer about it last week, the text of which follows:

___________________Begin ___________________________________________________

Happie Halloween!

A world-wide call out to all Wiccans, Radical Faeries, Chaoticians,
 Subversives, Pagans, Eco-warriors, Vampires, Undercover cops
 (natch), Drummers, Voodoo gurus, Queers, Ragga-muffins, Mojo
 mixers, Space aliens, Funk masters, Techno-trippers, Groove-cats,
 Zombies, Pranksters, Cyber-tribers, Anarchists Antichrists and
 Anaochronists, Poseurs, Wanna-be's, Almost-was's, and Has-been's

L  e  v  i  t  a  t  e
the S. F. Stock Exchange!!

A HUGE and VERY WEIRD CELEBRATION of the anniversary of
 the great stock market crash and the 13 + 13th anniverary of the
 levitating of the Pentagon. Help exorcise the Financial District of the
 demons that have plagued us all! Laugh while you levitate the stock
 exchange and dump it into the bay!  Jump for Joy as you banish the
 Bohemian Clubbers to the Hell from which they sprang, and (this is
 the REALLY weird part) golden toilet bowls sprout from
 the sidewalks.  Hoo-oooo, kids - it'll be so scaaarrrry!

don't miss: Night of the Living Dead Businessmen

Friday, October 29, 5:00 P. M.
        @
The S. F. Stock Exchange (Bush & Pine Sts.)

friend tell a friend tell a friend tell a friend tell a friend tell a friend

You:  Costumes  Haints  RYTHM  Food ART  Performance  Screwing Around Lunacy
 Magick  ART  Performance  Music  Dope  FUN  Color  Surpriiiiise!  Dancin'
 Elvis  BadNews  SEX  Ghastly  SPELLS  Liberacio'n  &Shit

The Corporate Monster doesn't stand a Ghost of a chance

info?  USENET alt.society.resistance

___________________________End______________________________________________  
__


Now THIS kind of early planning I can get behind!

I think we owe it to ourselves to spread the word on this kind of stuff. 
 Post
 this info all over the net and on every BBS in the world.  Cross post!
 Blanket post!  Post-modern post!

See you there!


S. Washburn

 --

Consider the lillies of the field, they toil not,
neither do they spin.  Worry not for tommorrow,
the worries of today are enough.  If a man asks
you to walk a mile with him, go with him two. Turn the other cheek.

From sfraves-owner  Tue Oct 12 13:27:13 1993

At  1:17 PM 10/12/93 -0700, Bob Carasik wrote:
>Yay! Tell me more.  I've already heard of this via Cacophony Society,
>but perhaps there's more to it.  Would you mind posting more details
>to the list?  Thanks.

>AstroBoy


Well, it is all pretty straightforward. The flyers, the posters, the
net.propaganda all basically says all there is to say about it- I know the
guy organizing it and he is expecting 5-digit crowds- there are quite a few
travelling out here for it, from what I hear. The Cramps are supposed to be
there for a short performance, along with some other acts pending (of
course there is no permit, so the crowds will have to stay thick to help
hold the police away, but that shouldn't be a problem), and some people who
didn't want to be announced. Anyway, it all culminates in -you guessed it-
the Stock Exchange levitation, wherein it gets dumped in the Bay. The
organization of it is all very not there- if you want to do something show
up and do it!


jamie

jamiel@sybase.com

From sfraves-owner  Tue Oct 12 14:18:09 1993
From: Laura La Gassa <laura@soda.berkeley.edu>
Date: Tue, 12 Oct 93 14:18:02 -0700
Subject: Re:  This Sat
Status: 

JD asks about Liquid Air:

>Hmmm!!  How long will it last??   Will it go on into the morning at least 
>till 8 am?    If so,  then I will definately try and attend it.

Well, you know how it is with with free outdoor renegades:  they generally go 
until either it becomes a good idea to leave (i.e. the sun comes up and 
non-ravers start appearing on their morning jogs and get annoyed that we're 
around) or until we decide to leave (i.e. all the DJs have played and people 
are getting cold and tired and the attendance starts dwindling) or until we 
HAVE to leave (i.e. the cops show up).  Being willing to party under these 
conditions is part of what makes a renegade a renegade.  If you want iron-clad 
guarantees then go to a club.

We DO promise new DJs deadicated to having fun and bringing you the music they 
love, a BEAUTIFUL sound system, and nice organized caring people hosting the 
event.  And since it's a free/donations event, you get to decide what it
was worth to you, and pay accordingly, instead of having to put money up in
advance and then feel ripped off if you didn't have a good time.

Laura

hello all``


I've been lurking around on this mailing list for a couple-o weeks and
thought I take a shot at the 'rave' world.

that likes to dance till dawn-excuse memorning and prefer shock
treatment to bring me back into reality..  enuf...

to be on the sfrave scene, discussions of smart drinks, fun, games,

From sfraves-owner  Tue Oct 12 18:00:12 1993
From: Arthur Chandler <arthurc@sfsuvax1.sfsu.edu>
Date: Tue, 12 Oct 1993 17:54:44 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: Re: hello sfraves from SunShine
Status: 



On Tue, 12 Oct 1993, Lavonne Walton wrote:

> Anwyay is this list dying out??? I thought the focus was going
> to be on the sfrave scene, discussions of smart drinks, fun, games,
> costs, which ones to go/avoid and good/bad stories.( I can be blind sometimes..)
> 
> so whats up????
> 
> lvn

  Sunshine:

  The rhythms of this list are a lot like raves: Sometimes a groove-thread
comes through that sets the email going at 180 BPM. Other times, folks are
mulling over other things in their lives, and only read/lurk. A good rave
(like the GG Park event) draws lots of stories. Others, nothing.
Sometimes there's philosophy, sometimes record reviews, sometimes just
general weirdness. But don't go away! Just stay with us! If you get lonely,
zoom over than download the sfraves FAQ -- good for serious reading.
  "To rave is to affirm."

From sfraves-owner  Tue Oct 12 19:43:52 1993
From: brycer@netcom.com (Bryce Ryan)
Date: Tue, 12 Oct 93 19:44:23 PDT
Subject: re:Whats best rave this Sat night?
Status: 

Well, I do have a vested interest in one particular rave.
But, I want to say that they're *all* gonna be good, if you're in
the right mood for that particular experience.  We have Revival
with the Wicked posse, It's a Small World with the ever wonderful
Carlos n Dutch, the startup of Diverse City with Jon Williams and
La Paix.  As well as the awesome Rhythm at 1015 with Jan Cooley
and Markie.  All should be great, up to their usual high standards,
and showcasing some of the best well-known talent the Bay Area has
to offer.

I think it's important to mention that I have lots of involvement
with the Fluid Groove posse.  We are a loose association of 
volunteers who believe in bringing together the best talent and
thinking the Bay Area has to offer (as well as the best talent
available throughout the country!).  We are dedicated ravers
who've been around the scene and have seen how it's done. So, I
speak with some pride in our accomplishments. But, you should
know that I speak with some prejudice.

The *only* renegade that night will be Liquid Air.  Brought
to you by the Fluid Groove posse.  We care about ourselves enough to
bring quality sound (nrg's Sound Vision sound system--truly the 
best system *i've* ever heard at a renegade), quality DJs (Tamara, 
Lee, Laura, Chris and Jon D. [God's personal DJ, BTW]), and a quality 
location.  

Bring that together with a quality price (free, but we'll ask you for 
a donation to help cover our expenses) and a truly outstanding group of 
people, stir, and you have the essence of rave. Truly the basics of rave.
No high prices, no problem with ins and outs, no problem with
ID checks at the door (what door?), engaging conversation where you
can hear your partner(s) if you want, pumping music, driving bass bins,
beautiful scenery, free water, fresh air.   Is there something I
missed? Oh, yes, while providing you the safety and space to be your
true self, without judgement, in celebration. And, plenty of space to
dance in.

Anyway, I extend a personal invitation to you and yours to come experience
a universe of sound surrounding you like Liquid Air. I can't guarantee
you'll have a good time; only you can help us there. We hope you'll come
share our favorite music in an atmosphere of peace and joy.
-- 
Bryce Ryan ---------- AMBIANCE ------- brycer@netcom.com------
Sound surrounds you like Liquid Air --- Next Party 10/16 -----
415-487-8497 -- Audio by Sound Vision -- Flyer by Dave Scruton

all :)

From sfraves-owner  Tue Oct 12 20:57:53 1993
From: bbehlen@soda.berkeley.edu (Brian Behlendorf)
Date: Tue, 12 Oct 1993 20:57:34 -0700
Subject: Re: Source for DJ equipment needed
Status: 

Uncle Ralph's in Berkeley has 1200's for $399 each; they *might* be grey
market but U.R. is a totally reputable electronics store so they'll fully
warrantee everything (not like you NEED a warranty on 1200's, but still).

They also have pretty good prices on Numark and (if you're not a musical
snob, they have always worked fine for me)  Gemini mixers.

You couldn't find any listing for Pro Sound Audio?  I do remember it
being in Garden Grove, CA if that helps...

	Brian

From sfraves-owner  Wed Oct 13 00:52:03 1993
From: andy@kingkong.wco.ftp.com  (Andy Nourse)
Date: Wed, 13 Oct 93 00:51:18 PDT
Subject: Re: fwd from nm-list re raves vs. industrial (etc).
Status: 


>   Dogmatic thinking of any kind becomes tiresome in a big hurry.

    Always preferred catma to dogma, myself... :^)

>   I find it hard not to find ravers incredibly naive and childish at times.

    I don't think we are really all that naive about the state of
    things, we may prefer not to rub our noses in it all the time.        

>   I suppose its just a subculture thing.  Industrial is a post-punk 
>   thing and rave is a sort of return to hippie values.

    What are "post-punk" values?

>   And as punks used to say, "Never trust a hippie."

    Before that (a lot before) it was "Never trust a Prankster",
    which was said by the Merry Pranksters, of themselves. :^)

>   in a society which uses psychotherapy and "self-help" as tools of social 
>   control and brands any act of rebellion as "negative", of course I'm 
>   going to be damn suspicious of anybody telling me to be more "positive".  

    I wouldn't dream of telling you that.  But for me, being negative
    all the time got really depressing, and wallowing in negativity was
    disempowering and generally got in the way.  I would justify it
    on the grounds that that obviously was they way things were, and
    that I was just being realistic about it all.  The problem was
    that it made it very difficult to visualize how it might look if
    it were better, which is a precondition to making it *be* better.

>   I think the rave scene tends to limit the creative potential of techno.  

    I think perceptions of the rave scene might be limiting.
    F'rinstance, most DJs are afraid that people can't dance to something
    in 7/4 time, so they won't play it.

>   For example, Sven Vath's Accident In Paradise is a great piece, but how 
>   widely embraced has it been by ravers?  Not much;
>   "Can't dance to it, man." 

    As someone who will attempt to dance to just about anything,
    I think I'd take that as a challenge.

X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.3 PL11]

Circa 93 - Media Release
 
om laboratories presents
Circa 93: Central Processing Unit                  Ticket Information:
A Showcase of Art, Music, and Technology           +1 213 683 3549
Directed and Produced by Tef & Richard Duardo      +1 714 502 2225
on November 13, 1993                               Advance purchase $20 
at 500 E. Commercial Street                        at Ticketmaster
one block east of Alameda in downtown L.A.         $25 at door
a benefit for L.A.'s best                          Concession info 
                                                   +1 213 687 0775
 
 
Om Laboratories, on November thirteenth, will be producing its second annual
CIRCA event. Circa 93 is a digital showcase, merging art, music, and
technology. We will be presenting a live performance show, featuring MOBY,
ORBITAL, and APHEX TWIN. The rising digital shamen from Chicago, Los Angeles,
New York, and San Francisco will pulse the booming bass, commanding every
foot to groove. High sensory stimulation, in the form of real-time computer
generated graphics and animations by AREA 17 using an assortment of platforms
including 3DO, CD-i, Macintosh, and PC. We will also be featuring a live
connection to the Internet Virtual Rave through which attendees can interact
with Internet users worldwide.
 
The concept is based upon using the newest technological advances, in a
direct applicatioon for enhancing the entertainment experience. This
interactive digital showcase is a platform for artists creating in new media.
Also the cutting edge animations created by CARL SIMS on his latest
artificial life software (published in Art Futura's last issue) will be
featured, as well as visuals from the "MEMORY PLACE" showcase.
 
For your information, the promotional schedule for this event includes
200,000 full color posters, 40,000 teaser flyers, as well as 40,000 inserts
in both the L.A. Weekly and Urb Magazine. The promotional team stretches
across the entire West Coast. This production is all about bringing everyone
together, both to reflect on 1993 and to experience the future.
 
For more information or for PGP public key, finger or email circa@netcom.com.
--

Or if you have internet access, check out vrave.

telnet sfraves.stanford.edu 7283

(the way to remember 7283 is to spell RAVE on a telephone keypad)


	Cosmic Roy

From sfraves-owner  Wed Oct 13 07:41:54 1993
From: Laura La Gassa <laura@soda.berkeley.edu>
Date: Wed, 13 Oct 93 07:41:32 -0700
Subject: Re: fwd from nm-list re raves vs. industrial (etc).
Status: 

Someone from some industrial list or something said:

>   For example, Sven Vath's Accident In Paradise is a great piece, but how 
>   widely embraced has it been by ravers?  Not much;
>   "Can't dance to it, man." 

Well, I don't know where this person has been, but "Accident in Paradise"
was really HUGE in the New York/New England area about a year ago.  You'd
hear it at every party, rave, or techno club night, and the crowd always
went crazy.  It was as big as Hardfloor's "Acsperience" was (before 
"Acsperience" came out).  How can you not dance to a 4/4 time track with
an absolutely killer bass line?  Sven Vath couldn't have made it easier
if he tried.  I played it at Your Sister's House and people had no trouble 
dancing to it.

I wonder if the person who said this is confusing the sort of young, trendy, 
club-kid type of raver (we have a lot of them out East) with what a lot
of us consider "ravers" to be:  thoughtful people who prefer to make a 
space for and take a stand for positivity while rejecting pollyannaism,
people who are open-minded about exploring many forms of dance music, and
people who just LOVE to have fun.

Laura

From sfraves-owner  Wed Oct 13 09:52:46 1993
From: laura@soda.berkeley.edu (Laura La Gassa)
Date: Wed, 13 Oct 1993 09:52:40 -0700
Subject: finding renegade parties
Status: 

JD (crunch) asks (and possibly a few other pepole are wondering, so I'm 
posting to the list):

>>>Saturday, October 16th - Liquid Air
>>>        DJs Tamara, Laura, Jon D., Cris
>>>        Audio by Sound Vision
>>>        info: 415.487.8497

>then coming back to Liquid Air.   Where's it gonna be?   

Tips on finding renegade parties:

 * Renegade locations are not given out in advance for security reasons.

 * Call the information line a day or so before the party to find out when and 
	where the actual directions will be given.  In the case of Liquid
	Air, you can call the info line after 10pm on the night of the party to 
	find out exactly where the party is located.
	
 * When you call, have paper and pen ready to take down directions.  Call back 
	a second time or record it on your answering machine so as to check 
	what you took down. 
	
 * Obtain a street map for the areas you usually go to renegades in (there
	are some wonderful ones available in local bookstores), and  check 
	the party location directions against the map before you depart.

 * Bring the info line phone number with you when you go out in case you get 
	to the actual party location and don't see the party (like, maybe it 
	got busted and so had to move and hopefully the new location will be 
	on the info line), or in case you lose the directions.

 * Even if you are not the driver, call and get the directions anyway in
	case the driver loses them, or in case you end up being much more
	familiar with the area described than the driver.

I have followed these steps ever since I started raving over a year ago and I 
have never gotten so lost that I missed a party.

Laura

From sfraves-owner  Wed Oct 13 12:39:11 1993
From: andy@kingkong.wco.ftp.com  (Andy Nourse)
Date: Wed, 13 Oct 93 12:38:26 PDT
Subject: Re: fwd from nm-list re raves vs. industrial (etc).
Status: 


>   Dogmatic thinking of any kind becomes tiresome in a big hurry.

    Always preferred catma to dogma, myself... :^)

>   I find it hard not to find ravers incredibly naive and childish at times.

    I don't think we are really all that naive about the state of
    things, we may prefer not to rub our noses in it all the time.        

>   I suppose its just a subculture thing.  Industrial is a post-punk 
>   thing and rave is a sort of return to hippie values.

    What are "post-punk" values?

>   And as punks used to say, "Never trust a hippie."

    Before that (a lot before) it was "Never trust a Prankster",
    which was said by the Merry Pranksters, of themselves. :^)

>   in a society which uses psychotherapy and "self-help" as tools of social 
>   control and brands any act of rebellion as "negative", of course I'm 
>   going to be damn suspicious of anybody telling me to be more "positive".  

    I wouldn't dream of telling you that.  But for me, being negative
    all the time got really depressing, and wallowing in negativity was
    disempowering and generally got in the way.  I would justify it
    on the grounds that that obviously was they way things were, and
    that I was just being realistic about it all.  The problem was
    that it made it very difficult to visualize how it might look if
    it were better, which is a precondition to making it *be* better.

>   I think the rave scene tends to limit the creative potential of techno.  

    I think perceptions of the rave scene might be limiting.
    F'rinstance, most DJs are afraid that people can't dance to something
    in 7/4 time, so they won't play it.

>   For example, Sven Vath's Accident In Paradise is a great piece, but how 
>   widely embraced has it been by ravers?  Not much;
>   "Can't dance to it, man." 

    As someone who will attempt to dance to just about anything,
    I think I'd take that as a challenge.



------- End of Forwarded Message

From sfraves-owner  Wed Oct 13 18:55:12 1993
From: csc@pilot.njin.net (Sean Casey)
Date: Wed, 13 Oct 93 21:55:04 EDT
Subject: Re: finding renegade parties 
Status: 

Even with my handy-dandy recording answering machine, I've often had
to listen to a message 2 or 3 times to get it down. Much worse if
someone is at a payphone next to a noisy street. Or if the listener
isn't familiar with the streets involved. I once wasted 30 minutes
because a slurred street name took me 8 miles out of my way (in the
San Jose area) to the wrong street.

Although he's probably not, assume your listener is on LSD. Speak
S-L-O-W-L-Y and C-L-E-A-R-L-Y. Have a guinea pig listen to your
message and evaluate its intelligibility.

Like Laura, I've always gotten there, even before I knew one street in
town. Yet I have been sorely frustrated before. That's what good
directions do: give you that warm fuzzy feeling. And I'm all for warm
fuzzies.

Sean

Status: 


Please forgive me for this completely out of context post... but can
someone remind me what the uv catastrophe is....  it's been anoying me
all week...

i recall it's something to do with some approximation that works for
the low-energy part of a spectrum, but fails to converge when you
integrate to infinity... (ie is wrong)... what was the approximation,
and what was it for...?  black body radiation...?

thanks,

	Cosmic

From sfraves-owner  Thu Oct 14 05:59:14 1993
From: bbehlen@soda.berkeley.edu (Brian Behlendorf)
Date: Thu, 14 Oct 1993 05:58:15 -0700
Subject: Re: The Ultraviolet Catastrophe
Status: 

On Oct 14,  1:18pm, you proclaimed:
} Please forgive me for this completely out of context post... but can
} someone remind me what the uv catastrophe is....  it's been anoying me
} all week...
} 
} i recall it's something to do with some approximation that works for
} the low-energy part of a spectrum, but fails to converge when you
} integrate to infinity... (ie is wrong)... what was the approximation,
} and what was it for...?  black body radiation...?

:):)  Roy, you know too much for your own good.

(I could have sworn this was posted to SFRaves before, but I couldn't 
find it in the archives...)

I *think* it had to do with early quantum physics - they were looking
for an equation which would relate energy absorption and radiation 
with visible light.  They took down measurements and plotted graphs
and came up with one equation that appeared to work; however, the
closer it got to a certain bandwidth in the ultraviolet region the
higher energy states were created, and extrapolating they found that
one region went to infinite energy.  Thus, it was called the 
"Ultraviolet Catastrophe", cause it meant a breakdown in normal
Newtonian and classical physics and was one of the first steps towards
quantum physics.  Ovid could probably describe this much better than
I just did, as I think he was the one who came up with it in the first
place.  

	Brian

So's I go to MOTION...didn't want to saty too long since I have to go to
work EARLY the next morning. Ended up closing the place with everyone else
who shouldn'ta been out dat late.

AMAZING!  First Lauren starts out with a really depp funky fucked up set. 
That shit was so phat my head began to spin!  Wicked set! Since he was the
opener not too many people were there, but by the time he closed, people
began to come to the dance floor.  Then came the hatted one, Rick Preston.
He got the place moving.  He played some familiar stuff, but he kept it
fresh by dropping plenty of fresh material.  Nad the crowd really
aprreciated it.  It was a nice crowd too.  SJ is definitely in the house
(but they always knew that!).  So Rick spins a good 2 hour set, and
everyone is asking, uh, "where's Markie?".  At about 12:30 Markie shows up.
 And to make matters even worse he tries to make up for being a little late
;).  Needles to say he brought his wrecking ball with him to finish the
demolition job Lauren & Rick started.  He brought the place down!  All of
the DJ's played excellent sets, and shit was right on.  Sound system
straigntened itself out (it did not do Lauren justice), and the night went
off well.

So now I'm late to work.  Lotsa planning to do for some upcoming events. 
Got to finish my program, got a small hangover, my week is ending up
OK....man I shouldn'ta satyed out so long...but I'm happy I did.  Or is
that Aidide?

Got a chance to talk to the famed Bob R., Larry C. was there as well
grooving to the thickness.

Hi Bob!
Hi Larry!

Well, hope to see others later this week :)

Motion was phat!

Later,
John

From sfraves-owner  Thu Oct 14 10:17:38 1993
From: Roy Badami <roy@harlequin.co.uk>
Date: Thu, 14 Oct 93 18:18:36 BST
Subject: Re: Ultraviolet Catastrophe
Status: 



  Gioni> 	To bad I just sold back my Modern Physics book :) But
  Gioni> does this go along with Black Body Radiation and such
  Gioni> theories?

Er black body radiation isn't a theory as such... more a phenomenon.
The uv catastrophe is kind of historical in the development of
physics....  the catastrophe was that the theory of the day seemed to
work well enough for for predicting the amount of heat and light
radiated, but things started to go wrong when you got to the
unltraviolet... and the real catastrphe is that it predicted that a
body would radiate an infinte amount of energy in total!

What i can't remember is... what was the theory of the day... and what
is the correct answer.... 'fraid i've pretty much forgotten all my
physics...

	Cosmic


From sfraves-owner  Thu Oct 14 10:55:12 1993

Subject: Re: The Ultraviolet Catastrophe
Status: 


> I *think* it had to do with early quantum physics - they were looking
> for an equation which would relate energy absorption and radiation 
> with visible light.  They took down measurements and plotted graphs
> and came up with one equation that appeared to work; however, the
> closer it got to a certain bandwidth in the ultraviolet region the
> higher energy states were created, and extrapolating they found that
> one region went to infinite energy.  Thus, it was called the 
> "Ultraviolet Catastrophe", cause it meant a breakdown in normal
> Newtonian and classical physics and was one of the first steps towards
> quantum physics.
That's the basic idea.

> Ovid could probably describe this much better than
> I just did, as I think he was the one who came up with it in the first
> place.  
No, the name was used in 1987 by one of my college roommates, who used the name
as the title for his radio show.  He got the name out of his physics book.  We
stole the name from him.


From sfraves-owner  Thu Oct 14 10:59:30 1993

To take it a step further...

Since theoretically it takes an infinite amount of energy to accellerate a body
to light speed, maybe the UV catastrophe is our ticket to light speed travel. Now
if we can just come up with a way synthesize this UVC in something small enough
to fit in a space ship and then to somehow harness this energy and redirect it to
do our bidding.

Should be simple enough, we get the Brits and Americans to work out the theories,
we get the Germans to solve the engineering problems and we get the Japs to
develope it into a product.

Then we allow the Russians to steal the plans, make one first, and try it out.

Look out Star Trek, sfravers will be the first ones to Cygnus, wow talk about
getting spaced man.....

John T.

From sfraves-owner  Thu Oct 14 13:01:50 1993
From: JACOB%SLACVM.BITNET@Forsythe.Stanford.EDU
Date: Thu, 14 Oct 1993   13:00 -0800 (PST)
Subject: Re: The Ultraviolet Catastrophe
Status: 

In-Reply-To: bbehlen@soda.berkeley.edu -- 10/14/93 06:09

hi folx!
well, the way it worked is something like this: at the end of the 19th
century, physicists were studying the emission spectrum from black bodies ,
bodies emitting radiation at all wavelengths. the classical picture
of atoms predicted that the intensity of this radiation was propostional
to the wave length to the inverse fourth power. thus at ultraviolet
wavelengths ( i.e. small, smaller than 400 nm) the intensity would go to infty!
well, the data clearly did not support this. also, the total emitted energy
was the integrated intensity over the full wavelength sectrum. the classical
form gave an infinite total energy, also wrong. the problem seem to come
from a rather innocous assumption: em energy is emitted and absorbed
continuously. max planck was able to solve this problem by assuming that em
radiation is emitted and absorbed in small packets, quanta. this  changed
the intensity spectrum so that it did not blow-up anymore at uv wavelengths.
it also gave a finite total energy, as it should have. this was the birth
of quantum mechanics.
 take care/shalom/back from croatan
ovid

I have one recommendation this weekend - "Your Sisters' Liquid Orb 
Air Boogie Buffet House" - this weekend should be one long party!  :)   

Catch SFR DJs Laura and Tamara's triumphant return to the Bay Area,
Laura tonight at Your Sisters' House and both (as well as our other 
great DJs) at Liquid Air on Saturday night.  Friday night's Orb 
performance promises to be a aural and visual extravaganza.

If that's not enough for you, the New Moon party tonight has potential
as an after-party for YSH, and Saturday night has plenty of choices
(if you just can't stay in one place :)...so no sleeping till Sunday
afternoon!

From sfraves-owner  Thu Oct 14 16:07:53 1993
From: "Susan R. Kameny" <susie@sutro.SFSU.EDU>
Date: Thu, 14 Oct 1993 15:38:38 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: dat ing the orb
Status: 

is anyone bootlegging the orb??? 

now for susie's quick guide into sneaking in a dat into the warfield.. 

have you ever wondered how to bypass all those cute little yellow jacketed
bgp people???  ------------------ MATERIALS NEEDED----------------------

1. (perferably) a dat                                                   
2. a purse/bag that will hold it (to be used in step 2)
3. masking tape
4. a charismatic smile
5. a part of your body you wish to be exagerated
6. some "phat" (ie large fluffy clothing) 
step 1 attaching it to your body
 
find a suitable and unobtrusive part of your body to enhance...(your inner
thighs, breasts, whatever) and tape your dat in it...(i have found that
women wearing long skirts and taping the dat to ones inner thigh does the
trick best because bgp is scared of lawsuits of molestation) normally bgp
people touch just your sides, but lately (at other concert venues) they
have gotten a bit more adventurous...
 
once inside (if you are not successfull beg for your equiptment back by
telling them you had just come from work and "forgot" to put your
"walkman" in your car... 
  
go to the bathroom and put the dat in the purse and the mic (preferably
small but high quality) hanging unobtrusivly out side of the purse (also
get away from the chatty neighbors, the sing alongers, and the screamers)
(another helpful hint...try and position yourself in a good place to get
the best quality recording)
 
and if anyone per chance does get a nice (or not nice) recording of the
orb...i would be so ever grateful for a copy...partyon...susie (:

From sfraves-owner  Thu Oct 14 17:58:59 1993
From: red@net.bio.net (Ben Wing)
Date: Thu, 14 Oct 93 17:56:22 -0700
Subject: that's "Tu Lan"
Status: 

In article <9310142350.AA13916@netcom.netcom.com> you write:
|	I'm up for going to Lu Tan's tomorrow night. Could someone
|post where it was again? I think that 7:00 would be a good time, so as
|of now I'm planning on being there then.
|	Mail me if you're planning on going... it might be wise to
|call in advance with a warning. (reservation/etc.)
|	(A phone number, if you know it, would be nice.)

"Lu Tan's" ...  Hee hee hee ... :)  Tu Lan is located at 8 6th St.,
which is at the intersection of Market and 6th.  If you're approaching
from Market (a VERY good thing to do, since that particular stretch
of 6th St. is one of the absolute worst areas of town) it's on the
right at the very beginning of 6th.

This is definitely not a reservation-type place.  Just walk right in,
and if there are too many people they can always move us upstairs.

7:00 might be a bit early?

ben

was that they aren't happening this week.  However, they recommended the New
Moon Party, which they said is taking place on beach near Pacifica. Not quite
enough detail to assuage my uncertainty about being able to find this thing.
So, if anyone could divulge some geographic data (and temporal), I'd appreciate
it.

From sfraves-owner  Fri Oct 15 09:37:50 1993
From: crunch@netcom.com (John Draper)
Date: Fri, 15 Oct 93 09:38:11 -0700
Subject: YSH cancelled - New Moon party happened partially
Status: 

  As you all might have guessed,  YSH was cancelled but the info line
referred all callers to Pacifica.   So I headed over there for the 
New Moon party,  and got in at least 1 1/2 hours of dancing before
the Kokomo club closed.   Naturally,  the rain cancelled the beach
part of it.

  Please consider this as rumour...   But it looks like the Kokomo
club managers has invited the New Moon people back to appear every
thursday to dance,  and they would be allowing 18+ folks to
attend at least until 3:30 am.    The venue is pretty nice,  although
rather small,   but the beach is directly behind the club.  Now here is
the really good news.   Because it's in Pacifica,  the Kokomo club
will be offering 3 shuttles to move people there from the SF area,
but don't know if they plan on shuttling people back again.

  When talking to Erik,  the dude who organizes the New Moon party,
I told him to contact me if this is firm so I can get it out to
SFR group.    Lets keep our fingers crossed,  and hope the Sisters
find a place soon.   I miss the YSH gatherings,  as these are the
only places I can contact all my homeless friends.

Cheers
CC

From sfraves-owner  Fri Oct 15 11:07:55 1993
From: Bob Ramstad <rramstad@us.oracle.com>
Date: Fri, 15 Oct 93 11:07:20 PDT
Subject: Orb When? (was: that's "Tu Lan")
Status: 


ahem.  as a veteran of many many many Warfield shows, the 2 drink
minimum is generally enforced only at the tables in the lower level,
and that's only if your entire group is not ordering stuff (as long as
some of you are occasionally ordering drinks, you won't have a
problem).  they don't have nearly enough waitresses to go around and
hassle everyone.  also, normally during set break / between bands is
primetime for the waitresses, and there won't be any.  (if you do buy
something, please tip well, I have friends eking out a living there,
thanks.)

it'll be interesting to hear how the venue works out.  if enough
people take drugs and hang out in the balcony to avoid the
(inevitably) overcrowded floor, it could work out quite nicely.  my
guess is also that the curiosity seekers will be overwhelmed by all
the freaks :-)

(fyi, I won't be there, staying home and saving $20, I've got traffic
school tomorrow at 8 am for a ticket I got coming back from YSH a few
months ago...)

yow, and enjoy yourselves,
Bob

From sfraves-owner  Fri Oct 15 14:58:26 1993
From: gregg@fly2.berkeley.edu (Gregg Helt)
Date: Fri, 15 Oct 93 14:56:41 PDT
Subject: Warfield security policy
Status: 


	Anybody know what the Warfield policy is towards backpacks, 
water bottles, etc?
						gregg


From sfraves-owner  Fri Oct 15 15:10:02 1993
From: Bob Ramstad <rramstad@us.oracle.com>
Date: Fri, 15 Oct 93 15:09:53 PDT
Subject: Warfield security policy
Status: 


Not sure what other people will say, but the Warfield policy has been
generally mellow but sometimes wildly inconsistent in regards to food
and beverages / water.  I've seen guards allow people to bring in
cookies / fruit / sandwiches / water and I've seen guards not allow
sealed bottles of water in (but rarely).

A reasonable sized pack with clothes / books / random stuff should be
no problem.  They sell food and drinks and therefore sometimes enforce
no food / drinks.  Definitely no glass or cans.

also no cameras, or DAT recorders, or videocameras :-)

(I think they still have their 'no lasers' sign, too)

Bob

From sfraves-owner  Fri Oct 15 17:42:34 1993
From: Peter Werner <boe666@u.washington.edu>
Date: Fri, 15 Oct 1993 17:39:44 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: Rave Doubts
Status: 


Roy Badami (roy@harlequin.co.uk) writes:

>>   For example, Sven Vath's Accident In Paradise is a great piece, but how
>>   widely embraced has it been by ravers?  Not much;
>>   "Can't dance to it, man."
>
>  Laura> Well, I don't know where this person has been, but "Accident
>  Laura> in Paradise" was really HUGE in the New York/New England area
>  Laura> about a year ago.  You'd hear it at every party, rave, or
>  Laura> in Paradise" was really HUGE in the New York/New England area
>  Laura> about a year ago.  You'd hear it at every party, rave, or
>  Laura> techno club night, and the crowd always went crazy.  It was
>  Laura> as big as Hardfloor's "Acsperience" was (before "Acsperience"
>  Laura> came out).  How can you not dance to a 4/4 time track with an
>  Laura> absolutely killer bass line?
>
>
>Hmm... I wonder if he was talking about the album (as a whole).  Most
>of the album is rather too ambient to spin anywhere except the
>chillout room, (unless perhaps you mix something on top of it).

I definitely was talking about the ambient tracks.  What I've heard at 
our local (Seattle) ambient noise club (Seven Beats Per Minute) was 
outstanding. Do any ravers listen to this stuff?  If not, I'll stand by 
my point about the rave scene holding back the creative potential of 
techno music.

Laura La Gassa (laura@soda.berkeley.edu) also says:

>(ravers are) people who are open-minded about exploring many forms of 
>dance music

But are they open to *non*-dance music?  Music is more than just 
something to dance to; good music stands on its own whether you can dance 
to it or not.  This "tyranny of the beat" is exactly what I'm pointing out 
when I say the rave scene holds back creative potential.

Andy Nourse (andy@kingkong.wco.ftp.com) writes:

>>   I suppose its just a subculture thing.  Industrial is a post-punk
>>   thing and rave is a sort of return to hippie values.
>
>    What are "post-punk" values? 

Did I say anything about post-punk values?  What I mean is that punk had
a healthy cynicism toward the most cherished hippie illusions (peace, 
love, harmony, ad nauseum).  That scepticism has been carried into 
post-punk genres such as industrial.  Now the rave scene has resurrected 
the old hippie rhetoric, engendering "attitude" (whatever the hell that 
means) on the part of those of us who are too jaded for all that.  

(BTW, did you read the part of my post where I said I was being somewhat 
flippant about the whole "never trust a hippie" thing.)

>>   in a society which uses psychotherapy and "self-help" as tools of social
>>   control and brands any act of rebellion as "negative", of course I'm
>>   going to be damn suspicious of anybody telling me to be more "positive".
>
>    I wouldn't dream of telling you that.  But for me, being negative
>    all the time got really depressing, and wallowing in negativity was
>    disempowering and generally got in the way.  

Did you read my whole statement or was it just not posted?  My next 
sentence was:

>>That doesn't mean I necessarily embrace negativity for its own sake (a
>>la Boyd Rice) either.

>    I would justify it on the grounds that that obviously was they way 
>    things were, and that I was just being realistic about it all.  The 
>    problem was that it made it very difficult to visualize how it might 
>    look if it were better, which is a precondition to making it *be* 
>    better.

A problem with idealism is that it sets you up for disappointment when, 
as happens quite often, things don't go as well as expected.  A worse 
problem is that idealism often leads to its nasty flipside, fanaticism.  
Study the history of any revolution, ideology, or religion and you'll 
see this "Jacobin" dynamic.

Beast of Eden

(Cc replies to nm-list@reef.cis.ufl.edu)




From sfraves-owner  Fri Oct 15 17:57:26 1993
From: Jon Drukman <jdrukman@us.oracle.com>
Date: Fri, 15 Oct 93 17:55:31 PDT
Subject: Rave Doubts
Status: 

Peter Werner writes:

>I definitely was talking about the ambient tracks.  What I've heard at 
>our local (Seattle) ambient noise club (Seven Beats Per Minute) was 
>outstanding. Do any ravers listen to this stuff?  If not, I'll stand by 
>my point about the rave scene holding back the creative potential of 
>techno music.

i rave.  i own "accident in paradise."  i listen to the non-dance
tracks.  retract your statement.

>But are they open to *non*-dance music?  Music is more than just 
>something to dance to; good music stands on its own whether you can dance 
>to it or not.  This "tyranny of the beat" is exactly what I'm pointing out 
>when I say the rave scene holds back creative potential.

the claim that listening to *any* form of music "holds back creative
potential" is ridiculous.  where do you get off saying something like
that?

>Did I say anything about post-punk values?  What I mean is that punk had
>a healthy cynicism toward the most cherished hippie illusions (peace, 
>love, harmony, ad nauseum).  That scepticism has been carried into 
>post-punk genres such as industrial.  Now the rave scene has resurrected 
>the old hippie rhetoric, engendering "attitude" (whatever the hell that 
>means) on the part of those of us who are too jaded for all that.  

believe it or not, some of us rave and some of us are still skeptical.
however, at a really good rave, for a short time, even my hardened
skepticism melts before an incredible onslaught of positivity.  if you
think there's something wrong with being positive - even temporariliy
- then that's your problem.

>A problem with idealism is that it sets you up for disappointment when, 
>as happens quite often, things don't go as well as expected.  A worse 
>problem is that idealism often leads to its nasty flipside, fanaticism.  

yeah yeah yeah, life sucks, nothing lasts, nasty brutish and short, i
got it all.  believe me, i'm pretty pessimistic 99% of the time.  it's
just that every once in a while i can let go of it.  i think most
ravers are pretty well adjusted that way, when it comes to attitude.

Jon Drukman                                         jdrukman%dlsun87@oracle.com
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
This calls for a very special blend of psychology and extreme violence.

From sfraves-owner  Fri Oct 15 20:32:40 1993

Subject: More from the California Aggie
Status: 


	This one made me laugh out loud:
Disorderly Conduct
	At approximately 6:40 p.m. Wednesday, a male juvenile was found
face down on the sidewalk and lawn area near the 600 block of A street. 
The juvenile exposed himself to the reporting party and was found eating
dirt and lawn upon officer's arrival.  Admitting to be being under the
influence of LSD, he was unable to care for himself and was taken into
custody and transported to Sutter Davis Hospital for treatment.  The Davis
Police Department picked up the suspects mother and took her to the
hospital, where she took custody of her son.  The case has been forwarded
to Zane Probation Detention Center and a copy has been sent to the
Department of Youth Services.

Poor kid, talk about a BAD trip!

Y' all have a good time at the ORB show tonite and I'll see ya tomorow at
Liquid Air!

G

> >when I say the rave scene holds back creative potential.
> 
> the claim that listening to *any* form of music "holds back creative
> potential" is ridiculous.  where do you get off saying something like
> that?

Did you even read what I said before you responded?  Where do I claim that 
listening to a form of music holds back creativity?  What I said was that 
the lack of willingness to listen to non-dance music held back techno.  
That's my main criticism of dance music in general; when music is seen as 
merely a means to an end (in this case dancing) rather than an end in 
itself, the music will suffer.  I'm not saying there's no good dance 
music (though an awful lot of crap is turned out in the name of 
"danceability"), but what there is has come from paying as much attention 
to the music as the beat.

> believe it or not, some of us rave and some of us are still skeptical.
> however, at a really good rave, for a short time, even my hardened
> skepticism melts before an incredible onslaught of positivity.  if you
> think there's something wrong with being positive - even temporariliy
> - then that's your problem.

You definitely did not take the time to read my post or the one before it 
(your response came before the original even bounced back to me).  I've 
already answered the positivity/negativity thing twice.  I won't repeat 
myself a third time.  I will say in my defense that I am quite capable of 
getting some joy out of existence without recourse to ideological constructs 
like "positivity".

> yeah yeah yeah, life sucks, nothing lasts, nasty brutish and short, i
> got it all.  believe me, i'm pretty pessimistic 99% of the time.  it's
> just that every once in a while i can let go of it.  i think most
> ravers are pretty well adjusted that way, when it comes to attitude.

How nice that y'all are so "well adjusted".

Beast of Eden

(cross-post responses: nm-list@reef.cis.ufl.edu and
sfraves@techno.stanford.edu)

From sfraves-owner  Sat Oct 16 07:40:09 1993
From: Rishad J. Quazi <rquazi@libserv1.ic.sunysb.edu>
Date: Sat, 16 Oct 93 10:39:52 EDT
Subject: Rave Doubts (fwd)
Status: 

> 
> >(ravers are) people who are open-minded about exploring many forms of 
> >dance music
> 
> But are they open to *non*-dance music?  Music is more than just 
> something to dance to; good music stands on its own whether you can dance 
> to it or not.  This "tyranny of the beat" is exactly what I'm pointing out 
> when I say the rave scene holds back creative potential.
> 

"Music" is certainly more than just something to dance to, but the question
here is "what is techno"? Last time I checked, techno meant electronic
dance music, and as such we are somewhat confined to forms of music that
can be danced to by mere definition. This is why the 'ambient' music genre
does not rightly fall under techno, if you ask me.
