From sfraves-owner  Sat Oct 16 08:20:07 1993
From: larryc@netcom.com (Larry Ching)
Date: Sat, 16 Oct 93 8:20:37 PDT
Subject: Re: Rave Doubts
Status: 

RE: The "Rave Doubts" Thread  
 

> >Peter Werner writes:
> 
>I definitely was talking about the ambient tracks.  What I've heard at 
>our local (Seattle) ambient noise club (Seven Beats Per Minute) was 
>outstanding. Do any ravers listen to this stuff?  If not, I'll stand by 
>my point about the rave scene holding back the creative potential of 
>techno music.

>   
> ... Music is more than just 
> something to dance to; good music stands on its own whether you can dance 
> to it or not.  This "tyranny of the beat" is exactly what I'm pointing out 
> when I say the rave scene holds back creative potential.

> ... What I said was that 
> the lack of willingness to listen to non-dance music held back techno.  
> That's my main criticism of dance music in general; when music is seen as 
> merely a means to an end (in this case dancing) rather than an end in 
> itself, the music will suffer.  .......  
> ... but what (good techno) there is has come from paying as much attention 
> to the music as the beat.
> 
> Beast of Eden
> 
> (cross-post responses: nm-list@reef.cis.ufl.edu and
> sfraves@techno.stanford.edu)
>  

Let me react to some of the points covered above -
1. I also rave and listen to ambient - also some new age and/or ambient 
   industrial, depending on my mood.
2. I get the impression that there's a "danciability vs musical quality"
   hypothesis going on here. Also , a confusion between catagories and
   sub-catagories within a musical scene. 
3. For me , good dance music at a rave has to have much, much more than a
   dancable beat - else , just turn the drum sequencers on and that'll do.
   [ BORING ! ]
4. When I go to a rave , the music in the dance area BETTER BE " a means  to
   an end (in this case dancing)" - that's what it is for, for the
   environment it is being mixed in. For , the states of conciousness 
   acheivable at raves are induced in a unique fashion by the music - 
   not just danciablity , but other factors are required for me -
   "trancability".
5. I had/have high hopes for the Rave Dance Music - the basic requirement
   of danciblity , and NO OTHER HISTORICAL/AESTHETIC REQUIREMENT , means 
   that ANYTHING can be done on top of the rythmn track. 
    ( I use the term Rave Dance Music 
   because I also think that there's a confusion of musical labels
   happening in this thread too. Rave Dance Music [RDM] is defined as music
   at raves that's primarily to be danced to , and I'll refer to the dance-
   secondary stuff as New Cool Music [NCM] ).  
6. An example: the existance of dance jazz did not prevent the emergence of
   cool jazz to "just" listen to. The existance of RDM will not prevent the 
   evolution of NCM . In fact , I expect a cross-fertilization , as most of
   the ravers I know listen to both types , and some of them make RDM as
   well. 
7. Is there a conflict between my points 4 and 5 ? Depends on the person
   making the music ... none of those guys/gals ask MY opinion !!! :-) 


  Gotta go now ( How was the Orb , you SFRavers ? )

					Larry Ching/larryc@netcom.com

From sfraves-owner  Sat Oct 16 09:27:03 1993
From: geoffw@nexsys.net (Geoff White)
Date: Sat, 16 Oct 93 09:24:53 PDT
Subject: Re: Rave Doubts
Status: 



	Well the way that I see it is as follows:

	1. Raving for me and for many others is a form of ritual.
	   It is a communal ritual, in other words it requires the
	   presence of others, people you have some bond with (this
	   may be as deep as family or just that you like to see each
	   other at the same parties).

	2. The focusing activity at this ritual is THE DANCE, that is
	   not to nullify all of the other activities that go on at
	   a party but the thing that brings us all together and for
	   me, has the most powerful effect is the fact that all of these
	   different people are moving to the same rhythm, and doing what
	   their BODIES are telling them to do. For some, this is the first
	   time in their lives that they have discovered that they even
	   HAVE a body.

	3. For some, THE DANCE is an entry point into achieving an ALTERED
	   STATE, similar to a state achieved by many other "primative"
	   cultures on the planet, loosely refered to as Trance Dancing.

	4. Once someone learns to enter this state (with or without
	   chemical assistance), it can become very intoxicating, it is the
	   reason (IMHO) that so many of the "hippie" values are present
	   in the rave community, when you enter this state, you tend to
	   see how things are interconnected rather then how, thing are
	   seperate.  This can have a countering effect on cynicism.

	5. There is room for a wider variety of music at raves, but remember
	   that the thing that make a Rave a Rave and not some folks standing
	   around caught in their ego, evaluating (as opposed to actualizing)
	   their situation is the fact that the music is compelling you to
	   move and to merge.

	6. I am not getting at anything mystical here, the reactions I'm
	   talking about can be looked upon as being totally physiological/
	   psychological.  

	7. I don't consider myself a "hello kiddie" raver, I enjoy a good
	   SRL performance and I believe I understand the position from
	   which they do their art, but Mahakali (to wax mystical now :)
	   is only one aspect of creation and her path is hard and often
	   full of tears, although like all true paths, there is liberation
	   at the end.  Some of my Industrial friends do walk this path
	   and have my deepest respect, others are just "posers with attitude"
	   who I have seen fall to pieces at the first rumbling of a good
	   5.x earthquake (maybe they can't handle unbridled Kali who doesn't
	   really need man-made machines to wreak destruction).  Growing up 
	   in the inner city, I've lived next to toxic area, express trains,
	   and other sources of industrial influence, in those environments
	   you learn to co-exist even embrace these things because it is
	   necessary to survive.  Eventually, if you are lucky, you live
	   long enough to see another way.  You realize that the hard path
	   that you had followed was necessary in order to get where you
	   are (it is true that in the jungle, concrete or organic, only the
	   strong, quick or smart survive) but there are other ways of being
	   more appropriate to other environments.  That is why I live here
	   now and don't want to live in Brooklyn where I lived for 10 years.

	8. Raving, above all other things that it is, IMHO should be an
	   expression of LOVE.  It doesn't have to be the "hello kiddie"
	   type of love if that doesn't turn you on, it can be the
	   "tough love" that I keep hearing about but am not exactly sure
	   what is ment by it.  But LOVE is and should be the driving force.



				- G

I think Geoff's dance theory is strong.
Emphasis on the body. For us every day is a 
cyber-day. Just because it seems like the
millenium brings a new way.  Dispite the attractiveness
of T. McKenna and others'  theories about evolving out of the 
"monkey body" and the role of digital tech in
achieving this evolution, WE LIVE IN OUR BODIES, and I
think we will take them with us. 

I rave for the fact that dance music is evolving fast
and the gay discos arent keeping up.

MY favorite line from the movie TGIFriday
"Kiss concert ,  ... thats kid stuff. We're disco queens now!"

From sfraves-owner  Sun Oct 17 11:01:36 1993
From: jsl@netcom.com (John S. Lee)
Date: Sun, 17 Oct 93 11:02:02 -0700
Subject: Rhythm!...ouch my head hurts!
Status: 

Rhythm was the SHIT last night.  I came just in time to hear the last part
of Jan's set.  It was really deepdopefunky!  I never knew she could spin
like that!

Next up to the plate was Markie...all I can say is omigod!  Every time I
hear him lately he keeps transporting my head to another dimension.  Markie
is the shit when it comes to music selection, mixing, mood, and whatever
other category you'd like to name.  That crowd went crazy when he hit the
decks.  And not once did I hear a record skip :)  Incredible!

With all the bases loaded Jeno came on.  I have not heard Jeno spin in
quite a while.  And when I have heard him spin he was not the same Jeno who
put me into dimension 8.  Last night he managed to put ALL my doubts aside.
 He's more dangerous than ever.  He brought out some stuff that was
absolutely insane.  He even brought back a few oldies in a way that only
Jeno can do.  Home run!

Leon came on next.  I only heard the first 30 minutes of hit set
(unfortunately), but his shit was right on, and the crowd wanted more.  So
did I ,but any more dancing without the aid of psycho-trop's woulda
rendered me useless ;)

Rhythm is a great club.  Nice people, I would say about 75% gay crowd. 
Culturally mixed.  And when people bump into you the words "excuse me"
always followed.  The music is not to be believed.  I would suggest going
whenever you get a chance.  It is one of the few weeklies that are going
off!

-------
Happenings:

DJ James has a couple of new tapes he's sporting around lately.  A really
cool mix of garage/house/acid that he did.  A grand total of 200 minutes! 
The stuff is really well put together, and shows why James is one of the
greats when it comes to mixing/music selection.  He ain't selling 'em, so
if you get copies consider yourself in good shape.

I wrote a letter to URB about the TEPID coverage we're getting in the
SanFrandisco section.  We'll see what happens.

Look for a new Friday thing going on starting around the 5th of Nov.

20Hz (A new record label in SF), is looking for new talent to sign.  If you
have good music you'd like to press to vinyl, get in contact with me.  20Hz
is looking for dance tracks as well as dance track "tools" (had to cop that
Alfie, sorry ;).  If you have the desire, and the talent, and you beleive
in yourself, get in contact with me.

A new promoter is now on the net.  He does some pretty samll parties like
Basics, Gathering, etc. etc.  He is doing a new clothing line from his
company called Communion. His addr is: choices@netcom.com .

========
Errata:

This year IMO has been interesting to say the least/most.  There were FAR
fewer parties this year than the previous few years.  Tons of promoters
have dropped off the scene, and all that is left it seems, are those people
who are genuine enough to last.  There are still 1 or two greedo's left,
but they will not last long.  For the most part I would say that this scene
is undergoing a shift.  I would not say that it is evolving, but it's focus
is changing.

People don't attend the events in such large numbers anymore.  Prices seem
to have stabilized in the $10-$15 range.

I would have to say that the 21+ crowd is very jaded about the scene right
now.  They have the parties that they will attend, and only rarely venture
out to new happenings.  This is why it is soooo good to see a few new
promoters on the scene.  It is good to get the younger people involved with
the scene, because the one thing that is sorely needed is an infusion of
new blood.

Smaller parties are the main attractions.  People seem to like the more
intimate parties, and I for one am all for that.

But in talking to some of my friends who have been on the SF tip since the
beginning I am starting to hear "Hell, it's not what it used to be...". 
Well damn right, nothing stays the same.  The idea is to keep your palette
fresh enough so that you can appreciate the new seasons offerings.  Many
just want the same 'ol same 'ol.  Well, I for one have very fond memories
of Toon Town and so on, but I in now way EXPECT that to ever come back.  So
I try to look for new things that people are doing, and appreciate them for
what they are.  Everyone will have that blowout party to which all others
are compared.  The idea is to build upon that experience with new
experiences.  Too bad many want to use the experiences they have had to
pass judgement on current happenings (I have been guilty at times).  This
is unfair to the "scene"(if it is truly a movement/entity) as a whole, and
this is why many have dropped off.  Oh well, there will alwys be room for
new blood. I'm too busy looking to the future.  I guess I'm still waiting
for my "blowout" event to happen :)

I hope Liquid Air went off.  I was not up to the drive last night, and when
I heard that it was 30 mins outside of the city, I decided to go & stay @
Rhythm!  If the party was in city limits (an increasingly difficult thing
to do) I would've gone.

One other word.  I know a few of you are interested in throwing a renegade.
 And many of you are concerned with the "competition".  Well, there IS no
"competition".  Every party has it's core group, and every group is always
being rebuilt/re-invented.  If you decide to throw a party, but it just
happens to be on a night of someone else's decide:

- Are you going for the same demographic?
- Do you know who's throwing a party opposite yours?  If so, have you told
them what you plan on doing?

If you've answered no to either, then go ahead and do your gig.  Keep your
costs low, and full speed ahead!  There is nothing wrong with parties being
opposite each other, as long as there is communication, and clarity of
purpose.  SF has had it's cut-throat moments, but most of this is due to
EGO.  Most of the people who have had such ego's are gone, so do your gig. 
There will never be a "perfect" time (I have had friends throw parties
opposite mine every time I've done one.  Many times it was mere
coincidence.  Other times it was deliberate.  I just said "Fuck it", and
did my gig ;).  The only person you need be true to is yourself, and if
you've been straight-up with folx and they "try" to screw you then it's
their bad.  It will come back to bite them back, for greed/ego has the
ugliest payback.  Witness the current crop of SF/SJ/Sac promoters for
proof.

I've rambled enough...drank a wee bit too much.  Gotta nurse this small
hangdaddy!

Peace,
John

>:c sfraves@techno.stanford.edu
>Every once in a while, one of those postings comes along on sfraves which
>really sums it all up in terms of overview and feeling about what's
>happening in the house.techno.rave.dance scene . . . and jslee's latest
>really did it.  Way to be!
>
>We had an event in Portland last night that finally reached my expectations
>of what our local scene can be and might become.  OPEN HOUSE was fully
>legal and held in a *parking garage* at the back side of Powell's
>Technical Bookstore (for those who know this town), the bookstore which
>is like Going to Mecca for us software types.  I arrived just before
>2 and heard Garth and then Mike Stevens (a good local DJ) spinning it
>up in very fine fashion, while several hundred of my fellow Portlandites
>made like they were having a real good time :)
>
>But it got better.  After the appointed 6 am shutdown, about 60 of us
>ended up over at the Pine Street Theatre (now called La Luna) for an
>impromptu afterparty -- and got off BIGtime!  Unfortunately Garth had
>already headed to the airport (going home after Thursday in Baltimore,
>Friday in DC and last night in Portland), it would have been nice for
>us to show him a little of PDX at its best (although I think he had
>a good time in any event).  My friend Manoj is talking about doing
>a regular Sunday morning thing at Pine Street -- the staff there seems
>to be all for it.  This might be the breakthrough we're looking for up
>here -- it's been so hard to get any momentum going in this town.
>
>Now if we could only convince The Orb to come up here the next time
>they go out on tour stateside . . .
>.
>

From sfraves-owner  Sun Oct 17 17:37:26 1993
From: Thomas C Butcher <tb303+@CMU.EDU>
Date: Sun, 17 Oct 1993 20:36:18 -0400 (EDT)
Subject: Re: Rave Doubts
Status: 

Excerpts from internet.new-music: 17-Oct-93 Re: Rave Doubts by Sami
Khoury@uclink.berke 
> What the hell are you talking about, Lazlo?  Wielding weapons on small
> children?  Hurting techno while playing with yourself?  Like what you
> like, listen to what you listen to.  Screw trying to define and categorize
> all for the purpose of having a spiffy label to affix squarely on your
> forehead.  That's what political correctness is for.
>  
> Sami

Well, by categorizing groups of similar music types, those who don't
know what or where to look can find something that might fit what genre
they prefer.  I know that categorizations are a product of the 'bad
people' or 'politically correct,' but in today's state of musical
affairs, sometimes subgroups can help.

That doesn't mean that categorizations are good, though.  Artists are
often signed for the sole purpose of a record company's want to 'share
the market.'  Thus, sometimes bad music arrives carrying the badge of a
certain type of music.  Categorizations, though, also can provide a
means for someone to discover another genre (s)he likes.  I know this
has happened to me... I listened to strictly electronic music for many
years during the mid-80s (the Jean-Michel Jarre/Kraftwerk stuff), but
hearing something like Tangerine Dream made me want to explore more
hybrid musical textures.

Many artists (Induction :) ) aspire to be a part of a certain category
but actually end up inventing a category of their own.

?

Tom

"Why can't everybody love everybody else?"
"I'm incapable of that sort of unselfish love."

From sfraves-owner  Sun Oct 17 23:23:18 1993
From: brycer@netcom.com (Bryce Ryan)
Date: Sun, 17 Oct 93 23:23:47 PDT
Subject: Liquid Air
Status: 

Thanks to all from this list who attended the October Liquid Air.
After a brief false start at our initial site, we moved to our
backup location, and the party went off.  We had a beautiful bay
side site, right amongst the bay flats.  The weather cleared up
nicely.  One side effect of the starry night was that it got really
chilly just between 4 and 7.  We had a fine blaze going, and some
even finer music from Tamara, Chris, Laura and Jon.  I was very
impressed with everyone's sets--they were spectacular.  We tried
split sets this time: each DJ did a one hour set, and then another
one hour set.  This seemed to work out fine for everyone.

Thanks to all the volunteers who helped load and unload the truck
twice: we couldn't have done it without you!  Thanks to Ethan for
God's personal sound system, Sound Vision.  Truly *the* best
sound system IMO.  

This is the last well-planned renegade that the Fluid Groove posse
will be doing until the weather becomes more predictable.  I had
several moments of anxiety throughout the day Saturday, but it
all worked out fine (this time!).  We saw some truly spectacular
cloud formations, many people reported seeing amazing meteors,
and Laura's second set brought up the sun in a wonderful way. It's
so nice to dance into the light.

On a more serious note, one of our planned DJs, Lee An, was unable
to attend because of an injury to his back.  Please send your cards
and letters to Lee...I hope he gets well soon.  

We'll be doing more indoor events throughout the rainy season...look
for us in December! We've also been contemplating daytime events...
stay tuned for details.
-- 
Bryce Ryan ------- AMBIANCE -------- brycer@netcom.com--------
Sound surrounds you like Liquid Air --- Next Party Dec93 -----
415-487-8497 -- Audio by Sound Vision -- Flyer by Dave Scruton

From sfraves-owner  Mon Oct 18 02:54:23 1993
From: Roy Badami <roy@harlequin.co.uk>
Date: Mon, 18 Oct 93 10:55:13 BST
Subject: Re: Rave Doubts
Status: 


  Peter> I definitely was talking about the ambient tracks.  What I've
  Peter> heard at our local (Seattle) ambient noise club (Seven Beats
  Peter> Per Minute) was outstanding. Do any ravers listen to this
  Peter> stuff?

They certainly do.  I would class this as "ambient house".  By
"ambient" i don't necessarily mean beatless, but i mean it's primarily
music for listening to, rather than dancing to.  By "house", i mean
that it's come out of the house/dance scene, using that term in the
broadest possible sense.

Many of the best parties will have an ambient chill out lounge where
exactly this kind of music is played, where people can relax and have
a smoke after exhausting themselves on the dance floor.

I should say that I am of course answering from a UK perspective, but
IMHO ambient music is very much a part of the rave scene...


	Cosmic

From sfraves-owner  Mon Oct 18 09:40:27 1993
From: hsarbaz@koko.csustan.edu (Hoss Sarbaz)
Date: Mon, 18 Oct 93 09:40:00 -0700
Subject: Re:  Liquid Air
Status: 

Where was it we drove from 12:pm to 4:30am looking for it? The second directio
ns said, "......take 880 south to Fremont Blvd passed the 84, make a left on
Cushing and it will be at the end of the road....".

1) Cushing Pkwy only went to the right off Fremont Blvd.
2) If you took a left It would still be Fremont Blvd.
3) You had to make a U-turn from the Fremont Off ramp to get to Cushing.
4) there was total silence on Cushing and no one in site (I give credit to
Bryce and his posse for that because it did not get busted).
5) there were two other exits Central Fremont and Fromont Blvd, which was
confused the hell out of us and one or two other carloads of fellow ravers we
happened to run into at a gas station, I think it was Nath and his Posse, they
were lost just like us.


Maybe next time I'll get to meet all you guys! oh well!(snap of the finger).

PS I was looking forward to it so was Bob and our friends Dan and Missy.

hoss

From sfraves-owner  Mon Oct 18 09:43:31 1993
From: Jon Drukman <jdrukman@us.oracle.com>
Date: Mon, 18 Oct 93 09:41:39 PDT
Subject: Rave Doubts
Status: 

peter werner:
>Did you even read what I said before you responded?  Where do I claim that 
>listening to a form of music holds back creativity?  What I said was that 
>the lack of willingness to listen to non-dance music held back techno.  

it seems to me that the 2nd and 3rd sentences in that paragraph equate
to the same thing.

>That's my main criticism of dance music in general; when music is seen as 
>merely a means to an end (in this case dancing) rather than an end in 
>itself, the music will suffer.  I'm not saying there's no good dance 
>music (though an awful lot of crap is turned out in the name of 
>"danceability"), but what there is has come from paying as much attention 
>to the music as the beat.

this paragraph is a stellar example of the 100% content-free post.  of
COURSE there's crap in the dance music arena... there's crap in EVERY
genre, even in your personal favorite genre du jour (whatever that may
be).

what exactly is your point?  "the lack of willingness to listen to
non-dance music held back techno" is a meaningless statement - who
exactly did it hold back, and how do you know their music would have
been any better had they listened to non-dance music?

tell me if my interpretation here is correct: i think your main
complaint stems from what you perceive as a desire on the part of
certain musicians to make purely "functional" music - ie: music that
only works on a dance floor.  but, what's the big deal?  there have
been ritual drummers around the world doing nothing but beats for
people to bug out to since time began - but you probably think that's
a more "pure" form since it's non-electronic and oh so trendy to have
a japanese kodo drummers CD on your coffee table these days.

(note: no disrespect to the kodo drummers - i think they're awesome!)

so, i repeat, what is your point?

Jon Drukman                                         jdrukman%dlsun87@oracle.com
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
This calls for a very special blend of psychology and extreme violence.

From sfraves-owner  Mon Oct 18 10:42:09 1993
From: Arthur Chandler <arthurc@sfsuvax1.sfsu.edu>
Date: Mon, 18 Oct 1993 10:34:41 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: Dancing and Listening
Status: 



  One of the interesting --- and apparently inevitable -- morphs in
Western music is the transition of music from the dance floor to the
concert hall. It happened in the time of Louis XIV, it happened with the
waltz, it happened with jazz, it even happened at the Fillmore and Winterland
with rock: at first, the music is made to dance to. Then, after a while,
more and more people just sit or stand it out and listen. Charlie Mingus,
the great jazz bassist, used to say "You can't listen and dance at the
same time. So sit down, shut up, don't make noises, and listen to our music!"
  I wonder if the same could happen to techno and/or house? 
  If you were composing music primarily to be listened to, would you tend
to make it more complex than if you were making it solely to danced to?



From sfraves-owner  Mon Oct 18 10:47:12 1993
From: csc@pilot.njin.net (Sean Casey)
Date: Mon, 18 Oct 93 13:47:06 EDT
Subject: Re: Rave Doubts
Status: 


I'm not really sure what techno is. I get different answers if I talk
to a non-raver, a raver, a DJ, and a record store employee.

I used to use it to refer to the entire genre of "harder than new age"
electronic music. More often I'm seeing it used to describe only some
of it, specifically the harder stuff.

Names, genres, philosophies... labels seem very important to us.
Reminds me of a story I once read where some aliens in a bar were
talking about that particularily human need and its implications.

Sean

From sfraves-owner  Mon Oct 18 10:58:36 1993
From: Rishad J. Quazi <rquazi@libserv1.ic.sunysb.edu>
Date: Mon, 18 Oct 93 13:58:29 EDT
Subject: Dancing and Listening (fwd)
Status: 

>   If you were composing music primarily to be listened to, would you tend
> to make it more complex than if you were making it solely to danced to?

i think it should be made simpler, if the music is to be danced to in an
informal 'free-style' form a la rave dancing. IMHO, good rave dance music
is like a mantra to take you into a trance -- it repeats a phrase over
and over (the bassline) while morphing and mutating slightly with each
iteration (eg. acid bassline squiggles change phase or form with each
bar). if the rhythms or melodies are too elongated or complex, it is
hard for my soft brain to dance to, even harder to trance to. didn't
someone on this list once say that fetal-womb sounds are the easiest
thing to dance to? perhaps that's what trance-dancing is all about --
reviving long suppressed memories of womb rhythms and sounds.

        O         ~    ~
         o    ~        ~               ~
          .   _/,_        ~         ~      ~
           . /o...\__//        FiSH ~ Rishad J. Quazi
             \_'__/``\`      rquazi@csws1.ic.sunysb.edu
        ~      \`          RQUAZI@SBCCVM.BITNET
           ~          .     ~    ~               ~  ~
           \/  .  .     .   \ \/        .      .

From sfraves-owner  Mon Oct 18 12:01:06 1993
From: Bob Ramstad <rramstad@us.oracle.com>
Date: Mon, 18 Oct 93 12:00:58 PDT
Subject: Liquid Air
Status: 


I need to also put in my 2 cents... (and I'll freely admit that I'm
100% biased).  These events that Bryce and Ethan have been putting on
are EXACTLY what people on the list have been wanting --- inexpensive,
outdoors, adventurous music (not the same old shuffle-house-beat
shit), really great people, very open situations.  Given all this,
I'll never understand why more people from the list don't make it out.
Sigh.

Big thanks to all the DJs who made it so groovy... and it's getting **
really ** obvious to me that we are gifted to have some great DJs here
on the list.

Not to rag on Wicked, but the last FMR I went to had around 1 1/2
hours of music before being busted, had over a thousand people, had
people selling nitrous in the crowd, and also featured about 40
minutes of killer tunes mixed in with some fairly standard pedestrian
boring stuff.  On my scorecard, Liquid Air had around 6 hours of
music, a nice sized crowd with plenty of space for everyone and mature
enough to be able to handle a bonfire (!), people doing drugs were
courteous enough to keep it low key, and hours and hours of very
creative music.  Liquid Air was closer to SF than many FMRs... and the
reality is that we all know that renegades need to be more creative
(and willing to go out of town) in order to find good sites which
won't get busted.

Big howdy to everyone who made it out, it was great dancing and
hanging out with you all, and I'm looking forward to the next one!

Bob

From: tomf@tekigm2.MEN.TEK.COM (Thomas E Flynn)
Subject: Re: HR4079 (long)
Date: 13 Apr 90 09:57:48 GMT
Organization: Tektronix, Inc., Beaverton, OR.

In article <125@ctbilbo.UUCP> pete@ctbilbo.UUCP (Pete Ritter) writes:
>A few nights ago on the radio, I caught the tail end of a discussion of
>a bill before Congress that would temporarily suspend the 4th (search and
>seizure) and 8th (cruel and unusual punishment) Amendments.  I think the
>bill was HR4079 and "temporarily" was 5 years.  I got the idea that the
>purpose of the bill is to make it easier to prosecute dealers and users of
>illegal drugs.  Anyone who knows the details of this bill, please enlighten
>me.  More and more, the "WOD" is becoming the "WOC".
>  

I just received a copy of H.R.4079 in the mail.  As soon as I read the 
original posting, I phoned up the Bill Status Office, in Washington, 
((202)225-1772) and requested a copy.  For those interested in obtaining
a copy, I was referred to the House Document Room, (202)225-3456.  They 
sent a copy, free of charge (it took 3 days). 

H.R.4079 is truly an incredible assault on our Constitutional rights.  The
Bill is 96 pages long, however, I have listed several interesting excerpts 
below.  The excerpted text is straight out of the Bill, except where noted
in brackets.

- - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - -

				H.R. 4079

     To provide swift and certain punishment for criminals in order to
          deter violent crime and rid America of illegal drug use.

         House of Representatives, February 22, 1990, Mr. Gingrich. 
[Gingrich is the main sponsor, however, there is a list of other 
 Representatives who, presumably, want their name on the Bill, also. -tf].

SECTION 1. SHORT TITLE

    This Act may be cited as the "National Drug and Crime Emergency Act".

From sfraves-owner  Mon Oct 18 12:56:52 1993
From: bbehlen@soda.berkeley.edu (Brian Behlendorf)
Date: Mon, 18 Oct 1993 12:56:39 -0700
Subject: Re:  Liquid Air
Status: 

On Oct 18,  9:40am, you proclaimed:
} Where was it we drove from 12:pm to 4:30am looking for it? The second directio
} ns said, "......take 880 south to Fremont Blvd passed the 84, make a left on
} Cushing and it will be at the end of the road....".

It was still there - stayed there until 8am that morning, after the sun had 
risen.

} 1) Cushing Pkwy only went to the right off Fremont Blvd.
} 2) If you took a left It would still be Fremont Blvd.
} 3) You had to make a U-turn from the Fremont Off ramp to get to Cushing.

I think you may have confused right and left :)  Actually, while still
on the off-ramp there is a sign that says "Cushing" with an arrow in the
right direction.  It may have been a little confusing, I admit; actually
I think more people got tripped up on which Fremont to exit at, since there
were two Fremont Blvd exits separated by about 10 miles.  The "past the 84"
meant go down the 880 past the 84, exit Fremont Blvd; apologies to those
who took the first and got lost, and kudos to those who finally found it :)

} 4) there was total silence on Cushing and no one in site (I give credit to
} Bryce and his posse for that because it did not get busted).

There was a dirt road at the end of Cushing: "Take Cushing all the way down;
it becomes a dirt road" said the directions.  We were at the very end, in the
middle of nowhere.

Anyways, sorry about the mixup; it was a great party!  There must have
been a meteor shower that night because I saw at least a dozen streaks
in the sky.  The sunrise was one of the most stunning sunrises I have 
ever seen, as it was coming up behind fluffy clouds :)  

Thanks to Bryce! and to everyone else involved in throwing this....
even around 5am when it got REALLY REALLY cold I was still happy to
be there.

	Brian

From sfraves-owner  Mon Oct 18 13:36:57 1993
From: pashdown@slack.sim.es.com (Pete Ashdown)
Date: Mon, 18 Oct 1993 14:36:56 -0600 (MDT)
Subject: Orb Be in U
Status: 

I just got over one of the most incredible weekends of my life.  Excuse me if
I sound a little dazed, but I've really lived a lifetime these past three
days.

Friday night, I boarded a flight for San Francisco, flying in for one reason,
and one reason only.  To see The Orb.  When I first saw The Orb two years ago,
it was with 100 other people in a small Salt Lake City venue for $3.  I had no
interest in DJing, throwing parties, or doing any sort of promotions.  That
night turned my life around as I danced harder than I have ever done to music
that I had, for the most part, never heard before.  It was a pivotal point in
my life.

I had attempted to book them for this tour in Salt Lake, and although they
expressed an interest, it turned out that they couldn't make it through on
their schedule.  Matt E. Silver is a gem of an agent/promoter and the nicest
guy on the planet as well.  If there is anyone in this country I could pick to
run a tour for the scene, and not for exploitation, it would be Matt E.  I
told him that I would try and fly out to see Orb wherever I could do so, and
he stated that I should tell him where so he could put me on the guest list.
It turned out that he did a lot more than that for me.

Brian Behlendorf picked me up at the airport and after some noodling around,
we went to a fantastic Vietnamese restaurant near the Warfield for dinner.  I
hurridly chowed down my food, and stated that I had to find the tour manager
before things got underway.

I ended up having to wait for around an hour before Matt E. finally showed up.
Malcolm, the UK manager apologized for having me wait and slapped me a pass.
Besides the one I scored for Jon Drukman, these were the only two "FLOCK!"
passes that I saw running around that night (besides the one that Alex was
wearing).  The crew had the "All Pastures" badges, but that was about it.  I
was given a rather privileged position for the night, being able to go
*anywhere* but not have any responsibilities.

Jon and I watched Alex and Thrash do some soundchecking for a while.  I got a
good close look at Alex's equipment, which included a Stanton CD-33 DJ CD
player.  I also got to talk with Buck about his Universe gig, which sound
absolutely amazing.  I asked him about doing Salt Lake and he gave me a really
reasonable price.  He's a very nice guy.

I also got to meet the Reese Pursell, the guy who is responsible for
Astralwerks in New York.  It was a total surprise to run into him on this
tour, but looking at the Wau!/Mr. Modo based "Excursions into Ambience II"
promo I got, it isn't surprising at all.  Reese gave me a preview of the
future of his label, and without a doubt, this is going to be the best dance
label in America.  Its very exciting to look forward to, but it was also very
flattering for him to be the one person who I sent promo packets to who heaped
high praises on my writing.

While talking to Matt E. in one of the offices, a fatherly sort of figure
walked into the room with a permanent smile on his face.  Matt introduced him
as Adam Morris, which didn't register with me until later.  I knew he was
someone, but I couldn't remember who.  I was in such a dazed state that I was
having trouble remembering names of people who were close to me.

The lineup of DJ's changed to give Alex and Lewis time to DJ.  Alex took the
stage first at 10:00 to spin off a very interesting set.  It wasn't closely
beatmatched, more use of taking advantage of beatless breaks, but it was still
wonderful to watch and listen to.  During his set is when I noticed the lights
the most.  They had four 20 foot cloth spheres that they were doing
projections off.  My favorites were when they projected an earth with a black
and white baby, and then an enormous eye that blinked back at the audience.
The slides and film loops were high class.  The video, unfortunately, was not.
Standard computer animation videos, and other junk with what seemed to be one
single Video Toaster 4000 running the show.  The stuff I've seen our own Taste
VJ do, ZapKerPow!, kicked their butts all over the floor.  Too bad to have
those huge screens with no punch behind them.

While Lewis DJ'd, I wandered around backstage again.  I finally found the
dressing room where Alex and the rest of the backing musicians were hanging
out.  There was a large star, with the name "Jerry" painted on the door.  Matt
E. introduced me to Alex and said that I had some things to give him.  It was
Alex's birthday by coincidence, so it was kind of nice to have brought him
some presents.  I gave him a book filled with pictures of Utah, a Taste
t-shirt, and copies of all the fliers I have done along with rave journals
that I have written bound into a book.  In addition, I wrote Alex and Kris a
letter which he read very closely and carefully.  Alex seemed genuinely
touched by what I had written and put out his closed fist (a gesture which he
and Adam Morris seemed to use exclusively) for me to punch my closed fist
into.  I felt embarrased to have brought my entire Orb collection along with
me for him to sign, so the bag stayed closed all night.  Alex stated that he
was in need of some reading material for the tour and thanked me for the
books.

It wasn't much longer before he got up to take the stage again.  I returned to
the audience to watch what I had been so anxiously awaiting for two years.
They kicked off with a new track, "Plateau" which was a bit more than ambient.
More along the lines of "4th Dimension".  After playing a highly remixed
version of "Little Fluffy Clouds" a few others, and "Blue Room" I realized I
was being stupid to have to deal with being crowded and pushed around by other
people when I had a pass.  I went up to a vantage point on the stage, no more
than 15 feet (but not visible to the audience) and danced my way into space.
I stayed there for the rest of the show, watching Alex mix and Thrash tweeking
knobs on his monster-equalizer (this thing is about 12 feet wide).  I was
slurping in the moment as hard as I could.  The sound in front of the stage
wasn't that great, so the sound in the back was a bit muddled.  Did I CARE
though?  I was seeing angels at that point.

"The Valley", the other new track, kicks some serious booty.  I can't wait to
get this thing in my paws.  Most of the night was taken up by "Adventures"
material.  The only tracks from "U.F.Orb" were "Blue Room" and "Towers of
Dub".

Alex's girlfriend came up and stood beside me and danced a bit.  I turned to
her and asked if it ever got boring.  She said that it did sometimes, but she
always looked forward to new places to play.

After almost two hours of this, the show came to a close with my favorite,
"Outlands" which rolled over the audience like a tidal wave.  While I was
madly moving around in the darkness on the side, I saw Alex glance over at me
with a grin.

Finally, they ended.  I asked a stage hand to get me a setlist (which I left
at home today) to keep.  Then I went down into the basement where a girl was
spinning some very groovy soul and jazz.  She simply segued from one record
into another, which taught me a lesson about DJing.  Sometimes it isn't all
technique, but just the music that make you move.  I hung around in that room
for a while and danced, then tried to make my way back to the dressing room to
retrieve my music and t-shirts.  I was surprised to find that access had been
restricted to everyone except the crew.  Reese told me that they would open it
up soon, so I went back and relaxed in the backstage dancefloor.  Adam Morris
walked by and asked me if I enjoyed the show, I told him it was unbelievable
and he put his fist out for me to bash.  I thought he was trying to shake my
hand at first, and after a bit of confusion, we finally bashed/shook each
other's fists.

Around 3:30, I got very nervous about things, so I went up onto the stage,
down another stairway, and basically snuck into the dressing room.  Alex and
Kris weren't there, but my records were, so I sat down and grabbed a much
needed bottle of water.

While sitting there listening to people talk, it finally registered to me who
Adam Morris was.  He's Mr. Modo of the label.  I asked him if he was any
relation to Mixmaster Morris and he laughed and said no.  I told him about the
rumor that he was the same person (which he obviously isn't) and he seemed
very peeved about that and stated that he might as well be since Rising High
copied everything that Wau!/Mr. Modo did.  I then asked about the deal with
Big Life, and then followed up with that I really didn't need to know if he
didn't want to talk about it.  He affirmed that with another laugh.  Adam went
on to talk with me about the records that the Hardkisses had given him,
especially one known as "Ultraviolet Catastrophe" which I gave a sparkling
recommendation.  We then talked about the Grand Canyon and about how they
wanted to see that on this tour.  I managed to convince them that it would be
much easier and more rewarding to see Zion National Park, then told him about
the book I gave Alex.

It was getting close to closing, so we both left the dressing room after
saying our goodbyes.  Apparently Alex and Thrash had collapsed on the bus
after the show, no doubt to a large amount of jet lag, so I didn't see them
again.  I went back to the auditorium and met up with Brian and the rest of
the SFRaves crew and tried to find a ride to the airport from the afterparty.
Reese was supposed to spin, so I was looking forward to hearing him.  However,
no such luck was able to come my way.  After the night's experiences though, I
wasn't too disappointed.  I thanked Matt E. (for the umpteenth time) and said
goodbye to Reese.

After being held over in the airport until 10:30, I was on my way home.

Other things happened this weekend, such as promoting and running a sold-out
Crash Worship show that night in Salt Lake City, then helping out the owners
of the venue in running the second held-over night on Sunday, but I won't bore
you with the fantastic details of that experience.  I'm aware of what a pig I
am for posting all of above on the net, but I know my life is hard. :-)  Grab
the brass ring folks, there's nothing you can't do.

From sfraves-owner  Mon Oct 18 13:50:10 1993

the Orb show, got only 3 hrs of sleep, and decided to take a nap at

From sfraves-owner  Mon Oct 18 15:17:13 1993
From: csc@pilot.njin.net (Sean Casey)
Date: Mon, 18 Oct 93 18:16:44 EDT
Subject: Re: Liquid Air
Status: 

Despite:

   1. My car being towed Saturday.
   2. Half the munchies I was going to give away being stolen from
      Susie's.
   3. Two people I really wanted to bring backing out.
   4. Getting lost twice finding the site.
   5. Having a badly upset stomach all night.
   6. 3.5 hours of sleep in three days.

   Total cost for weekend, including food, records, two postcards,
   gas, tows, and fines: $230. (sigh)

I still had a good time. I wasn't my bouncing around grinning self,
but I really enjoyed the music and the company. I thought everyone
played really fun sets.  I especially enjoyed Laura's faster set and
Tamara's second one. As a matter of fact Tamara and John played a few
songs I decided I *had* to have even though I don't own a turntable
(!), so I picked them up at Star on Sunday ;).

Thanks to the DJs for playing great music, to Bryce for putting it on
(that was a great spot), and to everyone else for showing up and
sharing a good vibe. Definitely worth the drive.

Sean

From sfraves-owner  Mon Oct 18 16:37:14 1993
From: amaranth@ucscb.UCSC.EDU (Kristen M Johansen)
Date: Mon, 18 Oct 93 16:36:18 -0700
Subject: Re: Liquid Air
Status:

nobody has cars up here!  Is there any interest in staring a carpool list/
ridesharing group?  I'd certainly be interested.

From sfraves-owner  Mon Oct 18 17:12:11 1993
From: Peter Werner <boe666@u.washington.edu>
Date: Mon, 18 Oct 1993 16:57:17 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: Deep Doubts

>I would class (the Accident In Paradise CD) as "ambient house".  By
>"ambient" i don't necessarily mean beatless, but i mean it's primarily
>music for listening to, rather than dancing to.  By "house", i mean
>that it's come out of the house/dance scene, using that term in the
>broadest possible sense.

house and techno, somebody throws a wrench in it :).  I thought that 
house was '70s disco based while techno was the more "electronic" stuff.

From sfraves-owner  Mon Oct 18 17:14:44 1993

From sfraves-owner  Mon Oct 18 17:27:14 1993
From: Jon Drukman <jdrukman@us.oracle.com>
Date: Mon, 18 Oct 93 17:25:14 PDT
Subject: Deep Doubts
Status: 

>Every time I think I have a working definition of the differences between 
>house and techno, somebody throws a wrench in it :).  I thought that 
>house was '70s disco based while techno was the more "electronic" stuff.  
>Anybody have a better working definition?

that's actually not bad.  house definitely had its roots in the
chicago gay/disco scene - nowadays you've got a few major variants but
they're all based on that swing beat.  techno comes from detroit and
started with really minimal dark electronic stuff like cybotron and
mayday - see the recent Transmat label compilation for a quick primer.

the main thing that seems to confuse people is house music vs the
house scene.  the "scene" includes tons of different styles of music -
nowadays you've got garage house, hardtrance, acid, techno, acid jazz
and more on the dance floor.  ambient house is music for chill-out
rooms, and you might find these under the same roof with screaming
pumped-up dance floors.  so ambient in the sense of atmospheric,
relaxing, whatever and house in the sense of "part of the house
scene."  but definitely not connected to house music...


Jon Drukman                                         jdrukman%dlsun87@oracle.com
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
This calls for a very special blend of psychology and extreme violence.

From sfraves-owner  Mon Oct 18 18:34:51 1993
From: throb@netcom.com (Robert Oliver)
Date: Mon, 18 Oct 93 18:35:23 PDT
Subject: Re: Liquid Air
Status: 

Here's my anecdotes to the renegade.

 I tried to arrive early at the first site to help with the set up.  Not only was I late in arriving at what I thought was the end of Neptune, but I spent over half an hour walking along various bike paths and tripping over a Fitness Trail situp platform--good warm up exercise!  The local "parked" teenagers looked askance at me each time I walked past them ("What's this guy walking around here for?"). :)

After calling and getting directions to the second site, even *I,* who often travels along 880, took the first Fremont exit and spun around there a couple of times before realizing that I had not yet passed 84.  Yea, I'm stoopid!

I was really thrilled to reach the locale after driving and walking around for almost two hours.  Yes, it was c-c-c-cold!  My solution was to dance as much as possible (energy permitting, I used the full body dance method inspired by Amit) or place myself near the fire--warm personalities and hugs abated the chill as well!  Thanks to Tam's, Chris', Laura's, and Jon's sets, I could not stand still.  I am still sore from the Orb-Liquid Air dance-a-thon weekend! 

When I drove out after 7 a.m., I passed two private security guards (apparently from the nearby office building) who were walking on the dirt road away from the renegade.  They waved and smiled at me as I passed them.  I guess something alerted them to our goings-on, but after checking out the situation from a distance (too far to walk?) they decided to let it go.  Another exemplary result of spreading a positive vibe!

I definitely look forward to the next Fluid Grooves production!!

Rob

p.s. Cindy, I'm sorry that you could not make it to Liquid Air.  If you have not found your driver license by the next event, I will give you a ride!  :)

--

From sfraves-owner  Tue Oct 19 04:11:50 1993
From: Roy Badami <roy@harlequin.co.uk>
Date: Tue, 19 Oct 93 12:11:49 BST
Subject: Re: Dancing and Listening
Status: 


  Arthur>   One of the interesting --- and apparently inevitable --
  Arthur> morphs in Western music is the transition of music from the
  Arthur> dance floor to the concert hall. [...] I wonder if the same
  Arthur> could happen to techno and/or house?


I think it already has.  A good example is the series of Artificial
Intelligence albums on Warp.  This electronic listening music is
sometimes called "intelligent techno" because it often is more complex
than electronic dance music.

	Cosmic

From sfraves-owner  Tue Oct 19 04:57:16 1993
From: Roy Badami <roy@harlequin.co.uk>
Date: Tue, 19 Oct 93 12:58:06 BST
Subject: Re: Deep Doubts
Status: 


  Peter> Every time I think I have a working definition of the differences between 
  Peter> house and techno, somebody throws a wrench in it :).  I thought that 
  Peter> house was '70s disco based while techno was the more "electronic" stuff.  
  Peter> Anybody have a better working definition?

House in the great grandfather of all modern "rave" dance music, from
garage, through tehcno to gabba.  So it is sometimes used as an
umbrella term to encompass all of this (the house scene).  Substitute
"dance" if you prefer.  House, as a kind of music, generally has a far
more specific meaning, but i certainly wouldn say that all house is
funky disco based... i'd call that hi-nrg, but that's not really what
i'm into, so others will probably correct me...

Discalimers:
	(a) At times I'm pretty clueless about the definitions, too,
	    particularly when it comes to the subgenres that i'm
	    less interested in.


	(b) Some names -- "hardcore" for instance -- mean different
	    things in the UK and the US




	Cosmic

From sfraves-owner  Tue Oct 19 08:52:24 1993
From: pashdown@slack.sim.es.com (Pete Ashdown)
Date: Tue, 19 Oct 1993 09:49:55 -0600 (MDT)
Subject: XDZebra Review #37
Status: 

Sorry for the delay, I've had a zillion other things to do in my life and the
music has been piling up at home.  You should see a few more reviews come out
this week.  I've also stopped sending this to all the rave lists, save SFRaves
and NERaves.  There will be a subscription service for XDZ Reviews soon.

XDZebra Review #37

        Addiction
        266 Delmar Ct.
        Salt Lake City, UT 84101-1817

When in Utah call the T A S T E hotline 801-461-3375.

Trying to find these releases?  Try Ear/Rational: angst@psych.colorado.edu
also Twitch Remix Service,584 Castro St,Suite 600,San Francisco,CA,94114

Back issues are available from me by mail or by ftp'ing to techno.stanford.edu.
They're in the pub/raves/music/reviews directory.

XDZebra Reviews may be reproduced without permission under one condition,
they remain intact and unchanged.  If you publish this in print, mail me a
copy via "Addiction".

------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Review #37 Contents:
House of Acid Jazz - A Collection of Acid * Jazz * House - Volume 1
Twitch CD 8
ADSR: Obsession
Narcosis - A Journey Through the Outs and Ins of Underground
Excursions in Ambience - The Second Orbit
Apollo Compilation


House of Acid Jazz - A Collection of Acid * Jazz * House - Volume 1
Astralwerks: ASW 6103-2
1  121	03:27 The Funky Fellows: Ring Ring
2  130	03:56 Babe Root: Radio La La
3  127	04:28 Trans-Bassix: Zoom
4  134	04:26 Coincidance: The Wonderful World Of
5  130	03:56 Two Bloody Xylophones: Geen Aansluiting
6  130	04:02 Fritz and his Jazzcats: Good Inside
7  121	04:11 Jacomo Brothers: Jazzy Guitar
8  140	04:44 The Funkatears: Hot, Hot
9  134	04:30 Jazz Inc.: Random Access
10 130	04:04 Delfinokkio: No It Isn't Fun
11 132	03:52 Funky Tribe Two: Dance
12 121	04:46 The Funky Fellows: Ring Ring Ring Ring

Comments: Mui mui!  Louie Louie!  This comp jumped me out of my socks and
dazed my boogie machine like nothing in recent times.  Other attempts at acid
jazz have left me ho-humming, but everything on here jumps off into your lap
and forces you to move.  Elements of Italo House, with capable jazz riffs, and
even a smattering of breakbeat makes Astralwerks' latest release wonderful to
listen to and exstatic to dance to.

Summary: 9/10.  Fab, fab, fab.  Kudos to the seven DJs involved in creating
this wonderful sound.


Twitch CD 8
Twitch: TW-CD-08
1  124	05:29 DOP: Non-Stop
2  124	06:37 Harri: Skelph
3  124	05:50 Helicopter: On Ya Way
4  125	07:12 The Wildchild Experience: Jump to My Beat
5  125	05:16 Mother: All Funked Up
6  125	04:57 Daisy Glow: Sunday in the Park
7  127	06:24 Central Fire: Central Fire
8  127	06:20 Direckt: Two Fatt Guitars
9  129	07:30 Up Above The World: Unleashed in the East
10 130	06:47 Meat Beat Manifesto: Mindstream
11 132	05:53 Front 242: Religion
12 133	06:02 PG1: Jazz Energy

Comments: The artwork of sticks on the cover of CD 8 possibly represents the
massive collection of rhythm on the inside.  Catchy tunes like "On Ya Way"
with its stick-in-your-head vocal samples, and "All Funked Up" with its
snippest of 70's rock make for a tasty Twitch treat.  "Jump to My Beat" is
almost a short beat collection in itself, but tends to fail in the structure
department.  Even though I'm sick to death of "Two Fatt Guitars", Twitch has
done a capable remix of this, and the poopy single by Front 242.  "Religion"
gets a dancey boost, but still retains a bit of the original growl, which will
appeal to industrial fans.  I'm not too happy with the "Mindstream" remix
which sounds two much like the Orbital remix with vocals mixed over the good
parts.

Summary: 7/10.  Sticks and rhythm and boom boom boom.  Good funkiness with a
bit of variety for good measure.  Worth the price for the "Unleashed in the
East" track alone.


ADSR: Obsession
Cargo Records/Floorshaker: FSP 002
Side A:
1  139	Obsession
Side B:
1  138	Pure Energy (Fire Mix)
2  136	Suboceana (1993 Remix)

Comments: Preying upon my weakness for female vocals, ADSR goes right for the
jugular in laying down their sound.  All three of these tracks use a breathy
sample in excellent ways, but tend to suffer from repetition.  The
instrumentation is done well, but the bass kick really gets boring the third
time around.  "Obsession" itself is a nice dark trancer, and although "Pure
Energy" and "Suboceana" are based on the same sample, they fit their names
well.

Summary: 7/10.  Skillful use of sampling, but lacking in form.


Narcosis - A Journey Through the Outs and Ins of Underground
Guerilla: GRCD 009
Out Disc One:
1  132	05:53 Emojonal: Silence of Water
2  135	07:05 Hole in One: Game From the Planet Onchet
3  135	07:08 DJ Hell: My Definition of House Music
4  131	08:39 Abfahrt: Come into my Life
5  127	06:14 Trance Induction: New Age Heartcore
6  136	06:09 Fix: Flash
In Disc Two:
1  110	05:35 Effective Force: Diamond Bullet
2  140	06:54 Morganistic: In The Shadow
3  120	09:10 Sandoz: White Darkness
4  130	06:22 Dave Angel: Brother From Jazz
5  115	14:59 Mystic Institute: Ob-Selon Mi-Mos (Global Communications Remix)

Comments: At first glance you'd think you had just purchased the latest from
the Third Mind label.  At first listen, you're almost sure of it.  Guerilla
has certainly taken a hard left turn with this compilation.  Dark, but not
hard, moody, but not dreary, these are works of power and force.  Even though
there is an obvious stain with the ultimate rip-off track, "My Definition of
House Music" and Abfahrt's vocals are cheese deluxe, the rest are stunning in
their timeless form.  "Game From the Planet Onchet" is quirky, bleepy, with a
good mix of spiraling sine waves and happy dolphins.  Sandoz shines with
"White Darkness", a turn of the page to classic Moog style electronics with a
rare use of lyricless male vocals to make things difficult.  Finally, be
prepared to be run over by Mystic Institute with a spacey, high- emotion track
that gives new meaning to the word "sweep".

Summary: 9/10.  Save for a pair of noodlers, this comp excites me to see
Guerilla is out of the progressive garage and looking around the planet.


Excursions in Ambience - The Second Orbit
Astralwerks: ASW AV6105-2
1  120	09:55 W.F.O.: No-One in the World (Edit)
2	08:52 Schizophrenia: Schizophrenia
3  120	08:42 Locust: Prospero
4  126	12:53 Maurizio: Ploy (Battersea Was an Island of Mud Mix)
5  133	05:29 The Grid: Crystal Clear (Clear, Like an Unmuddied Lake)
6  	08:34 Autocreation: Dark Smile
7  106	09:00 Megatonk: Belgium (Deep Space Filter Mix Edit)
8   95	11:20 Material: Mantra (Praying Mantra Mix Edit)

Comments: The second "Excursions in Ambience" from Astralwerks takes us on a
journey into the source, Wau! Mr. Modo.  All the tracks on this disc are from
the label or remixed by Orb.  It is really nice to have the three Orb remixes
of Maurizio, Grid, and Material in one place.  However, I would have rather
seen "Crystal Clear" absent than virtually cut in half with a fade-out.
Keiichi Suzuki's "Satellite Serenade" would have been much slicker in place of
the widely distributed Grid track.  Megatonk's "Belgium" is the bounciest
track on the disc, yet it is sadly edited with another apparent fade-out.  The
other two edits, W.F.O. and Material are done well, but of course, these are
awefully long "edits".  I especially like the W.F.O. track with its Karen
Carpenter samples used in a perfect manner.  The remaining three tracks by
Schizophrenia, Locust, and Autocreation make for dark ambient listening.
"Prospero" is the first track to remind me of the Biosphere "Microgravity"
album.

Summary: 8/10.  Sloppy edits aside, this is a terrific compilation of Wau!
Mr. Modo ambient work.  Things are really looking great for Astralwerks if
they keep digging up music like this for domestic release.


Apollo Compilation
Apollo/R&S: AMB 926 CD
1  133	08:14 Kinetic: Golden Girls (David Morley Remix)
2  117	07:26 Model 500: The Passage
3  125	08:20 David Morley: Evolution
4  	04:54 Biosphere: Cloudwalker
5  115 	04:51 Aphex Twin: X-Tal
6   83	10:30 Atlantis: Paradise (Part 1)
7  115	09:48 Electrotete: I Love You (Orb Remix)
8  142	07:22 David Morley: Calibration
9  112	09:27 Love Craft: Intelligent Universe
10 	06:03 Neuro: Mama (Justin London Mix)

Comments: Apollo seems to know just what my favorite kind of trance is.  Not
too hard n' fast, but not completely ambient as to fall asleep to.  Stir in
just the right amount of beat and rhythm and off I go.  This first comp is a
stellar representation of the label, starting off with the David Morley remix
of Kinetic, which is done so well it is a single in its own right.  David
Morley's other tracks show that this guy is definitely a rising star on the
scene with strong musicality and original ideas.  The Model 500 track is cool,
as is the brilliant Love Craft, along with the dated but strong releases from
Biosphere, Aphex Twin, and Atlantis.  Orb fans should note that the "I Love
You" remix is notably different from the clandestine b-side of "Satellite
Serenade", it is quite a bit cleaner with a stronger emphasis on the beat.
Which one I favor is hard to tell, I love them both.  The last remix of "Mama"
by Justin London is one of the most powerful beatless tracks I've laid ears
on.  It has to be heard to be believed.

Comments: 10/10.  Really a great collection of clean, strong, trance tracks.
R&S really does the compilation game well.

From sfraves-owner  Tue Oct 19 08:52:55 1993
From: laura@soda.berkeley.edu (Laura La Gassa)
Date: Tue, 19 Oct 1993 08:52:47 -0700
Subject: I left my heart in San Francisco
Status: 

Hello!

What a weekend!

I left New Jersey Thursday after work, having seen Alan's mail about YSH 
needing a space.  When I changed planes in Dallas I called the YSH number and 
was saddened to learn the party was off . . . but in a way it was just as well 
for me since it meant I had some extra time to spend with Brian.  Anyway, I 
wish the Sisters' much luck in the future, and hopefully I'll catch them on my 
next trip out (at Thanksgiving).

I really wasn't anticipating the Orb show.  In fact, I had gone so far as to 
tell Brian I'd only go if he bought my ticket . . . upon arriving at the 
Warfield I learned that all under 21's were going to be kicked out at 2.00 am.  
Not being from San Francisco, I had totally forgotten about the STUPID caberet 
rules, and so had not bothered to bring any ID with me since I'd had no plans 
to drive or drink alcoholic beverages.  

When I got to the door and was asked for ID, I said to the guy "look, I know 
you're just doing your job, but I'm 28 but I can't prove it because I left my 
ID at my boyfriend's house.  I just flew in last night from New York and we 
don't have any under-21 rules there so it just didn't ocurr to me to bring it 
with me tonight."  The guy said "well, can you go back to your boyfriend's and 
get it?"  To which I replied "no, he lives in Berkeley," and I turned to walk 
inside.  I was VERY suprised to feel him slip a wrist band on me as I was 
moving.  This made me happy, but it doesn't say much for the Warfield's 
enforcement of the laws -- well, maybe it indicates that some of the people who 
work there also agree that the current law needs to be changed.

Anyway, I thoroughly enjoyed the Orb show.  The lights were the most amazing I 
have ever seen -- and (giggle) I just realized that my "custom-mixed" colors on 
my xterminal at work are about the same shades of green and purple used in the 
show!  I was very pleased to note that the music was quite mixed up compared to 
all the album, single, and alternate versions I have heard.  This is a good 
example of doing techno "live" in my opinion.

The DJ right after the Orb was GREAT.  I was sitting in the balcony watching 
people dance like MAD to TECHNO -- that 130 bpm and higher electronic stuff -- 
and then one of my recent favorites (which I played to death when I was out in 
August) came on.  I started thinking "oh my god oh my god I can't believe I'm 
hearing "Meltdown" at such a big party in San Francisco" and so I rushed 
downstairs to join in.  So who was this DJ?  Was it Lewis who travels with the 
Orb?  Was it Dutch? Or am I just completely confused (which is possible 
considering what the Orb had done to my brain)?

Saturday was pleasant, most of it was spent either sleeping, practicing mixing, 
or listening to Tamara practice.  After a brief stop at Steve's to wish him a 
happy birthday, we headed out to Alameda for Liquid Air.

I was a bit alarmed to see that the parking was completely out in the open,
i.e. a cop or nosey person coming by would immediately notice a bunch of cars 
parked at the edge of the industrial park.  We walked up into the hills and 
decided the spot was beautiful, and when the truck arrived we started unloading 
and trucking the gear up the hill.  We didn't even have the first load halfway 
up the hill when a police car arrived.  We kept going up the hill in the hopes 
that they would let us go on, but there was no joy in Alameda that evening.  
So, we wheeled everthing back downhill and reloaded the truck and decided to go 
to the backup space in Freemont.

As soon as we got to the end of Cushing Parkway and saw the dirt/gravel road 
going off into nowhere, I knew we had found the perfect bust-free spot.  We 
were way off in the salt flats, and as long as it was dark we were invisible.  
And to make matters even better, there was a McDonalds' right by the 880 so I 
knew I'd be able to get breakfast in the morning.

The truck arrived and we got set up and Tamara put down her first record at 
about 1.35 am.  Her set was funky and bouncey, and shortly the party vibe 
became strong.  Chris, a non-net acid DJ Bryce discovered, followed, but I 
spent most of his set napping in Brian's truck because I was still rather dead 
from the Orb the night before.  I was kind of cold when I got started, and 
although I was playing some of my favorite old and new tracks, I just wasn't 
mixing very well and so wasn't very happy with myself.  I guess I just put 
myself under a lot of pressure to perform.  I know Liquid Air is a very "safe" 
environment for new DJs, but still I just really wanted to be "on" for everyone,
especially since my preactice sessions had been going very well.

Jon D. came after me and picked the absolute perfect track to follow my last 
one -- our music choices are generally very different, especially speed-wise, 
but his first record had this really great drony buzz that really complemented 
the last thing I played.  All through the night meteors were seen, and about 
this time Bryce broke out some crossaints to fuel my tired body.  Tamara's 
second set was really neat -- she looked like she was having SO much fun and 
put on all kinds of different records.  I really loved some of her more trancy 
choices.  The Michael Jackson thing was cutely cheezy, not annoying at all.  
Tamara left around 6.30 so she could get some sleep in before driving back to 
Los Angeles, so I took over again and played the 10 slowest records I own :-)  
My goal was to keep the music going until sunrise, and to make sure something 
happy was playing just as the sun broke over the hills.  Around 7.00 or so a 
police car showed up.  I was a bit alarmed but just kept going while Bryce 
talked to the officer.  The officer asked what we were doing, and Bryce told 
him "just listening to music and dancing" to which the officer replied "humm, 
I've never seen anything like this before."  He left, and just as my last slow 
happy record got going (DJ Hell's "My Definition of House Music") the sun rose 
from behind the mountains.  It was so wonderful and beautiful to see it come up,
and to see people smiling and dancing to happy music, that it totally made up 
for my earlier troubles with nerves and the cold.  I want to thank everyone who
was there and shared that perfect moment with me.

Most of all I want to thank Bryce for organizing the party, Ethan for trusting 
us with the sound system, and to the crew who loaded, unloaded, reloaded, 
unloaded, repacked, and ultimately put away the sound gear.

See you all around Thanksgiving . . . I'm really getting to like it a LOT out 
there and I hope that it won't be long before I am there permanently.

Laura

From sfraves-owner  Tue Oct 19 09:39:14 1993
From: Roy Badami <roy@harlequin.co.uk>
Date: Tue, 19 Oct 93 17:38:40 BST
Subject: Re: Deep Doubts 
Status: 


  Niels> What's "gabba"?

Gabba house (or gabber house).... (pronounced garber).

It's another name for Roterdam hardcore.  Really harsh fast techno,
pretty industrial sounding.

[The term is dutch, but i'm unsure of the origin, becaue it's a
non-word....  i wonder whether it equates to "gaga" -- a non word
uttered by babies, and by extension used coloquially to mean "mad"....
Technohead from DJ magazine claims there's a genre of techno called
"fuckin' mental".  I think that just about sums up gabba....]


	Cosmic

From sfraves-owner  Tue Oct 19 10:13:32 1993
From: andy@kingkong.wco.ftp.com  (Andy Nourse)
Date: Tue, 19 Oct 93 10:12:44 PDT
Subject: Re: Dancing and Listening
Status: 

>   Western music is the transition of music from the dance floor to the
>   concert hall. It happened in the time of Louis XIV, it happened with the
>   waltz, it happened with jazz, it even happened at the Fillmore and Winterland
>   with rock: at first, the music is made to dance to. Then, after a while,
>   more and more people just sit or stand it out and listen.

    Dancing is participation.
    Western society has increasingly become a society of spectators.

>   Charlie Mingus, the great jazz bassist, used to say "You can't listen
>   and dance at the same time. So sit down, shut up, don't make noises,
>   and listen to our music!"

    This seems like a very, very odd thing for him to say.
    As a musician, he certainly was able to listen and move with
    the music and "make noises" at the same time,
    otherwise he could only have played solo.

    I can only listen fully to music if I move with it.
    Otherwise my mind wanders.

>   I wonder if the same could happen to techno and/or house? 
>   If you were composing music primarily to be listened to, would you tend
>   to make it more complex than if you were making it solely to danced to?

    You don't have to make it *solely* to be danced to.
    Go ahead and make it more complex.
    I'll dance to it anyway!

                &andy



From sfraves-owner  Tue Oct 19 10:17:24 1993
From: Laura La Gassa <laura@soda.berkeley.edu>
Date: Tue, 19 Oct 93 10:17:16 -0700
Subject: ~Re: Deep Doubts
Status: 

Niels asks:

>What's "gabba"?
>
>Have the Ramones gone techno? :-) Gabba gabba hey!

In a way,  yes.  Imagine applying the Ramones' blinding speed, three
chord style, and rapid-fire lyrics to techno and you have a rough
approximation of "gabber haus" which is hardcore techno for the 
jock-types.  It's fast, it's silly, and when you're in the mood for
a guy screaming in dutch over a distored 909 it's great.

Brian hates the stuff.  I contend that there actually are a few
good gabber records out there . . . humm, maybe next time I'm in
San Francisco I'll shake off my fear of pushing the bpms too high
and go for it.  (Jo, you'd better be there for it, you might be the
only one dancing).

Laura

From sfraves-owner  Tue Oct 19 16:28:05 1993
From: alves@bethe.ucdavis.edu (David Alves)
Date: Tue, 19 Oct 93 16:03:42 PDT
Subject: Mingus
Status: 


>>   Charlie Mingus, the great jazz bassist, used to say "You can't listen
>>   and dance at the same time. So sit down, shut up, don't make noises,
>>   and listen to our music!"

>    This seems like a very, very odd thing for him to say.
>    As a musician, he certainly was able to listen and move with
>    the music and "make noises" at the same time,
>    otherwise he could only have played solo.
>    I can only listen fully to music if I move with it.
>    Otherwise my mind wanders.
>                &andy

So maybe my mind is wandering also, but I think alot of movement a musician
makes while jamming (especially in jazz) is to sorta keep track of stuff
in his head - other instruments or ideas that work and are inspired by
what is happening around him - in his own head at least he gets to play
more than one instrument.  And I don't mean to suggest that it is some
how really logical or calculated.  It is more organic than that.  
More spontaneous.

I think my point here is that the movements a musician makes are different
than the moves a casual/social dancer makes.  The musician is moving as part
of a creation experience and the dancer's situation is more interpretive.
Both are cool, but I think different.  So I don't buy your theory.

I think dancing can be distracting, like driving, or reading, or whatever
Listen with everything you have got.  Listen for something that does not
bore you to fucking tears. Focus.  Listen for something really cool.
I don't think it was such an odd thing to say.
Charlie Mingus will do you right.

Here's why -  there is so much crap music around that you've heard
3000 times as some other song or songs that it is easy to get used
to listening carelessly.  You know what is coming next.  You know the whole
damn song.  It's like you become numb to all the garbage you 
normally hear and you forget that some music deserves more attention.

For example, I was listening to an old John Lee Hooker cd the other
day (pretty non-techno - old blues) and for the first time 
I noticed his foot tapping on some of the really stripped down songs.
It blew me away.  He tapped his foot really well.
Then I started thinking about him and how he had to be recorded on a
stool on a wood floor.  What kind of wood floor did he prefer? 
His foot was maybe a whole band in his head.  It was amazing.
That kind of experience is to me the opposite of the tranced out listening
experience that dancing can help with.  

I don't want to say either is better.
I just think *that* is the kind of listening Charlie Mingus was
talkin about.

Dave

From sfraves-owner  Tue Oct 19 18:02:36 1993
From: Mark Baldwin <Mark_Baldwin@qmgate.Radius.COM>
Date: Tue, 19 Oct 1993 18:01:03 +0000
Subject: RE>Deep Doubts
Status: 

another factor that might confuse some is the fact that
the term hardcore gets used as an synonym of techno, and
(as someone already mentioned) hawdcoah has different
meanings to different people.  a "hardcore rave" in belgium
is most definitely going to feature different music than
it's counterpart in s.f. 

the difference could be extreme, too.  such as: in sf, brian
hosts a hardcore party (just an example ;-) and the music
has elements of very fast hip-hop, whereas in belgium, the
music would sound like what we californians might call 
industrial-dance, or ebm.

i honestly think that techno/ambient/and industrial have a
lot more in common with each other than many seensters are
willing to admit.

-mARK. (Unretouched Photos Prove It)
--------------------------------------
Date: 10/19/93 8:00 AM
To: Mark Baldwin
From: jdrukman%dlsun87 
>Every time I think I have a working definition of the differences between 
>house and techno, somebody throws a wrench in it :).  I thought that 
>house was '70s disco based while techno was the more "electronic" stuff.  
>Anybody have a better working definition?

that's actually not bad.  house definitely had its roots in the
chicago gay/disco scene - nowadays you've got a few major variants but
they're all based on that swing beat.  techno comes from detroit and
started with really minimal dark electronic stuff like cybotron and
mayday - see the recent Transmat label compilation for a quick primer.

the main thing that seems to confuse people is house music vs the
house scene.  the "scene" includes tons of different styles of music -
nowadays you've got garage house, hardtrance, acid, techno, acid jazz
and more on the dance floor.  ambient house is music for chill-out
rooms, and you might find these under the same roof with screaming
pumped-up dance floors.  so ambient in the sense of atmospheric,
relaxing, whatever and house in the sense of "part of the house
scene."  but definitely not connected to house music...


Jon Drukman                                         jdrukman%dlsun87@oracle.
com
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

This calls for a very special blend of psychology and extreme violence.

From sfraves-owner  Tue Oct 19 19:12:02 1993
From: Gioni Pasquinelli <pasque@ucdavis.edu>
Date: Tue, 19 Oct 1993 18:35:31 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: Re: Mingus
Status: 




On Tue, 19 Oct 1993, David Alves wrote:

> So maybe my mind is wandering also, but I think alot of movement a musician
> makes while jamming (especially in jazz) is to sorta keep track of stuff
> in his head - other instruments or ideas that work and are inspired by
> what is happening around him - in his own head at least he gets to play
> more than one instrument.

I just started taking an afro-latin drumming class and I have found that
when I am playing an instrument I dance differently than when I am just
dancing or listening.  A group of about ten people all play at the same
time but on different bells or drums and a different rhythum.  Moving
seems to keep everything organized in my head and I can stay on the beat and
still play my part.  If I don't move around or if I dance too "hard" then I
tend to get lost in all the other instruments and rhythums.  I can still
trance out though with out screwing up.  You just get into the biggest groove
and are entangled in all the sounds.  Everything just flows together into
one.

> 
> I think my point here is that the movements a musician makes are different
> than the moves a casual/social dancer makes.  The musician is moving as part
> of a creation experience and the dancer's situation is more interpretive.
>

The musician's movements are organizing and controlling the beats almost,
atleast in his mind, while a dancer's movements are flowing with the beats.
The musician knows whats coming next and the dancer is just following what
the musician has created.  I guess I could say the musicians moves are much
more structured and purposeful.

Later 
G

From sfraves-owner  Wed Oct 20 07:11:15 1993
From: larryc@netcom.com (Larry Ching)
Date: Wed, 20 Oct 93 7:11:51 PDT
Subject: Player Moves and Dancer Moves
Status: 

> 
> On Tue, 19 Oct 1993, David Alves wrote:
> > 
> > I think my point here is that the movements a musician makes are different
> > than the moves a casual/social dancer makes.  The musician is moving as part
> > of a creation experience and the dancer's situation is more interpretive.
> >
> 
> To which Gioni Pasquinelli wrote:
> The musician's movements are organizing and controlling the beats almost,
> atleast in his mind, while a dancer's movements are flowing with the beats.
> The musician knows whats coming next and the dancer is just following what
> the musician has created.  I guess I could say the musicians moves are much
> more structured and purposeful.
> 

 This only applies to the first time a dancer hears a piece of music. On later
playings , if the dancer has a decent enough memory , the dancer can also
anticipate the changes in the music , and use creative expression with the
body in concert with the music. Informed interpretation and expression 
can be a creative act also , as much as the creation of music.

 When I dance at raves , I like to do play anticipation games with the music.
A lot of the dramatic beatless passages in rave dance music all follow the
same general unwritten rules of duration , dramatic buildup , and other
factors. It's always neat to second-guess the music! 

 Of course , when I dance at a rave , I hope that people aren't watching
me or STARING at me while I'm dancing. I try to keep self-concioussness at
bay , and try to dance for myself , as opposed to what my dancing might
look like to others . I still get self-conciouss while dancing , tho'.

	Larry "Don't:Look At Me!" Ching/larryc@netcom.com
