From sfraves-owner  Wed Oct 20 10:13:10 1993
From: andy@wco.ftp.com  (Andy Nourse)
Date: Wed, 20 Oct 93 10:12:19 PDT
Subject: Re: Mingus
Status: 

>>> Charlie Mingus...used to say "You can't listen and dance at the same time...

>>  As a musician, he certainly was able to listen and move with
>>  the music and "make noises" at the same time...
>>  I can only listen fully to music if I move with it.
>>  Otherwise my mind wanders.

>   So maybe my mind is wandering also, but I think alot of movement a musician
>   makes while jamming (especially in jazz) is to sorta keep track of stuff
>   in his head - other instruments or ideas that work and are inspired by
>   what is happening around him - in his own head at least he gets to play
>   more than one instrument.  And I don't mean to suggest that it is some
>   how really logical or calculated.  It is more organic than that.  
>   More spontaneous.
>   
>   I think my point here is that the movements a musician makes are different
>   than the moves a casual/social dancer makes.  The musician is moving as part
>   of a creation experience and the dancer's situation is more interpretive.

    But hardly what I'd call casual.    

>   I think dancing can be distracting, like driving, or reading...

    Because driving or reading are completely unrelated to the music.
    Dancing, for me, is climbing into the music and exploring it.
    Particularly if I'm dancing to something that I've never heard
    before, and the more complex it is the better.  I don't just dance
    to the beat, I try to dance to *all* of the music.

>   Listen with everything you have got.

    When I'm dancing I do exactly that.  I listen with my whole body and mind.

>   Focus.

    There is a widely-held belief that to really focus, you must be perfectly
    still.  Most forms of meditation teach you to do it that way, you're told
    to be still and listen when in school, etc. etc..  This obviously works
    for a lot of people.  I've tried it.  It doesn't work for me.  Motion does.

>   I don't want to say either is better.
>   I just think *that* is the kind of listening Charlie Mingus was
>   talkin about.

    I think that's the kind of listening that I do, when the music is good
    enough.  (I like jazz too, by the way, and have been listening to it,
    [and dancing to it] long before there was such a thing as techno).
    
    This is a fascinating discussion.

                                        &andy

From sfraves-owner  Wed Oct 20 11:07:00 1993
From: Arthur Chandler <arthurc@sfsuvax1.sfsu.edu>
Date: Wed, 20 Oct 1993 11:04:39 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: Re: Mingus and More
Status: 


  The best way to experience music is to PLAY IT -- to have is course
through your fingers and up through your lungs (I'm a flutist), to feel
yourself in sync and in pitch with the people you're playing with and the
people you're playing for.
 But for listening -- surely there is no "best way" to get into the music.
It can be solitary and almost studious -- that's the way I listen to Bach
fugues. Or it can be exuberant and a "throw your hands up in the air" type
of experience. Some folks like to dance to techno. I like to juggle to it.
But I also like to listen to house and techno while I'm conversing with
folks Real Time on the NET. And -- is this just my generation? -- I like
some techno for driving the car. Yeah! The road can have a rhythm, and if
you can find the right music to go with navigating it, then that's a
musical trip too.
  Does anyone else out here do stuff other than dancing while you're
listening to techno -- listening not as a distraction, but as an energizer
and mood-setter for the activity?





From sfraves-owner  Wed Oct 20 11:15:29 1993
From: bbehlen@soda.berkeley.edu (Brian Behlendorf)
Date: Wed, 20 Oct 1993 11:15:05 -0700
Subject: Re: Mingus
Status: 

On Oct 20, 10:12am, Andy proclaimed:
} >   I think dancing can be distracting, like driving, or reading...
}   Because driving or reading are completely unrelated to the music.
}   Dancing, for me, is climbing into the music and exploring it.
}   Particularly if I'm dancing to something that I've never heard
}   before, and the more complex it is the better.  I don't just dance
}   to the beat, I try to dance to *all* of the music.

Actually, my *ideal* listening environ, where I can concentrate and
feel the music MOST, is playing video games, with the headphones on.
Being alone in a car comes a close second.  Both activities allow me
to put certain cerebral activities on auto-pilot and devote 100% of my
concentration power on the music (better make that, driving down the 5
freeway :) Dance is a not-too-distant third, but it seems to be hard
for me to keep up sometimes; I feel every part of my body when I'm
dancing and a lot of my concentration energy gets focused on that,
plus I'm also constantly concerned about the people I brought or know
at the party having a good time that I neglect myself.  Certain
chemicals can change this, of course; but those bring a whole
different mindset along with them anyways.

Why video games?  I dunno... it especially works with the very
symbolic ones like tetris or pong... maybe it's that my left brain 
needs something to do so my right brain can enjoy the music :)

	Brian


----------------------------------------------------------------------

showed Drug Abuse Resistance Education to be mostly ineffective]
flawed and not comprehensive: "Scientists, will tell you bumble bees
can't fly, but we know they can."

  Arthur> And -- is this just my generation? -- I like some techno for

In my experience, most ravers listen to techno in the car.  Or at
pretty much *any* other time, for that matter...

Even sitting at home chilling after a hard night's raving, listening
to techno (rather than ambient)

I think if you like a particular genre of music, you don't tend to
restrict when you listen to it, but can find it appropriate in pretty
much any situation.  I would claim this is universal, and not specific
to techno.


	Cosmic

From sfraves-owner  Wed Oct 20 11:41:55 1993
From: "Golden Boy" <deb9@thor.INS.CWRU.Edu>
Date: Wed, 20 Oct 93 14:35:48 CST
Subject: Re: Mingus and More
Status: 

On Wed, 20 Oct 1993 11:04:39 -0700 (PD, Arthur Chandler wrote:

>  Does anyone else out here do stuff other than dancing while you're
>listening to techno -- listening not as a distraction, but as an energizer
>and mood-setter for the activity?

HEY kidz...this is where i jump in...as a martial artist training can be 
exceptionally strenuous...it requires a great deal of concentration and 
energy...and the thought of trying to dredge up that much energy (it is 
there, even when it doesn't feel like it) can almost deter me from actually 
training.  

BUT...punching in techno motivates the hell out of me...the music takes me 
away and i ride the groove...ignorant of my energy levels...and you can't 
train slowly to something thats infusing your system with digitized 
adrenaline at 140bmp+...you end up matching your tempo of training to the 
tempo of the music...the only drawback is when I stop training and stop the 
music...I'm usually exceptionally drained...like removing a turbo booster 
so you can push the car home :)

I also jam my ass off when I write code at work...MAJOR motivator.

peace.
+++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++
<<GOLDEN BOY.CYBERTRIBE>>                             deb9@pop.cwru.edu
              

             "Elvis has left the building...permanently"

From sfraves-owner  Wed Oct 20 14:17:55 1993
From: JUMP IN THE FIRE <grigsby@agames.com>
Date: Wed, 20 Oct 93 11:49:32 PDT
Subject: dancing
Status: 


I can only dance to music inasmuch as I know beforehand or assume enough 
about the rhythm to flow with it and not feel as though I'm being dragged
along behind it.

Techno/house/funk gives you that straight 4 no matter what happens, so
I can let the bass spin me around without thinking on any level about
losing the beat even if I have never heard the tune before, which is
most of the time.

Jazz is harder -- much of it is straight rhythm but this is not always
true.  Often it's too fast for me to move in a familiar way, so I have
to know the music better in order to find a way that I can move inside
it -- which may mean just tapping my feet or nodding my head.

Classical is the hardest -- the rhythm almost never settles, so you
almost have to choreograph unless you know the piece very well.  Too
much effort for me.  Some people enjoy dancing as a rigorous
intellectual exercise; I enjoy it as "fun with my body" or a trance
state.

Given all this, I don't think rAvE t00nz should be either simpler or
more complex.  If those two measures and a break move me for six
minutes, that's all I need.  If the tone slowly modulates over time
with twenty different undercurrents swirling around the beat and that
moves me, that's great too, but fast cuts are no substitute for a good
groove.

// g

From sfraves-owner  Wed Oct 20 14:59:59 1993
From: Randy Tinkerman <rmt@well.sf.ca.us>
Date: 	Wed, 20 Oct 1993 14:58:56 -0700
Subject: musicianship vs. DJ'ing
Status: 


jdrukman says:

>DJ'ing is better.  Having been in my share of bands, I find that i'm
>usually too busy trying to concentrate on playing to actually 
>enjoy the experience.

Sheesh!  that probably holds true for garage level musicianship or          
equivilent, but is shear crap for true musicians.  Once you can play well   
enough that the music is coming thru you without much thought, or any       
thought, the level of enjoyment is a least the same as DJ'ing, if not
infinitely greater.

without dissing DJ'ing, or its gift of joy & exstasy to so many, i find it
hard to believe anyone would really think this....unless they just didn't
want to, or couldn't, make the tremendous effort necessary to reach that
stage of proficiency, a la Mingus, that true professionals reach rather
easily.

alpha

From sfraves-owner  Wed Oct 20 15:29:43 1993
From: Charles Blair <chas@stax.lib.uchicago.edu>
Date: Wed, 20 Oct 1993 17:30:50 -0500
Subject: Re: musicianship vs. DJ'ing 
Status: 

>> i find it
>> hard to believe anyone would really think this....unless they just didn't
>> want to, or couldn't, make the tremendous effort necessary to reach that
>> stage of proficiency, a la Mingus, that true professionals reach rather
>> easily.

I find it a bit odd, also. Whether it's easy to reach or not (there
seems to be a contradiction between "tremendous effort ... a la
Mingus" and "true professionals reach [it] rather easily," unless it
means that true professionals reach it rather easily on stage once
they've made the tremendous effort to achieve proficiency over the
years), I'm fascinated by the statement of at least one well-known
musician in print recently that he's experienced another (non-human)
presence on stage with him, the "ghostly other." What a trip.


From sfraves-owner  Wed Oct 20 16:13:50 1993
From: csc@pilot.njin.net (Sean Casey)
Date: Wed, 20 Oct 93 19:13:44 EDT
Subject: musicianship vs. DJ'ing
Status: 

Randy Tinkerman writes:

 > Sheesh!  that probably holds true for garage level musicianship or          
 > equivilent, but is shear crap for true musicians.  Once you can play well   
 > enough that the music is coming thru you without much thought, or any       
 > thought, the level of enjoyment is a least the same as DJ'ing, if not
 > infinitely greater.
 > 
 > without dissing DJ'ing, or its gift of joy & exstasy to so many, i find it
 > hard to believe anyone would really think this....unless they just didn't
 > want to, or couldn't, make the tremendous effort necessary to reach that
 > stage of proficiency, a la Mingus, that true professionals reach rather
 > easily.

It may be true for you, but it is not true for everyone. Either that,
or my musician and DJ friends are lying :).

I've known quite a few very good musicians and I'm getting to know
quite a few DJs. With one or two exceptions, the DJs are having a
whole lot more fun.

Just because something is intrinsically more difficult does not
automatically make it more rewarding. Many of my musician friends
would rather have some killer sex than a killer jam session.

This reminds me of: You might ask if computers make creating music
easy, will the music be better or worse. Most people shoot from the
hip and say "worse".  But who knows, it might be better. Some
incredibly creative people who don't want to study an instrument for 7
years might be enabled to bring us some wonderful stuff.

Finally, I think DJing is a tremendously creative process. You're
taking thousands of bits of sound, and putting them together to create
a spontansous experience. The mechanics are easily learned, but the
creativity and expression are what make it.

Sean

(If you want dues, consider the hours and money a DJ spends getting
good music.)

From sfraves-owner  Wed Oct 20 16:31:26 1993

interesting you should mention the "coming thru you without much
thought" - this is what used to be referred to as The Muse.  i never
had The Muse speaking through me when I was in my multitude of bands.
i have heard The Muse while writing music and DJing though.  it's a
very strange trance state where "i" takes a vacation and something
else is working in its place.

as for any qualitative difference between muse-influenced DJ'ing,
composing or performing... i dunno bout that one.  i think you just
wanted to take a cheap shot at me.  good thing i'm too mature to sink
to your level of baiting.

	I think this hold true for drumming-- even amatuer-level. When
I see a drum circle, and I have my drum with me, it is WONDERFUL,
because I can join the experience, and be *INSIDE* the music.
Wonderful. If I haven't my drum, I either scrounge for one, or it's
not as much fun. (Yes, it's great, but not as wonderful as actually
being within and an active part instead of just dancing and having
themusic outside of me.

From sfraves-owner  Wed Oct 20 18:37:47 1993
From: Raul Gilbert MinaMora <tow@well.sf.ca.us>

Subject: Re:  musicianship vs. DJ'ing
Status: 


It seems to me that if DJing works best for Jon so be it.
Why should that have any bearing on ones ability as a musician
or on achieving musicianship whether in the garage or the
concert hall? With all due respect to those who play instruments
(why some of my best friends play instruments :-) ;-) &+
these days a musician doesn't have to play an instrument,
visual artists don't need to bother with brushs or learning
to draw to create terrific work. I'm musicaly naive but my
understanding of musicianship is that it is a level to be
achieved, to some it may come easily others will have to work
hard and that it can vary from night to night for everyone.           

Gil

From sfraves-owner  Wed Oct 20 20:10:36 1993
From: mcorwine@comtch.iea.com
Date: Wed, 20 Oct 93 20:06:20 PDT
Subject: ideal listening environs
Status: 

I read somewhere that techno and speed metal were ideal for quick 
exercise such as sprinting and whatnot, but not for endurance exercise... 
I tried biking 20 miles listening to a relatively hard mix tape a few 
years ago and it didn't work all that well...

I also find techno ideal driving music as well, good to keep your mind 
off the monotony of the road and on the monotony of the music :) 

Personally, I love techno/house/acid on the dancefloor and living room 
floor best... Morning, noon, and night, asleep and awake, live or dead... 

It's hard to dance in my neck of the woods, as the crowds here are really 
into the glamorous aspects of dancing (ie. mating ritual, fashion runway) 
and I find dancing to be a personal activity.  However, I often find this 
intense personal experience more at raves here in Spokane, WA than those 
I have attended in Seattle... Hopefully when I join you nice people 
someday in SF I will experience more of the intense simultaneous oneness 
w/self and oneness with others I tasted at Evolution etc.

Matt.

From sfraves-owner  Thu Oct 21 08:20:49 1993
From: Charles Blair <chas@stax.lib.uchicago.edu>
Date: Thu, 21 Oct 1993 10:21:54 -0500
Subject: Re: musicianship vs. DJ'ing 
Status: 

>> Who's the "well-known musician", then....?

The guy who played bass for the Jefferson Airplane, except I can never
remember his name without looking at it, and I don't have the source
handy: a recent Bass Player magazine interview. Well-known enough
among bass players to get interviewed, anyway. :-) (At least, I'm
pretty sure it was he and not Jack Bruce who said it; both were
interviewed in the same issue.)

It seems this thread might degenerate into DJing vs. playing. Not
really the point, I think. Many forms of art lend themselves to
"channelling the muse." There's that passage at the beginning of the
Iliad where Homer is about to recite the list of the Greek ships who
went to Troy, and says something like (again, no source handy): I, a
human, could not possibly remember all of what I'm about to say, but
you, O Muse, who remembers everything, speak. (Again, this might be a
really bad paraphrase of the original, but it's close enough for the
point I want to make.) Then Homer launches on this long list of ships,
where they came from, who manned them, etc. 

Now, by Homer's time invoking the muse might have been a trope, but I
bet that in the oral tradition to which long poems like the Iliad
belong (by the way, Homer subscribed to the "tyranny of the beat," as
did Shakespeare in his sonnets and lots of other poets; sometimes the
"tyranny" of a style, in this case, a rhythmic or metric style, is a
boost to creativity, not a dampener), I bet that those tribal bards
really didn't believe they had conscious access to or could store a
lot of the information they could relate, and attributed what they
could do to a transcendental force. (The Odyssey begins, Speak to me,
O Muse, of a man ...) 

In short, I don't think the point is about this or that way to get
there. For me the interesting point is what the "there" might be. If
it's calling forth something you didn't know you had, or had access
to, if it's transcending the _boredom_ of the same old thing, the same
old tired experiences, the "is that all there is?" of a (tired) old
pop song, whether it's through dancing, or DJing, or playing the sax
(a la Coltrane, another musician dude with spiritual leanings), or
drumming, or writing some code that you didn't know you had it in you
to write, for me (and that's my $0.02) that's the interesting
thing. (The Greeks had a muse for dancing, and for other things as
well.) The rest is style wars, (self-)image wars, fashion wars,
opinion wars, and all the rest of that ego stuff. People like Homer
must have been at times totally awed and humbled by their art (the
fact that a goddess could speak through them), rather than
ego-tripping on it. In some sense, they must have been "ecstatic"
(literally, standing beside or outside oneself, `withdrawal of the
soul from the body, mystic or prophetic trance'--Oxford English
Dictionary). I view the "self" beside which one steps here as the ego;
I approach raving as something I don't want to do either with my ego,
or without my ego. I want enough of my ego there to bring something
back with me from the experience, but I don't want the ego to
dominate, so that what I'm experiencing is the same old thing. The ego
has to be side-by-side with the rest of me, and part of the experience
is to discover what the rest of "me" is.




From sfraves-owner  Thu Oct 21 08:49:08 1993
From: PLUI@IOSSVR.gm.hac.com
Date: Thu, 21 Oct 93 08:48:53 PDT
Subject: Front Page of Canada's National Newspaper (longish rave article)
Status: 

hullo, I finally got to use a scanner! here's the goods:

COVER STORY - GLOBE and MAIL -
Sat, Oct. 9 1993 (Canada) 

They only come out at night - Rave on the rise: Is the underground selling its 
soul?  
article by Charlotte Parsons (Globe and Mail Montreal)
------------------------------------------------------------------------

Between the bank and the hair salon, Alice gyrates in a cloud of glowing 
violet. A bearded man spins past her through the mist. He is wearing a purple 
tie-dyed dress; strands of pearls swing from his neck.  Alice remains unfazed. 
She knows what to expect after stepping through the looking glass into rave 
country.  The moment she walked into Place Newman, an otherwise ordinary 
Montreal shopping mall, she entered a dreamscape of shifting colours, throbbing 
music and outlandish attire.

Laser-lit and music-powered, the underground dance culture known as rave has 
escaped the grey backdrop of its industrial British birthplace. Now, young 
people from Hong Kong to Moscow are flocking to secretive surrealistic parties 
known for their creativity and their size. One in London drew an ardent crowd 
estimated at 30,000.

To the true believer, rave is more than just a label for an all-night dance 
marathon held in some unlikely location, such as an airport hangar, library or 
flea market. It is an alternative Lifestyle that allows its adherents to shed 
the bonds of daily existence for a Saturday-night extravaganza cloaked in 
fantasy and anonymity.
Rave 'has its own music, its own dress code, its own ethos. 
And has a dark side.

Next to Alice, a young woman with ribbons in her ponytails and Tweetybird on 
her skirt suddenly stops dancing, unzips her plastic Care Bears backpack and 
extricates a jar of Vick's VapoRub. She smears a dot below each nostril, zips 
the bag back up and resumes her frenetic dance.
She is less likely to have a cold than to be in the throes of ecstasy the 
street name for the drug that has come to be associated with rave culture. Its 
effects are reputedly heightened by the aromatic cold remedy.

Much confusion surrounds ecstasy, which is known to science as 
methylenedioxymethamphetamine.

The drug is often described by its initials, MDMA. No one is really sure 
whether to call it an amphetamine, a designer drug or a psychedelic. But it is 
surely illegal, which is why, in addition to high energy and great joy, most 
raves now feature a police presence.

The rave adventure begins with a phone call. The location is always kept secret 
until about 12 hours in advance, that's when a message appears on the 
organizers' phone line telling those who are mobile where to go which could be 
any place large and rentableand those who are not where to find the fleet of 
chartered buses that will take them there.

A crowd has already formed around a row of yellow school buses as Alice arrives 
at the preordained downtown street corner. In her checkerboard sunglasses, neon 
rubber earrings and plastic orange necklace, she blends in perfectly,. Hats 
straight from the pages of Dr. Seuss bob above the crowd. A teen-aged girl 
sporting braids and a flower-covered velvet bonnet swaps jokes with a young 
oriental man in a striped top hat.

In regular life, Alice is a student of anthropology, and she now finds herself 
standing between two interesting subjects: a man with blue hair and a teen-aged 
boy wearing a propeller-topped ball cap. Unable to resist she spins the prop, 
whose owner turns and smiles. Then the doors of the first bus open and she is 
swept aboard .

Bizarre costume is central to the rave lifestyle, and the rising demand for the 
elements of a bold visual statement has spawned a network of suppliers. Among 
them is XStatic, a shop just off Toronto's hip Queen Street West strip where a 
videotape of a recent rave flickers across a TV screen over the cash register.

The merchandise on offer ranges from ravewear (such as striped, floppy hats and 
form-fitting bodices) to cassettes featuring techno, the new, largely 
computerized music that drives the dancers. Lining the back wall and free for 
the taking are an array of underground publications on the latest in music and 
party trends.

One of the papers is called Tribe, and Mychol Holtman who writes its "Wazup" 
column, offers this theory to explain why rave has become such a magnet for 
restless youth since emerging from Liverpool and Manchester.
"It can be summed up in one word: unity," he says, arguing that ravers "are 
reacting to the 'me, me, me: forget everyone else' attitude of the seventies 
and eighties. "

Mr. Holtman feels that young people are increasingly depressed by their lot in 
life, by the fact that so many of them are heading straight from high school to 
the unemployment line. The rave "vibe" provides an antidote, he says. "They 
reassure each other that there is hope and love out there. "

This analysis strikes a chord with Dave, a Toronto rave producer who agrees to 
speak only if his last name is withheld. (Secrecy is a rave watchword.)

"There's no work. Kids are depressed. With the rave scene, they can go out and 
have a good time and forget about their problems," he says, adding that the 
experience can also benefit young people from unstable homes. "That sense of 
family is there for people who lack it. I think they get a lot of love and 
affection in the rave scene.".

Such sentiments, especially combined with psychedelic lights and wild costumes, 
not to mention drugs, may sound familiar to those who remember the hippie era. 
"It's a total peace movement," confirms Dave. "It's the same thing as the 
sixties. "

Canadian rave got its start two years ago with four techno-starved British 
expatriates. Over coffee at a Toronto cafe, disc jockey and rave producer Sean 
L recalls that they "were basically just looking for a place to go ourselves, 
because there was nothing here. "
Given their common background and affection for the music of Bob Marley, the 
four adopted the name Exodus, planned their first rave and distributed several 
hundred flyers in downtown bars to advertise it.

To their amazement, about 400 people showed up for the debut. It was an 
embryonic outing, far less elaborate than those to follow, but the novices 
responded to a mood and music unknown even in the avantgarde clubs many of them 
frequented. "I don't suppose there was one person there who didn't go home 
thinking, 'Wow, that was something else,' " Sean says.
Thus encouraged, Exodus began to arrange weekly raves, and soon other 
production groups emerged. As it grew in popularity, rave began to spread, 
popping up from Halifax to Vancouver. To its devotees, Saturday nights would 
never be the same.

The doors of Place Newman open just as the bus pulls up to unload its youthful 
cargo. On the way in, Alice is frisked for weapons and drugs by a woman wearing 
a puffy pseudo-fur I coat, orange bandanna and the special sneakers favored  by 
Montreal ravers. (They've been elevated several inches by a stack of extra no 
less .)

She surrenders her $15 ticket and sprints toward the heart of the mall, pausing 
where the rave merchants have set up shop. One table is labeled "Toys" and 
covered with glowing whistles and plastic troll dolls. The other overflows with 
lollipops and chewing gum.
She selects two miniature boxes of gum (50 cents), tips their cargo into her 
mouth and heads down the corridor as colored spotlights sway back and forth 
overhead, dragging circular puddles of purple across the floor.

Then the music takes hold of her.

The music of rave comes in several forms, with "techno" and "house" the best 
known. Asked to describe them, Sean says that house is " mellower, slowera bit 
more rhythmatic," while techno is harder and faster, "more abrasive, I guess." 
It has an extra 50 or 60 beats a minute, features a very heavy bass line and 
sparse vocals, and "it's always very loudthe louder the better. "

RAVE may be a British export but its music was born in the U.S.A. House 
appeared first, taking shape in Chicago dance clubs in the early eighties and 
mutating into techno after it hit Detroit. Not that the mutation has stopped. 
The sound changes so rapidly that disc jockeys,
dedicated to staying abreast of the latest trends, are often
bigger stars than the performers they play.

They cultivate a personal style captured on cassettes sold with their names on 
the label. A rave is a 'one off' occasion," explains Dave Crook, a Toronto disc 
jockey originally from Manchester, "and the only way they can describe what 
kind of music there's going to be is by putting the deejay's name on itit's 
like putting the band names on a concert flyer. 

The beat buffets Alice's body as green light scribbles across her face and 
glowing bars of neon criss-cross in time to the music. Fog rolls outward from 
the speaker laden stage in front of the Brico hardware store, and multicoloured 
ceiling lights stain the mist green, red, yellow and blue.

Suddenly, the colour vanishes as blinding sheets of white light stutter across 
the smoke, cutting Alice's dance movements to photo stills. Then she is plunged 
back into colour-slashed dark.
Rave electrician Neil Robertson says that many of these cosmic laser effects 
are done with mirrors. "They can project light onto mirrors, which create a 3-D 
image in the room. The mirrors are really small, maybe five inches, and can be 
used to make the image of maybe a pyramid. "
"Laser animation" is another rave specialty. A moving image of laser light is 
projected against the wall, and that's something you don't see in the clubs, " 
he says.

At Place Newman, lasers are being used to create illusory tunnels and surfaces. 
A ceiling of luminous green bars shoots out from the stage, just above the 
heads of the dancers. Then the flat surface appears to contract, transforming 
itself into a green-spoked spinning wheel.
According to Alice, there is method to this laser madness. "I think that, 
visually, raves are setup to enhance the experience of being on psychedelics 
she explains "although I do know a lot of people who don't use drugs who go 
just for the experience of being around people
who are free and happy. "

Of those who have chosen to indulge, many are on ecstasy, which is a variant of 
the sixties a love drug" MDA and the intoxicant of choice for ravers from 
London to San Francisco.

However, the growing attention being paid to ecstasy angers rave organizer 
Dave. "There are a million kids out there who come to these things who don't 
even do drugs, " he contends. "They come for the music." His brows knit in 
frustration. 
"If I could extricate drugs from the scene, I would. But can the Grateful Dead 
get the drugs out of their concerts? So why don't we disallow the Dead?"
 
"When I see a 17-year-old kid who's wrecked, I get upset. I really do. But I 
take care of these kids. And that's a lot more than I can say for those [rock] 
concerts."

ALICE is not on drugs, but after an hour of dancing she is certainly thirsty. 
She escapes the laser kaleidoscope and weaves through the crowd toward a heavy 
black curtain. As she slips past it, black lighting turns the white stripes of 
her dress electric mauve, and she arrives at the "smart bar. "

A woman in a black bodice is tending three blenders housing "smart 
drinks"liquids in cheery shades of red, orange and green. "They're made with 
amino acids, fruit and caffeine," she explains while pouring Alice's selection, 
raspberry, into a plastic cup. "They give you an energy boost. "

Across from the bar, an empty shop has been converted into the "chill-out 
lounge." Young people sit cross-legged in the light of a single candle, as a 
stereo set next to a tangled heap of pink and blue neon tubing emits music 
totally unlike the pounding techno on the other
side of the curtain.	

Called "ambient", it features a soft beat and keyboard	
washes that create an oasis for the bass-weary The smell
of clove cigaettes and hashish is in the air.

By 4 a.m. Alice has spent whatever energy her smart drink had provided. 
Exhausted, she manoeuvres through the crowd and out the door. She is struck by 
the sudden quiet as she steps back into the grey-black reality of the parking 
lot. 

A police cruiser sits idling, as its occupants gaze at the mall with apparent 
boredom. The two policemen have a long wait ahead. They've been assigned to 
watch over the party until it wraps upin another four hours. Bidding the 
officers good night, Alice boards the bus that will take her back downtown. 
Across the parking lot, a second bus pulls up with a fresh crop of costumed 
youth. For them, the night is just beginning.

Lately, the police have taken a passive approach to rave control. "When we find 
out about a rave party, then we'll monitor them says Detective
Sergeant Craig Hilborn of the Metro Toronto force's drug unit. "The main 
concern we have is the age of the participants and the possible use of illicit 
drugs."

He says there is little of the violence that would cause a policing problem. In 
fact, a rave in May did end in serious violence, but not at the instigation of 
its participants. Video footage of the Montreal force shutting down festivities 
at the Palais du Commerce show police in riot gear beating party-goers with 
nightsticks.

Yet, the future of rave may be in doubt. If anything, the phenomenon may fall 
victim to its own success.

In recent months, rave has left its underground birthplace and percolated into 
the mainstream. Fully aware of what happened to disco, punk and all the other 
subterranean movements that made this journey, hardcore ravers are growing 
disillusioned.

Popularity breeds commercialism, and the purists have become skeptical as 
second-generation competitors appear in the marketplace.
"The sole purpose of a lot of these people is just simply to make a killing, " 
complains Sean L. "I think what happened is, people saw what was going onfour 
or five hundred people dancingand thought, 'Hey, I could do that!' But to 
throw a rave you have to understand what it is; what the vibe is. "

At a recent event staged by Atlantis, one of the newcomers in Toronto, 
representatives of Chemistry, an early arrival, handed patrons their 
resignationslaminated cards that read: "The scene has gone commercial been 
bastardized and generally gotten f----d up. That's why we've reluctantly 
decided to pack it all in.... "

As the parties move away from their underground dance roots, Sean says, there 
is less emphasis on the music, and more on a carnival atmosphere with games and 
toys. For example, the Atlantis production featured a maze, a game of ring toss 
and a giant blow-up castle with a bouncy floor.

This is rave packaged by businessmen in their 30s, he says, and their target 
market is no longer the inner-city crowd who started it all. "They're appealing 
mostly to high-school kids from the suburbs. 

The pioneers fear that in losing its clandestine nature, rave may lose the key 
ingredient to its continued good health. They may not have to wait long to find 
out whether they're right.

This month's schedule in Toronto demonstrates just how quickly rave is losing 
its low profile. Atlantis is planning to hold one at the CN Tower, the tallest 
free-standing structure in the world.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

From sfraves-owner  Thu Oct 21 09:24:08 1993
From: crunch@netcom.com (John Draper)
Date: Thu, 21 Oct 93 09:24:40 -0700
Subject: dancing and listening to techno
Status: 

Vivian comments:

>I love to listen to techno while riding the stationary bike at the 
>gym or the stairmaster, but it is especially motivating while lifting 
>weights.  I also have  a friend that teaches aerobics. She coordinates 
>some of her steps to certain techno songs. It really is motivating.

Same here,  but I prefer the faster 150+ bpm stuff,  and doing a complete 
45 minute tape side on a stairmaster at 150+ BPM is perfect,  but finding
tapes at that speed is kinda hard.   Which brings me to another question,
Where can I get tapes of more faster techno...   I think I have graduated
from the slower 120+ BPM stuff.    Probably why I have so much energy...

Listening to Tecno while coding is GREAT,  as long as I don't have to
go and turn the tape over every 45 mins.  Thats why I got DMX.

But after raving,  while going from the rave to Boogie Buffet,  I listen
to KKSF (Ambient) to "chill out" and give my head a rest from the constant
"boom boom" which often lingers in my head for several hours after a rave.

CC

It was really incredibly good. Better than last week.  
I arrived a little before 10:30 and the place was dead.  I left and 
came back at about 11 and it had started to pick up . I think the 
line up went something like Loren, Harry Who and then Tony finished 
it up.(please correct me if I am wrong)  Tony, this new DJ, was really 
good.  I have not danced like that for a long time but let me tell 
you by the end of the night I was exhausted. I was feeling like i 
should go home being that I have to work at 8:30, but my feet would 
not let me walk toward the door, the music was that good.  Tony even got to play 
till about 2:20 or so.  A friend remarked at how even the crowd was friendly. 
I would highly recommend checking it out if you want to get out on 
Wednesday nights.  I even saw some non South Bay sfraves out there 
seeming to have a good time. 


See ya there next week,

I like to ski to techno, preferably on recently groomed packed powder
terrain so i can beat-match my schwing with da music. For more varied
terrain, I listen to Rare Groove, Funk, Reggae, and/or Dub. A few years
ago, I found myself up to my thighs in luscious Utah powder and found my
tape with the "Neville Brothers" on one side and "the Meters" on the other
was just right.

I find that it really helps me cut loose on the slopes, makes skiing more
like dancing.

PS: "We don' need no steenkin' snowboards!" :-)

From sfraves-owner  Thu Oct 21 10:17:45 1993
From: "Niels P. Mayer" <mayer@netcom.com>
Date: Thu, 21 Oct 93 10:18:03 -0700
Subject: Re: Front Page of Canada's National Newspaper (longish rave article) 
Status: 


> This month's schedule in Toronto demonstrates just how quickly rave is losing 
> its low profile. Atlantis is planning to hold one at the CN Tower, the tallest 
> free-standing structure in the world.

Yowsa! Although truly overground, I think the visuals at the top deck of
the CN Tower would be quite spectacular! And you could get turned into a
human popsicle by going outside to the chill-out-room-cum-observation deck.
It makes me ill thinking about how cool it would be to watch the sun rise
from that height.

Another thing I liked about Toronto is the cultural diversity. Lots of East
and West Indian culture, and some of the best food in the universe. The
culture diversity is also echoed in the music -- lots of reggae, and a
strong "Bhangra" scene there as well. I'd sure like to see a Bhangra rave
in SF, but nobody has even heard of it here.

If it weren't so bitter cold all the time, might even be a nice place to
live!

From sfraves-owner  Thu Oct 21 10:28:35 1993

> So will the Aphex/Orbital/Moby show be on par with the recent Orb show?

As far as a "show" goes, I would guess not.  I saw Orbital last year,
and although the music was great, I felt myself getting bored 1/2 way
through their set.  When I go out dancing, I'm used to a bit more
sonic variety than a set of Orbital could offer.  And there was no
visual element to speak of, which was the best thing about the Orb 
show IMO.

I haven't seen Moby or A.T. live, but I haven't heard anything positive
about Moby's performance.  If I go, it would be mainly for A.T. 

- leg of eel

Yup.  YAP will be at the Orbital/Aphex Twin/Moby show too, BTW.


> early twitch releases) is from the movie "Videodrome" -- I accidently
> caught that truly weird movie on cable one night and recognized a lot of
> the dialog from that song. Oh, I think Deborah Harrie (aka Blondie) was the
> actress that spoke most of the lines.
> 

Videodrome is one of the coolest pieces of art ever crafted by man :-)

It's heavily sampled by Front 242 and many other bands.

From sfraves-owner  Thu Oct 21 10:46:58 1993
From: dionf@ERE.UMontreal.CA (Francois Dion)
Date: Thu, 21 Oct 1993 13:42:12 -0400 (EDT)
Subject: Re: Front Page of Canada's National Newspaper (longish rave article)
Status: 

Beyond the ultraworld of PLUI@iossvr.gm.hac.com:
> 
> hullo, I finally got to use a scanner! here's the goods:

Dont believe the hype. Here's the real story.

> COVER STORY - GLOBE and MAIL -
> Sat, Oct. 9 1993 (Canada) 
> article by Charlotte Parsons (Globe and Mail Montreal)
> ------------------------------------------------------------------------
>She knows what to expect after stepping through the looking glass into rave 
>country.  The moment she walked into Place Newman, an otherwise ordinary 
>Montreal shopping mall, she entered a dreamscape of shifting colours,throbbing 
>music and outlandish attire.

That's an old rave... and it was a very lame one too.

[lots of cliches deleted - you will find that in any rave article]
>Rave 'has its own music, its own dress code, its own ethos. 

Dress code? True grungewear seems to be pretty much there (20% of the people)
but is not rave related at all. I see much more grungewear at pearl jam
concerts... In many case most people dont give a damn and wear what they want
to wear. BTW, grungewear is another media creation...

> And has a dark side.

yep. darkness breakbeat! :P

>Next to Alice, a young woman with ribbons in her ponytails and Tweetybird on 
>her skirt suddenly stops dancing, unzips her plastic Care Bears backpack and 
>extricates a jar of Vick's VapoRub. She smears a dot below each nostril, zips 
>the bag back up and resumes her frenetic dance.

People who take x knows what to do not do. That is take lots of water and do
not dance too much. Do you really think she was on x? If she is, somebody
please tell her the facts... It's that time once again for MDMA facts flyers.

>She is less likely to have a cold than to be in the throes of ecstasy the 
>street name for the drug that has come to be associated with rave culture.

She is more likely to not be on ecstasy. There is just so little that makes its
way in Montreal. Xers are far less than 10% of the crowd. I'd even say less
than 5%.

>The drug is often described by its initials, MDMA. No one is really sure 
>whether to call it an amphetamine, a designer drug or a psychedelic. But it is 
>surely illegal, which is why, in addition to high energy and great joy, most 
>raves now feature a police presence.

Bullshit. Most cops dont even know what X is. They still think there is acid in
smart drinks, that alcohol is served illegally in raves, that people dance
buck naked and mostly they bust events because of the club protection by the
mafia who still influences greatly the cops. Small events are no threat to the
clubs, so they go on unbusted (except for Bug and jam events - they sure dont
have their shit together). If it had anything to do with a real concern about
drugs, they'd bust the smaller ones too (which are quite easy to find too).

>The rave adventure begins with a phone call.The location is always kept secret 
>until about 12 hours in advance,

That's 24 hours of course, and secondly up to 1 week before the rumor has made
it's way in the streets. Also, it's not like it's difficult to get, some
promoters have publicities in newspapers, stickers everywhere, flyers in
every record shops, grungewear shops etc...

>that's when a message appears on the 
>organizers' phone line telling those who are mobile where to go(which could be 
>any place large and rentable)

precisely. Big raves are just money making skeems these days, which is a shame.

>Bizarre costume is central to the rave lifestyle,and the rising demand for the 
>elements of a bold visual statement has spawned a network of suppliers. Among 
>them is XStatic, a shop just off Toronto's hip Queen Street West strip where a 

I dont get it. Are they covering Montreal's or Toronto's rave scene? You cant
cover both in one article if you  are not clearly drawing the line, because
these are 2 totally different scenes.

> One of the papers is called Tribe, and Mychol Holtman who writes its "Wazup" 
> column, offers this theory to explain why rave has become such a magnet for 
> restless youth since emerging from Liverpool and Manchester.
> "It can be summed up in one word: unity," he says, arguing that ravers "are 
> reacting to the 'me, me, me: forget everyone else' attitude of the seventies 
> and eighties. "

Not. Raves are precisely me, me, me, forget what everybody else thinks. The
eighties were me, me, me, do like everybody else.

>Mr. Holtman feels that young people are increasingly depressed by their lot in 
>life,by the fact that so many of them are heading straight from high school to 
>the unemployment line. The rave "vibe" provides an antidote, he says. "They 
>reassure each other that there is hope and love out there. "

These are some sick puppies :)
This is again media hawgwash. It is proven regularly by the flame wars on the
rave lists (and particularly on alt.rave) that the peace, love, unity concept
is not really what it's all about. What is it about? well it is what it means
to each of you. It's for the fun of it? fine. It's for the enjoyment of music?
fine. It's whatever you think it is for you. But it is not ONE thing.

>not to mention drugs, may sound familiar to those who remember the hippie era. 
>"It's a total peace movement," confirms Dave. "It's the same thing as the 
>sixties. "

That's what a deal of people would want, but (un)fortunately it's not.

>Canadian rave got its start two years ago with four techno-starved British 
>expatriates.

That's news to the Montreal rave scene. My show is advanced in it's third
year and when i started it, i had been going to raves for a year. In fact,
i've been to acid parties which were then named warehouse parties and the
music was detroit techno, house and acid house. Now, that was in 88. What are
we listening in raves now? techno, house, acid (add ambient). Same difference.
Only the names have been changed to protect the innocents.

>Over coffee at a Toronto cafe, disc jockey and rave producer Sean 
>L recalls that they "were basically just looking for a place to go ourselves, 
>because there was nothing here. "
>Given their common background and affection for the music of Bob Marley, the 
>four adopted the name Exodus, planned their first rave and distributed several 
>hundred flyers in downtown bars to advertise it.
> 
>To their amazement, about 400 people showed up for the debut. It was an 
>embryonic outing, far less elaborate than those to follow, but the novices 
>responded to a mood and music unknown even in the avantgarde clubs many of them
>frequented.

Say what? clearly Toronto clubs must have been a sad place to be in the late
80s.

> RAVE may be a British export but its music was born in the U.S.A. House 
> appeared first, taking shape in Chicago dance clubs in the early eighties and 
> mutating into techno after it hit Detroit. Not that the mutation has stopped. 

At least they got that bit correctly. Except not everybody agrees on the
house->techno, but still.

> The sound changes so rapidly that disc jockeys,
> dedicated to staying abreast of the latest trends, are often
> bigger stars than the performers they play.

Ain't that a shame. That's mostly because techno bands release only one album
(when it's not simply one 12"), but the DJs play gigs upon gigs and so their
names appear more frequently.

>They cultivate a personal style captured on cassettes sold with their names on 
>the label. A rave is a 'one off' occasion," explains Dave Crook, a Toronto disc

predestined name? :)

> The beat buffets Alice's body as green light scribbles across her face and 

Which reminds me: Metropolis in Montreal is doing something very illegal:
their laser scans the whole dancefloor. I was very surprised (but no damage)
to receive a laser blast in one eye when i went there one friday night...
(it is a quite powerfull laser, like in big raves)

>"Laser animation" is another rave specialty. A moving image of laser light is 
>projected against the wall, and that's something you don't see in the clubs, " 
>he says.

Check out L'esprit, Le Metropolis etc... They have had laser animations on
walls and screens for several years...

>At Place Newman, lasers are being used to create illusory tunnels and surfaces.
>A ceiling of luminous green bars shoots out from the stage, just above the 
>heads of the dancers. Then the flat surface appears to contract, transforming 
>itself into a green-spoked spinning wheel.
>According to Alice, there is method to this laser madness. "I think that, 
>visually, raves are setup to enhance the experience of being on psychedelics 
>she explains "although I do know a lot of people who don't use drugs who go 
>just for the experience of being around people
>who are free and happy. "

As i said, a very small percentage take drugs. And raves are NOT the place to
experience psychedelics. If you want to try them, do it with friends so that
they can control the environment to prevent a bad trip.

>Of those who have chosen to indulge, many are on ecstasy, which is a variant of
>the sixties a love drug" MDA

It's not.

>and the intoxicant of choice for ravers from 
>London to San Francisco.

Nope. In commercial raves it's surely alcohol. Even if it's not sold at the
site.

[stuff about a dj saying the scene is not as bad as the grateful dead shows]
>ALICE is not on drugs, but after an hour of dancing she is certainly thirsty. 
>She escapes the laser kaleidoscope and weaves through the crowd toward a heavy 
>black curtain. As she slips past it, black lighting turns the white stripes of 
>her dress electric mauve, and she arrives at the "smart bar. "
> 
>A woman in a black bodice is tending three blenders housing "smart 
>drinks"?liquids in cheery shades of red, orange and green. "They're made with 
>amino acids, fruit and caffeine," she explains while pouring Alice's selection,
>raspberry, into a plastic cup. "They give you an energy boost. "

Ha. DNA smartbar. You gotta take 6 of these for anything to happen. Saturn 6
nights at DAX used to have real smartdrinks. Just one and you felt like you
were thinking clearer.

> Called "ambient", it features a soft beat and keyboard	
> washes that create an oasis for the bass-weary The smell
> of clove cigaettes and hashish is in the air.
> 
>By 4 a.m. Alice has spent whatever energy her smart drink had provided. 

Ya right. The drink didn't do anything. Usually the last club type crowd
finish to leave at 4... And a bunch of drunk clubbers get at the raves at
that time too.

>A police cruiser sits idling, as its occupants gaze at the mall with apparent 
>boredom. The two policemen have a long wait ahead. They've been assigned to 
>watch over the party until it wraps up?in another four hours. Bidding the 
>officers good night, Alice boards the bus that will take her back downtown. 
>Across the parking lot, a second bus pulls up with a fresh crop of costumed 
>youth. For them, the night is just beginning.

I think they simply dont want another H2O on their hand (another bug and jam
fiasco) with the riot squad. But when this event is far in the past, watch
them jump in with their baton and shield and beat up kids.

>Lately, the police have taken a passive approach to rave control."When we find 
>out about a rave party, then we'll monitor them says Detective
>Sergeant Craig Hilborn of the Metro Toronto force's drug unit. "The main 
>concern we have is the age of the participants and the possible use of illicit 
>drugs."

Hmm. We are talking about Place Newman in Montreal, MUC cops and we get a
quote from a Toronto detective? I dont get it.

>He says there is little of the violence that would cause a policing problem. In
>fact, a rave in May did end in serious violence, but not at the instigation of 
>its participants. Video footage of the Montreal force shutting down festivities
>at the Palais du Commerce show police in riot gear beating party-goers with 
>nightsticks.

Yep. Hey they got that right too! On the other hand, rap nights are extremely
violent. Stabbing, guns etc... but in raves, i've yet to witness violence
instigated by a raver.

> Yet, the future of rave may be in doubt. If anything, the phenomenon may fall 
> victim to its own success.

It will return to the form it should never have left.

>In recent months, rave has left its underground birthplace and percolated into 
>the mainstream. Fully aware of what happened to disco, punk and all the other 
>subterranean movements that made this journey, hardcore ravers are growing 
>disillusioned.

True. We've gone back to the underground after the H2O event, knowing things
will never be the same. And you know what? i like that better. keep it
underground. But the comparison is not correct. Techno music is here to stay,
while disco and punk are not anymore. Raves and techno is not the same thing.

>Popularity breeds commercialism, and the purists have become skeptical as 
>second-generation competitors appear in the marketplace.

I've yet to see a great commercial rave here.

>"The sole purpose of a lot of these people is just simply to make a killing, " 
>complains Sean L. "I think what happened is, people saw what was going on?four 
>or five hundred people dancing?and thought, 'Hey, I could do that!' But to 
>throw a rave you have to understand what it is; what the vibe is. "

You have to have logistic skills and that's all. Get the right people to DJ,
to do the lights etc... Small raves are less logistic, but require the
organiser to be much more in the movement and be multi disciplinary too.

>At a recent event staged by Atlantis, one of the newcomers in Toronto, 
>representatives of Chemistry, an early arrival, handed patrons their 
>resignations?laminated cards that read: "The scene has gone commercial been 
>bastardized and generally gotten f----d up. That's why we've reluctantly 
>decided to pack it all in.... "

I've heard that T.O is particularly bad in that way.

>This is rave packaged by businessmen in their 30s, he says, and their target 
>market is no longer the inner-city crowd who started it all. "They're appealing
> mostly to high-school kids from the suburbs. 

True.

>The pioneers fear that in losing its clandestine nature, rave may lose the key 
>ingredient to its continued good health. They may not have to wait long to find
>out whether they're right.

The underground is fine if you ask me.

>This month's schedule in Toronto demonstrates just how quickly rave is losing 
>its low profile. Atlantis is planning to hold one at the CN Tower, the tallest 
>free-standing structure in the world.

I think it's a bad place to hold a rave if you ask me.

Well, enough for now, let me know what you think.

Ciao,

From sfraves-owner  Thu Oct 21 11:02:58 1993
From: john@makesys.com (John Turman)
Date: Thu, 21 Oct 93 10:28:19 PDT
Subject: Re: DJ's vs Musicians...ad infinitum
Status: 

Hi gang,

After nearly 3 decades of sweat and toil, cut and bleeding fingers, muscle
spasms from hours of practice on a horribly set up steel string acoustic
guitar...playing in tiny crowded smoke filled dives...ducking flying beer
bottles...haggling with sleazy club owners over payment etc. I think it's
called paying my dues, (YUK)....

Just setting the stage for what's to come. I used to think of DJ's as low
life entrepenuers eager to make a quick buck off of other peoples sweat,
toil and talents, and to tell the truth, the early DJ's were pretty much
what I just described. 

Some had little or no knowledge of music, they just knew a couple of records 
that people liked to hear and they played them and got payed. And I might 
add, nearly all of them never even heard of BMI or ASCAP, (I used to ask them)
so needless to say, never payed a dime to them. But they didn't refuse payment 
at the end of the night after playing records that were represented by the 
aforementioned agencies. I looked at them as destroyers of the very industry 
they were profiteering from. They were taking from and not putting anything back 
into the music business.

The other thing I resented was that at every party or club that these "leeches"
played it was one less place that a live band got work. For awhile it actually
seemed that there would be no venues for aspiring new groups to be able to
display their wares for the general public and that music would stagnate, or
worse yet, die out altogether.

And then I went to a rave.......(cut to the chase).. WOW! I never knew DJing
could be considered an art form! Double WOW! Carlos.... Triple WOW! Jeno, 
Garth... etc. I guess you get the picture. I now have the greatest respect for
DJ's and for what they've added to the artform of music.

And much to my relief, there are still plenty of clubs who have the guts to
keep paying live bands, and giving new acts a chance to draw a following and
maybe get that recording contract nearly all us musicians dream of. But the
neat thing about it all, is that DJ's and live acts are now almost in a state
of symbiosis, re:Orb's show last Friday.

So in closing I say it's silly to have a DJ vs. musician vs muse vs Charlie
Mingus vs to move vs not to move vs I've got rhythm vs no you don't etc. etc. 
etc. flame war of any type.

And as different as all people are on this planet there will be differing forms
of expression on the dance floor as well as on the stage. And just because
one person says this and another says that ad nauseum....doesn't change the
fact that music AFFECTS us all in some way. So let's celebrate that and get
on to something new. Something POSITIVE.

Rave on, sisters and brothers,

John Turman




From sfraves-owner  Thu Oct 21 11:12:48 1993
From: lxfogel@srv.PacBell.COM (Lee Fogel)
Date: Thu, 21 Oct 93 11:12:39 PDT
Subject: Re: musicianship vs. DJ'ing
Status: 

Randy: 
> Once you can play well   
> enough that the music is coming thru you without much thought, or any       
> thought, the level of enjoyment is a least the same as DJ'ing, if not
> infinitely greater.

A lot depends on what kind of music moves you.  It's probably true that
Coltrane would get more pleasure from playing a sax solo than he would
DJ'ing a record of one of his solos. 

> without dissing DJ'ing, or its gift of joy & exstasy to so many, i find it
> hard to believe anyone would really think this....unless they just didn't
> want to, or couldn't, make the tremendous effort necessary to reach that
> stage of proficiency, a la Mingus, that true professionals reach rather
> easily.

Well, it's true, Randy, that many of us couldn't be bothered to spend the
tremendous effort it takes to become one with some old baroque era
sound utensil.  My meager home studio contains the equivalent of 16
separate instruments, which were meant to be played together. 
The music I listen to may have over 64 tracks of sound.  *This* is
the kind of music I want channeled through me, and I don't want to
depend on a bunch of band members being there to make it happen.  I am
very happy for Mingus, and all the other stone age musicians who have
reached great depths with their technological antiques.  I personally
find the sounds of archeology a bit stale, so why would I try to
become proficient at producing more of it?   

Unfortunately, I was born with only 2 hands and a couple of orifices
I can blow air through.  Until genetic engineering can improve my
situation, I'll have to be content with channeling music that has
been at least partially preconstructed.
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
Lee Fogel/\/\/\/\/\eVerything/\Is/\possiBlE/\/\/\/\/\lxfogel@srv.pacbell.com
____________________________________________________________________________

From sfraves-owner  Thu Oct 21 11:45:26 1993

John Turman writes:

>Some had little or no knowledge of music, they just knew a couple of records 
>that people liked to hear and they played them and got payed. And I might 
>add, nearly all of them never even heard of BMI or ASCAP, (I used to ask them)
>so needless to say, never payed a dime to them. But they didn't refuse payment 
>at the end of the night after playing records that were represented by the

i agree with just about everything you wrote in your article, except
for this one tiny point...

the record companies should be paying the DJs, not the other way
round!  it's called promotion, and it's why many DJs get loads of
freebies from the record companies in the first place...  in fact,
we've got tons of records lying around that say "DJ promotional copy"
on them...

From sfraves-owner  Thu Oct 21 12:29:22 1993

Well, I must say that I was a bit surprised to see this article in the Globe.

It was on the front page, and it was bannered across the top, with a page-wide
picture of a raver (clenching her head, lasers in the background), 
and a caption:  "Rave's chemistry: pulsating lights, throbbing music, and
for some, an outlawed drug. "

We are less than 1 week away from a federal election in Canada, I wonder if 
the article is an attempt to make raves a political issue? 

The whole article seems to be written for an older audience: 

>"They only come out at night"  
  ^^^^
Those crazy kids! I tells ya!  Now, in my day...!!!!  (feh!)

It goes on: 

>Mr. Holtman feels that young people are increasingly depressed by their lot 
>in life, by the fact that so many of them are heading straight from high 
>school to the unemployment line. The rave "vibe" provides an antidote, he 
>says. "They reassure each other that there is hope and love out there. "

Unemployment is one of the most critical issues in this election. I wonder
if this article was intended to be some kind of warning flag to the nation 
(Canada) that if we kiddies dont get some lovin... then there'll be a massive
upheaval of kids on E, orchestrated by Dr.Seuss and Alice in Wonderland... with
glowstick-armed troops stroming into the lap of Canada's cities and 'burbs.

It's like a message to all the "I-wonder-what-my-kids-are-doing-right-now" 
voters. Almost like a guilt trip: "Your kids are depressed! They need 
reassurance that there is hope and love out there! Give them that hope for a 
new and better life, a new and better Canada: Vote for __________ . !"  *gawd! 
*puke*
 
The timliness of this article is sick :)


pat.

Fact vs Fiction: The agony over ecstasy

From sfraves-owner  Thu Oct 21 13:21:41 1993
From: Lisa M. Wyatt <lwyatt@ocf.Berkeley.EDU>
Date: Thu, 21 Oct 1993 13:21:35 -0700
Subject: Re: dancing & listening to techno
Status: 


As for what to do while under the influence of sweet techno...
 
IUm not sure whether I could get through my my organic 
chem and math classes without the moving beat of techno 
and industrial music to keep me going. I often begin 
studying around 11 or so, and continue through to the 
wee hours of the morning with beat driving me most of 
the way. I enter my own little world, where itUs science, 
techno, and me, and it forms a rather intriguing scene. 
 
And every hour or so, I exit from this world by dancing 
off some of the energy thatUs been mountingup in me. 
Of course, IUd rather be dancing at a party, but at least 
IUm making the most of it, eh?
 
And I must say, skiing to techno sounds absolutely
fabulous. 
 
Live well.
Lisa.
 
 
 

From sfraves-owner  Thu Oct 21 13:36:23 1993
From: winston@lurnix.COM (Mark Guthrie)
Date: Thu, 21 Oct 93 10:55:51 PDT
Subject: ???
Status: 

>I'm fascinated by the statement of at least one well-known
>musician in print recently that he's experienced another (non-human)
>presence on stage with him, the "ghostly other." What a trip.

Well, so who was it?  If s/he said it in print it's not like your
gossuping or anything.


On another point, right on to Gil for that last post.  I was becoming
anoyed at the rather simplistic blanket statements being made about
musicianship until you made the point that I would have thought we
all would have excepted as a granted, that musicians are human,
which means that there is a whole range of tecnical virtuosity that
comes natural and easy to some and hard as hell for others and both
for some on any given day or jam session and that a person who has a 
hard time can still surpass a someone who has an easy time by 
persistence.  Lots of factors make up a circumstance.  Jerry Garcia
says he'll never be comfortable in his playing on stage.  He and the
other members of the dead have been in front of more audiences than
any other humans in earth history (by my figuring) and he still has
terrible stage fright for the first half hour or so of every show -
so much that he has to concentrate harder to play at the same level
as at other times.

-Mark

I oughta be there this time...

Tesla looks intriguing and The Cat in the Hat could be fun if it's in
the right space.  I haven't heard anything about the benefit for the
Coalition on Homelessness - I assume it's been postponed or cancelled,
if anyone knows otherwise, please post more details.  Also, the EndUp
seemed to be closed last Thursday, does anyone know if Housing Project
closed or moved back to Wednesdays?

Any mail (new listings, questions, comments, poetry) should be sent 
to me at "dhchung@us.oracle.com" NOT "dchung@us.oracle.com".
           ^
    
Have fun and see you next week!

From ames!sol.med.ge.com!lawery Thu Oct 21 11:22:17 1993
From: ames!sol.med.ge.com!lawery (Robert Lawery  x7-4575)
Date: Thu, 21 Oct 93 12:46:04 CDT
Subject: The Source Mag.
Status: R

Did any of you read the 50 issue of the SOURCE??  It retraces the origins of Hip Hop.  The cover sports Bambatta, Grand Master Flash, and Cool DJ Herk.

The interview with them is pretty cool and really worth reading.  It will bring back crazy old memories.  Additionally the have a spread on the old NYC graffitti bombers. (Who remembers ZEPHYR, SKEME-TNT, and FUTURA 2000 bombin' all over NYC back in the days???)  

The also have a real good quiz on the history of hip hop.  

The only problem I had with the issue is that the really didn't gove SKEME-TNT his proper daps!!!!  In the quiz the referred to him as a bombing king but the showed no pictures of his work which was really on and gave no bio on him like the gave zephyr, futura and some others.

It was a damn shame  Any folks who rode the 2 and 3 trains back in the days should remember what I'm talkin about.

Anyway, check out the issue its worth the 3 bucks!!!

Rob


----- End Included Message -----

From sfraves-owner  Thu Oct 21 14:45:15 1993
From: john@makesys.com (John Turman)
Date: Thu, 21 Oct 93 13:29:36 PDT
Subject: Re: DJ's vs Musicians...ad infinitum
Status: 

> 
> John Turman writes:
> 
> >Some had little or no knowledge of music, they just knew a couple of records 
> >that people liked to hear and they played them and got payed. And I might 
> >add, nearly all of them never even heard of BMI or ASCAP, (I used to ask them)
> >so needless to say, never payed a dime to them. But they didn't refuse payment 
> >at the end of the night after playing records that were represented by the 
> >aforementioned agencies. I looked at them as destroyers of the very industry 
> >they were profiteering from. They were taking from and not putting anything back 
> >into the music business.

Then J Drukman wrote:
> 
> i agree with just about everything you wrote in your article, except
> for this one tiny point...
> 
> the record companies should be paying the DJs, not the other way
> round!  it's called promotion, and it's why many DJs get loads of
> freebies from the record companies in the first place...  in fact,
> we've got tons of records lying around that say "DJ promotional copy"
> on them...
> 
> Jon Drukman                                         jdrukman%dlsun87@oracle.com
> -------------------------------------------------------------------------------
> This calls for a very special blend of psychology and extreme violence.
> 



I agree with you NOW on what should be instead of what is. But the original
idea of BMI and ASCAP was to provide a medium to allow the payment of royalties
to the performers who put the music on the vinyl to begin with. 

When I was a member of the musicians guild part of my union dues were for the 
payment of these BMI or ASCAP fees to allow my band to LEGALLY play cover tunes 
of other artists compositions. Plus it also removed the club owners from having 
the spectre of getting hit with copyright infringement suits.

Unfortunately or fortunately, depending on what side of the fence you reside in
the music business, there are legal ramifications as to public performance of
copyrighted works. In an ideal world everyone would be happy that their music
was being played and promoted and given a wide audience etc. But, in reality,
greed and a LEGAL sense of right and wrong has its hold on the music "business"
and people have to get payed too.

I don't want to start a whole flame fest on the rightness or wrongness of
copyrights there was recently a seemingly never-ending one in alt.guitar and
rec.music.makers.guitar so there's no need to resurrect the dead here.

The way I look at it is, there is this complete, organized, legal elephant
called copyright law, I chose to dance with it instead of trying to do "the
bump" with it. Mainly because had it stepped on my toes, which it is wont to
do now and then, it would have hurt a lot.

I think that what you propose is actually more in keeping with the realities
of today. I'm sure that if there were a will we could come up with a way.

One thing though, it sure would be cool if there were song lists available at
all the raves. I'm sure that the distribution of lists at raves would be one
step in the right direction of reversing the BMI/ASCAP thing.

From sfraves-owner  Thu Oct 21 15:43:54 1993
From: winston@lurnix.COM (Mark Guthrie)
Date: Thu, 21 Oct 93 14:15:59 PDT
Subject: Re: musicianship vs. DJ'ing
Status: 

I have to agree with Lee, computers give us the technology to become composers
and conductors, with out having to assemble an orchestra (a very annoyed one
in my case).  So in that regard, were kinda talking about apples and oranges
now, musicians who play instruments are very happy doing it with others in a
band setting, DJs are very happy playing and mixing tunes, and electronic
musicians are happy composing tunes with an electronic orchestra.

-Mark

From sfraves-owner  Thu Oct 21 18:21:23 1993
From: Sami Khoury <sk2000@uclink.berkeley.edu>
Date: Thu, 21 Oct 1993 18:00:50 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: Re: Aphex/Orbital/Moby
Status: 

I've seen Moby three times and Orbital once.  Lee's right concerning
Orbital.  The music sounds just like the CD, so if you like the CD you
won't be disappointed.  The problem is that there is almost NO live
element.  When I saw them, they were cocooned in their equipment with ALL
the stage lights off (except for those glasses with lights on the side of
one's head which Tom nor I have been able to find for the life of us) and
they looked like they were just standing there.  In contrast, Prodigy (I
mean Liam Howlett, NOT those dip-shit dancers) had live playing mixed with
sequenced stuff (one guy jumping around behind 5 keyboards and a drum
machine looks pretty damn cool).  Moby was good the first time I saw him
in Feb 92.  Then, he actually played live the piano part of Go.  Now...
Young American Primitive doesn't play a damn thing live either.  I saw him
with Moby and, if you watched carefully, you'd notice that NO MIDI was
going from his keyboards--despite the fact that, after talking to him
backstage after his performance, he told me that he DID use MIDI to
control those boards.  Oh well...He's no Induction...


On Thu, 21 Oct 1993, Lee Fogel wrote:

> > So will the Aphex/Orbital/Moby show be on par with the recent Orb show?
> 
> As far as a "show" goes, I would guess not.  I saw Orbital last year,
> and although the music was great, I felt myself getting bored 1/2 way
> through their set.  When I go out dancing, I'm used to a bit more
> sonic variety than a set of Orbital could offer.  And there was no
> visual element to speak of, which was the best thing about the Orb 
> show IMO.
> 
> I haven't seen Moby or A.T. live, but I haven't heard anything positive
> about Moby's performance.  If I go, it would be mainly for A.T. 
> 
> - leg of eel
> 




From sfraves-owner  Thu Oct 21 21:12:49 1993
From: larryc@netcom.com (Larry Ching)
Date: Thu, 21 Oct 93 21:13:22 PDT
Subject: DJ Don't Promote Musical Recordings
Status: 


DJs Don't Promote Musical Recordings - not at raves , that is.

 A recent series of posts have touched on the role of DJs as an avenue
of music business promotion . What follows is limited to the narrow
field of rave DJing.

 If a music publisher wanted to promote a recording , I think a rave
DJ would be a poor method of promotion. Looking at the standard operating
procedure at raves , it seems the last thing DJs want to do is provide
the audience any information on the specific cuts they're mixing.

I can think of a few reasons:
1. They're too damn busy.( A good reason , in my opinion)
2. They don't want other DJs/wannabe DJs from finding out "the easy way"
   what they spent time & money discovering.
3. It would cut into their "mystique" if the focus was shifted to the
   sources of the music instead of the tasty mixing of the DJ. ( Hopefully,
   this is a rare reason for hiding record labels). 

Are there any DJs you know that are exceptions to this?

-----------------------------------------------------------------------

 Whenever I fantasize about being a DJ , I always thought that it would be
a good idea to prop the empty record sleeves up where people could read 
them. ( If the record had an anonymous sleeve , I'd write the info on it).
I thought that it would be a good thing for the advancement of the
quality of rave music , as the audience could identify recordings that
they like , buy them , and provide the recording industry some motivation
to pump more $$ to the musicians of "quality". OF COURSE , this assumes
that the artists most supported by the audience = the artists of higher
"quality" [ sounds somehow wrong , doesn't it ;-)  ].
 
 What we need is a CONSUMER REPORTS of rave/techno/trance/tribal/etc
music ...

Larry Ching/larryc@netcom.com 

From sfraves-owner  Thu Oct 21 21:28:35 1993

for service , cooking ,etc. , as well as trying to find parking near
any restaurant. I was thinking that a park with a pavillion or roofed
structure would be good. 

 Can anyone suggest a South Bay site that fits the above criteria?

				Larry Ching/larryc@netcom.com
