Date: Thu, 21 Oct 1993 10:21:54 -0500
From: Charles Blair <chas@stax.lib.uchicago.edu>
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU


>> Who's the "well-known musician", then....?

The guy who played bass for the Jefferson Airplane, except I can never
remember his name without looking at it, and I don't have the source
handy: a recent Bass Player magazine interview. Well-known enough
among bass players to get interviewed, anyway. :-) (At least, I'm
pretty sure it was he and not Jack Bruce who said it; both were
interviewed in the same issue.)

It seems this thread might degenerate into DJing vs. playing. Not
really the point, I think. Many forms of art lend themselves to
"channelling the muse." There's that passage at the beginning of the
Iliad where Homer is about to recite the list of the Greek ships who
went to Troy, and says something like (again, no source handy): I, a
human, could not possibly remember all of what I'm about to say, but
you, O Muse, who remembers everything, speak. (Again, this might be a
really bad paraphrase of the original, but it's close enough for the
point I want to make.) Then Homer launches on this long list of ships,
where they came from, who manned them, etc. 

Now, by Homer's time invoking the muse might have been a trope, but I
bet that in the oral tradition to which long poems like the Iliad
belong (by the way, Homer subscribed to the "tyranny of the beat," as
did Shakespeare in his sonnets and lots of other poets; sometimes the
"tyranny" of a style, in this case, a rhythmic or metric style, is a
boost to creativity, not a dampener), I bet that those tribal bards
really didn't believe they had conscious access to or could store a
lot of the information they could relate, and attributed what they
could do to a transcendental force. (The Odyssey begins, Speak to me,
O Muse, of a man ...) 

In short, I don't think the point is about this or that way to get
there. For me the interesting point is what the "there" might be. If
it's calling forth something you didn't know you had, or had access
to, if it's transcending the _boredom_ of the same old thing, the same
old tired experiences, the "is that all there is?" of a (tired) old
pop song, whether it's through dancing, or DJing, or playing the sax
(a la Coltrane, another musician dude with spiritual leanings), or
drumming, or writing some code that you didn't know you had it in you
to write, for me (and that's my $0.02) that's the interesting
thing. (The Greeks had a muse for dancing, and for other things as
well.) The rest is style wars, (self-)image wars, fashion wars,
opinion wars, and all the rest of that ego stuff. People like Homer
must have been at times totally awed and humbled by their art (the
fact that a goddess could speak through them), rather than
ego-tripping on it. In some sense, they must have been "ecstatic"
(literally, standing beside or outside oneself, `withdrawal of the
soul from the body, mystic or prophetic trance'--Oxford English
Dictionary). I view the "self" beside which one steps here as the ego;
I approach raving as something I don't want to do either with my ego,
or without my ego. I want enough of my ego there to bring something
back with me from the experience, but I don't want the ego to
dominate, so that what I'm experiencing is the same old thing. The ego
has to be side-by-side with the rest of me, and part of the experience
is to discover what the rest of "me" is.




--0-1591537789-751264418:#24449--


From sfraves-owner  Thu Oct 21 22:56:29 1993
From: Amit Shoham <as@leland.Stanford.EDU>
Date: Thu, 21 Oct 1993 22:56:24 -0700
Subject: Re:  musicianship vs. DJ'ing
Status: 

Raul Gilbert MinaMora <tow@well.sf.ca.us> sez:
	
	It seems to me that if DJing works best for Jon so be it.
	Why should that have any bearing on ones ability as a musician
	or on achieving musicianship whether in the garage or the
	concert hall? With all due respect to those who play instruments
	(why some of my best friends play instruments :-) ;-) &+
	these days a musician doesn't have to play an instrument,
	visual artists don't need to bother with brushs or learning
	to draw to create terrific work. I'm musicaly naive but my
	understanding of musicianship is that it is a level to be
	achieved, to some it may come easily others will have to work
	hard and that it can vary from night to night for everyone.           
	
	Gil

There are two aspects to being an artist.  There's the
"eye" or "ear" and the sensitivity that allow the artist to conceive
of something meaningful or moving, and there's the technique necessary
to bring it to life.  These days, artists don't need to learn the
technique to create art, since the tools are available for them to
create a rough sketch (either a visual or a musical one) and then
painstakingly refine it to perfection.  The result is obviously no less
valid or good than the work of an artist that can immediately draw/play/
sculpt/etc. what's in his or her head.  But when an artist has the
necessary ability for creation to be immediate, the rewards are more
direct as well: the artist gets to be creator and audience simultaneously
and watch the work "unfold" in a way that is fresh in the artist's mind.
For most artists, once they experience "direct" creation, it is difficult
to accept tools that distance them from the art.  It seems to me that
turntables and other people's music leave you a lot further away from
the music than guitars/drums/keyboards/etc.

Amit

From sfraves-owner  Thu Oct 21 23:26:36 1993
From: vile@il.us.swissbank.com (Kurt Vile)
Date: Fri, 22 Oct 93 01:26:57 -0500
Subject: Re: musicianship vs. DJ'ing
Status: 



I have played violin for 15 years.....I have played in several orchestras including
the World Youth Sympohny Orchestra @ interlochen.

I have also playe guitar for 5, sax for 4, paino on and off me whole life, and I've  
toyed with a couple other things (incl. full midi setups)

I can DJ barely well enough to save my life (if someone said DJ or die to me I'd  
probably lose a limb or two but still stay alive)

they are two different worlds....one is creation/replication - the other is  
combination/beat-matching

Its not appearant to me that you can even compare the two - its apples and oranges,
DJ's match beats - musicians hold them.  I for one see no relationship b/w the 2
go figure.....

--Kurt

From sfraves-owner  Thu Oct 21 23:44:48 1993
From: larryc@netcom.com (Larry Ching)
Date: Thu, 21 Oct 93 23:45:23 PDT
Subject: DJs are poor promotion
Status: 

( My apologies if some of you already got this - I didn't see it in my
  SFRaves mail , so I'm assuming the original posting got lost. )

 In a recent post , someone mentioned that DJs act to promote recordings.
My opinion is , not so - at least not as well as other types of
advertising. 

 From what I've seen at raves , the DJs at these events have reasons not
to inform the audience of the recordings their listening to:

1. The DJs are too damn busy!
2. After spending time and money finding the good stuff ( and working
   through the junk ) , they don't want other DJs to find out the same
   information the easy way.
3. What the audience hears may be the result of a mixed of two recordings
   instead of a single one - there's no point in informing the audience
   what's playing on turntable A if you also need to mix what's on 
   turntable B with it.
4. Telling the audience what the cuts are would take away from the 
   DJ's "mystique" .

 Of course , there are some DJs that aren't supposed to be as close with
the info during a rave - Carlos was one fellow (?). Anybody else know
of other DJs that like to spread the word?

-------------------------------------------------------------

 During my fantasies of being a DJ , I always thought that it would be a 
good idea to show the empty record sleeves such that the audience could
read what the recording was - even if it was a blank sleeve , the info
could be written on the sleeve. This would help to promote the music , 
and maybe even act to evolve the music in a positive way. If more people
than the DJs actually knew what the recordings were , more of the 
"quality" recordings could be purchased , thus encouraging the recording
companies to invest more into the more popular musicians. [ Of course ,
this raises the question of wether popular/therefore/"quality" : I've never 
followed the purchasing trends of my generation , and that equation
has never been too valid to me ].
 

				Larry Ching/larryc@netcom.com

From sfraves-owner  Fri Oct 22 07:42:32 1993
From: jsl@netcom.com (John S. Lee)
Date: Fri, 22 Oct 93 07:43:01 -0700
Subject: DJ's & promotion
Status: 

Larry pointed out that DJ's, for the most part are poor promotion and makes
some valid points proving his theorem.

However, the one thing he does not talk about is that DJ's talk amongst one
another.  And usually that is the way news of a hot track spreads.  Now
some folks who DJ have the advantage of being recognized everywhere (due to
the length of time they've been playing, connections, etc.),  and as such
has access to record pools, direct mailings from labels, etc.  I can think
of 1 or two DJ's who fit this criteria (not counting the , uh, radio DJ). 
The info of a hot track does get passed down, and those DJ's who are not so
well connected (although they may be well known within a particular scene)
will end up buying said track.  This is one way to encourage sales.  As for
the sale of "house" or "techno"/"rave" whatever, you gotta remember, it is
doubtful you will ever sell 100,000 units.  The market just isn't that
large.  It's not pop so...

The creator/producer/record co.'s generally know this and tend to produce
fewer untis of any particular cut, than what a commercial label would do
for the mass market.  So the proces tend to be a bit higher than most other
12" for this reason, which , in turn restricts the markets even further. 
Also you have a problem with hardware.  How many records are made for the
masses anyway?  How many people even HAVE turntables anymore (with the
advent of CD, you can't even find full blown LP's anymore).  So, with all
this in mind, the DJ becomes VERY important in terms of any given track's
success.  Maybe the typical John/Jane/ or Harry (sans Who) will not end up
buying alot of material.  But the newer DJ's will, as well as some of the
vets, as well as radio DJ's, etc.  All of this helps in the promotion of a
record/label/track (since really all we're talking about is
exposure/sales).

As for the DJ mystique, and newer DJ's having it rough, well I would just
consider it a rite of passage.  Like a DJ told me most recently, "Everyone
want's to be a DJ.", and it's true ;)  There are more new DJ's than parties
to feature them.  Now you can't just expect to buy two 1200's and have
access to Markie's/Josh's/Jeno's/Garth's collection that they've spent
ten's of thousands on. Sheesh!  You've gotta earn your place within their
community, by being unique, being consistent/innovative/and proficient at
your craft.  The only thing this requires is time, and if you make that
investment the dividends will surely follow (i.e. an easier time finding
getting good tracks/ reccomendations by your fellow DJ's/ etc.).

One more point about DJ fees:  I think that they are ridiculous, and I hate
to pay DJ's upward to $250/hr to spin.  But consider the investment they
have to make.  During a typical buying session (at one store) a DJ will
walk out with $100-$200 worth of material (equiv. to about 10-15 records). 
Now that will not be the only buying session during the week.  Also
consider basic living expenses, especially if you life in SF.  When all is
said and done the DJ is, in many cases, breaking even if that.  If your a
better known DJ, then you'll be doing a bit better.  But even then the fee
may not even make up for the purchases of that week.

I do think that there is excessive ($700 - $1000 for a Sat.) fees.  But
these folks are few and far between.  Most of the DJ's in the area, have
reasonalbe rates.  And for the most part, I don't mind paying the fees.  

Just some thoughts on a Friday,
John

P.S.  PAYDAY!  Time to go out and purchase those 1200's I've wanted.  I
figure it'll be a matter of weeks before I would be easily able to unseat
the likes of a Jeno or a Markie ;)

Peace.

                 from the village of jsl@netcom.com

the middle of a busy set.

most useful technique.  if you really want to know what DJs are

From sfraves-owner  Fri Oct 22 09:44:51 1993
From: Jon Drukman <jdrukman@us.oracle.com>
Date: Fri, 22 Oct 93 09:42:55 PDT
Subject: DJ's vs Musicians...ad infinitum
Status: 

John Turman writes:

>I agree with you NOW on what should be instead of what is. But the
>original idea of BMI and ASCAP was to provide a medium to allow the
>payment of royalties to the performers who put the music on the vinyl
>to begin with.

yes, but the performers have to accept that there are channels of
promotion where payment of royalties just isn't done.  DJs have a
tough enough time paying the rent, let alone paying royalties.  for
better or worse, when you sign with a big label, you have to accept
that they are going to send out free copies of your work and you
aren't going to get one dime from that.

>I think that what you propose is actually more in keeping with the realities
>of today. I'm sure that if there were a will we could come up with a way.

i don't propose anything, i'm just reporting what already is.

>One thing though, it sure would be cool if there were song lists available at
>all the raves. I'm sure that the distribution of lists at raves would be one
>step in the right direction of reversing the BMI/ASCAP thing.

try picking up some of the free magazines like Urb or Move or XLR8R
next time you're out shopping.  if you want to spend some $, DJ
magazine covers far more records than you could possibly ever
find/buy/listen to...

From sfraves-owner  Fri Oct 22 09:48:15 1993
From: raisty@berlioz.nsc.com (Sue Raisty)
Date: Fri, 22 Oct 93 09:48:01 PDT
Subject: musicianship vs. DJ'ing (fwd)
Status: 

All of this talk about musicianship vs. DJing remind me of a book I
read once, the name of which escapes me.  It was a modern philosophy
type book that examined what made people happy and what did not.

It said that people derive true enjoyment and happiness (different
from pleasure) only from activities that require all their attention,
allowing them to temporarily lose their sense of self and become one
with the action they are performing.  They said this is why most
surgeons love their jobs and would not give up surgery for anything,
why rock-climbers have such passion for climbing, why musicians spend
years perfecting their art.  I think this "losing of the self" might 
be what the "ghostly-other" comment was referring too.  In contrast,
something can be fun and pleasurable without lending true enjoyment or
fulfillment; examples would be watching TV or eating if its just a
distraction and not done critically.

But virtually any activity, as long as it requires all your attention
and challenges you, can help you lose yourself and become one with
your actions.  Be that dancing, creating music, playing music, DJing,
programming, writing, driving,.....

Makes sense to me anyway.

Sue

From sfraves-owner  Fri Oct 22 09:51:43 1993
From: csc@pilot.njin.net (Sean Casey)
Date: Fri, 22 Oct 93 12:48:30 EDT
Subject: DJ Don't Promote Musical Recordings
Status: 

Larry Ching writes:
 >  If a music publisher wanted to promote a recording , I think a rave
 > DJ would be a poor method of promotion. Looking at the standard operating
 > procedure at raves , it seems the last thing DJs want to do is provide
 > the audience any information on the specific cuts they're mixing.

 > Are there any DJs you know that are exceptions to this?

Yes! Susan and Carlos. There have been several times when I or someone
else expressed interest about a track (either by pointing or trying to
read a spinning label) and Susan leans over and explains what the
track is and where to get it :). She's really into the music, doing
her own thing, and helping other people enjoy it. I've been murmuring
about getting some 1200s so I can do _my_ own thing, and she's totally
for it.

At Divinity, I heard a track that just blew me away. I tried to read
the label, but it was an unprinted backside. So I just pointed and
smiled to communicate "this is really awesome". Carlos smiled back,
and when he mixed it out, he handed me the record so I could read it :).

I don't get mad if DJs aren't nice, or if they want to hide labels or
that sort of thing. To each his own, eh? The ones who really are nice
though can make it a really special time for me, above and beyond the
experience of the music.

Sean

in Sac for the first time. Gonna move some furniture into my new place
(yay) and stomp around in the Sierras a bit (anybody want to go?). See
you next weekend.)

From sfraves-owner  Fri Oct 22 09:52:07 1993
From: Jon Drukman <jdrukman@us.oracle.com>
Date: Fri, 22 Oct 93 09:50:18 PDT
Subject:  musicianship vs. DJ'ing
Status: 

amit shoham writes:

>These days, artists don't need to learn the technique to create art,
>since the tools are available for them to create a rough sketch
>(either a visual or a musical one) and then painstakingly refine it
>to perfection.  The result is obviously no less valid or good than
>the work of an artist that can immediately draw/play/ sculpt/etc.
>what's in his or her head.  But when an artist has the necessary
>ability for creation to be immediate, the rewards are more direct as
>well: the artist gets to be creator and audience simultaneously and
>watch the work "unfold" in a way that is fresh in the artist's mind.
>For most artists, once they experience "direct" creation, it is
>difficult to accept tools that distance them from the art.  It seems
>to me that turntables and other people's music leave you a lot
>further away from the music than guitars/drums/keyboards/etc.

i'm smelling a whole lot of performance-oriented snobbery on this
mailing list and it disturbs me greatly.  i've been involved in just
about every kind of musical activity you can imagine, from thrash
metal live performance to live 105 style pop song recording in a
studio to dance music production/performance/DJing and i don't know
about this "distancing" thing... it sounds like another thinly veiled
excuse to put live performers on a pedestal.

everything has its merits.  some avenues of expression work better for
some people.  let's just leave it at that.

	John has some good points however I don't believe there are enough
DJ's around to support the record business by themselves.  If all the
party-goers were able to learn what was just played by a DJ the business
would sky-rocket.  This would create a more profitable business for all the
musicmakers that I never hear about (I hardly know any of the original
musicmakers) and would increase their supply giving us a wider selection of
music.  I hardly have any techno CD's or records cause I don't know what
to buy.
	I can't see any bad things happening except that the DJ's will
lose the secrecy of their records and have to buy more.
	And maybe I'm a bit ignorant but don't most DJ's have daytime jobs
to support them as well.  I could understand the DJ's that play most
every night not having one but then they are making enough money doing
that alone. 

Peace,
G

Gioni Pasquinelli
pasque@hamlet.ucdavis.edu

From sfraves-owner  Fri Oct 22 11:00:05 1993
From: SCRUTON@JOYCE.dnet.hac.com
Date: 22 Oct 1993 10:59:35 -0800 (PST)
Subject: DJ's vs Musicians...ad infinitum
Status: 

BTW, if you're all into sampling, it's great to be able to yank out a
  cello or a flute or whatever on demand, but what, as Frank Zappa, the
  KING of sampling, says, if you need the sound of a cello being scraped
  along a concrete floor?  Well, you have to get a real cello...

  ... THEN sample it!

Dave Scruton

From sfraves-owner  Fri Oct 22 13:12:17 1993
From: Bob Ramstad <rramstad@us.oracle.com>
Date: Fri, 22 Oct 93 13:12:06 PDT
Subject: How was YSH?
Status: 


good time.  really really cool space.  really really.  hope it can be
used again in the future.

the first DJ (Jen, the woman who sometimes does visuals, from TAZ)
played a lot of weird semi-dancable stuff and the crowd was restless.
Charlotte (formerly from Chicago, but now living here) was second and
got the energy level up.  Both of these DJs were playing stuff in a
Chicago house / funky style, very unusual for SF.  Jan Cooley was last
and spun her usual good stuff (but to be honest, I'm getting tired of
her record collection, she's really consistently good but plays a lot
of the same stuff, then again I've heard her like six times in the
last three months...)

Next week looks insane, with Jen opening, then DRC, Susan and
Rebecca...  !!!

I think I'm gonna die next week.  Wed: Motion with Spun, Thurs: YSH,
Friday: levitate the stock exchange + FMR, Saturday: too much to list,
Sunday: George Clinton... but at least I'll die happy 8-)

Yowsa,
Bob

From sfraves-owner  Fri Oct 22 17:35:10 1993
From: larryc@netcom.com (Larry Ching)
Date: Fri, 22 Oct 93 17:35:44 PDT
Subject: Re: DJ Don't Promote Musical Recordings
Status: 

> 
> I (Larry Ching) wrote recently:
> > If a music publisher wanted to promote a recording , I think a rave
> >DJ would be a poor method of promotion. Looking at the standard operating
> >procedure at raves , it seems the last thing DJs want to do is provide
> >the audience any information on the specific cuts they're mixing.

 To which Jon replied: 
> it sounds like you've got a chip on your shoulder from being denied
> your "right" of having a song ID'd for you.
> 

 Actually, I've never thought that the audience had a "right" to know what
the tunes were - my point is that the conditions at a rave and (maybe) the 
way rave DJs operate do not encourage the spreading of musical information
( that is , what recording is being played ) to the average raver in the
audience , during a rave.
 
 I used to come up to the turntables every once and awhile to see what
recording was being played , but I stopped doing that , as I felt it
was disturbing the DJ's concentration. And actually distracting the DJ
from their work to ask my question would be even worst. Now, I just stand 
and watch , occasionally , because the actual process of mixing is still
facinating.

 That's why I think there should be a way for the average raver to find out
what the recordings are , with a minimal or no bothering of the DJ.
 
( I'd really hate it if the DJs started announcing each cut they were
playing! Yuch! :
 "On turntable A , I got 'Brain Butter Popcorn' by Fiercely Bubbling
  Oatmeal on the Whiter-Than-White label , and on turntable B is 
  'The Sound of My Heartbreak' by Dwight Yokum's Mutant Bastards on the
  the Prancing Nag label - on sale NOW at BPM!!!" )

 Jon later said: 
> 
> all the DJs I know are very good about showing me the records, even in
> the middle of a busy set.

 Well , if the usual case is that there is a "professional courtsey" 
between DJs , that's nice. As far as non-DJs go , it seems from some other 
posts that some DJs are willing to share the information with "ordinary" 
folks, which is the focus of my original post .

Jon also said: 
> ...  if you really want to know what DJs are
> playing, start buying DJ magazines and going to DJ record shops!
> 
> [ Jon also recommends these magazines ( idm? ) as good sources of 
    music info ...] 
> 	Mixmag
> 	DJ
> 	Street Sounds
> 	Move
> 	Urb
> 	idm@techno.stanford.edu
> 
> for starters?
> 

 I almost forgot - every week , the SFRaves calender lists local
radio stations that play rave-oriented music , so that's another way
for folks to connect a name with a sound.

----------------------- 

 It's occured to me that I've been assuming that the companies that produce 
the recordings want to reach a wider scope of customers that that provided
by DJs and other professionals - I've assumed that the companies would
love to have their recordings in demand by a wider , non-professional
audience. If my assumption is correct , then they would be interested in
promoting their music to a wider audience than DJs and other pros.

 If the recording companies and/or the artists they record are content with
the amount of customers they have now , then the present information
situation at raves is good enough.

		Larry Ching/larryc@netcom.com


From sfraves-owner  Fri Oct 22 17:46:05 1993
From: Jon Drukman <jdrukman@us.oracle.com>
Date: Fri, 22 Oct 93 17:44:14 PDT
Subject: DJ Don't Promote Musical Recordings
Status: 

>> all the DJs I know are very good about showing me the records, even in
>> the middle of a busy set.
>
> Well , if the usual case is that there is a "professional courtsey" 
>between DJs , that's nice. As far as non-DJs go , it seems from some other 
>posts that some DJs are willing to share the information with "ordinary" 
>folks, which is the focus of my original post .

i think it's just a "friendliness" thing... if you are intrusive, you
can expect that the DJ won't be too excited about showing you the
record.  if i'm in the middle of doing something, i don't like to
explain what the record is to whoever's standing there, but if i have
a spare moment, i might just tell them...

>It's occured to me that I've been assuming that the companies that
>produce the recordings want to reach a wider scope of customers that
>that provided by DJs and other professionals - I've assumed that the
>companies would love to have their recordings in demand by a wider ,
>non-professional audience. If my assumption is correct , then they
>would be interested in promoting their music to a wider audience than
>DJs and other pros.

interesting point... i think that most of the small underground labels
wouldn't really care - they don't have the distribution to get into
Tower Records, and the "general public" isn't in the habit of stopping
by dance stores.  so, there's no real incentive for an underground
label to sell beyond the DJ store network.

and anyway, dance labels usually hit all their prospective customers
(DJs) by getting their items plugged in DJ-trade publications.  so,
it's like I said before... if you want to find out what DJs are
playing, hang around with them, read their magazines and go to their
shops.

Jon Drukman                                         jdrukman%dlsun87@oracle.com
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
This calls for a very special blend of psychology and extreme violence.

U Network, October 1993

Mad Scientists, computer viruses, guy zombied out on video

Elnor Kinsella

Michelle Robinson. 
Produced at Texas  A&M
Riding shotgun from a 5 year old P.O.V

Ruben Cabrea
Produced at Kansas City Art Institute

dodger at heart

Performed by Axon
Directed by Rob Campanell

pussycats, choirboys.  Created on an Amiga using DPaint IV

Performed by DHS
Directed by Benjamin Stokes
Boom boxes, Ironworkers, Mechanical voices.  All digital
animation.  Created on a Macintosh using Swivel 3D.

From sfraves-owner  Fri Oct 22 20:33:25 1993
From: red@net.bio.net (Ben Wing)
Date: Fri, 22 Oct 93 20:31:29 -0700
Subject: Re: How was YSH?
Status: 

In article <9310222012.AA13377@groovy.us.oracle.com> you write:
|
|good time.  really really cool space.  really really.  hope it can be
|used again in the future.
|

Have to agree here ...  the space has the industrial-warehouse chic
down to a tee: girders, boards, steel frames, Texaco trucks, etc.
all over the place, super-high ceilings, weird shadows all over the
place, even the location fits -- right underneath the freeway.
Really trippy, really cool.

I think they need to work on some other aspects; for one thing,
the layout was kind of disconnected so there wasn't a unified feel
among the people there.  Also, the music was not fast enough and not
energetic enough, contributing further to the unfocused-ness.  (Given
the vastness of the warehouse and the industrial location, they could
easily pump the music up WAY loud and there would still be plenty
of places you could go to get away from the noise.)

ben

From sfraves-owner  Sat Oct 23 00:41:06 1993
From: martian <turpin@stargate.apple.com>

Status: 




Hey, this could be interesting to check out.
I never got to see Invisible Site, but many
friends gave it rave reviews.



_-_-_-_-_-_-_-_-_-_-_-_-_-_-_-_-_-_-_-_-_-_-_-_-_-_-_-_-_-_-_

               G E O R G E   C O A T E S
                   Performance Works

                      PRESENTS 


                   Box Conspiracy:
                  An Interactive Sho

                 A Live Comic Musical

From sfraves-owner  Sat Oct 23 02:14:17 1993
From: hart@ntmtv.com (Chris Hart)
Date: Fri, 22 Oct 93 14:08:24 PDT
Subject: Re:  DJ Don't Promote Musical Recordings
Status: 


I can think of a few reasons:
1. They're too damn busy.( A good reason , in my opinion)
---------------
definitely a good reason, IMNSHO...

2. They don't want other DJs/wannabe DJs from finding out "the easy way"
   what they spent time & money discovering.
---------------

this is, IMNSHO, WEAK!!!  It is in direct conflict with the rave
ethos bantered around here, an ethos which I respect.  HOWEVER, when
someone who claims to be down with the "peace love & sharing" vibe won't
*share* the musical selection they're playing because they selfishly
want to be the only one with X, Y or Z rekkid...I revoke their status
as one of the "peace love & sharing" folks..."can't play both sides of
the street, Sonny"

3. It would cut into their "mystique" if the focus was shifted to the
   sources of the music instead of the tasty mixing of the DJ. ( Hopefully,
   this is a rare reason for hiding record labels).
---------------
I said it before, I'll say it again...if you've got SKILLS, this ISN'T
necessary...having the records does not a mix make...


Are there any DJs you know that are exceptions to this?

-------------

Our "own" Jon Drukman is a delightful exception to it, every *single* 
time I've asked him about what he or someone else is/was playing, he's
been right there w/ the 411.  Not only was he forthcoming with the info,
but he was also correct, and in fact answered questions that had originally
been directed at someone else.  Good show, Jon.

Also of this list, Lee, has directed me to a number of cool records, and
is very cool about giving up the titles, etc.

AND, Lee's friend Christopher (not me, nor the guy at fluid last week)
has given me a score of titles, many off a mix tape he made himself.
Christopher gave me the tape MONTHS ago, and I'm STILL listening to it;
it's hella good, and he has told me at one time or another what nearly
every cut on the damn thing is.  Was he worried that I wanted to get the
records & learn how to mix 'em?  Nope.  Am I gonna replace him on the scene
cuz I know what his records are?  Are monkeys gonna fly out my....well, you
get the idea...he's got SKILLS people...

these are DJ's with SKILLS, DJ's with STATURE, DJ's wiTH COURAGE!!!  DJ'S
WITH GREY POUPON MUSTARD!!!!  JUMP BACK IMPOSTERS!!!  RANT RANT RANT RANT!!!!

PHWEW!

From sfraves-owner  Sat Oct 23 10:09:13 1993
From: larryc@netcom.com (Larry Ching)
Date: Sat, 23 Oct 93 10:09:48 PDT
Subject: Re: Dwight Yokum's Mutant Bastards
Status: 


Randy Tinkerman recently posted this:
> 
> Larry, Dwight Yoakum's Mutant Bastards won't record on Prancing Nag records
> for another 23 years yet.  Or are you already hip to the next generation's
> techno backlash?

 -Note the "Mutant" in their name - those little genetic singularities grew
fast and died young ... they were musically gifted , though. Unfortunetly for
Prancing Nag Records , the Muties were their sole artist and money maker -
after the overheated cellur structure of the band simultaneous dissolved
during an extremely hot sampling session at a local foundry, the recording
company folded .

	Larry Ching/larryc@netcom.com

From sfraves-owner  Mon Oct 25 09:19:07 1993
From: lxfogel@srv.PacBell.COM (Lee Fogel)
Date: Mon, 25 Oct 93 9:19:01 PDT
Subject: week in review
Status: 


Vacation has given me the opportunity to go out a bit more than usual this
past week.  Here's a rundown of the first leg of my SF House scene tour.

10/15 - Fri.  The Orb.  I'm not a big Orb fan, and "Little Fluffy Clouds"
still nauseates me,  but this show totally blew me away.  I remember 
thinking about how the show was all effect, with no substance, then 
realizing that this was OK, because the substance was in the effect.  
Well, you had to be there I guess.  Simply amazing.

10/18 - Mon.  Checked out Jazid Up at the Oasis.  Didn't get going until
about 11:30.  It's a nice, laid back scene, like a night time version
of Boogie Buffet's sun room.  $5, free hoerderves.

10/19 - Tues.  I expected more from Together, since I had been hearing
great things about it.  Simon & Garth seemed to be having an off nite.
The vibe was mediocre, but not bad.  Big Heart City is closing; Together
will be moving to somewhere around 9th & Howard.  Maybe a shift from that
dark basement will bring it some new life.

Thurs.  The new Somar space for Your Sister's House definately has
potential.  They didn't get to use the performance area like they had
planned, so held it in the warehouse/storage section of the building.
The music and sound system were was simply awful, and the there was a
general lack of cohesiveness, so I opted for Delusions Of Grandure
(stupid name) at 1015 Folsom.  It's been a while since I've been there 
at nite.  I won't go into details, but they have really gone ballistic
with the visuals.  Jon Williams was playing a fantastic set.
There wasn't much of a vibe there, but the sound/lights/music made up
for that.  ComeUnity should be insane.

I went back to YSH, to give it another chance, but at 3, nothing much
had changed, so I called it a nite.

Fryday - The map point for Tesla, which took us to 150 Folsom,
the old home of Deep Faith until it was condemmed as a fire hazard.  The
place has really been fixed up.  They had nice visuals there,  and a
nice little bunch of people.  But at 1, the DJ was playing head pounding
hardcore on a pretty bad sound system.  It wasn't really a comfortable
place to chill and we just weren't in a hardcore frame of mind. We hung 
out for an hour, before finding out that we had already missed Shoban.
I heard that things really took off later.

Saturday - By now, we were starting to get disallusioned with the party
scene.  We hadn't planned to go to Basics, but were desparate for *some*
kind of event that we could completely get immersed in.  We arrived at
2:45, just as they were finishing with the under 21 roundup.  Condolences
to all the 18 - 21 yr olds out there.  Despite a horrible sound system
and the complete loss of visuals, Basics went off.  Totally.  It
was a great party, as good a vibe as any Basics I have been to.  We
left at 7, only because the sound had deteriorated into pure distortion.
Tony and Jeno ripped it up it.  I can't wait to hear Tony at Chez Groove, 
where we know that audio will be stellar. :-)

Sunday - Momentum carried us to Boogie Buffet, which was fun, as usual.
I fist fight broke out in the sun room, and in the anything goes
atmosphere of Boogie Buffet, it was hardly noticed before being broken
up, and everyone grooved on.

Janie & I fly out today for Cheops and the River Nile, but we'll be
back to celebrate our 10 yr. anniversary at the FMR.  It seems like 
there's going to be a Casper afterparty at Marx Meadows on Sunday,
which should be a nice warmup for the Halloween BulletProof
Boat Party.

- leg of eel

From sfraves-owner  Mon Oct 25 10:29:55 1993
From: raisty@berlioz.nsc.com (Sue Raisty)
Date: Mon, 25 Oct 93 10:29:38 PDT
Subject: Do you know?
Status: 

Sorry for taking up bandwidth, but does anyone know the name of the
charity that collects old pairs of eyeglasses to distribute to those
who cannot afford them?  I'd really appreciate it - I have 2 old pairs
of glasses.

Rave Related Content:  went to Basics Sat., and I had a pretty good
time at my first rave since moving to San Francisco from Boston.  But
I swear, every 5 minutes between 2am and 4:30am some security person
would tap me on the shoulder to look at my wristband, and they'd check
it REALLY carefully.  I mean, I know I look young, but geez.  Totally
ruined the vibe for me.

From sfraves-owner  Mon Oct 25 10:52:08 1993
From: csc@pilot.njin.net (Sean Casey)
Date: Mon, 25 Oct 93 13:52:03 EDT
Subject: Re: DJ Don't Promote Musical Recordings
Status: 

Maybe we need two kinds of events. One where the DJ is apart, a
performer, and the attendees are the audience. The DJ should never be
disturbed, and the audience shouldn't know what music is playing.
(Perhaps stage hands could help enforce this.)

At the other kind, everyone is a participant. The DJ isn't a
performer, she is one of us. We're all there to connect and make
something. We respect the fact that mixing is difficult when
interrupted, but we're not afraid to approach the DJ when he has a
spare moment, for he is one of us.

I'd much rather go to an event of the second kind (YSH or Liquid Air
being a perfect example). I'm a 60s love child I guess. I just really
get into the togetherness thing, and I much prefer DJs that are
positive and approachable. They don't _have_ to be; I just like it a
lot better that way.

flowers to ya, :)

Sean

From sfraves-owner  Mon Oct 25 10:57:22 1993
From: csc@pilot.njin.net (Sean Casey)
Date: Mon, 25 Oct 93 13:57:12 EDT
Subject: Do you know?
Status: 

Security people checking out my wristband at the Orb really spoiled
the vibe for me.

    "Your papers! We want to see your papers!"

America just keeps going downhill. Sigh.

Sean

From sfraves-owner  Mon Oct 25 11:12:41 1993
From: mw@sybase.com (Michael Wertheim)
Date: Mon, 25 Oct 93 11:12:21 PDT
Subject: basics
Status: 


This weekend's Basics at the Trocadero was easily one of the best ever.

Often, parties at the Trocadero that feature Jeno/Tony/Spun/etc suffer from
being way too overcrowded.  I usually can't enjoy myself at a rave if it takes
me 20 minutes to navigate my way through the crowd just to get a drink of
water.  Fortunately, Basics ended up with an ideal-sized crowd -- mainly
because there were no under-21 people there.  I hate to say it, put the lack
of the under-21 crowd really helped make this rave a success.  The crowd that
was there was very friendly.

Musicwise, it was brilliant.  I can't say that about any other rave that I've
been to since Let Freedom Rave on July 4th.  Jon Williams and Tony played
amazingly fierce, amazingly trippy acid sets.  Jeno played a decent set.  He
played quite a few good songs, but his set just wasn't anywhere nearly as
intense as Tony's.  Spun followed Jeno.  By the time Spun came on, the sound
system had deteriorated to the point of unlistenability, so we took off about
a half hour into Spun's set.

There were only a few bad points.  1) The music in the chill room was way too
loud.  Ambient music is meant to be played in the *background*, guys.  2) They
didn't use the standard Numark mixing board that the DJs prefer.  Instead they
used the club's mixing board (which had knobs instead of sliders).  It took
most of the DJs a few minutes to get used to the new board.  Spun never got
used to it, so most of his mixes were a bit off.



From sfraves-owner  Mon Oct 25 12:50:58 1993

From sfraves-owner  Mon Oct 25 14:23:11 1993
From: "Scott Nozawa*" <scott_nozawa*@quickmail.apple.com>
Date: 25 Oct 1993 14:34:18 -0800
Subject: DJ's 'n' all that
Status: 

                       Subject:                               Time:13:42
  OFFICE MEMO          DJ's 'n' all that                      Date:10/25/93


>Does anyone think DJ's should be untouchable and put on the level of 
>celebrity?
 
     The answer to this question is no.  However; (not to sound too heavy but...)
if one thinks of a DJ as more of a Technoshaman there are some things to
consider.  While the masses dance the DJ is in a trance paving the way for
theirs to happen.  I don't want to speak for all DJs so I'll just say that when
I spin I get into a kind of strange space, somewhat detatched from particular
events and individual people that are around me.  This enables me to hear the
vibe inside of me and to try to bring it out for people to enjoy.  When I'm on
the decks it's not that I'm tring to ignore people it's that I'm very inside
myself trying to present my set.  

     You have to remember, a DJ is only a DJ when he/she is on the decks!

******* PLUG *******    
If you are in the mood 
please come by Motion 
this Wednesday night 
to hear me (Tamotsu),
Rick Preston, and Spun
*******************

Keep it Alive and Thrive!                    T. Scot

One of the inspiring aspects of raves is that everyone seems to be
on the same level for a few hours.  I am fascinated by DJs who are 
capable of Hypnotizing me with the music, especially until the wee 
hours of the morning;  And then I can just walk up to them and start 
talking to them about my experience and almost any other things.  I 
am surprised, tho' as to how many people don't go up to the DJ after-
wards to comment on the experience.  They do need the feedback.

- Steve

Yes yes yes!  It's very LONELY to be in the booth with my records for

weird rush doing a good set, and smiles and hugs from friends and random
people afterwards goes a long way toward normalizing things again so I can
continue on and enjoy the party.

From sfraves-owner  Mon Oct 25 17:08:46 1993
From: Ravi Vinodrai Gadhia <rg@CS.Stanford.EDU>
Date: Mon, 25 Oct 1993 17:08:41 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: Tesla
Status: 

Hey All,

Hope everyone had a good weekend,...the year's almost over.  eeks!

Friday, I went to Tesla.  This party had a really good underground
feel...maybe too underground!  We arrived at 1 AM or so & Shobhan
was playing a good,fast,trippy set.  There was free beer (beer?!)
and people were socializing/drinking/& kinda dancing.

After Shobhan, came a DJ who played a pretty hardcore set that
drove away most of the crowd--a shame because around 3 AM, the 
music got CRAZZZY (good) and then SpaceTime Continuum come on
with a great set that got *everyone* tripping all over the place.  

With a nice vibe finally established, the party pumped along until
6ish when things turned Ambient.  Probably only 20 or 30 people
stayed until the end giving the party a very intimate feeling.

Fun for the party-goers, but the promoters were disappointed 
at the turnout.  :(  Oh well...  


Have a great week!
Ravi




From sfraves-owner  Mon Oct 25 19:56:23 1993
From: red@net.bio.net (Ben Wing)
Date: Mon, 25 Oct 93 19:56:20 -0700
Subject: Re: Do you know?
Status: 

About that security ...

At about 2am I went to Basics with a couple friends, one of whom was
under 21 ...  as soon as we found this out, we stopped and tried to
figure out what to do, and eventually took off.  By this point we
realized that the best thing to do would have been to just go on in
at the start and act like nothing was amiss.  Jen (the under-21'er) was
20 and about to turn 21, and we figured they might not notice.  Of
course, we had spoiled our chance by hanging around and making it
obvious there was a problem.  So we went home to see if there were
any other raves, but the only one was at 16th/Harrison, which we had
no interest in going to.  (and it was $20, too)  So eventually
(around 3:45) we decided to go back and try again.  Jen went first,
and did indeed get in.  I was last, and as I went through, the guy
said, "Hmm ...  weren't you the guy here before with the girl who
was under 21?"  I just stared at him and he eventually said, "Ah
fuck, it's late ...  I don't really care anyway."

ben

From sfraves-owner  Mon Oct 25 22:08:48 1993
From: jsl@netcom.com (John S. Lee)
Date: Mon, 25 Oct 93 21:46:58 -0700
Subject: weekend deadhorse show...
Status: 

I did not make it out on Friday or on Wednesday so I have nothing to say
about those two days.  But I have plenty to say about this Sat/Sun.

Sat. I went to BASICS.  I saw what I expected, and was not disappointed.  I
knew that @ 2:30 the "minors" would have to go, and I was gonna go with
them, right over to Rhythm.  But I asked one of the Basics Family what was
up, and they said that gurads wouldbe going thru the crowd looking for
armbands.  After about 45 minutes, they got all 21-- off the florr without
major interruption of the party.  If I were >18 && <21  I would not have
gone to the party.  Cab laws suck, and people should not pay good money to
go home @ 2:30.  Weak.

The "vibe" was absent by my account.  I mean, if you're "straight", and
wanted to go out, BASICS was the place to be.  Lots of hetero action, lots
of scamming, just lots of the usual.  No alcohol, which was a real bummer. 
Plenty of smoke(ing).  I like the Troc, too bad not much was done to it. 
That brings me to the next issue:

SOUND!

The sound sucked.  There is no better way of putting it.  Mostly either 
DISTORTED BASS or SCREAMING HIGHS.  There was no balance.  There was
however plenty of feedback, since they did not use sandboxes (or if they
did, they did not use them correctly for the Troc.  You need FOAM for that
place as well [wood, bouncy, floors]).  People were out of their heads, so
they danced anyway.  Bad sound killed whatever "vibe" people were trying to
get.  Despite that the DJ's did pretty well.  I was impressed by Tony
(again!), and Josh did the do.  Jeno was a bit off that night.  He did not
do it like he did it at Rhythm the previous week. Spun was incredible, but
after hours of that brutal sound system, people just could not keep up. 
Spun was wicked nonetheless!  I attribute the bad sound to feedback and a
shitty soundsystem.  A soundcheck next time would do wonders for such
situations.

There were hella tweekers there, but it was fun to see them after all this time.

Halloween:  I dunno.  I may just trip at home.  I know that there will be
two parties.  I know where they will be.  I think that I've done my
Halloween partying before, so there may not be a need to push any limits. 
The Boat Party sounds quite good tho.  But more later.

Cooled my brain (Sunday Morn.) at my partner's house.  Got up at around
12:30 to go to the Boogie.  It was hittin!  Felix was fucking it up, but
since I had already drank a 40 oz. of Crazy Horse, still feeling the efx of
some great "Hug Potion", I decided to put on the training wheels and head
home at 3:30p.  Besides, Preston ran out of drink tickets, and it was hot. 
I had no intention of spending $40 on drinks (easily done whilst frying),
so's I left.  Great party tho!!!

PS - The Troc is a nice club!!!

=========

Look, if I EVER ask anyone to pay $10-$15 to go to any of my gigs, rest
assured the sound will be the ONE.  Anything less is weakness and uncaring.
 Having a shitty soundsystem is a good enough reaon not to throw a party. 
Not doing a soundcheck is another.  This is one of the MANY reasons people
are saying "The Scene is Dead".

The "scene" as we all knew it 2 years ago is quite dead.  The scene we knew
a year ago is still dead.  The scene next year will make this one obsolete
too.  The scene is always re-inventing itself.  This year (YTD), has stunk.
 There have been a few bright spots, but this year is as good as gone. 
Parties are the shit if they are smaller, and more intimate.  Massives are
over.  They are the dead horse of the house scene.  People just are not
into massives anymore (Thank G-D!).  Large parties are cool (check Rhythm),
but MASSIVES are decidedly out.

The people who throw massives didn't care enough to put heart behind what
they were doing.  Parties getting shut down, stupid cab laws (which BTW are
being revised just as this "scene" becomes better defined - read thinning
out [PS shoulda done it sooner folx :( ]), greedy promoters, greedy DJ's,
fights, shootings, stabbings, tweekers, bad attitudes, politics, and
general rubbish have caused this scene to thin out.

That is all fine with me.  Since the only people who are left are those who
want to do things differently.  The people left are people who care about
the people attending their show.  And even though there may not be as many
parties, or many more massives, there will always be some choice parties to
check out every week, so don't lose heart.

It's mind-numbing to realize the speed that things change.  And if you
compare it to LA, we're still on top in terms of general integrity, and
DJ's (the best are in or soon will be in SF, PERIOD!!!).

=======

Derrick Carter is coming back to town soon.  Can't wait to hear him spin. 
He is the ONE.  Mark Farina soon, non?

John Howard has some new tapes made this week!  Gonna get mine!  Check him
out if you're out, or go to Boogie in the morning.

Nitty Gritty video "Let Your Backbone Slide" is available.  $25 for 45
minutes of the house scene in SF.  Great narrations, and crackin on!  Mail
me for your copy.

URB SFDisco section is going thru major politix.  Look for new writers soon
(long overdue!).

From sfraves-owner  Mon Oct 25 22:22:56 1993
From: Gioni Pasquinelli <pasque@ucdavis.edu>
Date: Mon, 25 Oct 1993 22:06:43 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: Chief Warkiller
Status: 


	Last Friday, wilma Mankiller, chief of the Cherokee Nation spoke
here at UCDavis.  It was pretty interesting hearing about how the
Cherokees' act like another nation almost.  They have their own schools,
hospitals, even welfare systems etc.  she talked mostly about the past and
how she came to become chief.
	She said something that caught my ears:
I'm not sure how to spell so I'll just spell it how it sounded.  If
anybody knows the correct spelling or can elaborate on it please do!
	She said "shaw-du-gay" which means the gathering of people for the
benefit of all.  Sounds like a good rave name to me :)

Peace,
G

Gioni Pasquinelli
pasque@hamlet.ucdavis.edu

From sfraves-owner  Tue Oct 26 12:33:58 1993
From: phred@well.sf.ca.us (Fred Heutte)
Date: Tue, 26 Oct 1993 12:30:13 -0700
Subject: Re: weekend deadhorse show...
Status: 

I'm sorry to hear that the sound at the Troc/Bridge has deteriorated so much.
Last winter, they had the best club/house/rave/younameit sound I've heard
*anywhere*.  I haven't met the audio geniuses who put it together but I did
meet some of their friends who described in some detail what it was all
about.  It was a great space with the best sound while it lasted, but as
with many things in the scene it achieved the pinnacle only briefly before
club and promoter priorities turned elsewhere.  But nonetheless I'm glad
to see the Troc space being used again for this stuff.

Glad also to see jslee's props to Tony, who's knocked off a whole laundry
load of my sox this year :)  I know that Funky Techno Tribe has a rep for
inconsistency and organizing problems -- especially the last one -- but
I'm looking forward to Saturday night.

If Carter & Farina start doing their two-on-four thang again, everyone
better be ready for brainmelt!

From sfraves-owner  Tue Oct 26 12:47:36 1993
From: Scott Everett Swiger <scottie@uclink.berkeley.edu>
Date: Tue, 26 Oct 1993 12:20:59 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: email & masscom
Status: 


Hi folks!

I'm doing a research paper for my Mass Communications class at Cal on
email as a form of alternative mass communication, and I'd like to get
some input from all ya'll.  Specifically, being fairly illiterate in the
actual workings (structure, technology, uses, etc.) of email, I'd like
some general info on what sort of uses email has to Joe Public. What sort
of user groups (for lack of a better word) exist out there and how can
they enable the "average" person to communicate with others in ways
different from existing forms of communication (in other words, what
differentiates email communication from other types?).  Other issues I'm
looking at include how email has affected and will affect mass
communications as an institution, what threats are being posed to email
users by the government (if someone could give me the email address/ph.#
of the Cypherpunks I'd ge most grateful), and basic questions of privacy
and rights in email use.

This discussion could be on sfraves or just send mail to me if your
response is lengthy, or if it's info I can get from existing
archives/files/whatever please point me in the right direction.

BTW, Mother Earth Sound System has not left the planet, we're planning an
indoor party up on the Sonoma State Campus in mid-November, and other
indoor parties for this fall.

If you like jazz OR house music, come to Le Chateau (the co-op in Berkeley
where a bunch of us live) this Saturday for our Halloween extravaganza.  
At noon, a tasty brunch with the Broun Fellinis providing jazzy grooves to
eat and dance by, then from about 2-7 pm, MESS DJs Brad, Stonie, and
Scottie (that's me) will spin some appropriately funky midday house, hip
hop, acid jazz, and dub, then (whew) stay for dinner at 7 and if you're
still standing, bands until late (it's a 13 hour party! and free if you
show up early and say your guests of Whit or Scott!)

In any case, BIG THANKS in advance to those that can help me out with info
for my project!

Peace + Respect...

			s   c   o   t   t   i   e
			*************************
			MOTHER EARTH SOUND SYSTEM
			*************************
			>>>RESPECT YOUR MOTHER<<<

From sfraves-owner  Tue Oct 26 14:57:58 1993
From: vivianm@src.dec.com
Date: Tue, 26 Oct 93 14:57:54 -0700
Subject: My weekend at Rhythm
Status: 


Rhythm is definetely a good party for Saturday nights.  I refused 
to go to Basics and Cat in the Hat.  I cannot see spending any more 
than 10 dollars to go somewhere to dance till dawn when I can do 
that in a club in San Francisco.  We got there close to 4, just in 
time to catch the end of Marky's set which was excellent.  After 
Marky was Jan Cooley who was also very good.  I really recommend 
it for anyone who does not want to attend a rave but dance till the 
morning.  The people get really into it, and sometimes you may get 
elbowed or accidentally hit, but that aside, it is a lot of fun.  
I wanted to go to Boogie Buffet after but wanted to freshen up a 
bit.  We couldn't find our friends that lived in the city, so we 
drove around for a bit.  We happened upon Vaness where we found this 
place called The Hot Tub.  For 10.50 per person per hour, you could sit in a 
hot tub and or sauna and take a shower .
The hot tub seemed to have some kind of soothing oil in it, it was very nice.  
A great way to relax after dancing all night. It sure beat renting 
a motel room to get cleaned up.  After that we went to Boogie Buffet 
feeling very refreshed and comfortable.  
Living 45 minutes from the city, it is nice to have somewhere to 
go and almost feel like you went home and came back again. 


;-)
vivianm

From sfraves-owner  Tue Oct 26 19:24:18 1993
From: nineball@remarque.berkeley.edu (9ball)
Date: Tue, 26 Oct 93 19:24:13 -0700
Subject: Off to new horizons.
Status: 


Hi again.

This will most likely be my last posting for quite some time (I
know, I know, so what...) as I am off to explore odd corners of
the world starting next week, namely Eastern Europe and the UK.
So far, it looks like the Czech and Slovak republics,
Poland, Bulgaria, possibly Turkey, and back to the UK (London)
and some time in Ireland (Dublin, Belfast.)

I'll let you all know when I return, (or perhaps during the
trip if I find an internet connection?) if I saw any evidence
of any sort of rave scene in those lands.  I would expect there
to be something in Prague, given the huge American and British
population there right now....

The bad news is I don't really plan on looking, as I've moved on
to other things recently.  I don't think I have ever really decided
to quit raving, it's just that it served it's purpose in my
life and other things seem to be popping up where I once spent
my time in those killer trances with some good people (YES! MOST
OF THE SFRAVERS INCLUDED!  You know who you are!)

Anyways, I'll read for a few more days, and if anyone has any ideas
or tips on what to do or where to go to find good people, ravers,
punks, and otherwise, in any of those countries (especially Prague,
London, Dublin, and Belfast) please e-mail me at

nineball@remarque.berkeley.edu

and let me know.

Later!

From sfraves-owner  Tue Oct 26 21:09:44 1993
From: "Pete Reiter" <megatest!plethorax!preiter@uu2.psi.com>
Date: Tue, 26 Oct 93 17:59:28 PDT
Subject: Basics
Status: 

Well, there seems to be some mixed reviews on Basics. Personally it was the best
party I've been to in a long time.

When we got there (around 11:30 p.m.) is was not yet going really strong, but
from looking around at the crowd I saw NO shirtless males, NO overdressed
females and a distinct absence of clubby types. In addition, the sound was
brilliant. Yes, by the end of the evening the sound system was completely 
unlistenable, but when we got there it was crystal clear and it completely
enveloped you without being terribly loud. The sound definitely deteriorated
sometime during the night. I bet they blew some speakers or something.

I thought Tony, Jon Williams and Jeno were all incredible. Spun's set was
probably also amazing, but I couldn't listen to it because of the sound system.

The vibe was definitely there, but it was one of those vibes that dissapears
as soon as you leave the dance floor. Maybe the vibey people just stayed on the
dance floor all night. I know I had trouble leaving.


						Pete

From sfraves-owner  Wed Oct 27 15:02:02 1993
From: PLUI@IOSSVR.gm.hac.com
Date: Wed, 27 Oct 93 15:01:54 PDT
Subject: 
Status: 

Here's the accompanying bit on e that was in The Globe and Mail from Toronto.

plu

-------------------------article------------------------------------------------
FACT VERSUS FICTION
The agony over ecstasy

BY CHARLOTTE PARSONS	
The Globe and Mail	 

The drug known to ravers as ecstasy has a history that is long and rife with 
misconceptions.  Methylenedioxymethamphetamine (MDMA) was patented 81 years ago 
in Germany by the Merck Pharmaceutical Co., and more or less forgotten until 
1976, when a research paper was published on its psychoactive effect on humans.

MDMA has been described as a psychedelic drug but Bruce Eisner, the U.S. author 
of Ecstasy, the MDMA Story, calls it an empathogen. This means that it 
heightens a user's appreciation of others without causing the perceptual 
distortions associated with a true hallucinogen.

"People on MDMA are open, loving and alert," he says. "They don't generally, 
with normal doses, have hallucinatlons or confusion. The change is more an 
internal change."

However, the rumour mill has accused ecstasy of a variety of negative side 
effects. It has been dubbed a "wheelchair" drug for supposedly sapping the body 
of spinal fluid. According to another story, it can cause symptoms similar to 
those of Parkinson's disease.

Mr. Eisner, a San Francisco writer with a master's degree in psychology, says 
he has found no evidence to support such claims. He says there are several 
shortterm side effects, but they are far less dangerous, they include a 
wiggling of the eyes, loss of appetite and, occasionally, jaw clenching. A user 
also may experience sleeplessness or fatigue until the drug wears off.

"This is typical of what happens" when a drug is made illegal", he says. 
"Availabiiity drops, prices go up and rumours abound. 

He says the link to Parkinson's may have stemmed from someone who confused MDMA 
with a synthetic heroin that can cause a false form of the disease when made 
incorrectly. But the rumoured draining of spinal fluid is groundless.

In all, about 20 people have died after taking MDMA. Mr. Eisner says the 
victims can be divided roughly into two groups: those who had heart problems 
and those who fell prey to "rave dehydration syndrome." 

Several British ravers died after organizers shut off the flow of drinking 
water to the site in an attempt to boost beverage sales.
Prices for ecstasy skyrocketed after it became popular on the rave scene and 
after the United States made it illegal in 1985. A single dose once cost less 
than $10 but now fetches about $45.

The high demand and dwindling supply of MDMA's ingredients have prompted 
basement chemists to produce bastardized versions of the drug. Amphetamine-
laced pills and powders have appeared on the rave scene masquerading as ecstasy.

"It's a real crapshoot whether people are going to get the real stuff or not, " 
Mr. Eisner says.

He blames the ban, arguing that with alcohol and cigarettes killing millions, 
it makes little sense to blacklist MDMA.

------------------abidda-abidda-abidda-thats-all-folx-----------------------

From sfraves-owner  Wed Oct 27 16:17:42 1993
From: Sami Khoury <sk2000@uclink.berkeley.edu>
Date: Wed, 27 Oct 1993 16:01:58 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: Re: A Faschist supervisor needs more pursuasion
Status: 

	My first encounter with these cabaret laws occured when I attended
the Orb show in SF.  I had not heard of such a ridiculous attempt to stem
crime in SF until I saw a guy walking around with a poster yelling that
all under 21ers (that's me) had to leave at 2 am.  Admittedly, the law was
enforced with an almost laughable amount of laxness (I just snipped the
excess from everyone elses bands and stuck em together with Marlo's
stickers), but the whole idea is ludicrous.
	I'm from Texas, and a similar law was enacted in Dallas for a bit.
It eventually got repealed by a district judge on the basis that *any*
curfew law essentially amounts to *house arrest* and is therefore unjust
for those youths who wouldn't be causing trouble regardless of the time of
day (or night).
	I can't vote in Cali and don't live in SF, but those of you for
whom both of those apply, you may want to take that Dallas judge's
rationale to that fascist, I-know-what's-good-for-you fuck up.

Sami


From sfraves-owner  Wed Oct 27 16:22:13 1993
From: gregrich@microsoft.com
Date: Wed, 27 Oct 93 15:37:21 PDT
Subject: ...Basics...
Status: 


A couple of us came down from Seattle for this party...and a good thing, too...

Basics was a _blast_; pure and simple, end of story.  We got there 
about 1:00am.  There were a couple of logistical hassles that were 
irritating (no in & out, and no serious ventilation for those of us on 
the verge of heatstroke), but overall it was an amazingly good party.  
That strange "Cabaret Law" thing was a palpable force, wreaking 
confusion on the minds of all the people who were just gathering to 
have a good non-alcohol time; people over 21 were given wristbands at 
the door, and instructed not to take them off, or they would be asked 
to leave after 2:00.  People under 21 were ushered off to one side and 
sort of kept going in little circles, not being able to decide whether 
to go in or not if they were just going to be ejected at 2:00.  A small 
saving grace was that it was only $10 for 18-21, $15 for 21+.  That was 
an annoying little thorn in the side of otherwise carefree and happy 
partygoers...  Anyway, they were handing out Cabaret rule information 
at the door, getting the relevant information into the hands of the 
people who were directly affected enough to care about doing something 
about it.  I really just wish they'd repeal that sucker...

Inside, the Trocadero sported a sitting/chilling area open to the front 
door, allowing some (desperately!) needed cool, fresh air in.  Through 
two sets of doors, the grand ballroom opened up, a 1500+ sq dance floor 
with a stage at one end (though the djs set up on the floor), sprinkled 
with the 30+ foot floor to ceiling columns.  Green and red argon lasers 
cut entrancing pseudotopographical shapes through lazy drifting 
floorfog, then started etching the image of the rotating earth on the 
ultraglow painted murals all over the walls, catching the attention of 
the hundreds of ravers busting it up in earnest, just flat out _going 
off_.  The lighting, which started out really bright, faded as the 
night went on, as it became clear that the crowd was feeling a little 
oppressed by the strength of the lightshow and psyched to fill the 
space with their own brightness.  And ALL NIGHT, the djs were dropping 
the _sick_ bridges, doing a nonstop mix of the most crazy, ridiculous 
grooves that I've heard in a long time.  Hats off!!!  At around 2:00, 
the security started doing their sweep, flashlights jumping from wrist 
to wrist to check for the sacred band. They even ID'd those of us they 
didn't believe were over 21.  That was a downer for a while, but the 
music came to bring us all back.  The sound did seem to get a little 
muddier as the night wore on, but I couldn't tell if that was 
exhaustion creeping over me or what.  Sounds like it was 'or what'.

There was a really supercoolnrg dood (the one shirtless guy there) 
hanging out just off to one side of the dance floor handling Free Water 
distribution, and his luv phaser was set to "inhibition-vaporize".  
Someone else was wandering the floor with Free Fruit (bananas); he 
probably had as much fun watching people's faces light up in the chill 
room as they did in seeing him appear out of quasi-impenetrable dark.  
The chill room was upstairs, with windows overlooking the dance floor.  
But the room itself reverberated with ambient soundwork of steamtrains 
rushing by in low frequency electronic rumbles, pushing through your 
skin to writhe directly on your nervous system.  There were people 
strewn all over the floor and couches, just hanging.  Like it.

Everybody there was so friendly!!  Smiles smiles smiles smiles smiles 
everywhere.  I was there with three up-until-that-moment-non-ravers, 
and got the immense pleasure of watching the ice melt as they became 
more comfortable with the concept of hundreds of people, most complete 
strangers to each other, jamming and bootstrapping off each other's 
energy.  I got the immense pleasure of being with them as they lit up, 
as the rhythm invaded their spines, watching them drop all of their 
external armor and groove with the vibe.  That's the kind of thing that 
makes hundreds of miles worth travelling.

yeah, baby; basics.  Looking forward to having Basics up here in sunny 
seattle.

Peace.

	>>Dread-Eye

From sfraves-owner  Thu Oct 28 09:44:17 1993
From: dionf@ERE.UMontreal.CA (Francois Dion)
Date: Thu, 28 Oct 1993 12:42:08 -0400 (EDT)
Subject: Re: looking for music...
Status: 

Beyond the ultraworld of Adam Sah:
> 
> A couple of years old I know, but for purely nostalgic value... Does anyone
>   have a copy of Apothesis?

I have 2 but i am not selling them (different versions on vinyl). I also have
it on a CD compilation. But dont despair, here's a quote from a text i posted
2 weeks ago on ne-raves:

-start-
As for Apotheosis "O Fortuna" it was an interesting use of Carmina Burana. It
was first released without the proper royalties paid to the estate of Carl
Orff on Indisc records (note that even if the result was interesting, the use
of opera was not a first either in techno - T99 for example - or house - the
malcolm Mclaren presents diva love opera house is another example). At that
point all copies were removed from the market, but after that an agreement
was reached between Carl Orff's estate and Radikal records who could then
license O Fortuna from Indisc (so much for sacrilege, heh?). It was then
released on full of compilations and even bootlegs have been made (i have
seen cd singles like "O fortuna" by carmina or "Carmina" by O Fortuna etc...
-end-

So you can get the bootlegs or buy a CD comp, like Too Technocal (SPG music
Canada). I think it was also on Only for the headstrong... not sure. But it
is on one comp easily found in HMV and other big stores like that. Also, it
is of course on a Radikal compilation. Dont remember which one. In fact there
may be two versions on 2 Radikal compilations.

So it's all over the place. Shouldn't be too hard to find.

Ciao,
-- 
Francois Dion

forward to is actually on Wednesday night - Come/Unity returns!
Come/Unity was appropriately named - it attracted the core of the
house community for some of the highest-vibe, highest-energy parties
the Bay Area has ever seen.

Of course, the weekend looks great too, with something special every
night - the full moon party Friday night, any of the parties Saturday
night, and Raising the Stone and the ol' Castro thing on Sunday.

Special thanks to Philip Chang for several of this week's entries!

From sfraves-owner  Thu Oct 28 14:29:57 1993
From: rpcaras@srv.PacBell.COM (Bob Carasik)
Date: Thu, 28 Oct 93 14:25:12 PDT
Subject: This Week's SF Rave Guide: 111 Minna party
Status: 

I jjust calle dthe 111 Minna number and the promoter filled in a few details:

ins and outs are OK.  dance area is OUTSIDE
9 - midnite: funhouse downstairs with whizzy sci-fi stuff like a Tesla coil.
8 - 11; Ernie Munson is spinning ambient in the dance tent  ( in a closed street ).
also 8 - 11: live jazz improv inside.
11 - 12 or 1 hip-house w/J. Campbell.
then: Tony Fader
then: Efx and Digit.  1 to 6, and some other names.

Not yer "classic rave" but sounds pretty interesting.

Promoted by an ex-Toon Towner.


Quoted by AstroBoy

From sfraves-owner  Thu Oct 28 16:48:46 1993
From: laura@soda.berkeley.edu (Laura La Gassa)
Date: Thu, 28 Oct 1993 16:48:38 -0700
Subject: VRAVE disaster
Status: 


Hi everyone.

Sorry for the mass mailing but I thought I'd explain something now before
any vraver users tried to log in.

There was a massive corruption of the user database for vrave, so the 
entire database had to be deleted.  This means you will have to start all
over again with you accounts:  log in as new, set up your account with
either your REAL name or your login name as your vrave login name, and
so forth.  Don't forget that you will have to log out and in so you can
see what you are typing, and in some cases you might have to be re-verified.

Laura

From sfraves-owner  Fri Oct 29 08:41:11 1993
From: LUKEY@WordPerfect.com
Date: Fri, 29 Oct 1993 09:39:19 -0600
Subject:  Mixing Board Requirements -Reply
Status: 

>>>>>>>>>>>>>>
	Hey,

	  I have a couple of questions for our resident experts in the area
of
	DJ'ing.  I am looking to start up myself and would like some
suggestions
	on some entry level mixing equipment (i.e. types, how many channels,
	and some relative costs).  Thanks in advance.
<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<

If you're looking for something basic and inexpensive that puts out a
good sound, you might want to check out a Realistic mixer (don't
laugh).  You can get a cheap 2 channel mixer for about $120 at Radio
Shack, and even though it is a cheap mixer, my friend the audio
specialist says they put out better sound than a Newmark.  But
anyways, all you really need is a cross-fader and hopefully monitor
cues.  Monitor cues allow you to hear either one of the channels, or
both at the same time through your headphones.  Some four channel
mixers only allow you to hear one channel at a time, and even though
you can still mix that way, it makes it a little tougher.

Dave Scruton     "Celtic Warrior"

From sfraves-owner  Fri Oct 29 09:33:05 1993
From: pashdown@slack.sim.es.com (Pete Ashdown)
Date: Fri, 29 Oct 1993 10:32:54 -0600 (MDT)
Subject: BPM Counter, Por Favor ! (fwd)
Status: 

> I'm sitting at home with my roommates Powerbook, and I've dialed in to my

From sfraves-owner  Fri Oct 29 09:45:00 1993
From: dionf@ERE.UMontreal.CA (Francois Dion)
Date: Fri, 29 Oct 1993 12:42:50 -0400 (EDT)
Subject: Re: Mixing Board Requirements -Reply
Status: 

Beyond the ultraworld of LUKEY@wordperfect.com:
> 
> If you're looking for something basic and inexpensive that puts out a
> good sound, you might want to check out a Realistic mixer (don't
> laugh).

Or even better, find the product that has been licensed by RS and you'll pay
even less. I paid half RS price on a Pyramid with equalizer, 4 stereo line
channels (12 stereo line inputs switchable), echo and 2 microphone inputs
It was the top model RS had in Canada. It has seen a few years of heavy use
(hasn't seen a lot of days without work...) and i have yet to change one
potentiometer. however i take good care of it and have a special deoxydant/
cleaner than *doesn't* remove lubrification. At some point i tought i had a
problem with a pot but it was my ground! The only mods i have done is
to add a monitor out (it only had headphone monitoring), added phantom power
to the XLR jacks, and upgraded a few components on the lower board, but these
mods are clearly overkill for most apps. It's just i needed better sound
until i can afford either a Mackie CR-1604 or (maybe an S8 24 track).
You'll say that all these channels are not required for DJing, true. I will
use it for more than DJing.

> You can get a cheap 2 channel mixer for about $120 at Radio
> Shack, and even though it is a cheap mixer, my friend the audio
> specialist says they put out better sound than a Newmark.  But
> anyways, all you really need is a cross-fader and hopefully monitor
> cues.  Monitor cues allow you to hear either one of the channels, or
> both at the same time through your headphones.  Some four channel
> mixers only allow you to hear one channel at a time, and even though
> you can still mix that way, it makes it a little tougher.

It depends on how you learned to mix. I learned to mix with a speaker
playing main out locally and in my headphones, the track beeing monitored.
Most beat on beat i do are with the pots up when i start the song when it's on
CD and if on vinyl, as soon as the turntable has gained its speed i put it on.
(of course, i first match the speed :P ). Anyway, back to monitoring, yeah,
well at the station we cannot cue just one channel and i hate it. I also
prefer dual non assignable x-faders than one assignable x-fader. Of course,
if one only wants to dj with 2 turntables, that's it, then a 2 channel mixer,
1 x-fader, entry level mixer is probably enough. But CDs are more and more
into the picture, so are the samplers, beat box, DATs etc... so 4 channels
may also be a good idea if you need 3 or 4 simultaneous sources.

Ciao,
-- 
Francois Dion
    '  _   _   _ 
 CISM (_) (_)  _) FM       Montreal , Canada       Email: CISM@ERE.UMontreal.CA
      (_)  / . _)             10000 Watts          Telephone no: (514) 343-7511

From sfraves-owner  Fri Oct 29 10:10:42 1993
From: LUKEY@WordPerfect.com
Date: Fri, 29 Oct 1993 11:01:35 -0600
Subject:  Re: Mixing Board Requirements -Reply -Reply
Status: 

>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>
>Beyond the ultraworld of LUKEY@wordperfect.com:
>>  > If you're looking for something basic and inexpensive that puts
>out a
>> good sound, you might want to check out a Realistic mixer (don't
>> laugh).
> Or even better, find the product that has been licensed by RS and 
> you'll pay even less. I paid half RS price on a Pyramid with 
> equalizer, 4 stereo line channels (12 stereo line inputs 
> switchable), echo and 2 microphone inputs

What was the price on that mixer?  I think I've seen some Pyramid
components before, but it was just car audio amps and subs.  

> deoxydant/ cleaner than *doesn't* remove lubrification. At some 

What's the name of this cleaner?  One thing about cheap mixers is
that you always have to clean things constantly or your x-faders etc,
will start acting strange on you.  Yesterday I was mixing on my
friend's system, and when I x-faded the mix from track 1 to track 2,
as soon as it reached the far right, all the way on track 2, track 1
kicked back in.  Messed up the mix pretty good, but the problem was
that the x-fader just hadn't been cleaned for a while, and was
starting to act funny electrically.

> (of course, i first match the speed :P ). Anyway, back to 
> monitoring, yeah, well at the station we cannot cue just one 
> channel and i hate it.

I like being able to cue either one or both, but if I had to, I'd
prefer to only be able to do one channel.  I mix all CD on a Denon,
and it's too hard to cue the beat while the other track is playing
through the headphones.  Once I've cued up the starting point, then I
add the other track to the monitor, so I can match them up.

BTW, somebody asked about a BPM program for a computer just a little
while ago.  Does anybody know of one for an IBM compatible?  I guess
I could write one, but I'd rather not if there's a good one already
available.  Any help on this would be greatly appreciated.

Thanks,
Luke.



<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<


From sfraves-owner  Fri Oct 29 10:19:27 1993
From: LUKEY@WordPerfect.com
Date: Fri, 29 Oct 1993 11:15:39 -0600
Subject:  Vinyl vs. CD
Status: 

I don't really want to start an argument about the merits of vinyl or
CD to store your music on, but I had heard from some of my friends
that because of the way the groove is stamped on a record, you can
hear lower subsonic sounds and higher supersonic sounds that aren't
possible on a CD because of it's frequency range.  Does anyone know
if this is true?  Supposedly this is a major reason why DJs prefer
vinyl.  I can understand that too, because really good deep house
depends on an almost subsonic bass line.


From sfraves-owner  Fri Oct 29 10:30:02 1993
From: Jon Drukman <jdrukman@us.oracle.com>
Date: Fri, 29 Oct 93 10:28:07 PDT
Subject: Vinyl vs. CD
Status: 

>I don't really want to start an argument about the merits of vinyl or
>CD to store your music on, but I had heard from some of my friends
>that because of the way the groove is stamped on a record, you can
>hear lower subsonic sounds and higher supersonic sounds that aren't
>possible on a CD because of it's frequency range.  Does anyone know
>if this is true?  Supposedly this is a major reason why DJs prefer
>vinyl.  I can understand that too, because really good deep house
>depends on an almost subsonic bass line.

i think it's a load of crap.  DJs (well, at least *THIS* DJ) prefer
records because right now all the DJ-oriented CD players SUCK!
although supposedly the new Denon has jog/shuttle dials so maybe that
will improve their usability a bit...

also, regarding the extra frequency info in vinyl - most DJs play
their records with VERY heavy tonearm weights... very likely to GOUGE
most of that extra info out after 4 or 5 plays, i'd say...

Jon Drukman                                         jdrukman%dlsun87@oracle.com
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
This calls for a very special blend of psychology and extreme violence.

From sfraves-owner  Fri Oct 29 10:32:10 1993
From: Roy Badami <roy@harlequin.co.uk>
Date: Fri, 29 Oct 1993 17:33:04 +0000
Subject: Re: Vinyl vs. CD 
Status: 


> I don't really want to start an argument about the merits of vinyl or
> CD to store your music on, but I had heard from some of my friends
> that because of the way the groove is stamped on a record, you can
> hear lower subsonic sounds and higher supersonic sounds that aren't
> possible on a CD because of it's frequency range.  Does anyone know
> if this is true?  Supposedly this is a major reason why DJs prefer
> vinyl.  I can understand that too, because really good deep house
> depends on an almost subsonic bass line.
> 

There's certainly no theoretical basis for the above, and with decent
equipment, i sincerely doubt that it's true in practice either.

The theoretically achievable response of CD is DC-22kHz.  Inpractice,
something like 10Hz-20kHz should be achievable.

	Cosmic
