From sfraves-owner  Fri Oct 29 11:15:40 1993
From: LUKEY@WordPerfect.com
Date: Fri, 29 Oct 1993 12:13:59 -0600
Subject:  Re: Vinyl vs. CD -Reply
Status: 

>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>
Vinyl just sounds better, at least for house music, that really
depends on full bass sound...
Also, vinyl is more mixable, you can do more with records compared to
cds...
<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<

With newer CD players, you can do almost anything you could do on
vinyl.  They even have some CD players with a scratch bar or an open
top so you can reach in and scratch with the disk.  The main thing
that I think vinyl has above CD is the ability to fine tune the
speed.  When you're in the middle of a mix, you don't have to use +
or - buttons to bump the speed a little bit, you can push the record
itself just a little bit, and it gives you a lot more control over
the pitch.  Buttons just aren't quite as user-friendly.


From sfraves-owner  Fri Oct 29 11:28:27 1993
From: Roy Badami <roy@harlequin.co.uk>
Date: Fri, 29 Oct 1993 18:29:26 +0000
Subject: Re: Vinyl vs. CD -Reply 
Status: 



> With newer CD players, you can do almost anything you could do on
> vinyl.  They even have some CD players with a scratch bar or an open
> top so you can reach in and scratch with the disk.  


Oh, come on, no way can you scratch by reaching into your cd player
and playing with the disc....

	Cosmic

From sfraves-owner  Fri Oct 29 11:34:11 1993
From: LUKEY@WordPerfect.com
Date: Fri, 29 Oct 1993 12:32:57 -0600
Subject:  Cleaning Mixers...? -Reply
Status: 

>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>
All this talk about cleaning mixers is making me nervous.  I have a
Numark 1650 mixer and it seems to be working just fine, but I got it
used, and it could
PROBABLY use some cleaning.  Where doth one start when one wants to
cleaneth the mixer?
<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<

Well, what I did to clean it was just take a can of WD40 or some
similar cleaner, and connect the small straw-like attachment to the
nozzle (for pinpointing small areas), and spray it down in between
the slider notches.  Move the slider back and forth a few times to
work it in, then spray it again.  This cleaned it out very well, and
you wouldn't really believe how much easier it is to use your
cross-faders after you do this.  Dirt and dust can clog your faders
and make them "catch" during a mix.

From sfraves-owner  Fri Oct 29 11:39:19 1993

open

Oh, come on, no way can you scratch by reaching into your cd player
and playing with the disc....
<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<

That's just what I'd heard from a friend of mine.  I know they have
some with scratch bars, so you just bump a control and it scratches
for you, but these are very expensive.  One nice component that I'd
like to try out sometime is the Roland DJ-70.  I've heard good things
about them, but has anyone here ever used one before?  It's a sampler
that is made for live sampling, looping, etc.  It has a scratch pad
built into it and a smaller keyboard so as not to take up too much
space.

From sfraves-owner  Fri Oct 29 12:06:09 1993
From: pashdown@slack.sim.es.com (Pete Ashdown)
Date: Fri, 29 Oct 1993 13:06:03 -0600 (MDT)
Subject: Re: Vinyl vs. CD -Reply
Status: 

> With newer CD players, you can do almost anything you could do on
> vinyl.  They even have some CD players with a scratch bar or an open
> top so you can reach in and scratch with the disk.

Ummm, CD's really don't work in the same way as vinyl does.  The only thing
they have in common is the fact that they're both round.  An "open top" CD
player would not only be ridiculous (the sound would stop as soon as you'd
touch the disc), but even if it did work the same way as vinyl, you'd have to
move the CD 100x farther in order to get it to do the same "scratch".

I've worked with just about every DJ CD player on the market.  Believe me,
they've got a long ways to go before they'll "scratch".  However, vinyl will
never go from 0 to 45 rpm in 0.01 second.

> The main thing
> that I think vinyl has above CD is the ability to fine tune the
> speed.  When you're in the middle of a mix, you don't have to use +
> or - buttons to bump the speed a little bit, you can push the record
> itself just a little bit, and it gives you a lot more control over
> the pitch.  Buttons just aren't quite as user-friendly.

Most professional DJs I've seen don't fine tune the player with their hands.
They bump the pitch control up or down.  I drag my finger on the vinyl, or
push it up.  I don't see that much difference between that and the +/-
buttons.

The moral of the story is, don't try and make CDs sound like vinyl or vinyl
sound like CDs.  They both have their individual caveats that you can
exploit.  This bit about vinyl being better for bass or house music is IMHO,
unadulterated bullshit.  Ask how many of the boom cars cruising the streets
how many of them prefer vinyl for their bass response.

From sfraves-owner  Fri Oct 29 12:24:16 1993
From: rslau@ucs.usc.edu (Robert Lau)

Subject: Re: Vinyl vs. CD -Reply

From sfraves-owner  Fri Oct 29 12:39:09 1993
From: bbehlen@soda.berkeley.edu (Brian Behlendorf)
Date: Fri, 29 Oct 1993 12:38:49 -0700
Subject: Re: Vinyl vs. CD -Reply
Status: 

On Oct 29, 12:13pm, you proclaimed:
} With newer CD players, you can do almost anything you could do on
} vinyl.  They even have some CD players with a scratch bar or an open
} top so you can reach in and scratch with the disk.  

You saw "Batman Returns", didn't you? :)  Seriously, I HIGHLY
doubt there exists a CD player which would allow you to directly
touch the spinning disc and scratch with it; not only is the data
encoded in a way thay would make no sense played backwards, but
try backspinning at 200rpm! :)

} The main thing
} that I think vinyl has above CD is the ability to fine tune the
} speed.  When you're in the middle of a mix, you don't have to use +
} or - buttons to bump the speed a little bit, you can push the record
} itself just a little bit, and it gives you a lot more control over
} the pitch.  Buttons just aren't quite as user-friendly.

The Denon 2000 has a sliding pitch control; I've used it successfully
by "pulsing" (bumping it down or up a small amount and then returning)
to get the same effect as holding a finger on the spinning platter of
a 1200, to fine-tune it.

	Brian


From sfraves-owner  Fri Oct 29 12:55:29 1993
From: dionf@ERE.UMontreal.CA (Francois Dion)
Date: Fri, 29 Oct 1993 15:52:56 -0400 (EDT)
Subject: Re: Cleaning Mixers...?
Status: 

>All this talk about cleaning mixers is making me nervous.  I have a Numark 1650
>mixer and it seems to be working just fine, but I got it used, and it could
>PROBABLY use some cleaning.  Where doth one start when one wants to cleaneth
>the mixer?

I'm crossposting to BPM because someone already brought the discussion there
while replying to you. First, never use WD40. Also, dont use something that
is not made for cleaning electrical contacts like lock de-icer (yup i've
heard this one a few times). Dont use alcohol either cause it will remove all
the lubricant. Radio shack sells a contact cleaner product specially made for
hifi volume controls. This is perfect. Dont put too much btw. If you really
want to deep clean, use compressed air (RS also sells that). If you do go for
a cleaner with lubricant (which contains a petroleum solvent to remove the
grease) (i dont suggest this) then you will have to do it each month or your
faders will grind down very fast. In worst case situation, you can get
replacement faders for most mixers. I had bought 2 when i got my mixer but i
have yet to use them (they costed 4.95$ each at my local electronic components
distributor).

Ciao,
-- 
Francois Dion

From sfraves-owner  Fri Oct 29 13:00:53 1993
From: LUKEY@WordPerfect.com
Date: Fri, 29 Oct 1993 13:57:33 -0600
Subject:  BPM counting software
Status: 

Well, never mind about the previous message regarding a BPM counting
program.  I just decided to whip one up really quick.  It's very
simple, and works with any DOS machine.  You simply press a key on
the downbeat, count 32 beats, then press a key again.  Remember when
you're counting beats, that the end of the 32nd beat is right at the
start of the next beat, so you'll want to press the key again right
on the downbeat of the 9th measure.  The program is very small, so
I've attached it to this message.  Feel free to give it to whoever
you want to.  If you have feedback on it for me, send me email
directly, so as not to tie up bandwidth.

begin 666 BPM.EXE

From sfraves-owner  Fri Oct 29 13:12:57 1993
From: LUKEY@WordPerfect.com
Date: Fri, 29 Oct 1993 14:09:58 -0600
Subject:  Re: Vinyl vs. CD -Reply -Reply
Status: 

>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>
> that I think vinyl has above CD is the ability to fine tune the
> speed.  When you're in the middle of a mix, you don't have to use +
> or - buttons to bump the speed a little bit, you can push the
record
> itself just a little bit, and it gives you a lot more control over
> the pitch.  Buttons just aren't quite as user-friendly.

Most professional DJs I've seen don't fine tune the player with their
hands.
They bump the pitch control up or down.  I drag my finger on the
vinyl, or push it up.  I don't see that much difference between that
and the +/- buttons.
<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<

What I was saying was that you can get greater control by dragging
the record or bumping it up than you can with +/- buttons, simply
because you have a feel for how much to drag, or how much to push the
record up.  +/- buttons work the same way, but your only control over
how much it changes the pitch is by how long you hold the button
down.


From sfraves-owner  Fri Oct 29 13:16:46 1993
From: LUKEY@WordPerfect.com
Date: Fri, 29 Oct 1993 14:13:30 -0600
Subject:  Re: Vinyl vs. CD -Reply -Reply
Status: 

>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>
The Denon 2000 has a sliding pitch control; I've used it successfully
by "pulsing" (bumping it down or up a small amount and then
returning) to get the same effect as holding a finger on the spinning
platter of a 1200, to fine-tune it.
<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<

That seems like a very hard way to do it.  The 2000 also has +/- keys
that do the same thing.  I'll have to give that a try though, but it
seems as if it would be tougher to get back to the original position
on the slider after bumping it.


From sfraves-owner  Fri Oct 29 13:20:48 1993
From: LUKEY@WordPerfect.com
Date: Fri, 29 Oct 1993 14:19:33 -0600
Subject:  Re: Vinyl vs. CD -Reply
Status: 

>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>
But if you want to get more bass in the 30-60 Hz, there are full of
bass reconstructor units you can buy. These will simulate a "first
harmonic" from the first harmonic in the 60Hz to 120 Hz zone down to
half in 30-60Hz.
<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<

What is an average price on a bass reconstructor?  I assume you could
find one at any type of store that sells proffesional audio
equipment.

From sfraves-owner  Fri Oct 29 14:29:08 1993

From sfraves-owner  Fri Oct 29 19:13:17 1993
From: megatest!kermit!preiter@uu2.psi.com (Pete Reiter)
Date: Fri, 29 Oct 93 16:53:02 PDT
Subject: Re: Vinyl vs. CD
Status: 

To me, the major reason why vinyl is currently better than CDs is the 
availability of music on the two formats. I'd give CDs the edge in sound
quality, only because most DJ's records are trashed. Just watch how your
average DJ treats their records some time. 

The vinyl vs. CD controls are not that big a deal. I would imagine that just
about anyone who DJs could get used to either one.

The real issue is, what format is the music you want to play available on?
There is just so much brilliant music out there on vinyl that will never
get to CD. If I were a DJ, and had to choose. I'd go with vinyl, for now.
I prefer the digital format because you don't need to baby it as much, but
let's face it, the music is what's important, not the format.



Pete

From sfraves-owner  Fri Oct 29 21:13:48 1993
From: martian <turpin@stargate.apple.com>
Date: Fri, 29 Oct 93 21:06:57 -0700
Subject: On Sale Now at the Shack!
Status: 



Hey everybody! I just made my dreaded spare parts trip to
Radio Shack and found that the Minimus 7 speakers are on
sale now ($29.99 each). I know it may sound strange indorsing
a RS product, but if you have never heard these little speakers,
you should stop by and take a look  (listen?) at them.

These are portable die-cast metal two way speakers that actually sound
very good especially for $60 a pair. They are very rugged and
can handle alot of abuse (electronically and physically).

These work very well for small dj'ing monitors, especially if
you mix with the higher frequency stuff, but they do put out
more bass than you would expect. They also work great for
outdoor/patio speakers.

Notes:

* do not expect them to sound like a pair of $500 speakers

* they are not self powered - you need an amp (for $30 what do you expect)

* They are sold separately so you can buy just one
  if you only need it for mono monitoring

* Apr. size = 10h"x6w"x6d"

* RS would be a great place if they would just get rid of the fucking
  idiots that work there.


??? fmr tonight ?????

shazam!

johnny t.

From sfraves-owner  Fri Oct 29 23:25:59 1993
From: larryc@netcom.com (Larry Ching)
Date: Fri, 29 Oct 93 23:26:37 PDT
Subject: On Sale Now at the Shack! 
Status: 

Forwarded message: (Originally from a johnnie t. post )
> Hey everybody! I just made my dreaded spare parts trip to
> Radio Shack and found that the Minimus 7 speakers are on
> sale now ($29.99 each). 

> These work very well for small dj'ing monitors, especially if
> you mix with the higher frequency stuff, but they do put out
> more bass than you would expect. They also work great for
> outdoor/patio speakers.

One thing , outside of the good characteristics - BEWARE! These speakers
are not magnetically shielded - so don't set them next to a video monitor 
or TV , and don't put magnetic media ( cassettes , floppy disks ) on them 
or next to them.

	Larry Ching/larryc@netcom.com

From sfraves-owner  Sat Oct 30 10:32:00 1993
From: larryc@netcom.com (Larry Ching)
Date: Sat, 30 Oct 93 10:32:38 PDT
Subject: Re: On Sale Now at the Shack!
Status: 

 
Minimus 7 speaker review , continued:
 
> 
> >> Radio Shack ... Minimus 7 speakers are on
> >> sale now ($29.99 each). 
> 
> > One thing , outside of the good characteristics - BEWARE! These speakers
> > are not magnetically shielded - so don't set them next to a video monitor 
> > or TV , and don't put magnetic media ( cassettes , floppy disks ) on them 
> > or next to them.
> 
> 
> OK - So $60 for the speakers 
>           +
>      $1.99 Box of Aluminum Foil
>  --------------------------------
> 
>   $61.99 - still a good deal :P
> 
 Unfortunetly , aluminium foil only works to for electric fields , not
magnetic . You have to buy a special foil that blocks static magnetic fields
to do the job right. ( I don't know where they sell this foil - I've seen
it advertised in electronic catalogs ).

 I own a pair of these , and the magnetic field is kind of wimpy , if 
picking up nails is an alternate function you want to use Minimus 7 
speakers for. However , it is strong enough to screw up the colors and
focus on a video monitor or tv. I haven't tried to erase magnetic tape with
it yet , but I wouldn't leave any magnetic media near it. 

 I tried wrapping the back & sides of one of my speakers with aluminium
foil , but it still put out a magnetic field strong enough to warp my
monitor's display. Wrapping a magnet in aluminium foil still allowed me
to pick up paperclips.

Larry " Doctor Science " Ching/larryc@netcom.com 

From sfraves-owner  Sat Oct 30 14:33:41 1993
From: dionf@ERE.UMontreal.CA (Francois Dion)
Date: Sat, 30 Oct 1993 17:31:34 -0400 (EDT)
Subject: Re: Vinyl vs. CD
Status: 

Beyond the ultraworld of Pete Reiter:
> 
> To me, the major reason why vinyl is currently better than CDs is the 
> availability of music on the two formats. I'd give CDs the edge in sound
> quality, only because most DJ's records are trashed. Just watch how your
> average DJ treats their records some time. 

Not only that. A stanton 500 is far from hi end. Same thing with the Shure 35.
Stanton 680EEEL are semi hi end. Now an Ortofon MC30 SUPER is definitely high
end audio and has better frequency response than any CD player (or even
higher the model MC2000 which has a frequency response of 15 Hz to 90KHz but
cost more than a Denon 2700 dual cd player!) but you wont be able to
scratch with that and it would be a waste with the tonearm found on the 1200.

> The real issue is, what format is the music you want to play available on?
> There is just so much brilliant music out there on vinyl that will never
> get to CD.

Never say never... You can buy a CD recorder for less than 4000$ CDN now,
and prices have been falling very rapidly. Also you can go to some music
store and get a record or DAT transfered to CD for 40-50$ CDN. Now it may
look steep, but you can have 70 minutes of only the songs YOU want. Now,
some evil minded people would then resell their vinyls, but that is not
legal... Also, now with the 128 Mb "floppies" it is trivial to store a full
hour of music in ADPCM and do a DJ "floppy" player with a pair of these and
a pair of 16 bit soundcards in a PC...

Ciao,
-- 
Francois Dion

From sfraves-owner  Sat Oct 30 19:30:14 1993
From: bbehlen@soda.berkeley.edu (Brian Behlendorf)
Date: Sat, 30 Oct 1993 19:30:09 -0700
Subject: FMR success story #545
Status: 

        The party last night went off really well; it was probably the largest
one there yet, with 2500 people or so.  The music started around 3, early for
them, so they got a LOT of nighttime music until the sun came up around 7.
The police showed up around 4, but a few of us talked to them and assuaged
their main concers, which were people hurting themselves in the water or on
the cliffs, cars being broken into, etc.  They didn't see any alcohol being
brought into the party, so that was a major plus for them.  Probably the
most brilliant thing was the columns of helium balloons someone had brought - 
it certainly provided an adequate explanation for the pshshshshst sound of
the nitrous tanks!

        The weather was PERFECT (I love california, did I mention?) and
when the sun rose one could see that a fair number of people in the crowd
actually got into the Halloween spirit bye dressing up.  

        The sound system could have been better, but it was because they were
using smaller speakers which were easier to haul up the ridge and down to
the beach.  I think at the next party we should collect money for the 
construction of a staircase from the parking lot up to where the gradual
sand pathway to the beach is on the left hand side.  Those rocks up the side
are REALLY dangerous.  How much would someone say a staircase could be 
built for?

        Anyways, it was great to see everyone, great to be a part of 
something I'll be telling my grandkids about, and great to show a couple
of new-timers the crown jewels of the SF scene.

        Brian

From sfraves-owner  Sun Oct 31 01:04:41 1993
From: StevenJ <aragorn@convex.csd.uwm.edu>
Date: Sun, 31 Oct 1993 03:04:27 -0600 (CST)
Subject: from smiles to frowns
Status: 

Melissa and I just got back home from Grave Reverence.  We had a
GREAT time, but we had to leave a bit early 'cause we're both
getting over colds and have stuff to do this weekend.  The event
was everything it promised to be:  back to basics, thumpin' music,
wide & thick vibe, friendly, smiling people.  The best set spun was
ESP Woody's; a mix of harder trancier stuff with just enough of a
house influence.  I danced my ass off for the whole set.  The
number of vendors was kept down to a minimum and the venue for the
rave was about 40 minutes out from Milwaukee in a skate rink (ala
Rejoice, but not quite as big).  When we left around 3am there were
about 750-1000 people bouncin' around and enjoying the vibe.  But
then...

The music stopped and a man came on the mic.  He said his name was
John and was speaking on behalf of a gentleman named Attorney
Pangman who has been taking care of the civil suit left-over from
the Grave fiasco of last Halloween.  Pangman also had a booth set
up in the vendor area handing out flyers about `fighting for your
right to be left alone' and so on.  As John continued to speak
about Attorney Pangman he used phrases which evoked images of the
cops busting us all at Grave last year, muscling us around, holding
us without charging us for hours and for some an entire day.  It
may be legal, but it's just plain wrong.  John spoke of how our
rights were violated and how Mr. Pangman has been fighting for
those rights for months in Milwaukee civil court.  This is a
dubious claim at best.

If you don't know what happened last year at Grave I can give a
very brief summary.  A very large rave took place, Grave, on
Halloween, 1992.  At about 1:30am the Milwaukee police shut down
the party and proceeded to hand-cuff us all and write citations
which included fines of over $300.  Most of the details aren't that
important for the point I'm trying to get to.  It seems that Mr.
Pangman is now running for a Wisconsin State Senate seat and feels
that he will be able to snatch up the `rave scene vote' by
proselytizing the masses at raves in the Milwaukee area.  I don't
know about you, but this makes me sick to my stomach.  Details
aside, he had very little to do with getting the charges against us
dropped last year, this was the work of Peter Musante.  I am in no
way trying to pump up Mr. Musante's reputation, this is not my
mission.  What I want to do is make you aware of who Mr. Pangman is
and what he is really doing.

By stopping the vibe at a rave he doesn't at all support the scene. 
Also, I am very disappointed in Drop Bass for allowing Mr. Pangman
to speak at Grave Reverence when what he is doing has absolutely
nothing to do with the scene.  He just wants votes.  If he wants
our vote, drop some info in our backpacks and let us make an
informed decision for ourselves.  If we need more info or want to
volunteer for his cause we'll call him.  If he is so strongly
fighting for our right to be left alone, then leave us alone.  I
just don't feel that a rave is the place for getting votes for
being elected to a public office.

I'm going to be getting copies of this letter to all the rave
mailing lists on Internet, to some of the Milwaukee and Chicago
zines and to Reactor in Chicago.  I'm not trying to whip up anger
aimed at Mr. Pangman.  He has every right to do what he is doing,
I just feel that it is wrong and I would hope that everyone
realizes what he is really trying to do and just ignore him.  After
the next Wisconsin State Senate election, he'll just go back to his
law practice and hopefully we won't have to deal with him anymore.


Steve White
stevenJ on vrave
aragorn@convex.csd.uwm.edu

From sfraves-owner  Sun Oct 31 07:51:46 1993
From: lxfogel@srv.PacBell.COM (Lee Fogel)
Date: Sun, 31 Oct 93 7:51:39 PST
Subject: Re: FMR success story #545
Status: 

Brian:
>         The sound system could have been better, but it was because they were
> using smaller speakers which were easier to haul up the ridge and down to
> the beach.

When I first saw those speakers, I got worried cause they seemed rather
puny.  But they really delivered a powerful punchy sound.  No complaints
from me.

I thought Garth played an amazing set of hard driving stuff, a lot of
old favorites and I lot of songs I usually hear in other people's sets.
None of that slower funky disco house music this time.  He really blew
me away.  Markie & Jeno also delivered the goods.  A 4th DJ that no one
seemed to know (Nick?) ended the party with some really nice trance.
I was in heaven.  This was one great party.  What little rowdiness
there was (fireworks, nitrous, screaming assholes) seemed to fade away
long before sunrise.

>  Those rocks up the side
> are REALLY dangerous.

You mean the ones by the tracks that I fell on my ass on climbing
down?  

> How much would someone say a staircase could be 
> built for?

How about an escalator?

> something I'll be telling my grandkids about, and great to show a couple
> of new-timers the crown jewels of the SF scene.

It was pretty beautiful for us old timers too.  Janie & I thank
everyone involved. :-)

- leg of eel

From sfraves-owner  Sun Oct 31 12:18:08 1993

From sfraves-owner  Mon Nov  1 09:42:41 1993
From: crunch@netcom.com (John Draper)
Date: Mon, 1 Nov 93 09:43:21 -0800
Subject: Rave report...
Status: 

Rave report
===========

  Busiest weekend for me since LoveStock...   I started at YSH where it
was held at end of 24th St.    Beautiful weather blessed us with wonderful
raving environment.

  Friday was the FMR,  Brian reported some on that,  but with about 2000+
people,  the energy was intense,   and the sound system might have needed
more balls,  I can see why nobody would want to haul bigger speakers
down that steep slope.

  I danced so hard that I had to jump in the ocean to chill out.   My first
"dip" was at about 4:30am,  and was most "chilling",  although the water
temperature was slightly warmer than the air.  I'd say about 60 degrees
or so.   But I think I might have raised the ocean temperature up a few
degrees I was so hot.    After that initial "dip",  I continued taking
ocassional swims to cool off.   Sure felt GREAT!!   Saw a few others also
taking the plunge.   The trick is to get past the breakers but not to
get out too far,  So's not to be "shark food".

   The party wound down about 1 to 2 PM,   and then I headed back up the
SF where we tried to find the "Boom box" party.   I looked for the radio
signal to try and tune it in on the car radio,   but wasn't sure of the
frequency.   I chilled out at Radions pad for a few hours then headed over
to Liz's party that evening,  then to the Taz party at 607 Haight st.

   Things were hopping over there,  but I also wanted to check out the
Vinnie St party.   It was really wonderful there..  But I missed the dungion
show by a few minutes (Drat!!).

   After that,  it was over to Casper,  thanx to the generosity of Carlos
who provided me an opportunity to attend.   As usual,  Carlos did his insane
set,  and I enjoyed very much the opportunity to provide my awsome energy to 
his sets.    It was very crowded,  but they had a nice outside chill area
but NO live video links (At least not while I was there),   like the flyer
said.

  Then over to the Funkey Techno Tribe I went,   and that enery was totally
awsome.   I think it was the best one yet.  Very powerful acid trance sets
kept my body moving in a tizzy.    By this time,  I had already been up
without sleep for 3 days,  and was pondering leaving early,  but thanx to
a head boost,  I stayed through the end,  before heading out to Boogie Buffet.

  Was thinking of heading over to the DNA for the after party,  but I liked
the Boogie Buffet scene and I just couldn't turn down the breakfast.

  How was the Crissy field party and the DNA after party... Any reports?
What about Awakening??  How was that?
  
Cheers.... T'was a wonderful sleepless weekend....  Now feel GREAT after
a 12 hour sleep.  Don't feel sore a bit...   And I'm back to work as
usual.   Have witnessed 3 sunrises since I slept last...

Hope you other ravers has as much fun as I did...

CC

From sfraves-owner  Mon Nov  1 10:28:22 1993

From sfraves-owner  Mon Nov  1 11:29:03 1993
From: laura@soda.berkeley.edu (Laura La Gassa)
Date: Mon, 1 Nov 1993 11:28:44 -0800
Subject: comparing CASPER "stories"
Status: 

I was at the East Coast Casper this weekend, and would like to compare
"stories" with any of you who went to the West Coast Casper.

(1) Video Link -- we were told in Rhode Island that the reason there was
	no video link was because the SF Casper crew didn't want to pay
	for their side of the link.  What story were you all given out
	in SF?

(2) Dutch -- I was looking forward to seeing him in Rhode Island, but
	I was told he pulled out two weeks before the event.  It's actually
	a very good thing he didn't come, for reasons that will be
	revealed below.

It was a dark and stormy night when the Trance Shuttle (piloted by Captain 
Mellow, with First Officer Finks navigating, Spaceman Spliff providing trance 
ambiance, and Cadet Trillian just being enthusiastic) arrived at Rocky Point 
Amusement Park near Warwick, RI, the site of the East Coast Casper.  

It was SOOOOO wet, simply pouring rain.  After wandering the park aimlessly
getting soaked we found "The Mausoleum," one of two major indoor dance areas.
Wonder of wonders, there was NO music coming out of it.  It seems that there
was some sort of lawyers banquet in the banquet hall next door, and they
couldn't hear the keynote speaker over dieselBoy's breaks.  So we checked out
the other dance floor and heard Guy DMC and Tiga spin and chilled with
Jake (Melon Dezign) a bit.  The visuals were so cool again, Jake, and thanks
for saying "hi" to us on the big screen.

At midnight all the net ravers met at the rollercoaster.  It had stopped
raining so some of us took a ride, and then we returned to the first dance 
floor where the music had taken off again.  The rest of the night was pretty 
much like any other rave -- lots of music, gorgeous lights, cool lasers,
friendly people.  

Personally, I was not too thrilled with the music except for Scott Henry's
otherworldly trance set.  Someone put down a really cheezoid wailing diva
house set, and then there was a spate of 70's disco, so that sort of put me 
out of the mood for dancing.  Overall, though, a huge number of people
were dancing their butts off, so I'd say that the party was a decent one.

And now for the aftermath:  around 6.00 am or so the promoter came on the
sound system and told us they had lost like 25K and so were collecting 
donations so they could pay the DJs.  I later heard from Jake (who will
hopefully share his story with us) that one of the investors, Greg, took
his money and left without making sure there was funding to pay the DJs
and lights/effects people.  There was a mob scene at the end, and I hear a 
number of people didn't get paid.  It seems to me there was quite a bit of 
poor planning here.  If they had merely rented the dance halls and not the 
whole park, and had charged $15 rather than $22/$25, I think things would
have worked out a lot better.  There wre a LOT of people there, but by
renting the whole park during this traditionally gross (weather-wise) time
of year, they were being a bit over-enthusiastic and naieve.

Oh well.  It was a nice party -- mainly because there were SO many ne-ravers
and other ravers there.  The people who came were having a great time.

See some of you at Colourbox on Wednesday, and at Timewarp on Friday!

Love and Community,

Laura

From sfraves-owner  Mon Nov  1 11:33:03 1993
From: Bob Ramstad <rramstad@us.oracle.com>
Date: Mon, 1 Nov 93 11:32:51 PST
Subject: weekend update...
Status: 


wednesday: Motion in SJ... a really good time, rick preston played
some incredible stuff, and spun was good too, though I left early
trying to conserve energy for...

thursday: YSH outside at the 24th and Illinois (off of 3rd) space,
with DRC spinning an INCREDIBLE set of hard driving tunes, followed up
by Susan and Rebecca.  I was in heaven!  Lots of fresh faces, good
sized crowd, good sound too.

friday: didn't make it to levitate the stock exchange (how was it?)
because I didn't get home until 7:30 AM :-) but I did get it together
for the FMR... it was wonderful to arrive at 2:45 AM and have the
sound going and about 2,000 people there already.  I was amazed when
someone told me that it was Garth that had been spinning for the first
couple of hours, it was totally different than the stuff he usually
plays.  Things really picked up for me once the sun came up and I
could see everyone... saw lots of friends I haven't seen since the
July FMR and/or Unity.

saturday: got home from the FMR at 1:30 PM, grabbed a couple of hours
of sleep and ate, went up to the city for Liz's going away party,
which was really nice and low key and it was cool to hang out with
everyone without a sound system for a change :-)  got home early
(1ish) to recover for...

sunday: thai food and George Clinton!  groovy show...

I think I would have died without that extra hour of sleep Saturday
night :-)

Bob

From sfraves-owner  Mon Nov  1 11:36:50 1993
From: csc@pilot.njin.net (Sean Casey)
Date: Mon, 1 Nov 93 14:36:38 EST
Subject: Vinyl vs. CD
Status: 

To answer the *original* question:

 > I don't really want to start an argument about the merits of vinyl or
 > CD to store your music on, but I had heard from some of my friends
 > that because of the way the groove is stamped on a record, you can
 > hear lower subsonic sounds and higher supersonic sounds that aren't
 > possible on a CD because of it's frequency range.  Does anyone know
 > if this is true?

The answer is: it depends on what you believe.

Theoretically, vinyl has a wider frequency range than a CD. A great
deal depends upon the mass of the needle, tracking weight, tonearm
mass, shape of the needle, quality of the pressing, how dust filled
the grooves are, quality of the preamp, turntable resonation, etc.
These variables are rarely ever all optimal at the same time, except
perhaps in very expensive high-end systems. How often are they optimal
at a rave?

In any case, the ability of almost all speakers to reproduce music
drops off dramatically near the ends of the audible spectrum. It costs
a fortune to be able to pump out high-volume 20hz, and practically
nothing recorded has it. Almost all the bass thump you will ever hear
is 50-60hz. Speaker cabinets are tuned specifically for this.

As far as high end goes, your hearing rolls off quite steeply starting
at about 16 KHz. Practically nothing recorded has audio above 20 KHz.
Belief comes into play here, because some people feel that the ability
to hear ultra-high frequency harmonics (say 20-160 KHz) is important.
Other people will point out that science says you can't sense sound in
that range at all. I should point out that powerfully amplified
ultrasonics carry a lot of energy. Your ear couldn't sense it, but 
would be rapidly damaged by it.

The theoretical low end of a CD is 1/4500 Hz :) (one cycle every 75
minutes), but they roll it off steeply at 20 Hz. D/A conversion gets
weird below that anyway, at least for audio. The high end is 22.5 KHz.

D/A conversion, oversampling, etc. is truly a black art, and one of
the most misunderstood pieces of commonly used technology. I'm not
even going to go into that one :).

For purity of sound and frequency response, the chances of a turntable
beating out a CD player at a rave are grim. For whatever reasons DJs
use turntables, it isn't because of wider frequency response. I'd say
the availability of records, and the "hands on" format.

Sean

(closet audiophile)

From: ww@blythe.org (Workers World Service)
Newsgroups: soc.culture.african.american
Subject: Racist School Voucher System Assailed, NJ
Keywords: New Jersey, education, racism, school vouchers
Message-ID: <w925Bc44w165w@blythe.org>
Date: Thu, 28 Oct 93 12:27:43 EDT
Reply-To: ww@blythe.org (Workers World Service)
Distribution: world
Organization: NY Transfer News Collective
Lines: 125


Via NY Transfer News Collective * All the News that Doesn't Fit


JERSEY CITY: COMMUNITY, TEACHERS EXPOSE RACIST VOUCHER SYSTEM

By Workers World Jersey City, N.J., bureau

On Oct. 11, the All-Peoples Congress held the first public
meeting in Jersey City to plan a response to a well-financed
national campaign against public education for all.

The dangerous initiative is called "school choice." Its leader is
Mayor Bret Schundler, a former Wall Street investment broker.

"School choice" is not about a child going to her/his school of
choice at all. It is a code word for school segregation.

It is also an effort to drain public schools of desperately
needed funds in order to bail out private schools through a
"voucher" system.

Under a "school choice" system, students from wealthier families
would receive public money to go to private schools.

But poor students wouldn't be able to afford the vouchers. And
private schools wouldn't be legally bound--as public schools
are--to accept all students, including people of color and those
who are disabled or have special learning needs.

Public funding of parochial schools violates the constitutional
separation of church and state. Reactionary forces have long
sought to overcome this barrier.

It amounts to privatization of the schools. A national
organization called "Citizens for School Choice" is coordinating
the effort.

To accomplish it here in Jersey City, Schundler has hired someone
from the right-wing think tank The Heritage Foundation.

WHO WILL PAY?

How would it work?

The mayor recently sent a mailing to 40,000 homes. In it he
promises parents a voucher worth $5,000 for each child taken out
of Jersey City public schools.

The information is misleading and inaccurate.

The voucher money would be pooled and divided equally among all
children currently enrolled in the private school. So the actual
value of the voucher would depend on the number of children
transferred.

This year the Jersey City schools will spend about $8,500 for
each of the district's 31,000 children. Using these figures, if
100 students transfer out of the public schools to private
schools, the voucher would be worth $50.

If 1,000 children leave the public schools the voucher would be
worth about $463.

The parents would make up the difference between the amount of
the voucher and the cost of the private school. The mayor doesn't
mention this.

UNION BUSTING AND SEGREGATION

Tom Favia, president of the Jersey City Education Association,
attended the Oct. 11 meeting, along with several teachers. Favia
discussed the union's opposition to vouchers.

He said: "This is union busting. The private school teachers are
underpaid and overworked."

Former Jersey City Superintendent of Schools--and the first
African American to hold this post--Franklin Williams was there,
too. He demanded, "What happened to $100 million in state aid to
our schools over the past four years?"

"The problem with the schools is unequal funding between the
suburban schools and inner-city schools," said Aura Highsmith,
YMCA board member and a parent. "The answer is not to take away
more money from public schools."

Public school teacher Vikki Chenette said: "The origins of the
school voucher movement are in the racist opposition to
desegregation. Vouchers are a code word for segregation and
racism."

The Rev. George Mazie is president of the Ministerial Alliance,
representing 26 churches in the Black community. He called for
demonstrations against the voucher plan.

Both Charles McCallister of the Bidwell Avenue Block Association
and Deacon Jake Mincey of the Mountain of Prayer Church
encouraged the community to join forces with the teachers' union.

All-Peoples Congress member Clinton Royster asked, "What will
happen to the curriculum of inclusion at these private schools?"
He said this underscores the voucher plan's anti-poor and
segregationist bent.

"School choice" is a first-step measure toward privatizing the
public schools. As it is, the public-school system is beset with
corruption, inadequate funding, insensitivity to people of
African, Latino and Asian heritage, and dominated by school
boards that are anti-gay and sexist.

As community leader John Jones concluded, "The answer is equal
funding and a strong united movement for community control of the
schools--not privatization."

                               -30-

(Copyright Workers World Service: Permission to reprint granted
if source is cited. For more information contact Workers World,
55 West 17 St., New York, NY 10011; via e-mail: ww@blythe.org.)

From sfraves-owner  Mon Nov  1 13:31:29 1993
From: Fred Heutte <phred@well.sf.ca.us>
Date: Mon, 1 Nov 1993 13:31:23 -0800
Subject: Halloweekend
Status: 

Well, it really started Wednesday when I picked up my new (new to me
anyway) 1200s :)

Thursday I flew in from portland and headed immediately to YSH.  Well,
not exactly immediately, it seems that Susie thought it was going to be
at the Somar space again.  Went there, found it deserted except for a
van with some folks who also seemed to be lost.  Turned out they were
from all over (one from New Jersey!) -- we called the info line, headed
to Cleo's in short order and then to the site.  So we made some new
friends along the way and helped them to get to the party and it all
worked out.  

And it was quite a workout -- musically, the best YSH I've been to (not
that I've been to all that many).  DRC was just flat kickin' out the jams,
a really high-intensity set with energy that just would not quit.  Susan
followed with an equally potent mix and both had a good portion of the
crowd going full-tilt.  When Rebecca arrived to do the cleanup spot, she
conferred for a moment and then gave Susan the go-ahead for what turned
out to be a brilliant second-wind finale; I think she was on for about
two and a quarter hours all told.  We had to leave fairly soon into
Rebecca's set which was deep and funkeeee.  The sound system was quite
good and Bob R "got down wit DAT" and I am certainly looking forward to
hearing my birthday show on tape :)

Plenty enough has been said about the FMR, so I won't add much more.
Eight of us arrived in M and P-ter Normals' little pickup truck at around
4:30 and found the massive in motion after parking way way waaaay up
Bonny Doon Rd.  I thought the vibe was much improved over the September
FMR, although still not all that great.  But there was much more dancing
and less nitrous and alcohol (and what there was of the latter was low
key and in good spirits).  If I were to quarrel about one thing, it's the
typical way the FMR crew sets up the sound.  Outdoor sound has some
characteristics that must be respected.  Although small, the system put
out quite a lot of oomph.  In the normal "sweet spot" (in the center in
front of the speakers, where you get the stereo image) it was just
simply too loud, and there was severe "combing" -- meaning you could
move just six inches and have the phase relationships change completely.
One solution is to spread the speakers out, maybe ten feet further from
the DJ table for each stack.  Another would be to create a 'dance floor'
by having four stacks pointing inwards, which would tend to concentrate
the crowd, *or* have four stacks tightly set around the DJ setup pointing
*outward* to help spread the crowd around and create four stereo images
to boot . . . just a thought, anyway.

The lineup was Garth, Markie, Jeno and Nickie.  I didn't think G., J. or
M. did anything exceptional, but they were steady with perhaps a nod to
Garth for taking a somewhat different approach.  Nickie (if I have the
name right) almost literally came directly off the plane from the UK
and played a nice mellow house/trance groove from about 11:30 to 1 pm
when things finally closed down.

Overall, an excellent time.  

I got a couple hour nap before we checked into the going-away party for
Liz of the YSH krewe.  Susie, Sean and others went off to Minna St. and
had a great time while I snoozed, overslept actually, to get ready for
a long Sunday run.  Initially I planned to make it to Funky Techno Tribe
but woke up late, at 5 am, so I went directly, instead, to the DNA one-
off afterparty.  Somewhat to my surprise and pleasure, since I missed FTT,
Tony was playing when I arrived at 7:30 (he wasn't listed on the flyer),
doing a decent if not great set for a sparse crowd, followed by Jeno who
got things moving a bit more.  Then I trucked over to Boogie Buffet, which
I haven't been to for a couple of months.  It was not overwhelming, just
exceedingly pleasant :)  This time, somewhat unusually, I spent little
time in the Buffet/Light/Slow room, and mostly jammed in the Boogie/Dark/Fast
room with a fine Rick Preston jam and a pumping set from none other than Jeno,
yet again, doing his third turn in about ten hours.  I had to look twice at
my plane ticket this morning to make sure I was on *R*eno Air :)

The Terence McKenna event had been heavily advertised -- I saw posters all
over town and flyers saturated Haight St. -- so I got there a little early
and discovered M Normal had already started her ambient set around 7:30
at the Great American Music Hall.  She ended up playing nearly two hours
until the next DJ arrived.  The crowd was restless and I was hungry, so
I ducked out to grab a bite, then decided to skip Terence (who I'm not
much interested in) and Robbie Hardkiss and check out two of the many other
events happening.  The brand-new Kilimanjaro event was happening at -- you
guessed it -- 1015 Folsom.  I'm a big fan of African and reggae, and they
had both, with the African/Caribbean sound in the "Boogie" space and 
dance hall in the basement.  I was disappointed with the turnout and the
DJs -- the upstairs was basically a salsa-oriented DJ who didn't understand
how to use the mixer (not in the sense of beat-matching, which is unknown
in that scene, but just in level-setting), and the downstairs was a not very
interesting selection of circa-1991 style dancehall as opposed to the new
techno-influenced stuff.  But I think the club has potential and of course
Ten Fifteen Folsom is a wondrous space under any circumstances.

Finally I checked in at the Trocadero.  It was set up nicely -- large
dayglo painted curtains, a fine Video Toaster driven light show, a good
woman DJ whose name I could not find out from anyone present, and I wasn't
about to interrupt her spinning to ask.  The odd thing is I was probably
one of ten paying customers in the place.  They were up against numerous
other events as well as the Castro block party and I just don't understand
the timing -- they must have lost a ton on space and equipment rental alone.
And the Troc is just not what it used to be.  There are some bass cabs on
the floor, but most of the sound is in some speaker decks hung around the
outside of the floor, leading to rather uneven and uninspiring sound overall
(though the blown-out distorted stuff reported previously seems to have
been fixed or replaced).  They were using the famed hanging tweeters as
hangers for party decorations, not audio :(  

The downstairs at Folsom has better sound now than the Troc.  (And it's 
really quite good -- we should have another sfraves party there I think . . .)

So now I'm back in the saddle in my office here in Portland.  Thanks to
everyone who made it such a great weekend.  The final note: several people
expressed considerable optimism about the scene.  The comment that 'the
energy is starting to come back' was heard from several quarters.  I don't
personally believe it ever *left*, but it's been scarce to find in recent
months as things have struggled through some kind of transition.  The old
style raves are gone gone gone, having mutated quickly into a commercial/
promoter approach which the scene has definitively rejected.  Big parties
are not out completely by any means, but they are certainly not the focus
they were even a year ago.  And the smaller parties are more diverse,
being put on in more places and bringing in a wider variety of music and
people.  

It sounds good to me!

From sfraves-owner  Mon Nov  1 14:31:16 1993

on anything that isn't a record, such as any part of the turntable.
I would think that the back-and-forth stresses that "scratching" impose 
would be pretty bad too.  Are any of them designed for that?

From sfraves-owner  Mon Nov  1 15:42:42 1993
From: kxbehni@srv.PacBell.COM (Keyvan Behnia)
Date: Mon, 1 Nov 93 15:42:37 PST
Subject: WANTED: Lounge Wizards
Status: 

Greetings.

I have been off the list for the last few months working on my Bar. It has been open since
Late August and we are finally getting our musical offerings sorted. The Bar is called Dalva
and is on 16th street between Valencia and Gurrero right next to the Roxie Theatre.

The main thing about Dalva is that the music is adventurous. First of all, there is Orpheus
our jukebox. It features latest releases ranging from Ultramarine, One Dove and MC Solar to Mathew Sweet,
Tindersticks and Lemonheads. 

As far as the current DJ line-up we have the folks from Message doing a Jazzbo thing on Tuesdays, 
I spin Vinyl 45`s on Wedensdays, Behind the Post Office will start FORTUNE this thursday and On Saturdays 
nights The Vibes Collective does a set bordering on anarchy under the title of Funk-Fu.

I would like us to have an ambient night and am looking for a good DJ. I envision music that would be 
an aperitif to a night out raving or substitue for a light adventure. There is no planned dancing at 
Dalva however there have been spontaneous bursts. But the emphasis needs to be on the music and my 
only requirement is that it be adventurous. Al the DJs at Dalva like the fact that they can play 
what they like without worrying about the dancefloor getting empty or a song being too new or slow.

So stop by, take a look at the place and say hello. I am usually there on Wed and Sat Nights.
or E-mail me with your questions, thoughts or ideas.


Keyvan

From sfraves-owner  Mon Nov  1 15:56:17 1993
From: "Susan R. Kameny" <susie@sutro.SFSU.EDU>

Subject: vote tommorrow-rave related!
Status: 

hiya i want to remind everyone that we are blessed with the right to vote
and tommorrow is election day and that i want to encourage all to remember
to go and vote!

now, here are some issue on the ballot that i feel are rave related and my
 humble opinion...

prop a--- this prop is a bond issue and the money is earmarked for somar!
as you all know this is where your sisters house now currently resides...i
think it is a lovey and important space and worth voting YES for to help
its preservation

prop n---this would make our city government review the city charter and
propose ideas for reorganization! i think this needs to be done...voting
yes might mean that permitting laws and that damm police code (ie cabaret
laws) be looked at too...

prop AA---i think everyone should take muni including city workers and
ravers...vote YES

prop BB---this poor police officer can't bring his dummy to work...i know
i would love to see a police officer at a renegade with a dummy telling
everyone to go home...vote yes so at least 1 one officer can have a sence
of humor and show that he is human/citizen.

state prop 174---this will be the demise of california's public education
system (both my parents are public school teachers) and uneducated people
means they don't have a good understanding of the humanities/arts and
their city and their world and this would be disasterous to raves...

these are just my opinions...but i wanted to show how this election will
have an impact on the "scene" and there is more to life than
raving...please don't make this a big thread, so send me private email if
you want to duke it out...(:(:

partyon...susie (:

From sfraves-owner  Mon Nov  1 17:14:26 1993
From: dionf@ERE.UMontreal.CA (Francois Dion)
Date: Mon, 1 Nov 1993 20:12:25 -0500 (EST)
Subject: Re: On Sale Now at the Shack!
Status: 

Beyond the ultraworld of Jim S. Thompson:
> 
> > The metal ones are not shielded? This is a bad move on their part... The MTX
> > , Ramsa and Bose are shielded for those who want to use them as multimedia
> > monitors.
> 
> 	I should think that the Minimus 7 speakers ARE shielded as they
> 	are in a metal box with a perf metal front screen.  This should
> 	act as a Faraday cage as far as EMI is concerned....

Yes, but what metal? zinc? steel? aluminium? Aluminium alloys for example,
are good to shield RFI but not EMI. The magnets put out a magnetic field,
not radio interference so aluminium is no good.

I have a pair of "designer" speakers (they are two 8 inches balls, sliding on
small bases) which are quite crap (well they dont compare to Camber :P) but
are made of steel and so are shielded. I cant however use them as multimedia
speakers because my monitor is on an arm...

Ciao,

From sfraves-owner  Tue Nov  2 09:17:06 1993
From: Robert Jesse <rjesse@us.oracle.com>
Date: Tue, 2 Nov 93 10:17:55 -0800
Subject: mdma+fluoxetine (PROZAC)
Status: 

thought some of you would like to see this.  i wonder if anyone has  
collected similar data for any of the SSRIs (selective seratonin reuptake  
inhibitors) other than fluoxetine, e.g. sertraline (ZOLOFT).
-----

From: lamontg@cs.washington.edu (Lamont Granquist)
Date: 25 Oct 93 20:51:33 GMT
Newsgroups: alt.drugs
Subject: Medline info on drug-drug interactions

----------------------------------------------------------------------
On drug-drug interactions:

               Accession Number: 93000357.    Citation: 2 of 4

Author:       Strassman-R-J.
~Title:       Human hallucinogen interactions with drugs affecting
              serotonergic neurotransmission.
Source:       Neuropsychopharmacology.  1992 Nov.  7(3).  P 241-3.
Abstract:     The absence of relevant human research studies of
              hallucinogenic drugs has not curtailed their unsupervised
              use.  Two cases are presented that suggest decreased
              sensitivity to the serotonergic hallucinogens psilocybin and
              LSD induced by drugs with effects on serotonergic
              neurotransmission, allopurinol and fluoxetine.  These reports
              suggest that hallucinogens' effects in humans are mediated by
              serotonergic receptors.

              Accession Number: 92272338.    Citation: 3 of 4

Author:       Picker-W.  Lerman-A.  Hajal-F.
~Title:       Potential interaction of LSD and fluoxetine [letter]
Source:       Am-J-Psychiatry.  1992 Jun.  149(6).  P 843-4.

              Accession Number: 93359556.    Citation: 1 of 45

Author:       McCann-U-D.  Ricaurte-G-A.
~Title:       Reinforcing subjective effects of (+/-)
              3,4-methylenedioxymethamphetamine ("ecstasy") may be
              separable from its neurotoxic actions: clinical evidence.
Source:       J-Clin-Psychopharmacol.  1993 Jun.  13(3).  P 214-7.
Abstract:     (+/-)3,4-Methylenedioxymethamphetamine (MDMA), a synthetic
              amphetamine derivative used recreationally by humans, damages
              brain serotonin neurons in experimental animals.  In
              preclinical studies, serotonin reuptake inhibitors block
              MDMA-induced serotonin release; they also block MDMA
              neurotoxicity.  Whether serotonin reuptake inhibitors also
              block MDMA's psychoactive effects in humans has not been
              established.  Reported herein are four individuals who
              describe their experiences after ingesting fluoxetine, a
              potent and selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor, before
              MDMA ingestion.  Their reports indicate that fluoxetine does
              not block MDMA's reinforcing subjective effects and raise the
              possibility that MDMA's psychoactive effects may be separable
              from its neurotoxic actions.

From sfraves-owner  Tue Nov  2 09:47:43 1993
From: ccat@netcom.com (Chris Beaumont)
Date: Tue, 2 Nov 1993 09:49:34 -0800
Subject: Non-neurotoxic epathogens/enactogens
Status: 

This is one of the reason that research needs to be supported,not suppressed.
Thanks for posting your refs,Bob.
-Chris.

--> something like this comes up. Don't like it? put that phrase in a
--> kill-file. Easy.

Dude, it isn't that easy.  I'm not sure what mailer you use that uses
kill-file, but mh and RMAIL (which I use) do not.  So please have a
little consideration out there!  These inappropriate messages get
mixed in with the rest of my mail, making it harder to find the
important stuff (such as letters from my boss).  

If I wanted to get political updates I would subscribe to an
appropriate list.  I do not want to sift through the stuff - PLEASE
don't send it.

I know some people on this list have a lot of time to read all the
mail and like to get the extra info on politics etc... But please,
just subscribe to an appropriate list on those topics or better yet,
read a newspaper or a newsgroup.  Some of us can't deal with the mail
volume - I have a job to do.n

And I'm really sorry for taking up bandwith here.  I just hope that
this message trims down the inappropriate topics here.  And it can be
done.  When I was on ne-raves last April-August or so, people decided
what are appropriate topics to the list and PEOPLE STUCK TO IT.  I
don't know why we can't do that here.

Sue

From sfraves-owner  Tue Nov  2 11:51:34 1993
From: Online Tsar <jonathan@wired.com> (Jonathan Steuer)
Date: Tue, 2 Nov 93 11:35:55 -0800
Subject: online internship at Wired
Status: 

Hi folks-

I know this isn't directly rave-related, but this position seemed like
something that might be of interest to the kind of folks in the SFR
tribe...

Whoever we hire will be working closely with me and the rest of the online
staff at Wired in trying to expand Wired's online offerings. We need help
as soon as possible, and the position requires coming in to the Wired
offices (in San Francisco), so Bay Area residents will likely have an
advantage over those of you reading this elsewhere.

I'll be completely upfront about on thing: the starting pay is lousy.
However, most successful interns at Wired manage to negotiate real
contracts for less-appalling wages within a couple of months.

Please direct replies and inquiries to online@wired.com, since I'm no
longer on the main SFR list. 

Thanks-

-jonathan-

****************************************************************************

                          WANTED: TEXT NERD

Wired is looking for a motivated individual to help us with our online
offerings. The 30-hr. per week internship position, commencing immediately,
includes the following responsibilities:

  o formatting text of back-issues of our magazine for distribution
    via the Internet and other online means

  o assisting in the maintenance / innkeeping of Wired areas on online
    services including alt.wired, America Online, Mindvox, and the WELL

You should be familiar with the Macintosh and with at least one
standard Mac word processing program (Word, MacWrite Pro, Nisus), and 
should also have some experience with electronic communication (email,
BBS's, mailing lists, Internet tools, etc. -- if you're reading this
online, you're probably qualified). Experience with Quark XPress and
more detailed net.knowledge are big plusses, but are not required.

Most important, you should be willing to work for not very much money
in what's most likely the best work environment you've ever imagined, and you
should be ready to absorb a lot of knowledge about online systems and how they
work. 

For more information, send email to:

   online@wired.com

with a brief but relevant ASCII resume and cover letter.
(Please: no phone calls,  snail-mail, or carrier pigeons)


Thanks!


    Will Kreth                          Jonathan Steuer
  Online Director                      Online Development

                          Wired
                     online@wired.com

From sfraves-owner  Tue Nov  2 12:10:43 1993

Subject: FYI -- Adam Curry (MTV) program "RAVE" mentioned on mtv.com
Status: 


I randomly came across this while browsing around in the world wide
web. MTV has a WWW and FTP/Gopher site mtv.com, and I found this in the
middle of browsing the following WWW URL
http://mtv.com/aboutus/aboutadam.html

| ...
| The other program will start airing fall 1993, entitled 
| RAVE, Adam goes to underground Rave-Parties in 12 separate
| major European cities. RAVE is music intensive,
| highlighting house and techno music. 
| ...

Perhaps you might want to give Adam some pointers to local SF Rave footage.
Or invite him to an upcoming event...

| Comments and suggestions are always welcome, please send
| them to me at: adam@mtv.com

--------------------
http://mtv.com/aboutus/aboutmtv.html

| What is mtv.com?
| 
| Good question...it's been asked alot lately. 
| 
| First of all, this site is NOT sponsored in anyway by 
| MTV Networks, although they ARE aware of my endeavours
| and support it. 
| 
| My name is Adam Curry, I have been an on-air talent (VJ)
| with MTV for the past 6 years. I've been living a second
| life in cyberspace for about the same period of time,
| and have taken it upon myself to put this site on-line,
| with all expenses coming out of my own pocket. Don't
| feel bad, I make enough at my "real" job. 
| 
| This site will always remain free to the internet
| community, something that might not be the case would
| MTV be running it themselves I'm afraid, but that's
| their business. 
| 
| Anyway, to make a long story short, this is my hobby,
| and you get what you pay for when you connect to this
| server. Within the next couple of weeks/months you
| should see alot of cool stuff coming online here,
| including video and audio stuff that will absolutely
| blow you away!

I'm pretty sure mh does, but I don't use it so I'm not sure (I was told
I should switch to it because it had it).  If your site has ELM compiled
it probably also has "filter", which can be run outside of elm, and
can filter your email into smaller mailboxes.  I can send you a sample
 .filter file, or try the man page.

However, your point is correct, you shouldn't have to use any sort of
filter here.

} When I was on ne-raves last April-August or so, people decided
} what are appropriate topics to the list and PEOPLE STUCK TO IT.  I 
} don't know why we can't do that here. 

Thats not my recollection, and I've been on ne-raves from day one.
Most recently there was a flame war about Barney which brought
techno.stanford to its knees :) I think it's inherent in rave mailing
lists to go off the topic every now and then, and if people can tie it
back in, brilliant, and if it spirals out of hand, kill it.  I can't
remember the last time the wuarchive FTP mailing list had a flame
war about Barney!

	Brian



From sfraves-owner  Tue Nov  2 14:28:43 1993
From: laura@soda.berkeley.edu (Laura La Gassa)
Date: Tue, 2 Nov 1993 14:28:36 -0800
Subject: breeding techno dogs or something (was politics)
Status: 

Geoff White comments:

>We are a different breed then our east coast counterparts.

I feel the need to say that statements like this upset me and
make me feel inferior (I currently live on the East Coast).

A number of you are ex-east-coasters.  Your work/school/personal 
life may be better in California than it was back East, and you might 
even prefer the scene in San Francisco to anything you might have 
experienced back East, but truth be told we're not any different 
"breed."  We are human beings who rave and who exist under different 
envrionmental conditions than you all, but we're still involved in 
netting and raving for the same fundamental reasons you all are:  we 
seek fun, information, community, friendship, peace, love, and happiness.

Comments like the above don't really serve to perpetuate the idea
of "unity."  It's one thing to say "well, Sue, they do things 
differently out east -- after all they are a younger crowd and are
much more geographically spread out" and yet another to imply that we
are fundamentally different to you by saying we are a different
breed.

Laura

From sfraves-owner  Tue Nov  2 15:02:57 1993
From: geoffw@internex.net (Geoff White)
Date: Tue, 2 Nov 93 14:58:05 PST
Subject: Re: breeding techno dogs or something (was politics)
Status: 

> Geoff White comments:
> 
> >We are a different breed then our east coast counterparts.
> 
> I feel the need to say that statements like this upset me and
> make me feel inferior (I currently live on the East Coast).

Laura I love you, the statement was not to imply that east coasters
are in anyway inferior, I lived on the east coast for 32 years, but I must
stick by my original statement, that is why I moved out here, I got tired
of being "different" and a "kook", out here I just like everyone else
(All the fruits and nuts slide to the left side of the country :)
> 
> A number of you are ex-east-coasters.  Your work/school/personal 
> life may be better in California than it was back East, and you might 
> even prefer the scene in San Francisco to anything you might have 
> experienced back East, but truth be told we're not any different 
> "breed."  We are human beings who rave and who exist under different 
> envrionmental conditions than you all, but we're still involved in 
> netting and raving for the same fundamental reasons you all are:  we 
> seek fun, information, community, friendship, peace, love, and happiness.

Yes but I got tired of being followed when I go into a store in Boston because
I was black, (the only city that I have ever been called a nigger while having
a beer bottle thrown at me).  Tired of not having cabs stop.  Tired of living
in fear because homicide is an epidemic in Baltimore where 90% of the crime
is black on black, tired of rude service station attendants, tired of having
to put on armor and carrying switch-blades or a nine in order to feel safe
while walking through the streets of Brooklyn.  I can't speak about
So Cal cuz I don't live there maybe it is as bad or worse then the east coast
(at least they don't have sub zero temperatures in the winter) but I must
say that yes we are a different breed, especially the people who emigrated here
from the east coast, most of my family is still back there putting up with all
of that.  When I left NYC when I was 14 I was sad, I though New York
was the greatest place on earth, now you couldn't PAY me to live there for 6
months.


> 
> Comments like the above don't really serve to perpetuate the idea
> of "unity."  It's one thing to say "well, Sue, they do things 
> differently out east -- after all they are a younger crowd and are
> much more geographically spread out" and yet another to imply that we
> are fundamentally different to you by saying we are a different
> breed.
> 
> Laura
> 


I know this will start some people howling but when you come out here and
live here a while, you'll understand.



			G

From sfraves-owner  Tue Nov  2 15:12:19 1993
From: mw@sybase.com (Michael Wertheim)
Date: Tue, 2 Nov 93 15:12:07 PST
Subject: Re:  breeding techno dogs or something (was politics)
Status: 


> >We are a different breed then our east coast counterparts.

> but truth be told we're not any different "breed."

Well, maybe "breed" isn't eactly accurate, but there are some definite
differences in the two scenes --

1) SF has silicon valley, which means that there are more over-21 intellectual
   types in the SF rave scene than there are in the East Coast.

2) SF is the LSD capital of the US.  The price is lower here, and quality and 
   availablity are higher.  The result is that the music in SF is more
   psychedelic, and you find more hippie/deadheads at raves in SF than you
   do on the East Coast.

------> SFR.karma.points.gz <------
>From SFRaves-request@techno.Stanford.EDU Thu Jul 22 13:27:18 1993
From: Derek Chung <dhchung@us.oracle.com>
Subject: Re: repeat messages? (fwd)
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU (SFRaves)
Date: Thu, 22 Jul 93 11:34:53 PDT
>
>This is just ridiculous Brian.  People send out mail to the sfraves list for
>the most incredibly stupid things.  A typical RFC822 mail header is about
>12-15 lines long.  I see people send out messages with bodies that are 3-4
>lines long.  It's totally ridiculous.  I just can't deal with it anymore.  I
>know I sound uptight, but I already deal with enough naive users as it is
>without having to deal with anymore.
>
>*I* don't send out meaningless flames everytime I something I marginally 
>disagree with.  Neither do I send out mail correcting every little flaw I see.
>I don't understand why I should ever need to see more than 1-2 messages a
>day from people.
>

OK, in response to this I'm proposing the "SFR Karma System" (SFRKS),
in which you can gain SFR Karma points for free luv-phaser recharges.

Here how it works:

points  
+10     positive post, about a relevant topic
+5      honest, open-minded rave reviews
+3      useful rave-related information
+1      good posts on a topic somewhat related to raves

-10     personal flame, on an undeserving target
-5      personal flame, on a deserving target
+1      good-natured, humorous flame, on a deserving target

-1      completely unnecessary posting - redundant information,
                irrelevant to raves, posting that should be on private mail...
-3      subscribe/unsubscribe postings to the entire list
-5      "Your music sucks" posts
0       honest mistakes

SFR Karma points can be redeemed at any time for luv-phaser energy.
Negative points require you to smile at 100 people for each point.

:)

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 o derek chung  o  oracle graphics  o  dhchung@us.oracle.com  o 415.506.6195 o

From sfraves-owner  Tue Nov  2 16:04:07 1993
From: Adam Sah <asah@ginsberg.CS.Berkeley.EDU>
Date: Tue, 02 Nov 93 16:04:38 -0800
Subject: Re: breeding techno dogs or something (was politics) 
Status: 

> Geoff White comments:
> >We are a different breed then our east coast counterparts.
>
> I feel the need to say that statements like this upset me and
> make me feel inferior (I currently live on the East Coast).
> 
> A number of you are ex-east-coasters.  Your work/school/personal 
> life may be better in California than it was back East, and you might 
> even prefer the scene in San Francisco to anything you might have 
> experienced back East, but truth be told we're not any different 
> "breed."  We are human beings who rave and who exist under different 
> envrionmental conditions than you all, but we're still involved in 
> netting and raving for the same fundamental reasons you all are:  we 
> seek fun, information, community, friendship, peace, love, and happiness.
> 
> Comments like the above don't really serve to perpetuate the idea
> of "unity."  It's one thing to say "well, Sue, they do things 
> differently out east -- after all they are a younger crowd and are
> much more geographically spread out" and yet another to imply that we
> are fundamentally different to you by saying we are a different
> breed.
> 
> Laura

I agree with you in principle, but as a classic "displaced New Yorker" of
  about a year now, I can honestly say that in practice, what you are
  saying is just not true:
  - the vibe out here is safer - meaning that people are reasonably friendly,
    and you can expend energy dancing and talking and... instead of keeping
    your guard up all the time.  At the FMR on Friday, people like Brian
    were actually making an attempt to look out for the safety of their
    fellow human...

  - people seem to be a lot cooler about money - I don't feel ripped off
    when I donate to help out something, and neither does anyone else, it
    seems.  Likewise, non-money goods are shared much more freely out here, 
    especially food and drink.

  - the weather is nicer.  This means that crashing outdoors in the middle
    of goddess-knows-where is doable (minus bears)- not something I would
    try in NY.  More fragile items can be left outdoors... there's even a
    building here on campus where there's no doors separating its "insides"
    from its "outside" - in NY, that would mean snow gets in all of the
    classrooms and heating would be expensive... I really think that this
    leads people to spend more time outdoors, leave things outside that
    would be destroyed by wind, (more) rain, snow, and extreme temperatures
    in other places - all of which (imho) leads people to be a little bit more
    aware of the environment we live in.  I'm not sure - but it also might
    mean that people are (somewhat) less apt to destroying any property
    they get near, stealing anything that isn't bolted down... The thing
    with cleaning up the beach after the FMR and the negotiating with the cops.
    I really couldn't imagine that happening where I'm (originally) from.
    Also, the geography is more interesting and varied, which again smacks
    you in the face and makes it hard to ignore your existence as a creature
    on this planet...

I don't think of myself as a "changed person" in any great sense, but the
  culture I'm living in *is* vastly different, and my own sensitivities
  have changed.  Since coming out here, I've gone CAMPING!  HIKING!
  (things I barely had heard of)  Outdoor partying - a concept!  What I'm
  saying is that people are different, but things are, and that makes
  enough of a difference.

But you're right, unity is what counts - so more east coasters should come
  out and visit! (and #&^&* clean up after themselves :)

adam "I admit it... I...I... I'm from... New York..." sah

From sfraves-owner  Tue Nov  2 16:32:34 1993
From: raisty@berlioz.nsc.com (Sue Raisty)
Date: Tue, 2 Nov 93 16:32:15 PST
Subject: I love the East Coast
Status: 

Well, since everyone seems to be telling me that sfraves is not for
rave related discussion, but for whatever the hell you want to blath
about:

--> > Laura sez:
--> > Geoff White comments: We are a different breed then our
--> >   east coast counterparts. I feel the need to say that
--> >   statements like this upset me and  make me feel inferior (I
--> >   currently live on the East Coast).

Geoff White sez:
--> Laura I love you, the statement was not to imply that east
--> coasters are in anyway inferior, I lived on the east coast for 32
--> years, but I must stick by my original statement, that is why I
--> moved out here, I got tired of being "different" and a "kook", out

	[lots of examples why the east coast sucks]

--> I know this will start some people howling but when you come out
--> here and live here a while, you'll understand.

For the record,
I LOVE THE EAST COAST and I want to move back there.  But I can't do
it yet lest I be labled as a job-hopper.

1) They have SEASONS there.  The trees actually turn purty colors in
the fall.  Purple and Red and Yellow and Orange. Its totally awesome.
The best that happens here is a few leaves are yellow.  They even have
wicked cool thunderstorms and snow!

2) They play HARDCORE.  (rave related comment)

3) They have awesome PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION.  I lived in Boston for 5
years and did not need a car.  You can get anywhere on the subway or
busses. 

4) They have no CABARET LAWS. (rave related comment)

5) The PEOPLE.  Call East coasters unfriendly, but at least they
aren't fake.  I don't like the mindless chatter with the supermarket
clerk that I get out here.  In my experience, East coasters are less
concerned with appearances and material possessions than Californians.
When I moved here, I could not imagine that so much emphasis would be
put on the car you drive, the furniture you own, the expensive
expensive hobbies you participates in (seems like paragliding, sky
diving, skiing, scuba diving, hang gliding, and other way $$$ hobbies
are the hip thing here.)  

6) With the exception of NYC, its a CHEAPER!  Lower taxes, lower
prices.

7) They have serious ICE HOCKEY.  (If anyone can tell me where I can
buy a reasonably priced Boys Large hockey helmet inthe Bay Area, I'd
appreciate the tip), and not just pros - for everyone. 

8) You don't have to go very far (at least in new england) to get
out of the sprawling city and suburbs.  In California, every time I
try to go into the wilderness to be alone there are already a zillion
people there. 

9) The East Coast has more CHARACTER.  In California, all the streets
are in a grid; every corner has a shopping mall with 3 restaraunts, a
drug store and a beauty salon, complete with a zillion speed bumps,
stucco walls, and a quasi-mexican red clay roof.  *Boring*  

10) NO EARTHQUAKES

11) Better NY style pizza.

I'm also curious about what you said Geoff.  Do you really think the
crime situation is alot better in SF than in Boston?  I really didn't
get that impression.  I'm much more scared walking around in SF.  But
maybe I'm just ignorant.


Sue

From sfraves-owner  Tue Nov  2 17:33:32 1993
From: andy@kingkong.wco.ftp.com (Andy Nourse)
Date: Tue, 02 Nov 1993 17:33:09 -0800
Subject: Re:  breeding techno dogs or something (was politics)
Status: 

At 03:12 PM 11/2/93 PST, Michael Wertheim wrote:
>> >We are a different breed then our east coast counterparts.
>> but truth be told we're not any different "breed."

There is a different breed, and many (though not all) of us come to SF
sooner or later.  The determining factor is not what coast you live on,
but what coast you WANT to live on (assuming you have experienced both).

Geographical impairment (wrong-coast syndrome) is cureable!

>2) SF is the LSD capital of the US.  The price is lower here, and quality and 
>   availablity are higher.  The result is that the music in SF is more
>   psychedelic, and you find more hippie/deadheads at raves in SF than you
>   do on the East Coast.

True, and, of course (since you bring it up), SF has the Grateful Dead!
I was going to Grateful Dead concerts for years before there were raves
and I still do, every chance I get.  The Dead and Deadheads have been
cultivating the Vibe for over a quarter-century.  I've been to 20
Grateful Dead concerts this year, and thoroughly enjoyed every one.
But where do we find the Vibe the rest of the time?  This Deadhead
is eternally grateful to you all for providing an answer!

(and that answer is yet another reason I'm really really glad I live
in the SF area now.  Boston seems to be a place where raves do not happen.
Grateful Dead concerts do, but only because they know that having the
Dead sell-out the Garden for a week is the best thing that happens to
their economy all year!)

The music is far more potent than LSD, although LSD certainly influences
the music.

                                &andy

Subject: Re: I love the East Coast
Status: 

>1) They have SEASONS there.  The trees actually turn purty colors in
>the fall.  Purple and Red and Yellow and Orange. Its totally awesome.
>The best that happens here is a few leaves are yellow.

I seem to always make it back to New England for the fall foliage,
probably always will.

>2) They play HARDCORE.  (rave related comment)

Are there any raves in the Boston area?  I never heard of any, but
maybe they were just too well hidden.  One doesn't hear of any on
the ne-raves mailing list either, though.
NYC has them, but it is a long way from Boston.

>4) They have no CABARET LAWS. (rave related comment)

True for NYC, but it always seemed like everything was being shut down
early in New England.  Early was never later than 2 AM, often 1 or earlier.

>5) The PEOPLE.  Call East coasters unfriendly

No, but the (in)famous New England "reserve" always seemed to make it
pretty difficult to get to know people.  This was always particularly
true in small towns.  It really bothered me when I lived there.

>paragliding, skydiving, skiing, scuba diving, hang gliding

Skiing is pretty big in New England too,
most of the others seem to be related to some desire to make-like-a-bird.

>7) They have serious ICE HOCKEY.

but we have the Guppies -- I mean Sharks  :^) :^)
