From sfraves-owner  Tue Nov  2 20:26:50 1993
From: laura@soda.berkeley.edu (Laura La Gassa)
Date: Tue, 2 Nov 1993 20:26:40 -0800
Subject: EC vs. WC bickering
Status: 

Well, all this discussion on why one coast is great etc. is NOT what I 
had in mind.  I was meaning to focus on the RAVERS in each place, that even
though we did things a bit differently on our list (ne-raves) and at our
parties (they are smaller and have lots of different types of music:
from deep house to early electro to trance to breakbeat to hardcore --
all at the same event even!) we were NOT "a breed apart" but part of some 
overall family.  

And what a family ne-raves is.  Although I get frustrated to HELL
sometimes by the dynamics, I am overall very proud of what we have
become.  We've managed to overcome ranges in age from 14 to 36 or so,
distances stretching from Maine to Washington DC, "occupational" 
differences from being a junior high student to being a brain surgeon,
all so we can spend time together sharing the music, the dance, the
fun, and the companionship.  For example, an ne-raver whom many of you 
have met, Michael Minnich, threw a party that was basically  the equivalent 
of Bryce's Liquid Air events.  This was in Washington DC in June.
People on the list drove from BOSTON (8 hours) to be at it.

I have been to San Francisco twice, and have met many active members
of the SFRaves community, and so was appalled by the idea that 
San Francisco Ravers -- no matter where they were originally -- held
themselves to be "a breed apart" from the North Eastern ravers ("our
East Coast counterparts").  It's funny, but once I even talked to 
Brian about this, saying that there were major similarities on the
BASIC level of what's going on -- and he insisted you all were different,
too.  Well, I didn't buy it then, but I'm thinking now I was wrong.
I was hoping the mere fact that we have some collective definition
of "raver" that we all claimed to be (music loving, peaceful, loving,
open-minded) would be enough of a base for some sort of overall unity
to be identified, but maybe not.

I'm very sorry I dragged you all into this thread.  I know Geoff
and everyone means well.

Laura

From sfraves-owner  Tue Nov  2 21:45:33 1993
From: howardb@enlil.premenos.sf.ca.us (Howard Berkey)

> 1) They have SEASONS there.  The trees actually turn purty colors in
> the fall.  Purple and Red and Yellow and Orange. Its totally awesome.
> The best that happens here is a few leaves are yellow.  They even have
> wicked cool thunderstorms and snow!

Carolina.    After moving to California, I DONT miss:

Blizzards
sub-freezing winters
Rain
Rain
Rain
Cold 
Cold
Cold
extreme humidity
predatory insects
swamps
[etc...]


> 2) They play HARDCORE.  (rave related comment)

Been there, done that.  Next?  :-)


> 3) They have awesome PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION.  I lived in Boston for 5
> years and did not need a car.  You can get anywhere on the subway or
> busses. 
> 

I commuted 35 miles for 9 months to work on BART + buses.  Which is
clean and fast.

> 4) They have no CABARET LAWS. (rave related comment)
> 

Ya got me there.  :-)

> 5) The PEOPLE.  Call East coasters unfriendly, but at least they
> aren't fake.  I don't like the mindless chatter with the supermarket
> clerk that I get out here.  In my experience, East coasters are less
> concerned with appearances and material possessions than Californians.
> When I moved here, I could not imagine that so much emphasis would be
> put on the car you drive, the furniture you own, the expensive
> expensive hobbies you participates in (seems like paragliding, sky
> diving, skiing, scuba diving, hang gliding, and other way $$$ hobbies
> are the hip thing here.)  
> 

Heh.  You haven't even scratched the surface :-)  
General Aviation  costs me $90/hr to learn to fly.  (The FAA is kinda
understandably sticky :-)
Then again, I get to fly airplanes.  I guess I could blow more cash on
booze and drugs and hawdcoah, but life is what you make it, I guess.

P.S.  Skydiving and Scuba are fun too.

> 6) With the exception of NYC, its a CHEAPER!  Lower taxes, lower
> prices.

You get what you pay for.  (I know its a cliche, but the quality of
life here is better than anywhere else I've lived.  Really.)

> 
> 7) They have serious ICE HOCKEY.  (If anyone can tell me where I can
> buy a reasonably priced Boys Large hockey helmet inthe Bay Area, I'd
> appreciate the tip), and not just pros - for everyone. 
> 

What was that about expensive hobbies? :-)

(Actually, I miss hockey too.)


> 8) You don't have to go very far (at least in new england) to get
> out of the sprawling city and suburbs.  In California, every time I
> try to go into the wilderness to be alone there are already a zillion
> people there. 
> 

Mt. Diablo national park is less than a 1/2 hr. busride from where I
work.  Beat that in NYC.

> 9) The East Coast has more CHARACTER.  In California, all the streets
> are in a grid; every corner has a shopping mall with 3 restaraunts, a
> drug store and a beauty salon, complete with a zillion speed bumps,
> stucco walls, and a quasi-mexican red clay roof.  *Boring*  
> 

You don't get in the city much here, do you?

> 10) NO EARTHQUAKES
> 

No terrorist attacks here.


> 11) Better NY style pizza.
> 

Try:
John Henry's Pizza (the Haight)
Volare's pizza (the Haight)
North Beach Pizza [note:  more chicago style, but very good]
Cafe Coexistance [Portland, OR]
(got one in for Fred :-)

> I'm also curious about what you said Geoff.  Do you really think the
> crime situation is alot better in SF than in Boston?  I really didn't
> get that impression.  I'm much more scared walking around in SF.  But
> maybe I'm just ignorant.
> 
> 

Sue, you aren't ignorant, just unaccustomed to SF.  I have to say
there is MUCH more racism present on the right coast (yes, even taking
the Pacific NW into acct), and definantly murder rates are higher
there.  I believe (someone correct me if I'm wrong) that rape and
assault are higher (rate-wise) there as well.  


All that said, I really like Boston and NYC for their own charm.  The
southern eastern seaboard is (in my experience) somewhat redeeming as
well.  I just prefer california.

-H-

From sfraves-owner  Wed Nov  3 00:37:52 1993
From: brycer@netcom.com (Bryce Ryan)

Subject: [POLL RESULTS] Daytime Liquid Air
Status: 

Thanks to all of you who responded to my poll concerning a daytime
liquid air.  The results are:

Yes, I would attend:	25
No, I wouldn't:		0

The ayes have it.  Because of the overwhelmingly positive response,
the Fluid Groove crew has decided to give it a whirl on Saturday,
November 20th, from 1-5 PM.  Curent DJ list includes Jon D. and
Lee An. As always, donations will be gratefully accepted for the
sound system (provided by Sound Vision), DJs and space. Please call
the info number below and the calendar as the date approaches.

Everyone who answered the poll: I expect to see you there with an SO
or friend...I'm making a list and checking it twice :) Thanks for all
your kind comments and suggestions: we really care what you think,
and are doing our best to make this *your* rave. Also, be sure to 
check out Chez Groove on Friday, November 12th, if you're in SF--
audio is also by Sound Vision, and DJs include Jon D., Lee, Tony,
Doran and Jamie. Rave hard, peace, and hope to see you at Come/Unity!

Bryce Ryan ------- AMBIANCE ----------- brycer@netcom.com-----

From sfraves-owner  Wed Nov  3 05:46:16 1993
From: winston@lurnix.COM (Mark Guthrie)
Date: Tue, 2 Nov 93 23:52:47 PST
Subject: Re: I love the East Coast
Status: 

Well Sue, you've unleeshed my very biased, unfair, immature (but hey you
were first, right?) "Why California Is Better Than Everywhere Else List".

1) We have distinct seasons but liveable weather.  If we want snow or
intense thunder showers or colored leaves we can go to the Sierras but
we don't live in misserable weather - for the most part.

2) We play VARIETY.

3) San Francisco's BART is a model for other railway systems.  I often 
overhear pleasantly surprised east-coasters compairing it against what
they're used to.  As for transportation in general, some cities are cool,
some suck, regarless of what coast your on.

4) We can buy beer in any store on any day of the week.

5) ----I will not make a people comparparison parody to Sue's origional
VERY stereotyped, mean, bitter, untrue, banter about super market clerks (?)
and Californians and what not.  It tells a lot, though.  Even though, 
East Coasters are just as easy to make mean-spirited stereotypes of.

6)If you exclude our large metro areas, the east coast isn't cheaper.  The
sticks are the same everywhere.

7)You can play any sport that exists here.  I'm quite sure you can find
anything from ice hockey helmuts to hang-gliders, which I'm sure is a
great sport, like skiing (did I mention we have this realy cool mountain
range called the Sierras, where you can do some of the best skiing and
rock climbing and hiking in the world?  Oh ya, and that it skirts one of
the most fertile agricultural areas of the world?  And that there are
beatuful red wood forests on one end and our very own desert on the other?
And to the west, our own ocean coast with SANDY beaches, surfing, etc.?

8)Cali and the rest of the west coast has more wildernes and better things
to do in it (see above).  We have almost any kind of terra you need, man.
If you can't find it, I don't know what to say.

9)Cali and the west has hella-character.  That's why everyone else always
jealously talks shit (see Sue's origional post).  Again, I refuse to make
rude but easily done stereotypes about east coast architecture, city 
planning, and culture.  But, San Francisco is one of the most beautiful
big cities and we have plenty of charismatic towns such as Berkeley,
Santa Cruz, and others.

10)There are earthquackes on the east coast with the emminent possibility of
a "big one".  True, not as much as hear but we don't get hurricanes (and
remnents thereof) or tornadoes or all-around shitty cold-ass misserable
weather and we don't have to shovel snow.

11)New Yorkers are always talkin it up about what we can't get here like 
they can there and it's always B.S.  Were as much or more of a culural mecca.
We can get anything you can.  I've had better bagels here than I can find
in NY.  That's an open challenge.  It is also just as stupid as any other
food comparison because it all comes down to individual taste and fond
memories.  On the subject of food though, we have a thriving culinary
culture, complete with some of the very best (in the worlk) wine from our
very own Napa valley and beer from the thriving micro beer revolution,
which started here.  Oh and what goes better with the food than Northern
California's finest green bud - the best in the world, smoke on that one.

Oh ya, we have the best coffee in the world too - better than seattle, whoo
got the rep from media/publicity hype, but they're technicly on the west
coast too, right?

12)We started the computer revolution.

13)Although it's crumbling, we have one of the best University systems.

14)You name it we got it.  Were cool, you suck.  Isn't this fun.

-Mark

From sfraves-owner  Wed Nov  3 06:11:04 1993
From: Harry Duran <hduran@UMDNJ.EDU>
Date: Wed, 3 Nov 1993 09:08:09 -0500 (EST)
Subject: EC-Technopoodles
Status: 

As one of the east coast people on the outer spectrum of our gaussian
raver distrubution I would like to contribute my own pair-a-lincolns to the
raging EC vs WC debate:

	I like the east coast and I love NEW YORK!!!!!
	I love the neravers that I have met and raved with
	I think that hardcore and trance, acid, and heavy house are Gods own
		music

	I think that the environment here is very different from SF and 
		spawns a certain adaptation in style...here I agree 
		wholeheartedly with Laura

	The concept that people are nicer/friendlier nastier/meaner here
		or there doesnt wash with me, personal styles may vary
		and the cultural vibe may differ but it is just as easy 
		to be a creep or a kewldewd in NYC, SF, Dallas, Miami
		or what have you because what you are to the outside world
		is what you are inside :)
			if you are sincere you will be perceived as sincere
			if you are a jerk your jerkiness will manifest

Bigotry hatred and cruelty are part of the human condition. I rave because I see
an incipient spirituality that I can relate to. The feeling of togetherness that I get while dancing with friends and complete strangers to mind blowing music
and the spontaneity of our net villages are what keep it meaningful for me.

THe emphasis should be on appreciating each others differences and celebrating our diversity rather than trying to one-up each other. 

Yes the east coast technopoodle may be a breed apart but we are all visitors in the same house when we rave. 

well thats enough from my little ultraworld
peace love and ecstacy

Harry; wazzup/techno-woofer

From sfraves-owner  Wed Nov  3 06:53:44 1993
From: "Golden Boy" <deb9@thor.INS.CWRU.Edu>
Date: Wed, 3 Nov 93 09:51:43 CST
Subject: Appropriate and Inappropriate topix
Status: 

hello kidz...goldenboy here...I've been on a few lists for a while on and 
off.  What i don't understand is people complaining about articles that they
feel are inappropriate for the "rave" lists. I mean, i do understand, but 
why duplicate what they would call inappropriate activity, by posting a 
article to the list that, according to thier definition, shouldn't be 
there. certainly the address of the person that posted the article is 
included with the article.   Some people say its as easy as a kill file or 
simply deleteting the one (as far as i know i only get one copy of each 
post, unless it's posted to mutliple lists) post.  It's my understanding 
that the person who determines what is valid and what is invalid on lists 
is the list-admin.  I could say, if you dont like the diversity of the 
posts, then unsub.  But thats rather elitest.  what i do want to say is 
that sometimes the list is just a way to ask for friends advice, or tell a 
few friends whats going on...or just talk a little shit.  i'm not 
advocating mindless babble on the net, but i'm not condemning occasional 
posts that don't focus "directly" on a rave, or the price of xtc.

if you're a "raver" or you go to raves and listen to techno, so what if you 
post something a tad away from the mainstream of conversation.  you're 
still a raver aren't you ? and this is a part of your life isn't it, hence 
theorhetically, its rave related. i read a lot of things about a man named 
mal (sfraves) that i have never met. and to me (in cleveland) that isn't 
rave related. yet, i was concerned for him because he's a raver and a 
human.  so i sent him a ne-raves sticker and card.  and from what i hear, 
he'z getting better everyday, yay mal ! :)

these lists have become so much more than a forum for strictly rave related 
topix.  many people have developed legit relationships on the lists.  i've 
been going through some rough times and some of the people on the 
net have been there for me, if not in person, then virtually (vrave :) and 
i'm very very thankful for that. 

and too rap this up...i'm not flaming anyone, just saying don't be so quick 
to jump on someone, for something so trivial. i recieve tons of mail, and i 
just use the old 'F6' key and whack the stuff i don't want to read. no 
sweat. no hassle. no loss.  besides, if you're at work, you shouldn't be 
reading rave related stuff anyway :) or so my boss says *looks over 
shoulder to make sure boss isn't around* :)

peace to the net. *steps down off of milk crate*...i don't think they make 
soapboxes anymore :)  *applies flame retardant gel #OZ472*
+++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++
goldenboy          
                          "Forget your name"
                        "Just close your eyes"
                             "Go insane"

> 


I reread this today and wanted to clarify a bit.  My points were 
that people who like "expensive expensive" hobbies generally don't do
it because it's "hip", but rather because they ACTUALLY LIKE what they
are doing, and that it's silly to castigate them because in your
opinion they are doing "the hip thing".

I don't have an above average salary, and learning to fly costs me
nearly what my rent does.  I do it because its important to me, and I
like it a lot.  I could give a fuck less if its "hip".

Also, I'm sure we all know people who blow easily the same amount on
cover charges, E, and/or other intoxicants on the weekend.  Whether or
not they are the "hip" things to do, people do these things because
they like them.  

Sue, have you actually tried any of the things you mentioned in the
above paragraph?  You might like them.

-H-

From sfraves-owner  Wed Nov  3 10:36:29 1993

> Brian about this, saying that there were major similarities on the
> BASIC level of what's going on -- and he insisted you all were different,
> too.

On the other hand, when I met you this summer, Laura, I came up with a theory:
Hypothetically, if I had ended up taking a job in NY three years ago, and if
you had ended up taking a job in SF three years ago, I would have ended up
getting into the faster music and you would have ended up getting into the 
slower music.  In other words -- it's not the people who are different; rather
it's the environment/atmosphere that's different.

From sfraves-owner  Wed Nov  3 11:15:24 1993
From: laura@soda.berkeley.edu (Laura La Gassa)
Date: Wed, 3 Nov 1993 11:15:18 -0800
Subject: access to EC information
Status: 

A number of people have written to me saying they either didn't know anything
was happening back East or couldn't find anything and could I help them on
their next trip that-a-way.

The best way to get information on what is going on is to give a yell to
the ne-raves (North Eastern US) mailing list before you go.  The address is
pretty easy to remember -- it's nearly the same as the sfraves address!

	ne-raves@techno.stanford.edu

Just ask for a copy of our calendar and you'll be on your way.  We also do
a lot of picnics and dinner parties before raves, so chances are if you
plan on attending something you'll be able to meet up with a bunch of the
ne-ravers.

Some of you who wrote to me mentioned you'd be East this summer . . . I'd
just like to note here that if the Universe continues to smile upon me as
it has been I'll be living in San Francisco by then.  Aside from being 
prettier than the part of New Jersey I live in, it also has Brian B. :-)
Records and CDs are portable, so since it's so hard to find techno in
San Francisco I'll just bring my own :-) (thus eliminating part of the music
issue). :-) :-) :-)

Be well everyone.

Laura

P.S.  In my opinion you can't get good "NY-Style" pizza in NYC, either.  The
best pizza I've had on the East Coast has been in Philadelphia.

From sfraves-owner  Wed Nov  3 13:10:06 1993
From: grigsby@agames.com@agames.com (JUMP IN THE FIRE)
Date: Wed, 3 Nov 93 13:09:17 PST
Subject: Pizza wars
Status: 


All you coastal types arguing about who has the best pizza are as jackals
squabbling over the lion's leavings.  Go to the Midwest, specifically
Chicago, if you desire only the perfect pie.  Edwardo's and Giordano's
both romp all over anyone else's idea of what deep-dish is supposed to 
taste like.  You can swim in an Edwardo's medium.  And, of course, the
original Uno's is there, should your tastes run to a more buttery crust.

And for those of you who think there is nothing between Tahoe and the
Appalachians, a resounding "piffle".  I have spent most of my life in the
zone no one on the coasts seems to care about, and while there are many
great things about California, Boston, etc., I still remember fondly lazy
summer nights on a tumbledown back porch in Ohio, smoking hash from a
doctored beer can and plugging at fluoro tubes with bows and an air rifle.
Oh- rent was $100/mo.

It's not where you are, it's who you're with.

// g

From sfraves-owner  Wed Nov  3 13:32:09 1993
From: vivianm@src.dec.com
Date: Wed, 03 Nov 93 13:30:35 -0800
Subject: Re: I love the East Coast
Status: 


Oh no, I think I have to include my opinions on this one having come 
from the East Coast, specifically New York, some 9 years ago. 

Mark writes::::
>1) We have distinct seasons but liveable weather.  If we want snow or
>intense thunder showers or colored leaves we can go to the Sierras but
>we don't live in misserable weather - for the most part.
I agree.  I hate the cold weather, but if I ever have a desire to 
visit and see the snow I adored as a child, I can go to the Sierras 
>2) We play VARIETY.
agreed.  I for one do not like Hardcore, I enjoy the house and gay 
house that I can hear in San Fransisco, I even enjoy an occasional 
disco tune here and there. Long live Sundays at the End Up. !!!:-) 
:-)
>3) San Francisco's BART is a model for other railway systems.  I often 
>overhear pleasantly surprised east-coasters compairing it against what
>they're used to.  As for transportation in general, some cities are cool,
>some suck, regarless of what coast your on.
where I came from in New York, (middle state) there was no such thing 
as public transportation.  I love the fact of jumping on Cal train 
and being at work in less time than it takes me to drive and with 
a lot less hassle. 
>4) We can buy beer in any store on any day of the week.
and the shopping malls are open on Sundays unlike New Jersey. (or have they 
repealed that now?)
>5) ----I will not make a people comparparison parody to Sue's origional
>VERY stereotyped, mean, bitter, untrue, banter about super market clerks (?)
>and Californians and what not.  It tells a lot, though.  Even though, 
>East Coasters are just as easy to make mean-spirited stereotypes of.
I for one enjoy talking to my sales clerks in the grocery stores, 
or anyone for that matter. Last time I visited my family in New York, 
I tried to be friendly with my store clerk, and couldn't even get 
her to look up from the cash register to barely acknowledge my presence 
much less to ask me how I was or to even smile. I don't know why 
people who deal with the public feel the need to be so rude. But 
then this is just my opinion. 
>6)If you exclude our large metro areas, the east coast isn't cheaper.  The
>sticks are the same everywhere.
I thought it was about the same.
>7)You can play any sport that exists here.  I'm quite sure you can find
>anything from ice hockey helmuts to hang-gliders, which I'm sure is a
>great sport, like skiing (did I mention we have this realy cool mountain
>range called the Sierras, where you can do some of the best skiing and
>rock climbing and hiking in the world?  Oh ya, and that it skirts one of
>the most fertile agricultural areas of the world?  And that there are
>beatuful red wood forests on one end and our very own desert on the other?
>And to the west, our own ocean coast with SANDY beaches, surfing, etc.?
at least you can go skiing in one weekend and rock climbing in another. 
On the east coast, you ski all winter and have little choice as to 
what else to do.  
>8)Cali and the rest of the west coast has more wildernes and better things
>to do in it (see above).  We have almost any kind of terra you need, man.
>If you can't find it, I don't know what to say.
agreed 150%.
(skipped 9)

>10)There are earthquackes on the east coast with the emminent possibility of
>a "big one".  True, not as much as hear but we don't get hurricanes (and
>remnents thereof) or tornadoes or all-around shitty cold-ass misserable
>weather and we don't have to shovel snow.
agreed again.
>11)New Yorkers are always talkin it up about what we can't get here like 
>they can there and it's always B.S.  Were as much or more of a culural mecca.
>We can get anything you can.  I've had better bagels here than I can find
>in NY.  That's an open challenge.  It is also just as stupid as any other
>food comparison because it all comes down to individual taste and fond
>memories.  On the subject of food though, we have a thriving culinary
>culture, complete with some of the very best (in the worlk) wine from our
>very own Napa valley and beer from the thriving micro beer revolution,
>which started here.  Oh and what goes better with the food than Northern
>California's finest green bud - the best in the world, smoke on that one.
Here I thought the same about pizza, not having found anything better 
than New York's. But I thanks to you on the list, next time I am 
in the Haight I will have to check out the restaurants some of you 
mentioned.,

From sfraves-owner  Wed Nov  3 14:00:08 1993
From: pashdown@slack.sim.es.com (Pete Ashdown)
Date: Wed, 3 Nov 1993 14:57:59 -0700 (MST)
Subject: XDZebra Review #38
Status: 

Ok, yes, I'm backlogged.  I'm trying to catch up, please be patient.  The
amount of material I've been receiving recently has almost tripled.


XDZebra Review #38

        Addiction
        266 Delmar Ct.
        Salt Lake City, UT 84101-1817

When in Utah call the T A S T E hotline 801-461-3375.

Trying to find these releases?  Try Ear/Rational: angst@psych.colorado.edu

Back issues are available from me by mail or by ftp'ing to techno.stanford.edu.
They're in the pub/raves/music/reviews directory.

XDZebra Reviews may be reproduced without permission under one condition,
they remain intact and unchanged.  If you publish this in print, mail me a
copy via "Addiction".

------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Review #38 Contents:
C-Tank: Nightmares Are Reality
Jeff Mills: Waveform Transmission Vol. 1
Wakin' Up A Dead Planet - Hardnoize Cross Europe
Coordinate 01
The Inner Works 1+2 Only Double CD - Limited Edition
X-103: Atlantis
Fast 4 Motion EP
The Kosmik Kommando: Universal Indicator Yellow
The Caustic Window: Joyrex J9 EP  [45]
Jesus Jones: Zeroes & Ones


C-Tank: Nightmares Are Reality
Overdrive: CD OVER 030-2
1  180  07:02 Nightmares Are Reality
2  180  04:32 Air Bounce
3  160  06:00 House Hallucination
4  175  05:47 Holomania
5  190  03:40 The Rave Zone
6  172  05:43 Tank Trap
7  179  04:42 Monotonic
8  200  05:11 Biolunch
9  164  04:51 Drugtrash
10 180  04:37 Lost and Intellect
11 180  04:00 Mutation Step
12 170  06:36 Walk on Base (Remix)

Comments:  In listening to C-Tank one gets the sense that the only form of
structure is a rotation of instruments through rhythm patterns.  Certainly
sheer speed is a virtue here, but when either a headache or sleep is induced
from listening to it, the hardcore label becomes a farce.  C-Tank can produce
some good tracks, I enjoy "Holomania" and "Walk on Base", but the majority of
this album smells of filler.

Summary: 6/10.  Hard and fast, but at the same time unsatisfying.


Jeff Mills: Waveform Transmission Vol. 1
Tresor/Axis: CD11
1  149  04:47 Phase 4
2  140  05:27 Jerical
3  137  04:52 Changes of Live
4  145  05:56 Berlin
5  154  04:21 The Hacker
6  140  04:47 Late Night
7  136  04:09 DNA
8  136  04:49 Man-Like

Comments:  Jeff makes hardcore that evolves and progresses over the length of
the entire track.  Sometime this is subtle as in "Man-Like", or it knocks your
head off as in "The Hacker".  The opener, "Phase 4" is especially crushing and
sounds monstrous on a big sound system.  The only track I really don't
appreciate is "Changes of Live" which takes a house piano riff and tries to
bend it into something hard.  It doesn't work, and begins to sound terrible
after the first 30 seconds.

Summary: 8/10.  Better than average, with a lot of intelligence thrown in.
Sort of a short album at 40 minutes, but only one bum track.


Wakin' Up A Dead Planet - Hardnoize Cross Europe
Monotone: MONO-020
1  142  04:50 Force Mass Motion
2  160  04:03 Tribes of the Moon: Type C.
3  147  04:52 Cyclo-S9: Cry
4  182  04:14 The Speedfreak: Cos It's Hard
5  153  05:12 Illuminatae: Tremora Del Terra (Rmx)
6  148  04:31 Cyberchrist: Somebody Kill That Mutherfuckin' Pig!
7  144  05:23 Jammin' Unit: Low Density
8  139  04:49 Walker: Elevator To Hell
9  182  04:34 Harlot: Elastische Sozialsysteme
10 140  03:57 Atom Heart: X.X.X.
11 180  04:32 Search & Destroy: Reach the Sky
12 167  04:44 Vinyl Countdown: Paroles (Remix)
13 147  05:32 Cybersonic: Jackhammer
14 143  04:41 Djungle Fever: Volume 001
15 157  04:42 Planet Love: 3 Times A Lady
16 155  03:10 Atmo Shinzo: Infrared

Comments: This is a surprisingly good hardcore compilation, distinguished of
course, by the pair of excellent tracks by Atom Heart, "X.X.X." and
"Infrared".  Most tracks have been edited down, but for the most part, what is
missing is just repetition of what has already been played.  "Type C." and the
Harlot track are excellent breakbeat, "3 Times A Lady" is very cool
spaceycore, and tracks like "Low Density", "Elevator To Hell", and the entry
by Speedfreak test the limits of noise, distortion, and hardcore rhythm.
There are a few dogs, "Reach the Sky" is terrible chipmunk, although "Tremora
del Terra" is actually the best chipmunk I've heard.  In addition, Cyberchrist
pulls out all stops to give us a real stinker.

Summary: 8/10.  Actually a higher hit rate than other non-label hardcore comps
I've purchased recently.  Yet this is still an arena for hardcore fans only.


Coordinate 01
Dossier: DCD 9044
1  138  03:33 Blackland: 1^3
2  130  04:37 Sect: Neuronatics
3  129  06:03 Intermix: Phase One
4  129  04:59 MC^2: Superconductivity
5  130  05:13 Sect: Andromeda Storm
6  139  06:38 Philth: Sub-Aqua
7  115  06:39 Mr. Fist: Lucifer Song
8  122  03:42 Digital White Noise: Demoralize
9  135  04:42 Ithakrash: You Will Fry
10 138  05:28 a Duck: Phenethylamine Backwash
11 146  04:19 X.Drone: Sub-Lunar
12 151  04:15 Tensor: Get Him
13 134  08:21 Downtime: I Want You (To Kill)
14 145  06:13 DV8R: Sounwave

Comments: Imagine what it would be like if everyone took inspiration from the
first Intermix album.  Imagine if this came together on a compilation that was
produced with crystal clear production.  Imagine no more, for Coordinate 01 is
a brilliant result of the production talents of Mike Balch and Bill Leeb.  I
was expecting something more along the lines of classic industrial, but what I
found was sounds that rival the best of the electronic dance groups today.
"Sub-Aqua" is the prime track on here, a truly stunning trance piece that
rises from the depth of night into the light of day.  "Phenethylamine
Backwash" is breakbeat like only Dwayne Goettel of Skinny Puppy could give us,
the Altern8 samples will probably enrage the rave critics even more.
"Sub-Lunar" reminisces of Swamp Terrorists with a speed guitar over fast
beats.  The initial track by Blackland and "Superconductivity" by MC^2 is up
to date cybermaterial without cyberpretentiousness.

Summary: 9/10.  Supremely delicious compilation.  Give us further Coordinates
DRT!


The Inner Works 1+2 Only Double CD - Limited Edition
Overdrive: OVER LE 1
CD 1:
1  130  05:33
2  126  04:54
3  123  05:11
4  123  04:19
5  138  05:32
6  130  05:26
7  141  05:48
8  134  05:16
9  140  05:23
10 144  05:40
11 138  05:40
12 136  04:19
13 138  04:47
14 122  04:39
CD 2:
1  144  06:13 Microbots: Microillusions
2  144  05:00 C-Tank: Walk on Base
3  145  04:52 Tracid Posse: Vivarium
4  130  06:33 Jim Clarke: Qualification (Round 4)
5  151  04:08 Syncroflash A/B: Motorbike Raiders of the Lost Dead
6  143  05:27 Cell-U-Loid: Midnight, Tonight
7  136  03:54 Psycho Drums: Pattern 6
8  157  05:35 Mark N-R-G: Bless to Kill
9  154  04:28 Syncroflash A/B: Request
10 126  05:40 Nino and Atomic Robo Kid: Low Technology
11 150  07:02 C-Tank: Narcotize
12 130  04:08 Sound to Light: Clean Condition
13 166  05:19 Clone I.D.: Beyond 160
14 150  03:38 Turntable Hoschis: Peace

Comments:  Apologies for the lack of a track listing on the first disc.  This
release came without any listings, and I had the "Inner Works 2" around, so I
copied that.  Frankly, it isn't too much to worry about though.  These two
compilations have about a 1/3 hit rate, the rest is droning drek.  If it came
down to which comp to purchase, I'd recommend the second, it seems to be a bit
more fleshed out.  However, both of them are way under the premium hardcore.

Summary: 4/10.  Boring attempts spotted with interesting successes.


X-103: Atlantis
Axis/Tresor: 12
1       01:22 Introduction
2  134  03:52 Atlantis (The Entrance)
3       01:31 Interlude A
4  135  04:18 The Gardens
5  145  04:05 Acropolis
6  133  04:42 Hagia Triada
7       01:08 Seduction of Europa
8  139  04:57 Temple of Poseidon
9  110  06:36 Minnia (The Queen's Theme)
10 146  01:11 Eruption
11      00:55 Interlude B
12 141  02:07 Tephra
13 134  03:30 10,000 Chariots
14 140  03:45 Curse of God
15      04:28 Thera
16 139  03:04 Magma (Technology)

Comments:  "Atlantis" is much easier to digest than the last X-102 album,
"Rings of Saturn", but it also gives further understanding as to what is
trying to be accomplished here.  High on structure, low on content, these
albums are a soundtrack for the imagination.  Some tracks would work on a
dance floor, but most are just there to listen to.  X-103 is more hardcore
than anything else, even though there are a few nice ambient tracks thrown in,
especially "Thera".  The rest is a prime example of analog work with a large
experimental flavor to the piece as a whole.

Summary: 8/10.  More mature than previous X-10 work.  A bit of ambience, but
largely on a hardcore sound.


Fast 4 Motion EP
Overdrive: LC 6695
Side A:
1  165  100 Meter Final
2  169  Practiceroom
Side B: [45]
1  151  Hardcore Baseline

Comments: So I suppose this is my first taste of "Darkness" and although "100
Meter Final" is fairly slick, "Practiceroom" sounds like speedy breakbeat
diddling on a tape.  "Hardcore Baseline" throws the breakbeat for a return to
Force Mass Motion or Prodigy styled hardcore.  Listening to "Baseline" all the
way through could be a painful experience, which is probably why they've laid
the breaks out neatly on the record, it makes for better mixing.

Summary: 4/10.  Ho hum.  I'm sure there's better stuff available in this
genre, but the B-side takes the value way down.


The Kosmik Kommando: Universal Indicator Yellow
Rephlex: MC 202
Yellow Side:    [45]
1  141
2  
Sign Side:
1  140
2  137
3  141

Comments: Kosmik Kommando pulls off acid from the depths of distortion on the
"Yellow Side".  The first track is severely noisy, but not really hardcore in
an odd way.  However, with the following noisefest that defies description
with track two, I started to wonder if KK was going for the techno equivalent
of smashing his guitar.  Probably the noisiest electronics to hit my
turntables yet.  "Sign Side" sounds quited different, still acidic, but more
like Atom Heart's work.

Summary: 7/10.  Noiselicious and very original one side, but rather standard
on the B-side.


The Caustic Window: Joyrex J9 EP  [45]
Rephlex: CAT 009 ii
Paper Side:
1  152
2  159
Black Side:
1  150
2  136

Comments: At first it took me a while to determine the correct speed this
should be played at.  In reality, it sounds good on 33 as well, slow and
crushing with a dub sort of effect.  However, the samples used point to the
fact that this is indeed a 45.  Joyrex J9 represents more of a tubey hollow
sound for Richard James.  Although track 1 on the "Paper Side" is bitterly
acidic and hard, track 2 is almost ambient.  To emphasize this, it is recorded
at an obnoxiously lower level as well.  On the "Black Side" is an tribal acid
track that emphasizes the previously mentioned "hollowness".  Finally, the
closer is a reuse of the "We are the music makers" sample, but to better
effect than "Ambient Works 85-92".

Summary: 8/10.  Better than average release for the multitalented Richard
James.  Plus some free "Magic Gum"!  How can you lose?


Jesus Jones: Zeroes & Ones
EMI UK: 12FOOD44
Side A:
1  145  Zeroes & Ones (The Prodigy Versus Jesus Jones Mix)
2  120  Zeroes & Ones (Central Nervous System Mix)
3  120  Zeroes & Ones
Side B:
1  140  Zeroes & Ones (Aphex Twin Reconstruction #1 Mix)
2  140  Zeroes & Ones (Aphex Twin Reconstruction #2 Mix)

Comments: Gripping my intestines and bracing for the worst, I threw down the
Jesus Jones record and started it spinning.  Hmmm, sounds like Prodigy with a
Jesus Jones sample.  Then it sounds like Jesus Jones with more guitars.
Finally, just JesusJones.  Turning it over, I found Aphex Twin with a Jesus
Jones sample locked up, smashed down, and thrown into an ambient dungeon.
Richard James shoots and scores again.  This reminds me a lot of the Curve and
St. Etienne remixes, little snippet of the original thrown over unique rhythms
and sound.  I can only imagine what Aphex thought of the original piece.

Summary: 5/10.  One side is good.  The other side is expected.

From sfraves-owner  Wed Nov  3 14:17:13 1993
From: geoffw@internex.net (Geoff White)
Date: Wed, 3 Nov 93 14:12:18 PST
Subject: Re: Pizza wars

From sfraves-owner  Wed Nov  3 14:23:50 1993
From: csc@pilot.njin.net (Sean Casey)
Date: Wed, 3 Nov 93 17:22:06 EST
Subject: Pizza wars
Status: 

Impellizaris in Louisville Ky. They make their own sausage and tomato
sauce. A medium pizza is on average 3" thick, has many many layers,
takes about an hour to cook, and weighs 14 (!) pounds. Price: $26,
feeds 6-8. It is without question the best food I have ever eaten.

Sean


From sfraves-owner  Wed Nov  3 14:29:03 1993
From: csc@pilot.njin.net (Sean Casey)
Date: Wed, 3 Nov 93 17:28:59 EST
Subject: DAT deal falls through: Looking for used 1200s.
Status: 


I was going to purchase a portable DAT deck, but the guy I was going
to buy it from succumbed to the lure of quick cash and sold it to
someone else.

So instead I'm looking for a pair of used 1200s, pref with styli. If
anyone knows of a good deal, please point me to it. Also looking for a
mixer, a high quality but not overfeatured one. And a shrubbery.

Thanks,

Sean

From sfraves-owner  Wed Nov  3 14:45:03 1993
From: geoffw@internex.net (Geoff White)
Date: Wed, 3 Nov 93 14:40:08 PST
Subject: Re: ENOUGH ALREADY
Status: 


> From SFRaves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU Wed Nov  3 14:23 PST 1993
> From: laura@soda.berkeley.edu (Laura La Gassa)
> Date: Wed, 3 Nov 1993 13:57:42 -0800
> To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
> Subject: ENOUGH ALREADY
> 
> 
> All this EC/WC stuff is really making me sick, especially now that it's
> starting to get personal what with -H-'s last letter in referene to
> Sue Raisty.
> 
> This has all served to confirm to me that a number of people in San
> Francisco do have smug superiority complexes.  Well, I've had enough,
> and am unsubscribing from sfraves.
> 
> Laura
> 
Laura, please don't unsubscribe we do value your opinion
I think most of this was all in fun.  You have to realize that SO MANY
of us out here were raised and grew up on the east coast, if we really liked it,
we would be there right now, it's not that the EC is bette than the WC but for
ME there is no question that HERE is where I want to live and I don't
want to live THERE.  I think NYC is a great place and I love to visit,
we have a saying "they always come back to Baltimore" and I do go back
and enjoy my stay.  I went to Denver a few weeks ago and liked it,
even passed through Salt Lake City, prety place.  I liked the land scape
but sooner or later I began to notice al of the people staring at me
(with aparent fear) (this old guy in the Colorado Springs airport actuall told
his wife to "watch out for that wild one over therre " (And I wasn't even 
dressed that ravey) The bottom line is that when I walk down the streets of SF
no matter how wild I look, people either smile at me or ignore me, they don't
look at me with hostility or fear, It's like they know we are all part of the
same tribe.  If I smile at someone in NYC if they are a woman she thinks I'm trying to hit on her and if he a man he thinks I'm gay or about to mug him :)
This is the place for me.  And I intend to stay through the quakes and
the fires and the epidemics.  Ecotopia is my home.



				G

From sfraves-owner  Wed Nov  3 15:24:42 1993
From: howardb@enlil.premenos.sf.ca.us (Howard Berkey)
Date: Wed, 3 Nov 1993 15:22:20 -0800 (PST)
Subject: Available now at Housewares...
Status: 

Housewares on Haight has two items I strongly recommend: Aphex Twin
Tickets (with Moby, Orbital, Young American Primitive, DJ's, etc...)
for $16 and the Exist Dance comp, "Transmitting from Heaven" for $17.

The ED comp is really, really good.
(I think Mike already reviewed it so that's all I'll say, besided if
you like Eden Transmission's "I'm So High" you'll like the remix,
apparently done at Casa Twitch by Mike himself, and that the High
Lonesome Sound System tracks are especially good).

-H-

From sfraves-owner  Wed Nov  3 15:44:44 1993
From: bbehlen@soda.berkeley.edu (Brian Behlendorf)
Date: Wed, 3 Nov 1993 15:44:33 -0800
Subject: Re: East and West
Status: 

Will people PUHLEAZE stop this coast-bashing?  It's embarrasing to those
of us here who have friends outside of California on this list who can 
conclude nothing from it other than San Franciscans are complete snobs!
I know we aren't!  It's not wrong to love where you live, I love it here
and it's not been without living elsewhere, but I don't go around trying
to cram that viewpoint into other people's faces because there are some
facets of life out here I can see people not liking.  WE ARE NOT PERFECT.
California is NOT MECCA. 

        Brian

From sfraves-owner  Wed Nov  3 16:57:38 1993
From: DWATANAB@uci.edu (Dana Watanabe)
Date: Wed, 3 Nov 93 16:57:26 PST
Subject: E v C
Status: 

first off... id REALLY like to repeat
saying that this is east coast v. west coast pisses me off

but anyhow..
id REALLY like to support what laura said
no.. not EVERYONE in SF is smug about living there
but..

like i just said like 20 minutes ago to brian
when i go up to SF and say that im from LA
people feel pity for me
they apologize
they act like i am missing an apendage or something
and quite frankly in case you cant tell
ITS FUCKING ANNOYING

wow... that feels good

although i cant really say im living in LA by choice
i do love El Pueblo de La Reina de Los Angeles
i love the beach, even santa monica
i love the mountains, i love the smog, i love being in a club all night
and in the morning seeing the hollywood sign, i love pink's hot dog
stand, i love mc arthur park even
its what makes me enjoy where i live and have lived

im not saying i dont get smug about living in LA, i do
and people in NY and Boston and all over have acted smug
about where they live, especially in this discussion

but what does any of that have to do with people
i used to make fun of the hardcore east coast stuff
but now i know too many people and cant help but respect them
and their musical/cultural choices

which is what i thought this was all supposed to be about

but i've been wrong before so it wouldnt surprise me if i am again

 ,
dana 

"Forget all this chocolate and vanilla, what you need is some Sasparilla!"
-Doc Martin
(originally from SF and visits often, but he seems quite happy where he is)

From sfraves-owner  Wed Nov  3 17:23:50 1993
From: raisty@berlioz.nsc.com (Sue Raisty)
Date: Wed, 3 Nov 93 17:23:42 PST
Subject: ???
Status: 

geoffw@internex.net, howardb@enlil.premenos.sf.ca.us,
andy@kingkong.wco.ftp.com, mw@sysbase.com, laura@soda.berkeley.edu
Subject: EC/WC wars - I've had it. (long)
BCC: raisty

OK, fine.  I get the point.  I should go back to where I've come from.
Well believe me I'm working on it.  And I'll probably unsubscribe from
this list as soon as possible because it has a pretty crappy vibe.

But before I go, let me respond to some of the avalanches of email I
have received.  Since so many people had duplicate attacks, I'm going
to do it all in one letter.  Besides I erased alot of it already so I
can't even send it to the zillions of individuals who sent me stuff.

--- I am working on moving back to New England but I can't do it yet.
I just graduated from college, so Howard, I am not qualified to be a
contractor.  I don't have any experience and I'm finding out I'm
really ignorant about my field too.

--- Zillions of people have suggested that I must be a moron since I
complained about having to go a long way to get to the wilderness and
be alone, away for people.  You all missed the point of my original
post.  I'll give it to you, California has many more National parks
and open spaces, etc...  But you can NEVER seem to get away from all
the people.   I've been to just about all the places y'all suggested
and there were still TONS of people there.  Even when I went camping
with a wilderness permit in Tahoe.  Believe me, I've tried.  No need
to get hostile.

--- And YES I have tried some of those expensive hobbies.  And YES
they seem fun and I have no problem with someone who is participates
in one of them because she truly loves it.  But it seems like all the
people I've met here are not into it because they love it, but into it
because it is expensive and has "status."  I love bicycling and have
totally had my mtn. bike and road bike scoffed at out here.  True,
they're not made of titanium, but I'm not that good so why the hell
can't I use just a decent, average bike?  This NEVER happened out
east.  So what if I drive a 4-door and not a sportscar, if i'd rather
save my money for tickets home than blowing it on parasailing or the
latest fad?  You'd think it was a crime according to most of the
people I've met out here.  And it especially ticks me when these same
material object-mongers start bitching about money (as they always
will), I mean if you can't afford your car payments, sell the damn
car!  argh. i apologize for going off, but I have NEVER met people so
preoccupied with owning the newest toys and doing the cool things as I
have out here.  PERHAPS I've just met the wrong people, but...

And yeah, hockey (the equip. anyway) can be expensive.  I've been
playing since I stopped growing at age 13, so I already have all the
stuff. In the east the ice time and leagues are cheap; I'm finding
that's not the case here.

--- While CAL train and BART and the buses out here are nice, they
really can't compare.  They don't run often enough, they shut down too
early.  And things are so much more spread out here it is really not
possibl to cover everywhere.  In Boston, I could go out drinking
anywhere in the city and get safely home without driving.  

--- Regarding my original objection to posting political, non-rave
related stuff to this list:  I've gotten all these little notes that
tell me something like "For your information, NE-raves is much more
babbley and strays from the topic much more than SF-raves".  Well,
maybe I just had good timing or something, but that is not my
experience.  When I was first on Ne-raves last Jan, there was a lot of
babble but after a serious discussion it seemed like "guidelines" were
established and people generally stuck to them.  At least until I left
in August.  and there was no where near the ammount of political
posturing on that list that there is here, or the declarations of what
is the "correct" political opinion to have if you are a raver.  

--- I DID NOT START THIS COAST WARS DISCUSSION.  Someone out there
called my list biased, unfair and immature, and implied I started the
whole thing.  Well, I was responding to what I saw as a totally
negative and wrong list of everything that was wrong about the east
coast by Geoff White. And he was responding to Laura, who complained
about a comment by Michael W. who said that sfravers are a "breed
apart from east-coast counterparts".  I was just giving the reasons
why I love the east coast.   

--- AND YES there are Raves in the Boston Area.  From all the mail I
get, it seems like a lot of this list really thinks that there is no
scene up in the north-east (with the exception of new york).  Well,
that's just totally wrong.  Maybe I've just hit all the wrong raves
out here, but there seems to be much more of a feeling of community
out in NE.  Just an impression though.  So please DON'T lynch me.
 
--- PARDON me for my "VERY stereotyped, mean, bitter, untrue banter
about supermarket clerks" and for implying I am mean-spirited.  I've
never even met you.  Let me assure you that I am quite polite to the
supermarket clerks who start chatting with me.  And i believe that I
said: "I don't like the mindless chatter with the supermarket clerk."
Perhaps you are interpretting this statement incorrectly.  I do not
mean to imply that the supermarket clerks are stupid and have no
minds, its just their chatter is.  small talk generally is!  
I personally don't want comments on what I am buying "what do you need
that for?" and jokes about my purchases.  Perhaps some people like it,
but IN MY OPINION it is fake.  This person has no interest in being my
friend, so why act all chummy with me?  I just don't like it.

--- Believe me I'm not "jealous" of California's character, and that
is most certainly NOT the reason why I said I don't like it.  Please.
Have you ever been in a small New England town in the autumn?  Most of
the houses are different, and old, with basements and fireplaces and
shingles on the roof.  And the meandering streets and stone fences,
with rows of maple and oak trees that are bright bright shades of
purple and red.  There's nothing to compare in the Sierras I assure
you.  Been there.  I guess you've never been to New England though.
It has a hell of a lot more character - with the exception of the
Spanish missions, it's a lot older.

--- there are lots of GOOD microbreweries in boston at least, don't
claim it as SF's.  Commonwealth brewery, cambridge brewing co, boston
beer works, etc... (the Sam adams commercials claim they started the
microbrewery revolution, but thats not worth much...)

--- Thank you for the pizza suggestions.  I look forward to trying
them out.  Maybe it will help me forget my homesickness while I ache
to go back home.

And for EVERYONE who personally wrote me to tell me to get the fuck
out of their cherished state, thank you so much for thinking of me
enough to drop me a personal note.  It made my day, really.  Thanks
for acting like elitist prima donnas, and I'll be more than happy to
leave your state.

I'll get out of here soon, I promise.

sue raisty









From sfraves-owner  Wed Nov  3 17:24:28 1993
From: "Barry Alexander" <barryale@symantec.com>
Date: Wed, 03 Nov 93 17:24:04 pst
Subject: twitch email address?
Status: 



          has anyone out there ever ordered any stuff from twitch
          mail order?  i made an order recently and haven't got
          anything back yet.  does twitch have an email address?
          just wondering which black hole my letter fell into:
          ups or  twitch?  thanks!

          barry

claim it as SF's.  Commonwealth brewery, cambridge brewing co, boston
beer works, etc... (the Sam adams commercials claim they started the
microbrewery revolution, but thats not worth much...)

--- Thank you for the pizza suggestions.  I look forward to trying
them out.  Maybe it will help me forget my homesickness while I ache
to go back home.

And for EVERYONE who personally wrote me to tell me to get the fuck
out of their cherished state, thank you so much for thinking of me
enough to drop me a personal note.  It made my day, really.  Thanks
for acting like elitist prima donnas, and I'll be more than happy to
leave your state.

I'll get out of here soon, I promise.

sue raisty

From sfraves-owner  Wed Nov  3 17:55:44 1993
From: mw@sybase.com (Michael Wertheim)
Date: Wed, 3 Nov 93 17:54:43 PST
Subject: Re:  Available now at Housewares...
Status: 


> Housewares on Haight has two items I strongly recommend: Aphex Twin
> Tickets (with Moby, Orbital, Young American Primitive, DJ's, etc...)
> for $16 and the Exist Dance comp, "Transmitting from Heaven" for $17.
> 
> The ED comp is really, really good.
> (I think Mike already reviewed it so that's all I'll say,
I did write a review, but I never posted it to sfraves.  I'll append my review
to the end of this message.

> if you like Eden Transmission's "I'm So High" you'll like the remix,
> apparently done at Casa Twitch by Mike himself
The Up Above The World track on the Exist Dance CD is their original version.
The UVC remix of this track is on Twitch CD #8.

-------

Exist Dance - "Transmitting From Heaven"
Exist Dance ED CD 01

bpm  time  artist - title
---  ----  -----------------------------------------
103  6:50  Tranquility Bass - "Cantamilla"
134  6:46  Eden Transmission - "I'm So High"
133  6:50  Voodoo Transmission - "Voodoo Fire"
133  5:54  Eden Transmission - "Transmission Maya"
125  4:22  High Lonesome Sound System - "Psychic Dreaming"
128  3:29  Tylervision - "Purdy Deyenol"
130  4:30  High Lonesome Sound System - "Champion Sound"
132  7:43  Up Above The World - "Straight Up Caffeine"
128  4:53  High Lonesome Sound System - "We're Go: Stage One"
130  7:34  High Lonesome Sound System - "Waiting For The Lights"
 90  8:06  Tranquility Bass - "They Came In Peace"
101  5:45  Tranquility Bass - "Mya Yadana"


Exist Dance is two guys from LA who put out records under various names.
Their two most well-known tracks are "I'm So High" by Eden Transmission
and "Mya Yadana" by Tranquility Bass.  "I'm So High" was an incredibly 
popular trance track in the San Francisco rave scene, right up there with
"Papua New Guinea" and "Stella".  "Mya Yadana" was released on the Caroline
Records compilation "Excursions in Ambience" and was many people's first
exposure to Exist Dance.

The Exist Dance guys collect old jazz and swing records from the 20s, 30s
and 40s.  Two of the more interesting tracks on this CD, "Cantamilla" and
"They Came in Peace", consist of samples from these old records combined 
seemlessly with hip-hop beats and Orb-ish ambience.

The remaining tracks on the CD fall into various other categories -- 
tribal ("Voodoo Fire"), ragga-tinged hip-hop ("Champion Sound"), acid trance
("I'm So High" and "Straight Up Caffeine") and ambient dub ("Mya Yadana" and
"They Came In Peace").  But each track is so well-written and well-produced
that it's almost degrading to try to pigeon-hole them into such typical genres.

And "Purdy Deyenol" by Tylervision is definitely the funniest song I've
heard in quite a while.

This CD is being distributed by Caroline, which means that most record stores
should be able to get it.


From sfraves-owner  Wed Nov  3 19:21:53 1993

I think you all are distnictly mistaken......

The midwest (Mich, Ill, Ohio, Ind, Wisc) is where it is at.....

why?!? one might ask? well for starters the lack of natural disasters comes to mind, I  
don't have to worry about being blown away by a feirce wind, having the earth shake and  
roll until my funturie disentegrates (imagine what that would do to a turntable  
spinning a record...ouch (oh has there ever been an earthquake during a party?!? and if  
so what did it sound like?) ), there is a general security in natures wonders around  
here....(and shoveling snow can be hella fun...plus you west coasters can't enjoy  
things such as making snow-creations (such as snowpersons to be pc) you can't enjoy a  
good snow ball war....or any of those other snow type things)

lets see....the weather provides a good amount of variety (one minute it will be a nice  
50 and sunny...5 minutes later it will be 30 and snowing) which keeps people on there  
toes.....the people in "that warm habitable place" are missing the pure pleasure and  
joy of going to party where you HAVE TO DANCE, just to keep warm (vibe! vibE! viBE!  
vIBE! VIBE!) we even have large patches of grass in some cities.

we have more variety that you can imagine (multiple room parties doesn't hurt)  we have  
3 scenes as apposed to everyone elses 1, which gives us twice as much variety. (the  
ungerground, the disco-house scene, and the ravers all very distinct and seperate)

CHICAGO TRANSIT AUTOHRITY rules the earth - I can get ANYWHERE in chicago and the  
suburbs through this marvel....

who would want to buy beer anyhow?!? (not I, but you can buy it at any-point in time)

mid-westerners are a family...drawn together by our lack of a good beach, which  
incedently elminates troubles from beer-musciling beach types....why were else could  
you have a conversation with a punk, a ganbanger, myself, a bussniess man, and a llbean  
dressing person on a crowed subway train during rush hour -- withou being killed! (this  
happened the other day :) 


we have the a fair tax system (our property values are increasing faster than the rate  
of tax)

sports?!? let see umm well we get our fair share (can you go curling on either  
coast...I doubt it!)

we have lots of flat areas, with lostsa neat grasses and lostsa forset land....anything  
else would tend to get boring now wouldn't it?!?

oh we have the best pizza to (nothing beats chi-deep dish nothing)

-----

in other words...be proud of were you live, make the most of it beacuse EVERYWHERE has  
its advantages and disadvantages, we all know what each part of the us is like so why  
are we blabing about who is better? its like an 8th grade ego comeption around here....

LETS END THIS STUPID THREAD!

thanks,

--Kurt

I read what you wrote, and I re-read what I wrote.  I don't think I was
attacking you, in fact I think I was agreeing with a lot of what you
said, but if it felt like an attack when you read it, I am sorry.

>I should go back to where I've come from.
Only if you want to.  Wherever feels like home to you.

>PERHAPS I've just met the wrong people
Possibly so.  Or I've been lucky.  

>--- AND YES there are Raves in the Boston Area.
So Laura tells me.  For whatever reasons the entire scene remained
completely invisible to me all the time I was living there.

>Have you ever been in a small New England town in the autumn?  Most of
>the houses are different, and old, with basements and fireplaces and
>shingles on the roof.  And the meandering streets and stone fences,
>with rows of maple and oak trees that are bright bright shades of
>purple and red... I guess you've never been to New England though.

I lived in New England for 40 years, most of it in small towns.
I grew up in an old colonial house in which all the floors and walls
were just a little out of kilter (as they always are in old houses)
in a town with more maple trees than people.  I even tapped said
maple trees late in the winter for a few seasons for maple syrup.
New England towns are certainly beautiful, especially in the fall.
  
I always seemed to have trouble getting to know the people who
live in them though.  My problem, not theirs, and certainly not
yours.

Just a quick reminder to let everyone know about
today's SFR South Bay Lunch ...

When: Thursday  
Time: 12.00 noon
Where: Greer Park, Palo Alto

Directions:

* From 101 (South or North) take the Oregon Expressway Exit
  Northbound: Past San Antonio Road 
  Southbound: Past University Avenue 

* Left at the first signal - W. Bayshore
  (it's a frontage road that takes you south again)

* Follow this road approx. 1/4 mile (pass apartment complexes on right)
  
* You will see the park on your right hand side. Park in the first
  carpark to your right.

* We'll meet on the grassy knoll , behind the round baseball fence.

Bring lunch, toys, yourselves!

I can only speak for the last 3 hours, but from my unaltered POV,
ComeUnity rocked!  It was as though it never went away.  I would have
prefered the front room as a chill space over the basement, but I didn't 
do much chilling anyway.  Garth gave me a good workout, not quite as
consistent and aggressive as at the FMR, but pretty damn powerful
nonetheless.  The in-house lighting effects weren't used all that much, 
defering to the excellent double screen Synergy display.  All in all,
no surprises, just another wonderful morning for the SF house family.  
Thanx Malachy, for bringing it back. :-)

- leg of eel 

From sfraves-owner  Thu Nov  4 10:41:58 1993
From: "Mike Romo*" <mike_romo*@quickmail.apple.com>
Date: 4 Nov 1993 10:31:46 -0800
Subject: Come Unity Unified
Status: 

                      Subject:                              Time:  10:22 AM
  OFFICE MEMO         Come Unity Unified                    Date:  11/4/93
Well, after digging through the sort of innane East vs. West arguments, I just
wanted to say a resounding "hello" to everyone who went to Come/Unity (and to
all of you who didn't make it--"hello!")...
that party is the absolute model on what the scene should be like.  Fantastic
vibe (a lot of my friends who were totally clean (like myself) noted that they
felt like they were on e--now THAT'S a good party) and Ripping music.  Simon (I
thought) was outta control.  When I left at three Jeno was in his element,
throbbing the crowd to mindless submission....or just fantastic dancing.  Great
crowd...

Nothing beats Come/Unity.  For all of you who missed it, please make it the
next time (fingers crossed!)---paying five bucks for anything else seem
ludicrous...

only complaint?  Well, like Pete said, "Man, the ambient room is so ambient,
it's all I can hear!"  I thought it was about as ambient as World War II...

Ripping good time.  Well worth my bleary (but refreshed!) head...

take care all.  You know, the east/west thing did bring out a lot of good
things--it made people tell us about their homes.  I thought that was really
cool.  The quote about it's not where you are, but who you are with really is
quite perfect.  I am glad all of us feel so strongly about where we live and
dance.  I was a bit concerned that people were asking Sue to leave
California--no need for that, obviously.  If she don't like it, she don't like
it!  No problem.  A lot of people don't like California.  That's their trip.  I
enjoy it immensely, but I grew up in the City--but I love visiting New York
when I can.  

I feel like typing more, but I have to get back to work.

Love the morning, feel the headache.

mike

it's easy to mix up who said what.  For the record, I *never* said that

least 90% if what ended up getting posted to the list) seemed like it was
being discussed in a reasonably mature manner.  You listed 12 reasons why
you prefered the east over the west, and a bunch of people calmly challenged
your reasons.  It didn't turn into a flame war until you and Laura went on
the defensive and started taking everything personally.

From sfraves-owner  Thu Nov  4 11:18:49 1993
From: "Mike Romo*" <mike_romo*@quickmail.apple.com>
Date: 4 Nov 1993 10:47:01 -0800
Subject: GH B(S)
Status: 

                      Subject:                              Time:  10:39 AM
  OFFICE MEMO         GH B(S)                               Date:  11/4/93
GHB is a high concentration of some amino acid(s).  It was first used by body
builders, but they discovered that if they took a lot of this salty liquid
(tastes a lot like sweat) they got pretty high.  (According to the paper
(Chron) it was a sleep supplement, meaning body builders using steroids
couldn't sleep so they took GHB and it chilled them out so they could sleep
(thanks to Zak for his reporting)...
I have tried it, and it's kinda weak, especially compared to other things. 
It's a liquid, and it hits you fast--a good analogy was it was like being drunk
without the slurring of the speech or the burping.  Fucking hard to dance to
(at least at F/X with that skate ramp floor)...  I really really really doubt
anyone could die from it, unless they took a whole helluva lot (yukky), and the
thing is, before you took that much, you would probably puke, you beging to
feel nauseous and dizzy ANYWAY....I bet you River Phoenix mixed it with
something else.  
GHB is pleasant, but you would have to go out of your way (IMHO) to kill
yourself on it.

And that anonymous klubber probably hasn't been THAT high, then.  It's cool,
but not too big of a deal...

Mike (trying to be clean for awhile--I felt fantastic at C/U!!) RRRR

All this negative press is bad for GHB.  It's a cool, natural drug, and lots of
people like it.  I hope this doesn't make the press/feds go nutso on it.

From sfraves-owner  Thu Nov  4 12:39:24 1993
From: ambient@netcom.com (Joe Rice)
Date: Thu, 4 Nov 93 12:39:46 PST
Subject: Re: GH B(S)
Status: 

Mike Romo* wrote:

(stuff deleted)

> (at least at F/X with that skate ramp floor)...  I really really really doubt
> anyone could die from it, unless they took a whole helluva lot (yukky), and the
> thing is, before you took that much, you would probably puke, you beging to
> feel nauseous and dizzy ANYWAY....I bet you River Phoenix mixed it with
> something else.  
> GHB is pleasant, but you would have to go out of your way (IMHO) to kill
> yourself on it.

GHB was extremely popular in the LA scene for awhile last year, and from what 
I've seen it's fairly safe (although I don't see it's attraction).  There were, 
however, at least two instances of people having seizures and collapsing, 
leading to hospitalization. One person supposedly died, but I can't confirm 
that.  I can confirm the hopitalizations.  The important factor in these cases 
was that GHB was ued in combination with other drugs. The big no-no,from what 
I understand, is using GHB with alcohol.  Crystal was also involved in one 
of the cases.

Basically, any drug can be relatively safe _if used reponsibly_.

Regarding River Phoenix, according to the LA times this morning, the 
toxicology reports won't be available for 6-8 weeks.  Reports of cocaine, 
valium, PCP laced joints, ecstacy, and GHB arejut hearsay until then.

Joe

----------(Joe Rice)--------------------------(they entered the vortex)--------
-----(ambient@netcom.com)------------------(and the dreams became reality)-----

From sfraves-owner  Thu Nov  4 13:00:28 1993
From: geoffw@internex.net (Geoff White)
Date: Thu, 4 Nov 93 12:55:06 PST
Subject: The Scene's not dead (yet) !
Status: 

> that party is the absolute model on what the scene should be like.

AMEN! Thanks Mal, you really outdid yourself,(although I half expected as much)
This is one of those parties when you have almost given up hope on the scene
and afterward you say "damn, well maybe...."
It was great to see so many "old-timeers" people who hadf stopped going out
who came out to Come-Unity partly to see/be with Mal and support his parties,
partly because they remembered what the old Come-Unities were like.  I saw some
"newbies", newborn Rave Goddesses(tm) like Joy who Tranced the entire night, this was her first Come-Unity and it was a BLAST!

> Fantastic
> vibe (a lot of my friends who were totally clean (like myself) noted that they
> felt like they were on e--now THAT'S a good party) and Ripping music. 
YES!!! around 5:30 when Garth really ripped into his set, I felt that familiar
"on fire" sensation and I had not partaken of anything stronger then a little
rasta assist :)
> 
> Nothing beats Come/Unity.  For all of you who missed it, please make it the
> next time (fingers crossed!)---paying five bucks for anything else seem
> ludicrous...

Yes and If you want offer more then just $5, Mal could use the money and 
if he asked for $15 at the door it would still be a deal!

For me it took a while for this Come-Unity to really get rolling
but when it did BOY! I really got my TRANCE-FIX last night during Garth's
set which started sorta discoy (I'm not too partial to this) but then moved into
some REAL HOUSE MUSIC (which I love, wailing divas and all) he then tranced us
but still stayed funky.  I remember looking around me in the early morning
light and seeing FAMILY.  There were a few tweekers there but not overly so,
and the attitude that was in the room withered when confronted with the
relentlessness of the VIBE! My luv-phasers were a little rusty but by the
middle of Jeno's set they were firing with the strength and precision
of a year ago.

Mal say's these are going to be MONTHLY parties (at least!) so  we can look 
forward to them.  I know he is doing these parties because he feels that the 
scene needs them and I agree.  I think we have an oppertunity to gather
momentum now starting with the last FMR, Come-Unity, let's make sure YSH and
the upcomming Liquid Air parties are successful and heavy with the Vibe.

There is a Wicked on Nov 13 and Mody/Orbital/Aphex Twin the following day
followed by a fanother FMR and a C4? somewhere? Not to mention John Lee's
friday party which will be F.A.T.!

Who says we can't singlehandedly transform the scene?


From sfraves-owner  Thu Nov  4 13:05:22 1993
From: vivianm@src.dec.com
Date: Thu, 04 Nov 93 13:05:18 -0800
Subject: Re: coastal wars
Status: 




>Second, this "flame war" seems really lame in my opinion.  90% of it (or at
>least 90% if what ended up getting posted to the list) seemed like it was
>being discussed in a reasonably mature manner.  You listed 12 reasons why
>you prefered the east over the west, and a bunch of people calmly challenged
>your reasons.  It didn't turn into a flame war until you and Laura went on
>the defensive and started taking everything personally.

I agree, but we did not exactly know until she told us, that Sue 
was recieving private email messages telling her that if she didn't 
like CA she should leave.  I don't exactly think that was an excusable 
thing to say to her being that she was just stating her opinion like 
the rest of us.  I thought it was fun to participate in the discussion 
of why I like California. Unfortuntely people seem to take things 
personally (as I can be accused of doing in the past) and start flaming, 
as people often will.  I will be the first to apologize if my "jumping 
on the bandwagon upset anyone".  I like to think that sfraves is 
an open forum and a bit more personal than any other newsgroup on 
the net. I feel like I can post my opinion more openly and freely 
since I do know quite a few of the people that post, unlike other 
newsgroups.  To me sfraves is like talking to a bunch of friends 
all at once. And not having to repeat yourself over and over like 
you would if you were talking to someone face to face.  
Does anyone else feel this way, or am I just rambling. 


:-)

vivianm

From sfraves-owner  Thu Nov  4 13:12:58 1993
From: Jon Drukman <jdrukman@us.oracle.com>
Date: Thu, 4 Nov 93 13:11:03 PST
Subject: Available now at Housewares... 
Status: 

chris hilker pedantically asks:

>As long as we're being pedantic, how come the track is called "Unleashed in
>the East" on the Twitch CD and "Straight Up Caffiene" on TfH? The flyer
>Exist Dance sent me says that there's a track called "Unleashed..." on the
>b-side of the "Caffiene" 12". Did Kandel and company pull a title switch on
>you?

the track listing for the Up Above The World 12" single (Exist Dance
Records ED 09):

	Unleashed In The East
	Straight Up Caffeine
	Bonus Trip

UitE and SUC sound remarkably similar - in fact they are the same song
in two different incarnations (Tom Chasteen mix and Mike Kandel mix).
We didn't specifically remix one particular version, since they both
sound the same.  So we got to pick which title we wanted to use.  For
my money (and I think I'm speaking for all of the UVC here),
"Unleashed In The East" is a great title; "Straight Up Caffeine" is a
less great one.

Jon Drukman                                         jdrukman%dlsun87@oracle.com
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
This calls for a very special blend of psychology and extreme violence.

From sfraves-owner  Thu Nov  4 13:33:50 1993
From: Jessica Grace Wing <she@leland.Stanford.EDU>
Date: Thu, 4 Nov 1993 13:33:46 -0800 (PST)
Subject: Delusions of Grandeur TONITE!
Status: 

Delusions of Grandeur is a weekly party put on every Thursday at
1015 Folsom by the Hardkisses.  I've been the last few times and it's
been really fun!  Last week was a bit mellow, but the week before
the energy was amazing -- people were cheering and yelling, hands
in the air, etc.  The music is also really good -- Scott 'n' Robbie 
Hardkiss and Jon Williams, plus guest DJ's sometimes.  And the
visuals by Synergy are AMAZING... I can't even describe it but
I'm sure some of you know what I'm talking about!!!

The party starts at 10, ambient music 'till midnight, then dancing
'till 5 or 6.  Costs $5 and is a great alternative to YSH.

BY the way, the sound system in that big room with the towers of
speaker is the best thing I have ever heard in my LIFE!!  

Love 'n' pine-nuts -- JESSICA

From sfraves-owner  Thu Nov  4 13:51:49 1993
From: amaranth@cats.ucsc.edu
Date: Thu, 4 Nov 93 13:51:41 -0800
Subject: Re: GH B(S)
Status: 

----
GHB is a high concentration of some amino acid(s).  It was first used by body
builders, but they discovered that if they took a lot of this salty liquid
(tastes a lot like sweat) they got pretty high.  (According to the paper
(Chron) it was a sleep supplement
 
   --stuff deleted--

It's a liquid, and it hits you fast--a good analogy was it was like being drunk
without the slurring of the speech or the burping.  Fucking hard to dance to
(at least at F/X with that skate ramp floor)...  I really really really doubt
anyone could die from it, unless they took a whole helluva lot (yukky), and the
thing is, before you took that much, you would probably puke, you beging to
feel nauseous and dizzy ANYWAY....I bet you River Phoenix mixed it with
something else.

-----

  I was told that GHB has very negative effects when mixed with alcohol (i.e.
death).  Could this have been what happened to River Phoenix?  I've seen it 
around a couple times at raves, but only in southern California, and the guys
selling it would usually give out a little warning not to mix it with anything
else..
 
  -K.

majordomo@sfraves.stanford.edu with either the line

s*bscribe sfraves-calendar   or
uns*bscribe sfraves-calendar   

(type 'u' in place of the '*' - i've taken out the 'u' so this message
 passes thru majordomo's filter)

From sfraves-owner  Thu Nov  4 13:59:48 1993
From: bbehlen@soda.berkeley.edu (Brian Behlendorf)
Date: Thu, 4 Nov 1993 13:59:14 -0800
Subject: Re: ENOUGH ALREADY
Status: 

On Nov 4, 12:42pm, Sue quoted Mark as saying:
} --> I third or fourth the "Don't unsub Laura", unless I missed one I
} --> thought Howards mail was tactful and made good points and us
} --> west-coasters are just being defensive after Sue's harsh
} --> critisizm.

} I find this ironic because I was being defensive after YOUR harsh
} criticism.

I think the lesson here is that we need to look at this from more
angles than just the CA-centered perspective or the East Coast
perspective or what not.  A lot of things became clear when I
considered the hypothetical situation where I posted a list to
ne-raves of why I live in California and not on the east coast - I
could FULLY expect to be flamed to pieces, probably a lot worse than
people flamed Sue.  Or I could post to SE-Raves saying how I'd never
go to a rave in Florida because I'd be afraid of being mistaken for a
German tourist, or post to NW-raves saying I'd never go to a Seattle
rave because I don't own any plaid, etc etc.
 
So, please, let's lift our mouths out of the muck and go on?

How was the 21-- policy at C/U?

	Brian

From sfraves-owner  Thu Nov  4 14:14:02 1993
From: lxfogel@srv.PacBell.COM (Lee Fogel)
Date: Thu, 4 Nov 93 14:13:55 PST
Subject: coastal piss
Status: 

Growing up in the NY Metropolitan area, the geography wars I heard
mostly revolved around which part of New York you were from.   Forget
about even *trying* to be cool if you were from New Jersey or Long 
Island.    It all seems so old and pointless, just like nationalism 
and racism.  I guess it's all just part of the territorial nature of 
humans, who are nothing more than stupid animals who, once having 
sprayed their territory with piss, feel threatened when some other 
stupid animal exhudes even the slightest scent of antagonism toward 
their turf.  Someday, hopefully, people will spend more energy learning
how to take pride in themselves instead of their spacetime coordinates.

ObRave: Groove Kitchen at the Troc, shitty sound and all, should
be an improvement over 174 King St.  I'll be arriving late, hopefully
for Markie's set, but Doc Martin or Mark Farina should also be good.
